However, the reliability of palpation in accurately detecting tumors remains uncertain. In this study, we aim to determine the reliability of palpation in the assessment of tumors. A total of 100 patients with suspected tumors were included in the study. Each patient underwent palpation by two different physicians, blinded to each other's findings. The results were then compared to the gold standard of histopathological examination. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of palpation were calculated. Preliminary analysis showed that palpation had a sensitivity of 80%, specificity of 75%, positive predictive value of 70%, and negative predictive value of 85%. These findings suggest that palpation may have a moderate level of reliability in detecting tumors, but further investigation is needed to confirm these results and assess its usefulness in clinical practice.

Tuberculosis of the esophagus.  Tuberculosis of the esophagus is rare. Tuberculosis of the esophagus is a rare manifestation of extrapulmonary tuberculosis and accounts for less than 1% of all cases of tuberculosis. It primarily affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV infection or those receiving immunosuppressive therapy. The clinical presentation of esophageal tuberculosis is nonspecific and includes symptoms such as dysphagia, odynophagia, and retrosternal pain. It can mimic various benign and malignant esophageal conditions, making the diagnosis challenging. Endoscopic findings may include ulcerations, strictures, nodules, or mass-like lesions. Microscopic examination of biopsy specimens reveals characteristic granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis. The gold standard for diagnosis is the isolation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from esophageal tissue cultures. Treatment involves a combination of anti-tuberculosis drugs for a prolonged period, usually 6 to 9 months. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as esophageal stricture or perforation. Further research is needed to optimize diagnostic strategies and treatment outcomes for this rare form of tuberculosis.

Enhanced antitumor reactivity of tumor-sensitized T cells by interferon alfa. Interferon alfa (IFN-) has been a known immunomodulatory agent used in cancer therapy. We investigate its effect on tumor-sensitized T cells in order to enhance antitumor reactivity. T cells were collected from patients with various types of cancers and sensitized against their respective tumor antigens. These tumor-sensitized T cells were then cultured in the presence or absence of IFN-. Subsequently, their antitumor reactivity was evaluated by measuring cytokine production and cytotoxicity against tumor cells. Our results demonstrate that IFN- treatment significantly increased the production of interferon-gamma (IFN-), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-), and interleukin-2 (IL-2) by tumor-sensitized T cells. Moreover, IFN- treatment enhanced the cytotoxicity of these T cells against tumor cells. These findings suggest that IFN- can boost the antitumor reactivity of tumor-sensitized T cells, potentially improving the efficacy of cancer immunotherapy. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and to optimize the clinical application of IFN- in tumor immunotherapy.

Multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses. We report a rare case of multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses. A 42-year-old female presented with chronic sinusitis symptoms refractory to standard treatments. Imaging studies revealed multiple mucosal thickening and opacification in the paranasal sinuses, as well as intracranial mucoceles extending into the frontal and ethmoid sinuses. A surgical intervention was performed, and fungal cultures confirmed the presence of phaeohyphomycosis. The patient was subsequently treated with antifungal therapy and showed significant improvement in her symptoms. Phaeohyphomycosis is a rare fungal infection caused by dematiaceous fungi, characterized by the presence of pigmented septate hyphae. Although predominantly observed in immunocompromised patients, our case highlights the importance of considering this fungal infection in immunocompetent individuals presenting with refractory sinusitis and complications such as intracranial mucoceles. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate treatment are crucial for successful management of this rare but potentially debilitating condition.

Rett syndrome: findings suggesting axonopathy and mitochondrial abnormalities. Rett Syndrome (RS) is a severe neurodevelopmental disorder predominantly affecting females. This study aimed to investigate the presence of axonopathy and mitochondrial abnormalities in RS patients. Autopsy brains from six girls with RS and six age-matched controls were examined histopathologically and immunohistochemically. The RS brains showed significantly decreased axon density in multiple regions, including the corpus callosum and white matter tracts. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed reduced expression of neurofilament proteins, suggesting axonal degeneration. Additionally, electron microscopy revealed abnormal mitochondrial morphology and reduced number of cristae in RS brains compared to controls. Mitochondrial dysfunction was further supported by decreased expression of mitochondrial proteins in RS samples. Interestingly, astrocyte activation was observed in RS brains, possibly indicating a reactive response to the underlying axonopathy and mitochondrial abnormalities. These findings provide novel evidence for the presence of axonopathy and mitochondrial dysfunction in RS, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of the disorder. Further research is needed to unravel the molecular mechanisms underlying these abnormalities and identify potential therapeutic targets for RS.

Indications and results of relaxing retinotomy. Retinal detachment is a serious ophthalmic emergency that requires immediate intervention. Relaxing retinotomy is a surgical technique used to relieve tension and facilitate reattachment of the retina in cases of severe proliferative vitreoretinopathy or posterior retinal membranes. This study aimed to evaluate the indications, outcomes, and complications associated with relaxing retinotomy.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 56 eyes of 53 patients who underwent relaxing retinotomy between 2014 and 2019. The main indications for surgery included recurrent or chronic retinal detachment associated with severe proliferative vitreoretinopathy (n=38), posterior retinal membranes (n=14), and diabetic tractional retinal detachment (n=4). Visual acuity, anatomical success rate, and intraoperative and postoperative complications were evaluated.

The mean preoperative visual acuity was 0.030.01, which improved to 0.180.07 at one year postoperatively (p<0.001). Anatomical success was achieved in 50 eyes (89.3%), with 42 eyes (75%) achieving attached retina at the final follow-up visit. Intraoperative complications included iatrogenic retinal breaks (n=8) and proliferative vitreoretinopathy progression (n=3). Postoperative complications included retinal redetachment (n=4), persistent subretinal fluid (n=2), and proliferative vitreoretinopathy recurrence (n=1).

Relaxing retinotomy is an effective surgical option for cases of retinal detachment associated with severe proliferative vitreoretinopathy, posterior retinal membranes, and diabetic tractional retinal detachment. It results in significant visual improvement and high rates of anatomical success. However, careful consideration of the potential complications and individualized patient selection is crucial for optimal outcomes. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate our findings.

Temporal movement control in patients with Parkinson's disease. The aim of this study was to investigate the temporal movement control in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD). Ten PD patients and ten healthy controls were recruited for this study. All participants were assessed using a standardized motor task that required them to tap their fingers rhythmically for a specific duration. The timing accuracy and variability of the finger taps were measured using a digital timing device. Results showed that PD patients exhibited significantly decreased timing accuracy and increased temporal variability compared to the control group. Furthermore, the severity of motor symptoms in PD, as assessed by the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale, was found to be correlated with the degree of temporal variability in movement control. These findings suggest that temporal movement control is impaired in PD, and this impairment may be associated with the underlying motor symptoms of the disease. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapeutic interventions to improve temporal movement control in PD.

Risk factors for white matter changes detected by magnetic resonance imaging in the elderly. White matter changes detected by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are common among elderly individuals and have been associated with various risk factors. This study aimed to identify specific risk factors for white matter changes in the elderly population. A total of 200 participants aged 65 years or older underwent brain MRI scans, and their medical records were reviewed to obtain relevant information. Multivariate logistic regression analysis revealed that increasing age, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and smoking were independently associated with the presence of white matter changes. Additionally, a higher body mass index and lower education level were also identified as potential risk factors. These findings highlight the importance of managing these modifiable risk factors to prevent or delay the development of white matter changes in the elderly population.

Inflammatory breast cancer.  Historically, the prognosis of inflammatory breast cancer has been poor. However, with advances in treatment strategies, the prognosis has improved in recent years. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the outcomes and prognostic factors in patients with inflammatory breast cancer. 

We retrospectively analyzed the data of 78 patients diagnosed with inflammatory breast cancer between 2010 and 2017. The median age at diagnosis was 49 years. The majority of patients presented with locally advanced disease (stage III) at the time of diagnosis. 

Multimodal treatment approaches were used, including neoadjuvant chemotherapy, surgery, radiation therapy, and targeted therapy. The overall response rate to neoadjuvant chemotherapy was 65%, with 30% achieving a complete pathological response. 

The 5-year overall survival rate was 62%, and the disease-free survival rate was 55%. Prognostic factors associated with worse outcomes included lymph node involvement, hormone receptor negativity, and HER2 positivity. 

In conclusion, inflammatory breast cancer remains a challenging disease with poor prognosis. However, with aggressive multimodal treatment, including targeted therapy, there has been improvement in outcomes. Further research is needed to identify novel treatment approaches and potential biomarkers for better risk stratification of patients with inflammatory breast cancer.

The effect of enoximone and dobutamine on hemodynamic performance after open heart surgery.  A clinical comparison. Enoximone and dobutamine are widely used in the management of low cardiac output syndrome following open heart surgery. This study aimed to compare the hemodynamic effects of enoximone and dobutamine in patients undergoing open heart surgery. A total of 50 patients were randomly assigned to receive either enoximone or dobutamine infusion postoperatively. Hemodynamic parameters, including heart rate, mean arterial pressure, central venous pressure, cardiac index, and systemic vascular resistance, were measured at baseline and at regular intervals up to 24 hours postoperatively. 

The results showed that both enoximone and dobutamine effectively improved cardiac performance after open heart surgery. Enoximone was associated with a significant increase in cardiac index compared to dobutamine at 6 hours postoperatively. However, there were no significant differences between the two groups in terms of other hemodynamic parameters. 

In conclusion, both enoximone and dobutamine are effective in enhancing hemodynamic performance after open heart surgery. The choice of medication may depend on individual patient characteristics and the desired hemodynamic response. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes and potential adverse effects of these agents.

Cytologic criteria to distinguish hepatocellular carcinoma from nonneoplastic liver.  The authors reviewed a series of fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) specimens of the liver to identify useful cytologic criteria to distinguish hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) from nonneoplastic liver. The study aimed to identify cytologic criteria that can effectively distinguish hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) from nonneoplastic liver in fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) specimens. A total of 100 FNAB specimens were reviewed by the authors. Various cytologic features were analyzed, including nuclear size, nuclear shape, chromatin pattern, and presence of nucleoli. Statistical analysis was used to determine the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive values of these criteria for HCC diagnosis. The results revealed that specific cytologic features, such as nuclear size greater than 5m, hyperchromatic nuclei, and irregular nuclear borders, were highly indicative of HCC. These criteria demonstrated a high sensitivity and specificity for distinguishing HCC from nonneoplastic liver, providing valuable diagnostic information for clinicians evaluating liver FNAB specimens.

The accuracy of predictions about progress of patients on a stroke unit. The accuracy of predicting the progress of patients on a stroke unit is crucial for providing appropriate and timely interventions. This study aimed to assess the accuracy of predictions made by healthcare professionals regarding the prognosis of patients on a stroke unit. 

Data from 92 patients admitted to a stroke unit were analyzed retrospectively. Predictions of outcomes, including mortality, functional status, and length of hospital stay, were made by healthcare professionals within 24 hours of admission. The actual outcomes were determined at discharge. 

The results showed that healthcare professionals accurately predicted mortality in 85% of cases, with a sensitivity of 88% and a specificity of 82%. However, predictions of functional status and length of hospital stay were less accurate, with sensitivities ranging from 47% to 58% and specificities ranging from 53% to 60%. 

In conclusion, while healthcare professionals demonstrated good accuracy in predicting mortality in stroke unit patients, their predictions regarding functional status and length of hospital stay were less precise. Further research is needed to identify additional predictors that could improve the accuracy of these predictions.

Occipital condyle fracture presenting as retropharyngeal hematoma. Occipital condyle fractures are a rare but potentially serious injury that can be challenging to diagnose due to their nonspecific symptoms. We present a case of a 62-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with worsening neck pain and difficulty swallowing following a fall. Initial imaging studies revealed a retropharyngeal hematoma, initially raising concerns for an occult malignancy or infection. However, further evaluation with computed tomography (CT) scan of the cervical spine identified an occipital condyle fracture, which was likely the underlying cause of the hematoma. The patient was managed conservatively with cervical immobilization and close observation, as surgical intervention was not indicated. This case highlights the importance of considering occipital condyle fractures in the differential diagnosis of retropharyngeal hematomas and emphasizes the role of CT scan in accurately diagnosing this rare injury. Early recognition and appropriate management can lead to improved outcomes in patients with occipital condyle fractures.

Toxicities in rats with free versus liposomal encapsulated cisplatin. Cisplatin is a widely used chemotherapeutic agent for the treatment of various solid tumors. However, its use is often limited by its toxicities, particularly nephrotoxicity. One approach to mitigate the side effects of cisplatin is by encapsulating it in liposomes, which can enhance its therapeutic index and reduce systemic toxicity. In this study, we compared the toxicities of free cisplatin versus liposomal encapsulated cisplatin in rats. Rats were intravenously administered either free cisplatin or liposomal cisplatin at equivalent doses. Blood and urine samples were collected at various time points to assess renal function parameters such as serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and urinary protein levels. Additionally, histological examination of kidney tissue was performed to evaluate the extent of renal damage. Our results showed that liposomal encapsulated cisplatin had significantly lower nephrotoxicity compared to free cisplatin. These findings suggest that liposomal encapsulation of cisplatin may be a promising strategy to improve the therapeutic efficacy of cisplatin while minimizing its toxic effects, particularly nephrotoxicity. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential clinical applications of liposomal cisplatin in cancer treatment.

Chemical peritonitis secondary to intraperitoneal vancomycin. Chemical peritonitis is a rare complication of intraperitoneal vancomycin administration, and there is limited literature available regarding its presentation and management. We report a case of a 65-year-old male with severe Clostridium difficile infection who developed chemical peritonitis following intraperitoneal vancomycin administration for suspected bacterial peritonitis. The patient presented with abdominal pain, distension, and fever. Computed tomography scan revealed ascites and diffuse peritoneal enhancement. Paracentesis showed turbid fluid with elevated white blood cell count and decreased pH. Vancomycin was identified in the peritoneal fluid using high-performance liquid chromatography. The patient was managed conservatively with intravenous antibiotics and peritoneal drainage, leading to symptomatic improvement and resolution of the chemical peritonitis. This case serves as a reminder to consider intraperitoneal vancomycin administration as a potential cause of chemical peritonitis in patients presenting with abdominal pain and ascites. Prompt recognition and appropriate management are crucial to avoid further complications. Further research is warranted to determine the optimal management strategies for this rare complication.

Rhabdomyosarcomas in the head and neck: MR imaging evaluation. Rhabdomyosarcomas are rare malignant tumors that primarily affect children and adolescents. Head and neck involvement is common, accounting for approximately 40% of all cases. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) plays a crucial role in the evaluation of these tumors, providing detailed anatomical information and aiding in treatment planning. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the role of MRI in the assessment of head and neck rhabdomyosarcomas. A total of 25 patients with histopathologically confirmed rhabdomyosarcomas were included. MRI findings, including tumor location, size, extent, invasion of adjacent structures, and presence of metastasis, were analyzed. The majority of tumors were located in the orbit, followed by the parameningeal region and paranasal sinuses. MRI accurately depicted tumor size, extent, and invasion of adjacent structures, aiding in surgical planning and prognosis determination. Additionally, MRI provided valuable information regarding the presence of distant metastasis. In conclusion, MRI is an essential imaging modality for the evaluation of head and neck rhabdomyosarcomas, contributing to accurate diagnosis, staging, and treatment planning.

Suggestive evidence that pelvic endometriosis is a progressive disease, whereas deeply infiltrating endometriosis is associated with pelvic pain. Pelvic endometriosis (PE) and deeply infiltrating endometriosis (DIE) are common gynecological conditions associated with pelvic pain. This study aimed to investigate the progression of these conditions and their correlation with pelvic pain. A total of 100 patients with confirmed endometriosis were included in the study. Patients underwent laparoscopic examination to assess the severity and location of endometriotic lesions. Progression of endometriosis was determined based on the change in lesion size and extent over a 5-year period. The results showed that PE was a progressive disease, with an increase in lesion size and extent observed in 80% of cases. In contrast, DIE was strongly associated with pelvic pain, with 90% of patients reporting moderate to severe pain. Overall, these findings suggest that PE is a progressive disease, while DIE is a distinct entity characterized by severe pelvic pain. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted treatment strategies for these conditions.

Salivary flow rates in patients with head and neck cancer 0. Salivary flow rates can be significantly reduced in patients with head and neck cancer due to various treatment modalities, such as radiation therapy and surgical interventions. This study aimed to evaluate the salivary flow rates in patients with head and neck cancer and investigate the impact of different clinical factors on saliva production. A total of 50 patients with head and neck cancer were included in the study, and their unstimulated and stimulated salivary flow rates were measured. The results demonstrated a significant reduction in both unstimulated and stimulated salivary flow rates compared to healthy individuals. Furthermore, a negative correlation was identified between salivary flow rates and the extent of surgical resection and radiation therapy dose. These findings emphasize the importance of monitoring salivary flow rates in patients with head and neck cancer to prevent further complications associated with xerostomia and its detrimental effects on oral health and quality of life.

Gallstone dissolution with methyl tert-butyl ether in 120 patients--efficacy and safety.  Of 612 patients with cholesterol gallbladder stones, 120 were eligible for percutaneous transhepatic litholysis with methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE).  Puncture of the gallbladder was successful in 117/120 (97. In this study, we investigated the efficacy and safety of gallstone dissolution using methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) in 120 patients with cholesterol gallbladder stones out of a total of 612 patients. Percutaneous transhepatic litholysis was performed in these eligible patients. Successful puncture of the gallbladder was achieved in a majority of cases (97.5%). Following MTBE administration, complete gallstone dissolution was observed in 78 patients (65%), while partial dissolution was noted in 28 patients (23.3%). The remaining 14 patients (11.7%) showed no response to the treatment. Adverse events were observed in 46 patients (38.3%), with the most common being transient abdominal pain and mild elevation of liver enzymes. No major complications or cases of MTBE-related mortality were reported. Our results demonstrate that MTBE is an effective and safe method for gallstone dissolution, with a high success rate and minimal adverse events.

Headaches and multiple sclerosis: a clinical study and review of the literature. Headaches are a common symptom experienced by individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS), but the underlying mechanisms and optimal management remain unclear. In this study, we conducted a clinical investigation and reviewed the literature to gain insights into the relationship between headaches and MS. Our study cohort comprised 78 patients with confirmed MS and a history of headaches. Detailed clinical evaluation, including neurological examination and imaging studies, was performed. We found that 62.8% of patients experienced headache attacks, which were predominantly migrainous in nature, while the remaining 37.2% had tension-type headaches. The severity and frequency of headaches varied among individuals, with some reporting chronic daily headaches. Additionally, we observed a positive correlation between the presence of headaches and disease activity in terms of relapse rates and disability progression. Furthermore, our literature review revealed various hypotheses regarding the pathophysiology of headaches in MS, including neuroinflammation, cortical spreading depression, and comorbidities such as depression and anxiety. The management of headaches in MS should focus on individualized approaches, taking into consideration the patient's clinical characteristics, comorbidities, and treatment tolerability. Further research is warranted to elucidate the mechanisms underlying headaches in MS and to develop optimized therapeutic strategies.

A phase II multi-institutional trial of low-dose N-(phosphonacetyl)-L-aspartate and high-dose 5-fluorouracil as a short-term infusion in the treatment of adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.  A Southwest Oncology Group study. In this phase II multi-institutional trial conducted by the Southwest Oncology Group, the efficacy and safety of low-dose N-(phosphonacetyl)-L-aspartate (PALA) in combination with high-dose 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) were evaluated as a short-term infusion for the treatment of adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. PALA is an inhibitor of aspartate transcarbamylase, an enzyme involved in the de novo pyrimidine synthesis pathway, and has shown promising results as a radiosensitizer and chemopotentiator in preclinical studies. 

Twenty-five patients with locally advanced or metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas were enrolled in the trial. Patients received PALA at a dose of 0.18 g/m^2 followed by 5-FU at a dose of 1 g/m^2 as a 24-hour infusion. The treatment cycle was repeated every 2 weeks. 

Preliminary results showed a partial response rate of 16% and a disease stabilization rate of 64%. The median overall survival was 8 months, and the median progression-free survival was 3 months. Grade 3 or 4 toxicities included neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and diarrhea. 

In conclusion, the combination of low-dose PALA and high-dose 5-FU as a short-term infusion shows promise in the treatment of adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. Further investigation is warranted to determine the optimal dose and schedule of this regimen.

Flow cytometric analysis of DNA content in partial hydatidiform moles with persistent gestational trophoblastic tumor.  Hydatidiform moles may be classified as partial or complete based on genetic and pathologic criteria. Persistent gestational trophoblastic tumor (GTT) is a rare complication of hydatidiform moles, with partial hydatidiform moles (PHMs) more commonly associated with GTT. In this study, flow cytometric analysis was conducted to investigate DNA content in PHMs with persistent GTT. DNA histograms were obtained from 15 cases of PHMs with persistent GTT and compared to 17 cases of PHMs without GTT. The results revealed significant differences in DNA content patterns between the two groups, with a higher proportion of aneuploid and tetraploid cells observed in PHMs with GTT. This suggests that DNA content analysis using flow cytometry may be a useful tool in predicting the risk of persistent GTT in patients with PHMs. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore potential clinical applications.

Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis after M-VAC (methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin) chemotherapy. Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) is a common malignancy of the urinary tract, often treated with systemic chemotherapy such as M-VAC. While hematological and gastrointestinal toxicities are well-documented side effects of this regimen, central nervous system (CNS) involvement is rare. We present a case of a patient with TCC who developed meningitis-like symptoms following M-VAC chemotherapy. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed malignant cells consistent with TCC, confirming the diagnosis of transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis (TCCM). This represents a rare complication of M-VAC chemotherapy and highlights the importance of considering CNS involvement in patients with TCC presenting with neurological symptoms after systemic treatment. Treatment options for TCCM are limited, often resulting in poor outcomes. Early recognition and prompt initiation of appropriate therapy, including intrathecal chemotherapy and supportive care, may improve patient outcomes in this devastating condition. Further research is needed to better understand the risk factors, pathogenesis, and optimal management strategies for TCCM.

Fetal death due to nonlethal maternal carbon monoxide poisoning. We report a case of fetal death due to nonlethal maternal carbon monoxide poisoning. A 28-year-old pregnant woman presented to the emergency department with headache, dizziness, and generalized weakness. She had a history of exposure to a faulty gas heater in her home. Carbon monoxide levels in her blood were found to be significantly elevated. Despite prompt treatment with high-flow oxygen, the fetus was found to be nonviable on ultrasound. This case highlights the potential dangers of carbon monoxide poisoning during pregnancy and emphasizes the importance of early recognition and treatment. Healthcare providers should be vigilant in educating pregnant women about the importance of proper ventilation and carbon monoxide detection in their homes to prevent such tragic outcomes.

Resolution of inferior vena cava syndrome after embolization of a hepatic adenoma. We present a case of a 42-year-old female with a history of inferior vena cava (IVC) syndrome secondary to a large hepatic adenoma. The patient presented with symptoms of abdominal pain, lower extremity edema, and a distended abdomen. A non-contrast CT scan revealed compression of the IVC by the hepatic adenoma. The patient underwent embolization of the hepatic adenoma, resulting in complete resolution of the IVC syndrome symptoms. A follow-up CT scan confirmed decompression of the IVC. This case highlights the successful use of embolization as a minimally invasive intervention for the resolution of IVC syndrome caused by hepatic adenoma. Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of this procedure.

Prediction of variceal hemorrhage in cirrhosis: a prospective follow-up study. Variceal hemorrhage is a common and serious complication in patients with cirrhosis. Early prediction of variceal hemorrhage is crucial for timely intervention and prevention of life-threatening bleeding episodes. In this prospective follow-up study, we aimed to identify predictors of variceal hemorrhage in patients with cirrhosis.

A total of 150 patients with cirrhosis were included in the study and followed up for a period of 2 years. Baseline clinical and laboratory data were collected, including demographic characteristics, etiology of cirrhosis, liver function tests, portal hypertension-related parameters, and presence of esophageal varices. All patients underwent regular endoscopic screening for varices and were monitored for the occurrence of variceal hemorrhage.

During the follow-up period, 35 patients (23.3%) experienced variceal hemorrhage. Univariate analysis revealed several significant risk factors for variceal hemorrhage, including the presence of large varices, Child-Pugh class C, low platelet count, high bilirubin level, and high international normalized ratio. Multivariate analysis identified the presence of large varices (OR 3.78, 95% CI 1.52-9.41) and Child-Pugh class C (OR 2.89, 95% CI 1.05-7.94) as independent predictors of variceal hemorrhage.

In conclusion, the presence of large varices and advanced liver disease (Child-Pugh class C) are strong predictors of variceal hemorrhage in patients with cirrhosis. These findings could assist clinicians in risk stratification and implementing preventive measures to reduce the incidence of variceal hemorrhage in this high-risk population. Further research is warranted to validate these predictors and develop a predictive model for individualized risk assessment.

Optimal interpretation of the supine exercise electrocardiogram in patients with right bundle branch block. Right bundle branch block (RBBB) is a common electrocardiographic finding that may present challenges in the interpretation of exercise electrocardiograms (ECG). The aim of this study was to determine the optimal interpretation of supine exercise ECGs in patients with RBBB. A retrospective analysis was performed on a cohort of patients with RBBB who underwent supine exercise testing. The exercise ECGs were reviewed by two independent cardiologists, blinded to clinical data, and classified into four categories: normal, abnormal but non-specific, true positive for ischemia, and false positive for ischemia. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) were calculated for each interpretation. The results showed that the optimal interpretation of supine exercise ECGs in patients with RBBB was achieved when abnormal but non-specific changes were considered non-diagnostic for ischemia. This approach resulted in a sensitivity of 75%, specificity of 93%, PPV of 46%, and NPV of 97% for detecting true ischemia. In conclusion, a cautious approach is warranted when interpreting supine exercise ECGs in patients with RBBB, taking into account the high specificity and NPV of abnormal but non-specific changes.

Surgical management of bile duct stones. Bile duct stones are a common medical condition requiring surgical intervention. Several surgical management techniques have been developed to address this issue, including endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with sphincterotomy, laparoscopic bile duct exploration (LBDE), and open surgical exploration (OSE). Each technique offers varying benefits and risks. 
ERCP with sphincterotomy is a minimally invasive procedure that has proven effective in the removal of bile duct stones. LBDE, on the other hand, offers the advantage of providing direct visualization of the bile duct and surrounding structures, thus allowing for comprehensive stone clearance. OSE is considered the gold standard for complex bile duct stones but requires a larger incision and carries a higher risk of complications. This abstract presents a comprehensive comparison and contrasts the three surgical management techniques for bile duct stones, aiming to guide clinicians in selecting the most appropriate approach based on patient characteristics and stone complexity.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Pelvic pain is a common and debilitating symptom that can have multiple causes. Understanding the anatomy and physiology of the pelvis is crucial in diagnosing and managing pelvic pain. The pelvic region contains numerous organs, including the bladder, uterus, ovaries, and intestines, as well as muscles, ligaments, and nerves. Dysfunction or pathology in any of these structures can result in pelvic pain. In women, conditions such as endometriosis, ovarian cysts, and pelvic inflammatory disease are common causes of pelvic pain. In men, prostate inflammation or infection may contribute to pelvic pain. Additionally, musculoskeletal issues, such as pelvic floor dysfunction or nerve entrapment, can also be responsible for pelvic pain. A comprehensive understanding of pelvic anatomy and physiology is essential for providing effective treatment and improving the quality of life for individuals experiencing pelvic pain.

Prevalence and association of asteroid hyalosis with systemic diseases.  We performed a cross-sectional study of 12,205 patients, which identified 101 patients (0. Prevalence and association of asteroid hyalosis with systemic diseases. We performed a cross-sectional study of 12,205 patients, which identified 101 patients (0.83%) with asteroid hyalosis. Out of these patients, 60% were male and the mean age was 65 years. The most common systemic diseases observed in this cohort were diabetes mellitus (38%), hypertension (32%), and hyperlipidemia (27%). Additionally, a significant association was found between asteroid hyalosis and systemic diseases, such as coronary artery disease (p<0.001), cerebrovascular disease (p=0.005), and chronic kidney disease (p=0.029). Furthermore, advanced age was also found to be a significant risk factor for the development of asteroid hyalosis (p<0.001). These findings suggest a potential relationship between asteroid hyalosis and various systemic diseases, highlighting the importance of systemic evaluation in patients with asteroid hyalosis. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms and clinical implications of this association.

Ponderal index as a predictor of postoperative complications.  Four hundred sixty-eight patients undergoing elective surgery were prospectively followed for the development of postoperative complications. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the usefulness of the ponderal index as a predictor of postoperative complications in patients undergoing elective surgery. A total of 468 patients were prospectively followed, and their postoperative outcomes were assessed. The ponderal index, calculated as weight in kilograms divided by height in meters cubed, was used as a measure of body composition. 

Results revealed that patients with a higher ponderal index had a significantly increased risk of developing postoperative complications. Specifically, for every 1 unit increase in the ponderal index, the odds of experiencing complications increased by 23%. Furthermore, the ponderal index showed a significant association with specific complications such as wound infections, respiratory complications, and urinary tract infections.

In conclusion, our findings suggest that the ponderal index can serve as a valuable predictor of postoperative complications in patients undergoing elective surgery. Its simplicity and easily calculable nature make it a useful tool for identifying individuals at higher risk and potentially implementing preventive measures to improve surgical outcomes.

Evaluating oxygen delivery and oxygen utilization with mixed venous oxygen saturation monitoring: a case study approach. Mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) monitoring is a valuable tool in assessing oxygen delivery and utilization in critically ill patients. This case study approach aimed to evaluate the use of SvO2 monitoring in clinical practice. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 25 patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) who underwent SvO2 monitoring. Data on oxygen delivery, oxygen consumption, and SvO2 levels were collected and analyzed. The results showed that SvO2 monitoring provided valuable information in identifying patients with impaired oxygen delivery or utilization. It aided in optimizing oxygen therapy and guiding hemodynamic management. Additionally, SvO2 monitoring allowed for early detection of oxygen debt and the implementation of appropriate interventions. Overall, this study highlights the clinical utility of SvO2 monitoring and its potential to improve patient outcomes in the ICU.

Computerized tomography as an indicator of isolated mesenteric injury.  A comparison with peritoneal lavage. Isolated mesenteric injury is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition that often requires prompt diagnosis and intervention. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of computerized tomography (CT) as an indicator of isolated mesenteric injury compared to peritoneal lavage. 

A retrospective analysis of 75 patients with suspected mesenteric injury was conducted. All patients underwent both CT imaging and peritoneal lavage. The results were then compared to identify the accuracy of CT in detecting isolated mesenteric injury.

The findings revealed that CT had a sensitivity of 87% and a specificity of 96% in detecting isolated mesenteric injury. In comparison, peritoneal lavage had a sensitivity of 53% and a specificity of 76%. The overall accuracy rate of CT was significantly higher than that of peritoneal lavage (p<0.001).

Based on these results, CT can be considered a reliable and accurate diagnostic tool for isolated mesenteric injury. Its high sensitivity and specificity make it an invaluable tool in the early detection and management of this condition, potentially reducing the need for invasive procedures such as peritoneal lavage.

Economic barriers to the use of oral rehydration therapy. Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) is a widely recommended treatment for dehydration caused by diarrhea, especially in resource-limited countries. However, its utilization remains limited due to various economic barriers. This study aims to identify and assess these barriers to the use of ORT. Factors such as the cost of oral rehydration salts (ORS), lack of affordability, availability, and accessibility of ORS, and inadequate knowledge and awareness about ORT were analyzed. Additionally, socio-economic factors and cultural beliefs were considered as influential aspects. The findings suggest that economic barriers, including high cost, limited availability, and low affordability of ORS, hinder the widespread implementation of ORT. Strategies to overcome these barriers should be implemented to ensure the effective use of ORT in managing dehydration and reducing associated morbidity and mortality.

Value of monoclonal anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO7) for diagnosing acute leukaemia.  The expression of myeloperoxidase (MPO) was studied in 100 cases of acute leukaemia (83 with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) and 17 acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) by both a conventional cytochemical method and the immunocytochemical antiperoxidase (APAAP) technique using the monoclonal antibody MPO7. The aim of this study was to evaluate the diagnostic value of monoclonal anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO7) for acute leukemia. A total of 100 cases of acute leukemia, including 83 with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and 17 with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), were analyzed using both a conventional cytochemical method and the immunocytochemical antiperoxidase (APAAP) technique with MPO7 monoclonal antibody. The results showed that the MPO7 monoclonal antibody had a high sensitivity and specificity for detecting the presence of myeloperoxidase (MPO) in acute leukemia cells. The MPO7 antibody detected MPO in 76 out of 83 AML cases (91.6%) and 15 out of 17 ALL cases (88.2%), while the conventional cytochemical method only detected MPO in 68 AML cases (81.9%) and 11 ALL cases (64.7%). These findings suggest that MPO7 monoclonal antibody is a valuable tool for diagnosing acute leukemia, with higher sensitivity compared to the conventional cytochemical method.

Lyme disease: recommendations for diagnosis and treatment The incidence and the endemic range of Lyme disease in the United States have increased steadily since the disease was originally recognized in Lyme, Connecticut, in 1975. Lyme disease is a tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi and primarily affects the skin, joints, heart, and nervous system. Early diagnosis and prompt treatment are crucial for preventing complications. This abstract reviews current recommendations for the diagnosis and treatment of Lyme disease. Diagnostic testing includes serologic assays, with a two-tiered testing approach recommended. Treatment options vary based on the stage of the disease, with oral antibiotics such as doxycycline being the first-line therapy for early localized or disseminated disease. Intravenous antibiotics may be necessary for severe manifestations or neurological involvement. Prevention strategies, including tick avoidance measures and tick removal techniques, are also discussed.

Heart disease in Asians and Pacific-Islanders, Hispanics, and Native Americans. Asian and Pacific-Islander, Hispanic, and Native American populations have been shown to have an increased prevalence of heart disease compared to the general population. This review aimed to summarize the current knowledge on the epidemiology, risk factors, and pathophysiology of heart disease in these ethnic groups. Several studies have indicated that these populations exhibit higher rates of traditional risk factors such as obesity, diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. Additionally, they may also have unique genetic and cultural factors that contribute to the development of heart disease. Understanding the specific challenges and risk factors faced by these populations is crucial in order to develop targeted strategies for prevention and management of heart disease in these high-risk groups.

The molecular biology of acute myeloid leukemia. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease characterized by the clonal expansion of immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow. The molecular basis of AML involves a variety of genetic alterations, including chromosomal translocations, gene mutations, and epigenetic modifications. These deregulated molecular events result in dysregulation of key cellular processes, such as proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. Recent advancements in genomic technologies have facilitated the identification of recurrent genetic alterations in AML, including mutations in genes encoding DNA methyltransferases, transcription factors, and signaling molecules. Understanding the molecular biology of AML has provided insights into disease prognosis, risk stratification, and the development of targeted therapies. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge of the molecular landscape of AML and discuss its implications for diagnosis, prognosis, and therapy.

Recovery from vegetative state of six months' duration associated with Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). We report the case of a patient who showed recovery from a vegetative state after six months of treatment with Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). The patient had suffered a severe traumatic brain injury resulting in a prolonged period of unconsciousness. Despite intensive rehabilitation efforts, the patient remained in a vegetative state with no signs of awareness or purposeful behavior. After initiation of Sinemet therapy, gradual improvements were observed, including increased responsiveness, initiation of purposeful movements, and the ability to follow simple commands. Repeat neurological examination and imaging studies revealed significant cortical reorganization and functional improvement in the injured brain regions. This case highlights the potential therapeutic role of Sinemet in promoting recovery from vegetative states and suggests the need for further research in this area.

The anatomical basis of the caecocentral scotoma. The caecocentral scotoma is a rare visual field defect characterized by a central scotoma in one eye and a peripheral field defect in the other eye. This study aims to investigate the anatomical basis of this visual field abnormality. Six patients with caecocentral scotoma were included in the study. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) were performed in all patients to evaluate the morphology and integrity of the optic nerves and chiasms. Additionally, visual evoked potentials (VEPs) were obtained to assess the functional integrity of the visual pathway. The results showed that all patients had structural abnormalities in the posterior portion of the optic chiasm, where the nasal fibers from the temporal retina and temporal fibers from the nasal retina decussate. These structural abnormalities were consistent with the observed visual field defects. This study provides valuable insights into the anatomical basis of the caecocentral scotoma, which can aid in the diagnosis and management of patients with this visual field abnormality. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential treatment options for this condition.

Endoscopic findings in Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis.  The endoscopic findings in the colon and terminal ileum in eight cases of Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis infection were studied. Endoscopic findings in Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis infection were evaluated in eight cases involving the colon and terminal ileum. The most common endoscopic features observed were edema, erythema, and loss of vascular pattern in the affected areas. Inflammation and ulceration were also observed in some cases. These findings were consistent with the clinical presentation of Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis, which typically manifests as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever. The endoscopic findings correlated well with histopathological examination, which revealed acute inflammatory infiltrate in the mucosa and submucosa. The presence of these endoscopic features highlights the importance of considering Yersinia enterocolitica as a potential causative agent in cases of enterocolitis, especially in patients with compatible clinical symptoms and risk factors such as consumption of contaminated food or contact with infected animals. Further research is needed to better understand the diagnostic and therapeutic implications of these findings.

Surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions: an overview. Surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions is a challenging procedure due to the complex anatomy and vital functions controlled by this region. This review provides an overview of the current surgical techniques and outcomes in the management of brain stem lesions. Various approaches, including the midline suboccipital, lateral suboccipital, and telovelar approaches, have been described for accessing different regions of the brain stem. The choice of approach depends on the location and extension of the lesion, as well as the surgeon's experience. Advances in neuroimaging, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), have aided in preoperative planning and identification of critical structures. Postoperative complications, such as neurological deficits and infection, are relatively common, but with careful patient selection and meticulous surgical technique, favorable outcomes can be achieved. Close multidisciplinary collaboration and long-term follow-up are essential for comprehensive management of patients with intrinsic brain stem lesions.

Overt hepatic encephalopathy precipitated by zinc deficiency. Hepatic encephalopathy is a severe neurological disorder that occurs in patients with liver dysfunction. While the exact mechanism remains unclear, it is believed to be a result of the accumulation of neurotoxic substances in the brain due to impaired liver clearance. Zinc deficiency has been implicated as a potential precipitating factor for hepatic encephalopathy. We present a case study of a patient with known liver cirrhosis who developed overt hepatic encephalopathy secondary to zinc deficiency. The patient's symptoms resolved completely following zinc supplementation, confirming the role of zinc deficiency in the pathogenesis of hepatic encephalopathy. This case highlights the importance of considering nutritional deficiencies, such as zinc deficiency, in patients with liver dysfunction presenting with neurological symptoms. Early recognition and correction of such deficiencies may prevent or ameliorate the severity of hepatic encephalopathy.

The cancer experience in the Framingham Heart Study cohort.  The almost 40-year records of The Framingham Heart Study (FHS) cohort were reviewed to establish the cancer experience of this noninstitutionalized group of white subjects. During the follow-up period, a total of 1,685 cases of cancer were diagnosed among the 4,430 individuals included in the study. The overall cancer incidence rate in the FHS cohort was found to be comparable to rates reported in previous studies of similar populations. Lung cancer was the most common type of cancer diagnosed, followed by colorectal, breast, and prostate cancer. The incidence of certain types of cancer, such as lung and bladder cancer, was found to be higher in male participants compared to females. Additionally, age was identified as a significant risk factor for the development of cancer, with incidence rates increasing with advancing age. The findings from this study provide valuable insights into the cancer burden in a noninstitutionalized white population and emphasize the importance of ongoing cancer surveillance in this group.

Prognostic indicators of the resolution of nonimmune hydrops fetalis and survival of the fetus. Nonimmune hydrops fetalis (NIHF) is a severe condition characterized by the abnormal accumulation of fluid in the fetus, leading to significant morbidity and mortality. The prognosis for NIHF is highly variable, making it challenging for clinicians to determine the optimal management and counseling for affected families. In this retrospective study, we aimed to identify prognostic indicators associated with the resolution of NIHF and fetal survival. Data from 82 cases of NIHF were analyzed, and various factors, including gestational age, ultrasound findings, maternal medical history, and fetal laboratory tests, were evaluated. The resolution of NIHF occurred in 58% of cases, with a fetal survival rate of 75%. Multivariate analysis revealed that gestational age at diagnosis, ultrasound findings of fetal ascites, and abnormal laboratory tests were significant predictors of resolution of NIHF and fetal survival. These findings provide valuable insights into the prognosis of NIHF and may aid clinicians in decision-making and counseling for affected families. Further research is warranted to validate and refine these prognostic indicators.

Computed tomography in the evaluation of the aorta in patients sustaining blunt chest trauma.  Computed tomography is used with increasing frequency to evaluate blunt chest trauma. In this retrospective study, we aimed to evaluate the role of computed tomography (CT) in assessing aortic injuries in patients with blunt chest trauma. We reviewed the medical records of 150 patients who presented with blunt chest trauma and underwent CT imaging. CT scans were analyzed for the presence of aortic injuries, including aortic dissection, intramural hematoma, and pseudoaneurysm. The results were compared to the gold standard, which consisted of intraoperative findings or follow-up imaging. CT demonstrated a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 98% in detecting aortic injuries. Of the 12 patients with confirmed aortic injuries, 10 were correctly identified by CT. Additionally, CT allowed for the identification of associated injuries, such as rib fractures and pulmonary contusions. Our findings suggest that CT is a valuable tool for the evaluation of the aorta in patients with blunt chest trauma, enabling prompt and accurate diagnosis of aortic injuries.

Gastro-oesophageal reflux during elective laparoscopy. Gastro-oesophageal reflux (GOR) is a common occurrence during laparoscopic procedures. This study aimed to determine the prevalence and severity of GOR in patients undergoing elective laparoscopy and identify any associated risk factors. A prospective observational study was conducted on 150 patients undergoing different laparoscopic procedures. Gastrointestinal symptoms and reflux scores were recorded before and after surgery. The results showed a high prevalence of GOR during laparoscopy, with 70% of patients experiencing symptoms and significant reflux scores postoperatively. Body mass index (BMI) and duration of surgery were identified as risk factors for GOR. In conclusion, GOR is a common occurrence during elective laparoscopy, particularly in patients with higher BMI and longer surgery duration. Proper preoperative assessment and management of GOR risk factors should be considered to minimize postoperative complications.

Mucinous cystadenoma of the lung. Mucinous cystadenoma of the lung is a rare neoplasm with fewer than 100 cases reported in the literature. We present a case of a 58-year-old woman who was incidentally found to have a large cystic lesion in her left lung. Radiographic evaluation revealed a well-defined cystic mass with internal septations. The patient underwent surgical resection, and histopathologic examination confirmed the diagnosis of mucinous cystadenoma. There were no signs of malignancy. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and remained asymptomatic during follow-up. Mucinous cystadenomas of the lung are benign tumors that should be considered in the differential diagnosis of cystic lung lesions. Complete surgical resection is the treatment of choice, offering excellent prognosis and minimizing the risk of recurrence.

Alzheimer's disease and related disorders in state mental hospitals: data from a nationwide survey. We conducted a nationwide survey to gather data on the prevalence of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related disorders in state mental hospitals. A total of 56 mental hospitals participated in the survey, providing information on a combined total of 9,874 patients. The average age of the patients was 76 years, and the majority were female (60%). Of the patients, 42% were diagnosed with AD, while 18% were diagnosed with other related disorders such as vascular dementia or Lewy body dementia. The prevalence of AD increased with age, with the highest rates observed in patients over 85 years old. These findings emphasize the significant burden of AD and related disorders in state mental hospitals and highlight the need for appropriate screening, diagnosis, and care for these patients.

A controlled trial of psychological treatment for the irritable bowel syndrome. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common functional gastrointestinal disorder characterized by abdominal pain and altered bowel habits. The effectiveness of psychological interventions in the management of IBS symptoms remains unclear. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of psychological treatment in patients with IBS. 

A randomized controlled trial was conducted involving patients diagnosed with IBS based on Rome III criteria. Participants were randomly assigned to either a psychological treatment group or a control group receiving standard medical care. The psychological treatment included cognitive-behavioral therapy and relaxation techniques.

After a 12-week intervention, patients in the psychological treatment group showed significant improvements in IBS symptom severity, pain intensity, and quality of life compared to the control group. Reductions in anxiety and depression scores were also observed in the psychological treatment group.

These findings suggest that psychological treatment, specifically cognitive-behavioral therapy and relaxation techniques, can effectively alleviate symptoms and improve the overall well-being of patients with IBS. Further research is warranted to explore the long-term effects and cost-effectiveness of psychological interventions in managing IBS.

Risk factors for white matter changes detected by magnetic resonance imaging in the elderly. White matter changes detected by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are common in elderly individuals and have been associated with various risk factors. In this study, we aimed to identify the risk factors for white matter changes in a population of elderly individuals. A total of 150 participants aged 65 years and above underwent brain MRI scans and were assessed for various demographic, clinical, and lifestyle factors. Logistic regression analysis revealed that older age, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and smoking were significantly associated with an increased risk of white matter changes. These findings highlight the importance of managing these risk factors to prevent or delay the development of white matter changes in the elderly population.

Radiologic staging of chest in testicular seminoma. Radiologic staging of chest in testicular seminoma plays a crucial role in determining the extent of disease and guiding treatment decisions. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of different imaging modalities in detecting chest metastasis in patients with testicular seminoma. A retrospective analysis of 120 patients diagnosed with testicular seminoma between 2000 and 2010 was performed. Chest X-ray, computed tomography (CT), and positron emission tomography (PET) scans were reviewed for evidence of metastasis. The results showed that CT and PET scans had higher sensitivity and specificity compared to chest X-ray in detecting chest metastasis. PET scan in particular demonstrated superior accuracy in diagnosing distant metastatic disease, aiding in the appropriate staging and management of patients with testicular seminoma.

Autosomal recessive chronic granulomatous disease caused by deletion at a dinucleotide repeat. Autosomal recessive chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by recurrent and severe bacterial and fungal infections caused by defective phagocyte function. While the majority of CGD cases are caused by mutations in the five known genes encoding components of the phagocyte NADPH oxidase complex, we report here a unique case of CGD caused by a deletion at a dinucleotide repeat within the CYBB gene. The patient presented with a history of recurrent infections, including pneumonia and abscesses. Upon evaluation, neutrophil oxidative burst activity was markedly reduced. Genetic analysis revealed a homozygous deletion of two cytosine residues at position 7310 within the CYBB gene. This deletion resulted in a frameshift mutation and premature termination codon, leading to absent expression of the cytochrome b-245 beta chain. To our knowledge, this is the first case of CGD caused by a deletion at a dinucleotide repeat in the CYBB gene, highlighting the importance of comprehensive genetic testing for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of CGD patients. Further studies are needed to investigate the frequency and clinical implications of such rare genetic mutations in CGD.

Treatment of chronic moccasin-type tinea pedis with terbinafine: a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Fungal infections of the feet, such as tinea pedis, are a common dermatological condition with chronic moccasin-type tinea pedis being particularly difficult to treat. This double-blind, placebo-controlled trial aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of terbinafine in the treatment of chronic moccasin-type tinea pedis. Seventy-five participants with moderate to severe symptoms were randomly assigned to receive either terbinafine or placebo once daily for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure was complete clinical cure at week 12. Results showed that terbinafine significantly improved clinical outcomes compared to placebo, with 57.1% of participants achieving complete clinical cure compared to 15.4% in the placebo group. Adverse events were minimal, with no significant difference between the two groups. These findings suggest that terbinafine is an effective and well-tolerated treatment for chronic moccasin-type tinea pedis.

Gentamicin iontophoresis in the treatment of bacterial otitis externa in the guinea pig model.  Pseudomonas otitis externa is one of the most common infections treated by otolaryngologists. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of gentamicin iontophoresis for the treatment of bacterial otitis externa in a guinea pig model. Pseudomonas otitis externa is a frequent infection encountered by otolaryngologists. Twelve guinea pigs were divided into two groups: one group received gentamicin iontophoresis and the other group received standard topical gentamicin treatment. The results showed that the guinea pigs treated with gentamicin iontophoresis had a significantly faster resolution of infection compared to the control group. Furthermore, histopathological examination revealed a significant decrease in the severity of inflammation in the gentamicin iontophoresis group. This suggests that gentamicin iontophoresis is a more effective treatment modality for bacterial otitis externa compared to standard topical application. Further studies are needed to investigate the potential of gentamicin iontophoresis in clinical practice and its impact on patient outcomes.

Choroid plexus tumors in the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. Choroid plexus tumors are rare brain tumors that typically arise in children. However, there have been reports of choroid plexus tumors occurring in adults with breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. We present a case series of three patients with breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome who developed choroid plexus tumors. All three patients were women in their 40s who had a history of breast cancer and sarcoma. The choroid plexus tumors were diagnosed based on imaging studies and confirmed by histopathological examination. These cases highlight the importance of considering choroid plexus tumors in the differential diagnosis of brain tumors in patients with breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. Further research is needed to understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of these rare tumors.

Major histocompatibility complex antigen expression in the affected tissues in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.  Monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry was used to examine spinal cord and muscle in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis for changes that would indicate ongoing or potential immune activity. The expression of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens in the affected tissues of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) was investigated using monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry. The study aimed to identify any changes in the spinal cord and muscle that may indicate ongoing or potential immune activity in ALS. Samples were obtained from postmortem specimens of ALS patients. The results revealed an increased expression of MHC antigens in both the spinal cord and muscle tissues, indicating an activation of the immune system. This immune response may play a role in the pathogenesis of ALS. Further research is warranted to explore the precise mechanisms underlying MHC antigen expression and its impact on the disease progression in ALS. Understanding these mechanisms may lead to the development of novel therapeutic targets for ALS.

Natural history of moderate aortic stenosis.  The natural history of severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis has been well documented. However, less is known about the natural history of moderate aortic stenosis. Moderate aortic stenosis is defined as an aortic valve area of 1.0-1.5 cm with a peak gradient of 20-40 mmHg. The progression of moderate aortic stenosis has important implications for clinical management and decision-making.

Several studies have been conducted to investigate the natural history of moderate aortic stenosis. These studies have shown that the annual progression rate of aortic valve area in patients with moderate aortic stenosis ranges from 0.1 to 0.3 cm. The overall progression rate is relatively slow, with a median time to severe aortic stenosis of approximately 10-20 years.

However, it is important to note that there is considerable heterogeneity in the progression rate among individuals. Factors such as age, gender, concomitant coronary artery disease, and hypertension may influence the rate of progression. Additionally, patients with rapid progression of aortic stenosis may be at higher risk for adverse cardiovascular events.

Understanding the natural history of moderate aortic stenosis is crucial for clinical decision-making. Regular monitoring of valve parameters and risk assessment plays a key role in determining the appropriate timing for intervention, such as aortic valve replacement. Further research is needed to better characterize and predict the progression of moderate aortic stenosis in order to optimize patient care.

The effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation.  The properties of the omentum and its effect on spinal neurologic disease was investigated. This study examined the impact of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation. The omentum, a fatty tissue in the abdominal cavity, was investigated for its potential in treating spinal neurologic disease.  Eighteen patients who underwent lumbar laminectomy with or without omental pedicle graft transfer were included in the study. Microcirculation measurements were taken using laser doppler flowmetry, and laminectomy membrane formation was assessed through histopathological analysis. The results showed that omental pedicle graft transfer significantly improved spinal microcirculation and reduced laminectomy membrane formation. These findings suggest the potential of using omental pedicle graft transfer as a therapeutic approach for spinal neurologic disease.

Early-onset dementia and extrapyramidal disease: clinicopathological variant of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker or Alzheimer's disease? A case of progressive dementia and extrapyramidal signs beginning at age 29, with a ten year course until death, is presented. We report a case of a 29-year-old patient who presented with early-onset dementia and extrapyramidal signs. The patient exhibited a ten-year progressive course until eventual death. Pathological examination revealed features suggestive of both Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker (GSS) and Alzheimer's disease (AD). The clinical and pathological findings raise the question of whether this case represents a clinicopathological variant of GSS or a manifestation of early-onset AD. Further research is needed to determine the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms and clarify the classification of this rare presentation.

Management of macular puckers associated with retinal angiomas. Retinal angiomas can be associated with macular puckers, which can lead to visual impairment. This study aims to evaluate the management of macular puckers in patients with retinal angiomas. A retrospective analysis was conducted on twenty-five patients (12 males, 13 females, mean age 58.3 years) diagnosed with retinal angiomas and macular puckers. The treatment options included observation, anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) injections, and vitrectomy with epiretinal membrane peeling. Visual acuity and macular thickness were measured before and after treatment. The results showed that vitrectomy with epiretinal membrane peeling resulted in significant visual improvement and reduction in macular thickness in the majority of patients. Anti-VEGF injections were found to have a limited effect, while observation showed minimal changes. The findings suggest that vitrectomy with epiretinal membrane peeling is an effective treatment option for managing macular puckers associated with retinal angiomas. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to validate these findings.

Surgical results of intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating hiatal hernia.  From 1981 to 1988, 138 patients with hiatal hernia were treated surgically at our centre. Intrathoracic gastric volvulus is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication of hiatal hernia. This study aimed to evaluate the surgical outcomes of patients with intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating hiatal hernia. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 138 patients who underwent surgical treatment for hiatal hernia between 1981 and 1988 at our center. Of these, 14 patients (10.1%) presented with intrathoracic gastric volvulus. The mean age of patients with intrathoracic gastric volvulus was significantly higher than those without (62.4 vs. 53.8 years, p<0.05). Most patients presented with acute symptoms including chest pain, dysphagia, and vomiting. Surgical intervention involved reduction of the volvulus, hiatal hernia repair, and in some cases, fundoplication. Postoperative complications occurred in 42.9% of patients with intrathoracic gastric volvulus, including pneumonia, respiratory failure, and surgical site infection. The overall mortality rate in this subgroup was 14.3%. In conclusion, intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating hiatal hernia is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Prompt surgical intervention is warranted to prevent potentially serious complications.

Obesity and vaginal hysterectomy. Obesity is a well-known risk factor for surgical complications, and its impact on vaginal hysterectomy has not been extensively studied. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the association between obesity and perioperative outcomes in women undergoing vaginal hysterectomy. A total of 500 patients who underwent this procedure were included in the analysis. The patients were divided into two groups based on body mass index (BMI): obese (BMI  30 kg/m2) and non-obese (BMI < 30 kg/m2). The study found that obese patients had significantly longer operative times, higher rates of intraoperative and postoperative complications, longer hospital stays, and higher rates of reoperation compared to non-obese patients. These findings emphasize the importance of careful patient selection, preoperative optimization, and close monitoring of obese women undergoing vaginal hysterectomy.

Experience with the use of coronary autoperfusion catheter during complicated angioplasty. Complications during angioplasty procedures can be challenging to manage, particularly in cases of critically ill patients or complex lesion morphology. The use of a coronary autoperfusion catheter has been proposed as an adjunctive technique to improve outcomes in such scenarios. We present our experience with the use of this catheter in a series of patients undergoing complicated angioplasty. The catheter was successfully deployed in all cases, allowing for continuous perfusion of the target vessel during balloon inflation and stent deployment. Post-procedure angiography demonstrated restoration of blood flow and resolution of complications in the majority of patients. Based on our experience, the coronary autoperfusion catheter appears to be a promising tool in the management of complicated angioplasty cases, offering potential benefits in terms of procedural success and patient outcomes.

The role of intracaval filters in patients with COPD and DVT. Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are at an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to their prothrombotic state. The use of intracaval filters in this patient population remains controversial. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 285 patients with both COPD and DVT to evaluate the role of intracaval filters in preventing pulmonary embolism (PE). Of the total patients, 135 received intracaval filters while 150 did not. Among the filtered group, only 4 patients developed PE compared to 18 patients in the non-filtered group. However, the incidence of filter-related complications, such as filter migration and thrombosis, was found to be 8%. The results suggest that intracaval filters may be beneficial in preventing PE in patients with COPD and DVT, but the potential complications associated with these devices need to be carefully considered. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and establish appropriate guidelines for filter placement in this patient population.

Differential memory and executive functions in demented patients with Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease. Dementia is a common neurodegenerative condition characterized by cognitive decline and impairment in memory and executive functions. Two common types of dementia are Parkinson's disease (PD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD), which have distinct pathological mechanisms. This study aimed to investigate the differential effects of PD and AD on memory and executive functions. A total of 94 demented patients, including 53 with PD and 41 with AD, were assessed using a comprehensive neuropsychological battery. Results showed that PD patients demonstrated better performance in executive functions compared to AD patients, while AD patients exhibited more severe memory impairments. These findings suggest that PD and AD may have distinct cognitive profiles and highlight the importance of considering the underlying neuropathology when evaluating and managing cognitive impairments in dementia.

Intradural spinal cord tumor presenting as a subarachnoid hemorrhage: magnetic resonance imaging diagnosis. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is commonly caused by ruptured intracranial aneurysms and rarely associated with intradural spinal cord tumors. We present a case of a 46-year-old female who presented with sudden onset severe headache and was diagnosed with SAH. Initial cerebral angiography did not reveal any aneurysm or vascular malformation. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed no evidence of bleeding, but incidentally demonstrated an intradural spinal cord tumor at the T4-T6 level. Subsequent MRI of the spine confirmed the presence of a homogeneously enhancing intramedullary tumor. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor, which was histologically confirmed as an ependymoma. Intradural spinal cord tumors rarely present with SAH as their initial clinical manifestation. This case highlights the importance of considering a spinal cord tumor as a potential cause of SAH, especially in cases where cerebral angiography is inconclusive. MRI plays a crucial role in the diagnosis and assessment of intradural spinal cord tumors, allowing for early and appropriate management.

Essential hypertension, metabolic disorders, and insulin resistance. Essential hypertension, metabolic disorders, and insulin resistance have been known to be closely interrelated. The objective of this study was to investigate the association between insulin resistance and the presence of metabolic disorders in patients with essential hypertension. A total of 320 patients diagnosed with essential hypertension were recruited for this cross-sectional study. Insulin resistance was assessed using the homeostatic model assessment for insulin resistance (HOMA-IR). Metabolic disorders including dyslipidemia, central obesity, and hyperuricemia were also determined. The results showed that patients with essential hypertension had a higher prevalence of metabolic disorders compared to the general population. Additionally, insulin resistance was found to be significantly associated with the presence of metabolic disorders in patients with essential hypertension. These findings suggest that insulin resistance plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of metabolic disorders in patients with essential hypertension and highlight the importance of managing insulin resistance as a therapeutic target in these individuals.

Hyponatraemia in patients with cirrhosis. Hyponatraemia, defined as a serum sodium concentration below 135 mmol/L, is a common electrolyte abnormality in patients with cirrhosis. It is associated with significant morbidity and mortality.
