Hot spots for growth hormone gene deletions in homologous regions outside of Alu repeats. Growth hormone (GH) gene deletions are an important cause of isolated growth hormone deficiency (IGHD). Previous studies have identified the presence of Alu repeats as hot spots for GH gene deletions. However, recent evidence suggests that there may also be homologous regions outside of Alu repeats that are prone to deletions. In order to further investigate this phenomenon, we conducted a comprehensive analysis of GH gene deletions in a cohort of 100 patients with IGHD.

Our results revealed a total of 27 GH gene deletions in 20 patients, with 12 of these deletions occurring in homologous regions outside of Alu repeats. These non-Alu repeat hot spots were found to be predominantly located in intronic regions, as opposed to exonic or promoter regions. Interestingly, we observed a significant association between the presence of non-Alu repeat hot spots and more severe phenotypes of IGHD.

In conclusion, our study provides further evidence for the existence of hot spots for GH gene deletions outside of Alu repeats. These findings have important implications for the genetic counseling and management of patients with IGHD, as well as for future research on the molecular mechanisms underlying GH gene deletions.

Extracranial metastatic glioblastoma: appearance on thallium-201-chloride/technetium-99m-HMPAO SPECT images. Extracranial metastasis of glioblastoma is a rare occurrence and its imaging characteristics remain poorly understood. We present a case of a 54-year-old male with a known glioblastoma who developed cervical lymph node metastases. Thallium-201-chloride/technetium-99m-HMPAO single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) was performed to evaluate the extent of metastatic disease. The SPECT images revealed intense uptake of both thallium-201 and technetium-99m in the cervical lymph nodes, confirming metastatic involvement. Additionally, the SPECT images demonstrated increased thallium-201 uptake within the primary intracranial glioblastoma lesion. This case demonstrates the potential utility of thallium-201-chloride/technetium-99m-HMPAO SPECT imaging in detecting extracranial metastatic glioblastoma and highlights the importance of considering extracranial spread in the management of patients with glioblastoma. Further studies are needed to elucidate the clinical implications and prognostic significance of extracranial metastasis in glioblastoma patients.

Conjunctival involvement in pemphigus vulgaris: a clinical, histopathological and immunofluorescence study. Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is a chronic autoimmune blistering disorder that primarily involves mucous membranes and skin. Conjunctival involvement is a rare manifestation of PV, and its clinical, histopathological, and immunofluorescence characteristics are not well documented. We present a descriptive study of five patients with conjunctival involvement in PV. All patients demonstrated conjunctival blistering and erosions, accompanied by characteristic histopathological findings, including acantholysis, intraepithelial bulla formation, and epithelial cell detachment. Direct immunofluorescence revealed deposition of IgG and complement component C3 within the conjunctival epithelium. Treatment with systemic corticosteroids and immunosuppressive agents was effective in controlling conjunctival involvement. Awareness of conjunctival involvement in PV and its diagnostic features is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

A cytotoxic T-lymphocyte clone derived from mice with progressively growing tumors. Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) play a crucial role in the immune response against tumors. In this study, a CTL clone was derived from mice with progressively growing tumors, aiming to investigate its cytotoxicity and potential anti-tumor effect. The CTL clone exhibited potent cytotoxic activity against tumor cells in vitro, as demonstrated by the significant reduction in cell viability and induction of apoptosis. Additionally, the CTL clone demonstrated the ability to secrete interferon-gamma (IFN-), a key cytokine involved in antitumor immunity. In a murine model, adoptive transfer of the CTL clone resulted in a significant reduction in tumor size and prolonged overall survival of the mice compared to control groups. These findings highlight the potential of CTL clones derived from progressively growing tumors as a therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the anti-tumor effects of these CTL clones and their potential application in clinical settings.

Endoscopic ultrasonography in diagnosis of the extent of gallbladder carcinoma.  Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) was performed preoperatively in 39 patients with gallbladder carcinoma.  Diagnosis of the anatomical extent of gallbladder carcinoma was compared with histologic analysis, and staging accuracy was evaluated according to the TNM classification. The aim of this study was to evaluate the use of endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) in diagnosing the extent of gallbladder carcinoma. A total of 39 patients with gallbladder carcinoma underwent preoperative EUS. The EUS findings were compared with histologic analysis to determine the accuracy of diagnosing the anatomical extent of the tumor. Additionally, the staging accuracy of EUS was evaluated using the TNM classification. The results showed that EUS accurately diagnosed the tumor extent in 34 out of 39 patients (87.2%). The staging accuracy according to the TNM classification was 61.5%. In conclusion, EUS is a valuable tool in diagnosing the extent of gallbladder carcinoma, providing important information for treatment planning and prognostic evaluation.

A self-administered hand symptom diagram for the diagnosis and epidemiologic study of carpal tunnel syndrome.  Noninvasive tests for carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) are of limited diagnostic value. Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is a common condition characterized by compression of the median nerve at the wrist, leading to symptoms such as pain, numbness, and tingling in the hand. Noninvasive tests commonly used for the diagnosis of CTS have limited diagnostic value.

In this study, we developed a self-administered hand symptom diagram as a tool for the diagnosis and epidemiologic study of CTS. The diagram consists of a simple outline of the hand, and participants are asked to shade areas where they experience symptoms. 

Preliminary results showed high sensitivity and specificity of the hand symptom diagram compared to traditional noninvasive tests for CTS diagnosis. This tool holds promise for improving early detection and monitoring of CTS in both clinical and research settings. Further validation studies are warranted to confirm its utility.

Leukoaraiosis, intracerebral hemorrhage, and arterial hypertension. Leukoaraiosis, a prominent manifestation of small vessel disease in the brain, has been associated with increased risk of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and arterial hypertension. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between leukoaraiosis, ICH, and arterial hypertension in a cohort of 234 patients. 

The severity of leukoaraiosis was assessed using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and graded based on the Fazekas scale. The presence of ICH was confirmed through computed tomography (CT) or MRI scans. Arterial hypertension was diagnosed based on medical history, physical examination, and blood pressure measurements.
Results showed a significant association between leukoaraiosis severity and the presence of ICH (p < 0.001). Patients with severe leukoaraiosis had a higher risk of developing ICH compared to those with mild or absent leukoaraiosis. Additionally, there was a strong correlation between leukoaraiosis severity and arterial hypertension (p = 0.043).

These findings suggest that leukoaraiosis may serve as a marker for increased risk of ICH and arterial hypertension. Early detection and management of leukoaraiosis in patients with arterial hypertension could potentially prevent the occurrence of ICH and improve patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to confirm these associations and explore potential therapeutic interventions.

Recent advance in treatment of Stanford type A aortic dissection. Stanford type A aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate surgical intervention. This study aims to evaluate recent advances in the treatment of Stanford type A aortic dissection and their impact on patient outcomes. 

The traditional treatment approach for Stanford type A aortic dissection involves open surgical repair using cardiopulmonary bypass. However, advancements in endovascular techniques have paved the way for less invasive treatment options. 

Endovascular stent grafting has gained popularity as an alternative treatment approach, especially in patients who are deemed high-risk for open surgery. This technique involves the placement of a stent graft within the dissected aorta to seal the entry tear and re-establish blood flow. 

Studies have shown that endovascular stent grafting offers comparable early and midterm outcomes to traditional surgical repair. Furthermore, it has the advantage of reduced operative time, decreased blood loss, and shorter hospital stays. 

The use of hybrid procedures, combining open surgical repair with endovascular stent grafting, has also shown promising results in patients with complex aortic dissections. 

Overall, recent advances in the treatment of Stanford type A aortic dissection have expanded the therapeutic options available, allowing for tailored approaches based on patient characteristics. However, further research is needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and durability of these interventions.

Muscle rehabilitation in impaired elderly nursing home residents. Elderly nursing home residents often experience impaired muscle function, leading to decreased mobility and an increased risk of falls and functional decline. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a muscle rehabilitation program in improving muscle strength, functional mobility, and quality of life in this population. 

A total of 50 elderly nursing home residents with impaired muscle function were randomly assigned to either a muscle rehabilitation group or a control group. The muscle rehabilitation group participated in a 12-week program that included resistance training exercises targeting major muscle groups, balance training, and functional activities. The control group received standard care without any specific muscle rehabilitation intervention. 

Results showed that the muscle rehabilitation group had significant improvements in muscle strength, as assessed by handgrip strength and leg press strength, compared to the control group. Functional mobility, as measured by the Timed Up and Go Test, also improved significantly in the muscle rehabilitation group. Additionally, participants in the muscle rehabilitation group reported improved quality of life, as indicated by higher scores on the SF-36 questionnaire. 

In conclusion, a targeted muscle rehabilitation program can effectively improve muscle strength, functional mobility, and quality of life in impaired elderly nursing home residents. Implementation of such programs in nursing home settings may help enhance the overall well-being and functional independence of this vulnerable population.

Chronic alcoholic gastritis.  Roles of alcohol and Helicobacter pylori. Chronic alcoholic gastritis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the stomach lining, resulting from long-term alcohol consumption. The precise mechanisms underlying the development of this condition are not fully understood. In recent years, there has been growing evidence suggesting the involvement of Helicobacter pylori infection in the pathogenesis of alcoholic gastritis. 

This study aimed to investigate the roles of alcohol and H. pylori in chronic alcoholic gastritis. We analyzed gastric biopsy specimens from patients with alcoholic gastritis and compared them to those with non-alcoholic gastritis. Immunohistochemical staining was performed to detect the presence of H. pylori in the gastric mucosa. Additionally, alcohol consumption was assessed through patient interviews and medical records.

Our findings revealed a higher prevalence of H. pylori infection in patients with alcoholic gastritis compared to those with non-alcoholic gastritis. Furthermore, alcohol consumption was significantly associated with an increased risk of H. pylori infection in patients with chronic gastritis. These results suggest that both alcohol and H. pylori play important roles in the development and progression of chronic alcoholic gastritis. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the precise molecular mechanisms underlying this interaction and to explore potential therapeutic interventions.

Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia associated with profound lymphopenia and abnormal T-lymphocyte subset ratios during treatment for early-stage breast carcinoma. Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) is a serious opportunistic infection commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals. We present a case of PCP in a patient undergoing treatment for early-stage breast carcinoma. The patient developed profound lymphopenia and abnormal T-lymphocyte subset ratios during chemotherapy. PCP was diagnosed based on clinical symptoms and confirmed by sputum examination. The patient was successfully treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and demonstrated clinical improvement. This case highlights the importance of vigilance for PCP in patients undergoing immunosuppressive therapies, even in the absence of advanced malignancy or HIV infection. Regular monitoring of lymphocyte subsets may aid in early identification and prompt treatment of PCP in this population. Further studies are warranted to investigate risk factors and optimal preventive strategies for PCP in cancer patients.

Computed tomography in patients with esophageal perforation.  Contrast esophagram is the diagnostic procedure of choice in patients with clinically suspected perforation of the esophagus. However, computed tomography (CT) has emerged as a valuable imaging modality in the evaluation of esophageal perforation. This study aimed to determine the diagnostic accuracy and clinical utility of CT in patients with esophageal perforation. 

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 50 patients with clinically suspected esophageal perforation who underwent CT imaging. The CT scans were independently reviewed by two radiologists blinded to the final diagnosis, and the findings were compared with surgical or endoscopic findings, or clinical follow-up.

CT accurately diagnosed esophageal perforation in 46 out of 50 patients, yielding a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 100%. In addition to the diagnosis of perforation, CT also provided valuable information regarding the extent and location of the perforation, presence of associated mediastinal or pleural complications, and presence of intramural gas or contrast extravasation.

In conclusion, CT is a highly accurate imaging modality for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation, offering additional information that can greatly influence patient management and surgical planning. Thus, CT should be considered as a valuable adjunct to contrast esophagram in patients with clinically suspected esophageal perforation.

Biliary and pancreatic metastases of breast carcinoma: is surgical palliation indicated? Obstructive jaundice developed in a patient concomitantly with the diagnosis of breast carcinoma. Metastases to the biliary and pancreatic systems from breast carcinoma are rare and often present a diagnostic challenge. This case report describes a patient who developed obstructive jaundice at the same time as her breast carcinoma diagnosis. Initial imaging revealed multiple liver lesions, and subsequent biopsy confirmed the presence of metastatic breast carcinoma. Further investigations, including magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, identified biliary and pancreatic involvement. The patient underwent surgical palliation with placement of metallic stents in the biliary system. She experienced resolution of her jaundice and improvement in her symptoms. This case highlights the potential benefit of surgical palliation in patients with biliary and pancreatic metastases from breast carcinoma, despite the limited evidence available. Further research is warranted to better understand the optimal management approach for these patients.

Clinical diagnosis of tamponade in Malawi. Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt diagnosis and intervention. However, in resource-limited settings such as Malawi, the clinical diagnosis of tamponade may present unique challenges. We conducted a retrospective study to evaluate the clinical features and diagnostic accuracy of cardiac tamponade in a tertiary hospital in Malawi. A total of 52 patients with suspected tamponade were included in the study. The most common presenting symptoms were dyspnea (82%) and tachycardia (75%). Physical examination findings included pulsus paradoxus (61%) and elevated jugular venous pressure (59%). Echocardiography was the primary diagnostic modality and was available for 50% of the patients. The overall diagnostic accuracy of clinical diagnosis was 75%, with a sensitivity of 84% and specificity of 67%. Our study highlights the challenges in diagnosing tamponade in a resource-limited setting and emphasizes the importance of targeted interventions and improving access to diagnostic tools in these settings.

NMDA antagonists potentiate antiparkinsonian actions of L-dopa in monoamine-depleted rats. The purpose of this study was to investigate the potential potentiating effects of NMDA antagonists on the antiparkinsonian actions of L-dopa in monoamine-depleted rats. Rats were subjected to monoamine depletion through the administration of reserpine and -methyl-p-tyrosine. Following the depletion, the rats were treated with L-dopa alone or in combination with various NMDA antagonists, including MK-801, memantine, and ketamine. Motor behavior was then assessed using the catalepsy test and the bar test. The results demonstrated that the administration of NMDA antagonists along with L-dopa significantly potentiated the antiparkinsonian effects of L-dopa in the monoamine-depleted rats. This was evidenced by a decrease in cataleptic behavior and an improvement in motor coordination. These findings suggest that NMDA antagonists may have therapeutic potential in improving the efficacy of L-dopa treatment in Parkinson's disease. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential clinical applications of this combination therapy.

Flow cytometric determination of breast tumor heterogeneity. Breast tumor heterogeneity is a crucial factor in predicting treatment response and patient outcomes. Flow cytometry is a useful tool for assessing tumor heterogeneity by analyzing the DNA content of individual cells. In this study, we analyzed breast tumor samples from 50 patients using flow cytometry to determine tumor heterogeneity based on DNA content. We found significant heterogeneity within the samples, with a diverse range of DNA content profiles observed. Furthermore, we correlated these DNA content profiles with clinicopathological characteristics and treatment response data. Our results demonstrated that tumor heterogeneity, as measured by flow cytometry, was associated with aggressive tumor features and poor treatment response. These findings highlight the importance of evaluating tumor heterogeneity to guide treatment decisions and improve patient outcomes.

Delayed brachial artery occlusion owing to a dog bite of the upper extremity. Dog bites can lead to various complications, including vascular injuries. We present a case of delayed brachial artery occlusion following a dog bite to the upper extremity. A 34-year-old male presented to the emergency department two days after sustaining a dog bite to his right forearm. On examination, he exhibited pain, swelling, and discoloration of the affected limb. Doppler ultrasound revealed complete occlusion of the brachial artery. The patient underwent emergent surgical exploration, which revealed partial thrombosis and intimal injury of the artery. Thrombectomy was performed, and the arterial flow was restored. Postoperatively, the patient was started on anticoagulation therapy, and his limb showed signs of improvement. This case highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion for vascular injuries in patients presenting with delayed symptoms after a dog bite, emphasizing the need for early intervention to prevent devastating complications.

Misinterpretation of the upper parathyroid adenoma on thallium-201/technetium-99m subtraction scintigraphy.  Pre-operative thallium-technetium subtraction scintigraphy of 50 patients with primary hyperparathyroidism, which was subsequently proven on histology to be due to an adenoma, was compared with operative findings. Thallium-201/technetium-99m subtraction scintigraphy is a commonly used imaging technique for localization of parathyroid adenomas in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism. In this study, we identified a potential misinterpretation of the upper parathyroid adenoma on this imaging modality. Out of the 50 patients with histologically confirmed adenomas, we observed that in 7 cases (14%), the upper parathyroid adenoma exhibited decreased thallium-technetium uptake, leading to a false negative interpretation. These cases required additional imaging or intraoperative exploration for accurate localization. The misinterpretation of the upper parathyroid adenoma may arise from various factors such as variability in radiotracer uptake or anatomical location. Clinicians should be cautious and consider alternative imaging or surgical approaches when encountering cases with discordant findings on thallium-201/technetium-99m subtraction scintigraphy. Further studies are warranted to explore potential strategies to improve the accuracy of this imaging technique for parathyroid adenoma localization.

Serological arguments for classifying Raynaud's phenomenon as idiopathic.  Twenty-five patients with idiopathic Raynaud's phenomenon were followed prospectively for a mean period of 48 months. During the follow-up period, none of the patients with idiopathic Raynaud's phenomenon developed any clinical or laboratory evidence of an underlying connective tissue disease. Serological testing, including antinuclear antibodies and rheumatoid factor, was consistently negative in all patients. Onset of Raynaud's symptoms occurred at a mean age of 38 years, with a female predominance. The majority of patients experienced recurrent attacks, with a mean frequency of 4 episodes per month. Based on the absence of serological markers and the lack of progression to an underlying connective tissue disease, these findings support classifying Raynaud's phenomenon as idiopathic and not associated with an autoimmune etiology.

Dissecting aneurysm of the pulmonary artery with pulmonary hypertension.  Pulmonary artery dissection was observed in a 64-yr-old female patient with severe pulmonary hypertension, which was probably primary (pulmonary vascular resistance, 817 dyn. Pulmonary artery dissection is a rare but life-threatening condition associated with pulmonary hypertension. We present the case of a 64-year-old female who presented with severe pulmonary hypertension and was found to have a dissecting aneurysm of the pulmonary artery. The patient's pulmonary vascular resistance was significantly elevated, indicating primary pulmonary hypertension. The diagnosis was made through imaging modalities such as computed tomography (CT) and confirmed by surgical exploration. Pulmonary artery dissection requires prompt recognition and intervention, as it can lead to catastrophic consequences such as acute pulmonary embolism, heart failure, and death. Awareness of this condition is crucial, especially in patients with known pulmonary hypertension, to ensure early diagnosis and appropriate management. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management strategies for this rare complication.

Aneurysmal dilatation in saphenous vein bypass grafts. Aneurysmal dilatation in saphenous vein bypass grafts is a rare but potentially serious complication. We present a case series of four patients who developed aneurysmal dilatation in their saphenous vein bypass grafts. All patients had a history of coronary artery bypass graft surgery using saphenous vein grafts. The diagnosis was made incidentally during routine follow-up imaging studies. Three patients were asymptomatic, while one presented with acute graft occlusion. In all cases, percutaneous intervention was successfully performed, including coil embolization and stent placement. Follow-up imaging studies showed complete exclusion of the aneurysm and patent grafts. The long-term outcomes are not yet available as the follow-up period ranged from 6 to 18 months. This case series highlights the importance of regular imaging surveillance in patients with saphenous vein bypass grafts to detect and promptly intervene in cases of aneurysmal dilatation.

Carcinoma of the external auditory canal: an update. Carcinoma of the external auditory canal is a rare malignancy that accounts for less than 1% of head and neck cancers. It is typically found in elderly males and is associated with chronic otitis externa, radiation exposure, and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. This article provides an update on the current understanding of the etiology, diagnosis, and treatment of this malignancy. Advances in imaging techniques, such as magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography, have improved the accuracy of diagnosis and staging. Treatment options include surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy, either alone or in combination. The role of targeted therapies and immunotherapy in the management of advanced disease is also discussed. Despite advancements in treatment, the prognosis for patients with carcinoma of the external auditory canal remains poor, emphasizing the need for early detection and intervention.

Monitoring of cortical blood flow during temporary arterial occlusion in aneurysm surgery by the thermal diffusion method. In aneurysm surgery, temporary occlusion of the arterial blood flow is often necessary to prevent intraoperative bleeding. Monitoring the cortical blood flow during this occlusion is crucial for ensuring the safety and success of the procedure. In this study, we utilized the thermal diffusion method to measure changes in cortical blood flow in patients undergoing aneurysm surgery with temporary arterial occlusion. A total of 20 patients were included in the study, and cortical blood flow was monitored continuously during the occlusion period. The results showed that the thermal diffusion method was effective in detecting changes in cortical blood flow, providing real-time information about the cerebral perfusion status. This information helped the surgical team make informed decisions regarding the duration and safety of arterial occlusion, minimizing the risk of ischemic injury and improving patient outcomes. The thermal diffusion method is a valuable tool for monitoring cortical blood flow during aneurysm surgery and has the potential to enhance surgical precision and patient safety.

Postural hypotension: pressor effect of octreotide not mediated by norepinephrine. Postural hypotension is a common clinical problem. Octreotide, a synthetic analog of somatostatin, is commonly used to treat refractory cases. However, the mechanism by which octreotide exerts its pressor effect is not well understood. This study investigates whether the pressor effect of octreotide is mediated through the release of norepinephrine. Twelve patients with postural hypotension were enrolled in this study, and blood pressure and norepinephrine levels were measured before and after octreotide administration. Results showed that octreotide significantly increased blood pressure in all patients, but norepinephrine levels remained unchanged. These findings suggest that the pressor effect of octreotide in postural hypotension is not mediated by norepinephrine release, indicating the involvement of alternative mechanisms. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanism of action of octreotide in postural hypotension.

High-risk factors in metastatic gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. Metastatic gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) is a rare and aggressive tumor with a high mortality rate. This retrospective study aimed to identify high-risk factors associated with metastatic GTN. A total of 75 patients with metastatic GTN were included in the analysis. The majority of patients had a history of molar pregnancy (69.3%) and underwent initial treatment with chemotherapy (81.3%). The high-risk factors identified were: age 40 years, metastasis at initial diagnosis, lung metastasis, liver metastasis, and high -hCG levels. The presence of one or more of these factors was significantly associated with decreased overall survival. These findings suggest that early detection and aggressive management of high-risk factors are crucial for improving outcomes in patients with metastatic GTN.

DNA sequences 3' of the Ig H chain cluster rearrange in mouse B cell lines. The rearrangement of DNA sequences 3' of the immunoglobulin (Ig) H chain cluster has been observed in mouse B cell lines. This rearrangement occurs during the development of B cells and is important for the production of functional antibodies. In this study, we examined the rearrangement patterns in several mouse B cell lines and found that they differed between cell lines. Furthermore, we identified specific DNA sequences that were involved in these rearrangements. Our results suggest that the rearrangement of DNA sequences 3' of the Ig H chain cluster is a dynamic process that is regulated at the DNA level. Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms underlying this rearrangement and its functional consequences in B cell development and antibody production.

Intra-abdominal palpation of a nasogastric tube in the stomach does not assure appropriate placement. The correct placement of a nasogastric tube (NGT) is crucial to ensure safe and effective delivery of enteral feeding or medication. Intra-abdominal palpation, commonly used to confirm NGT placement, may not always provide accurate results. This study aimed to evaluate the reliability of intra-abdominal palpation in verifying NGT position in the stomach. A total of 80 patients requiring NGT placement were included in the study. Results showed that only 65% of NGTs palpated as being in the stomach were truly confirmed through radiographic imaging. Complications related to misplacement were also observed in this study. These findings suggest that relying solely on intra-abdominal palpation is not sufficient to assure appropriate NGT placement. Additional confirmatory measures, such as radiographic imaging, should be utilized to reduce the risk of complications.

LDH isoenzymes in cerebrospinal fluid in various brain tumours.  This study examined the isoenzymatic pattern of LDH in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as well as the ratio between the five fractions of LDH among patients with various brain tumours, carcinomatous meningitis and control groups. The aim of this study was to investigate the LDH isoenzymatic pattern and the ratio of LDH fractions in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) among patients with different brain tumors, carcinomatous meningitis, and control groups. CSF samples were collected from patients and analyzed using agarose gel electrophoresis. The results showed significant differences in the LDH isoenzymatic pattern between the patient groups and the control group. Specifically, patients with brain tumors and carcinomatous meningitis had a higher level of LDH in CSF compared to the control group. Additionally, the LDH5 fraction was found to be significantly elevated in patients with brain tumors and carcinomatous meningitis, suggesting a potential association between LDH isoenzymatic pattern and the presence of these conditions. Further research is needed to explore the clinical implications of these findings.

The prognostic value of modal deoxyribonucleic acid in low grade, low stage untreated prostate cancer.  We selected for a prospective surveillance study 167 patients with untreated grades 1 and 2 prostate cancer. We investigated the prognostic value of modal deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) content in low grade, low stage untreated prostate cancer patients. A total of 167 patients with untreated grades 1 and 2 prostate cancer were enrolled in a prospective surveillance study. Modal DNA content was determined using image cytometry on prostate tumor samples obtained through biopsy or transurethral resection. Patients were followed up for a median period of 60 months. Results showed that patients with higher modal DNA content had significantly worse prognoses, with an increased risk of tumor progression and metastasis. Furthermore, modal DNA content was found to be an independent predictor of biochemical recurrence and overall survival. This highlights the potential of modal DNA content as a valuable prognostic marker in low grade, low stage untreated prostate cancer, aiding in personalized treatment decisions and patient management.

Diagnosis of cerebrovascular disease in sickle cell anemia by magnetic resonance angiography The study of blood flow by means of magnetic resonance techniques has led to a noninvasive magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) technique for imaging large cerebral vessels. Cerebrovascular disease is a common complication in sickle cell anemia (SCA), but its diagnosis can be challenging. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) in detecting cerebrovascular disease in SCA patients. A total of 50 SCA patients underwent MRA to assess the presence of stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysm in the cerebral vasculature. The MRA findings were compared to conventional angiography, which served as the gold standard. The results showed a high diagnostic accuracy of MRA in detecting cerebrovascular disease, with a sensitivity and specificity of 95% and 90%, respectively. MRA can therefore be considered a reliable noninvasive tool for diagnosing cerebrovascular disease in SCA patients.

Possible role of leukotrienes in gastritis associated with Campylobacter pylori.  This study was done to evaluate the role of leukotrienes (LTs) in gastritis associated with Campylobacter pylori. In this study, we aimed to investigate the potential role of leukotrienes (LTs) in gastritis associated with Campylobacter pylori infection. Gastric biopsies were obtained from 20 patients with C. pylori-associated gastritis and 10 control subjects. The levels of LTs, including leukotriene B4 (LTB4) and leukotriene C4 (LTC4), were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Our results showed a significant increase in the levels of LTB4 and LTC4 in the gastric mucosa of patients with C. pylori-associated gastritis compared to the control group (p<0.05). These findings suggest that LTs may play a role in the pathogenesis of gastritis associated with C. pylori infection and provide insight into potential therapeutic targets for this condition. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the exact mechanism underlying LT-mediated inflammation in C. pylori-associated gastritis.

Value of combined assessment of physical health and functional status in community-dwelling aged: a prospective study in Florence, Italy. As the population ages, there is a growing need to assess the physical health and functional status of the elderly living in the community. In this prospective study conducted in Florence, Italy, we aimed to evaluate the combined assessment of physical health and functional status in community-dwelling aged individuals. 

A total of 500 participants aged 65 years and above were enrolled in the study. Physical health was assessed using comprehensive medical examinations, including laboratory tests and imaging studies. Functional status was evaluated using standardized questionnaires, such as the Activities of Daily Living (ADL) and Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) scales.

The results showed that a combined assessment of physical health and functional status provided a more comprehensive understanding of the elderly population's overall well-being. Participants with poorer physical health also had lower functional status scores, indicating a strong association between these two domains.

These findings highlight the importance of considering both physical health and functional status when evaluating the needs and providing care for the aging population in the community. Such assessments can help identify individuals at higher risk of functional decline, enabling timely interventions to promote healthy aging and improve the quality of life for older adults.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: life-threatening complication of neuroleptic treatment in adolescents with affective disorder. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a severe and potentially fatal complication that can arise from the use of neuroleptic medications in adolescents with affective disorders. This study aimed to analyze the clinical characteristics and outcomes of NMS in this specific population. A retrospective chart review was conducted on 50 adolescents who were diagnosed with NMS. The mean age at onset of NMS symptoms was 15.8 years, and the majority of patients were male (62%). The most common presenting symptoms were fever (90%), altered mental status (74%), and muscular rigidity (72%). Complications such as renal failure, rhabdomyolysis, and respiratory failure were observed in 40% of cases. With prompt recognition and immediate cessation of neuroleptic treatment, the mortality rate was 10%. This study highlights the importance of early diagnosis and management to improve outcomes in adolescents with affective disorder who develop NMS.

Gallstone pancreatitis.  Choosing and timing treatment. Gallstone pancreatitis is a common cause of acute pancreatitis, resulting from the migration of gallstones into the pancreatic duct. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial for favorable outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the choice and timing of treatment for gallstone pancreatitis. A retrospective analysis of 60 patients who presented with gallstone pancreatitis between 2005 and 2010 was conducted. The majority of patients (85%) underwent cholecystectomy after resolution of the acute attack, with a mean time interval of 8 days. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) with stone extraction was performed in 15% of patients who developed complications or persistent common bile duct stones. The study supports early cholecystectomy after resolution of gallstone pancreatitis to prevent recurrent attacks and complications. PTC may be considered in selected cases.

Anterior perforations in lumbar discectomies.  A report of four cases of vascular complications and a CT study of the prevertebral lumbar anatomy. This report presents four cases of vascular complications associated with anterior perforations during lumbar discectomies. These complications occurred in patients undergoing the procedure for recurrent disc herniation. The patients experienced significant intraoperative blood loss and required emergent vascular repair. To further understand the anatomical factors contributing to these complications, a computed tomography (CT) study of the prevertebral lumbar anatomy was conducted. The study identified variations in the relationship between the lumbar discs and major vascular structures, including the aorta and vena cava. These variations may increase the risk of vascular injury during anterior perforations. Surgeons performing lumbar discectomies should be aware of these anatomical variations and take precautionary measures to minimize the risk of vascular complications. Additionally, preoperative imaging, such as CT scans, can aid in identifying patients at higher risk for such complications. Further research is needed to better understand and prevent these vascular complications during lumbar discectomies.

Pleuroperitoneal shunting for intractable pleural effusions.  Pleuroperitoneal shunts were implanted in 17 patients with intractable pleural effusions, 15 of which were malignant and 2 benign. Pleuroperitoneal shunting is an effective treatment option for patients with intractable pleural effusions. In this retrospective study, we implanted pleuroperitoneal shunts in 17 patients, 15 of whom had malignant effusions and 2 had benign effusions. The shunts successfully alleviated symptoms in all patients, with no complications reported during the procedure. Follow-up evaluations showed significant improvement in lung function and quality of life, with a mean survival time of 12 months for patients with malignant effusions. Recurrence of effusion was observed in only one patient, who underwent a successful revision procedure. Pleuroperitoneal shunting is a safe and effective intervention for managing intractable pleural effusions, providing long-term relief and improved outcomes for patients.

Beta camera for static and dynamic imaging of charged-particle emitting radionuclides in biologic samples.  A detection system based on microchannel plates has been constructed to image charged particles emitted by radionuclides in biomedical samples. A beta camera using microchannel plates has been developed for the imaging of charged-particle emitting radionuclides in biologic samples. This system has the capability to perform static and dynamic imaging, allowing for real-time tracking of the emitted particles. By utilizing the high spatial resolution and sensitivity of microchannel plates, the beta camera can provide detailed information on the distribution and dynamics of radionuclides within biological samples. This imaging technique has the potential to be highly valuable in various fields of research, including the study of radioisotope therapy, radiotracer imaging, and drug development. The beta camera system offers a non-invasive and efficient method for visualizing the behavior of charged particles in biologic samples, providing researchers with valuable insights into the mechanisms and effects of radionuclides in biological systems.

Radiotherapy for palliation of locally advanced prostatic carcinoma. Radiotherapy is commonly used in the palliation of locally advanced prostatic carcinoma. This abstract aims to review the efficacy and safety of radiotherapy in this context. Studies have consistently shown that radiotherapy provides effective pain relief and improves quality of life in patients with locally advanced prostatic carcinoma. In addition, radiotherapy has been found to control local disease growth and prolong survival. However, adverse effects such as urinary and rectal symptoms, erectile dysfunction, and fatigue can occur. To optimize treatment outcomes, careful patient selection and individualized treatment planning are crucial. Close monitoring and appropriate management of treatment-related side effects are also necessary. Overall, radiotherapy represents a valuable option for palliative treatment in patients with locally advanced prostatic carcinoma.

Neuropsychological deficits in fetal alcohol syndrome and fetal alcohol effects. Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) and Fetal Alcohol Effects (FAE) are a spectrum of developmental disorders caused by maternal consumption of alcohol during pregnancy. In addition to physical abnormalities, these conditions are also associated with a range of neuropsychological deficits. This study aimed to investigate the specific cognitive impairments observed in individuals with FAS and FAE. 
Several neuropsychological domains were assessed, including intellectual functioning, attention, memory, executive functions, and visuospatial skills. It was found that individuals with FAS and FAE consistently exhibited deficits in all of these domains, with varying degrees of severity. Additionally, there was evidence of global cognitive impairment, as measured by intelligence tests. These findings highlight the significant impact that prenatal alcohol exposure can have on the developing brain, leading to lifelong cognitive impairments and functional limitations. Early identification and intervention for individuals with FAS and FAE are crucial to mitigating the long-term effects of alcohol exposure during pregnancy.

Management of premature removal of the percutaneous gastrostomy.  Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) has become the preferred method of enteral access for nutritional support. Premature removal of a percutaneous gastrostomy tube is a common problem encountered in clinical practice. This can lead to various complications such as malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration pneumonia, and delayed recovery. The management of this issue requires a systematic approach to ensure comprehensive patient care.

Firstly, adequate education and counseling should be provided to patients and caregivers regarding the importance of tube maintenance and the potential consequences of premature removal. Reinforcement of proper handling techniques and the need for regular follow-up should be emphasized.

In cases where the tube is inadvertently removed, immediate assessment must be done to determine the patient's tolerance for oral intake and the need for a temporary alternative feeding method, such as nasogastric or nasojejunal tube placement. The decision for tube replacement should be based on individual patient factors, including nutritional status, swallowing function, and potential for future tube dependence.

In instances where the tube removal was deliberate, a thorough evaluation of the patient's condition and goals of care should be conducted. Discussion with the patient and family about the potential risks and benefits of further gastrostomy tube placement is essential to make an informed decision.

Overall, the management of premature removal of a percutaneous gastrostomy tube requires a multidisciplinary approach involving physicians, nutritionists, and gastroenterologists to ensure optimal patient outcomes.

Elevated intracranial pressure and computed tomography of the brain in fulminant hepatocellular failure. Elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) is a serious complication of fulminant hepatocellular failure (FHF) and is associated with a poor prognosis. Computed tomography (CT) of the brain is commonly used to diagnose and evaluate the severity of elevated ICP in these patients. 

In this study, we retrospectively analyzed the CT scans of 50 patients with FHF and elevated ICP. The most common CT findings included diffuse cerebral edema, midline shift, and obliteration of the basal cisterns. These findings were consistent with increased intracranial pressure and correlated with the severity of hepatic encephalopathy.

Additionally, we found that patients with a greater degree of brain edema on CT had higher rates of intracranial hypertension and poorer outcomes, including increased mortality. CT scans also provided valuable information regarding the presence of other intracranial pathologies, such as hemorrhage or ischemic infarction.

In conclusion, CT of the brain is a valuable tool in diagnosing and assessing the severity of elevated ICP in patients with FHF. It provides valuable information for determining optimal management strategies and predicting outcomes in these critically ill individuals.

Staging of ureteral transitional cell carcinoma by CT and MRI. The accurate staging of ureteral transitional cell carcinoma is essential for appropriate management and prognosis. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracies of computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in determining the stage of ureteral transitional cell carcinoma. A total of 78 patients diagnosed with ureteral transitional cell carcinoma were included in this retrospective study. The CT and MRI images were independently reviewed by two experienced radiologists, and the results were compared with the final pathological staging. The overall accuracy of CT and MRI in determining the stage of ureteral transitional cell carcinoma was found to be 81.8% and 86.2%, respectively. MRI was found to be superior to CT in the evaluation of tumor invasion depth and lymph node metastasis. In conclusion, both CT and MRI can provide valuable information for the staging of ureteral transitional cell carcinoma, with MRI showing higher accuracy in certain aspects.

Microalbuminuria in essential hypertension. Microalbuminuria is the presence of small amounts of albumin in the urine and has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and renal dysfunction. This study aimed to assess the prevalence and clinical significance of microalbuminuria in patients with essential hypertension. 

A total of 180 patients with essential hypertension were enrolled in the study. Among them, 54 patients (30%) had microalbuminuria, while the remaining 126 patients (70%) did not show any signs of albuminuria. The mean age of the patients was 58 years, and the majority were males (68%).

Patients with microalbuminuria had a significantly higher mean systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to those without albuminuria. Additionally, they had a higher prevalence of left ventricular hypertrophy and a lower estimated glomerular filtration rate.

Furthermore, patients with microalbuminuria had a significantly higher incidence of cardiovascular events, including myocardial infarction, stroke, and heart failure. They also had a higher risk of developing end-stage renal disease.

In conclusion, microalbuminuria is prevalent in patients with essential hypertension and is associated with higher blood pressure and an increased risk of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Early detection and intervention may be crucial in preventing further renal and cardiovascular complications in these patients.

Postoperative lumbar spinal instability occurring or progressing secondary to laminectomy. Laminectomy is a commonly performed surgical procedure for the treatment of spinal stenosis or disc herniation. However, postoperative lumbar spinal instability can occur or progress following laminectomy, leading to persistent pain and functional impairment. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and risk factors for postoperative lumbar spinal instability in patients who underwent laminectomy. A total of 100 patients were included in the study, with a mean follow-up period of 2 years. The prevalence of postoperative lumbar spinal instability was found to be 25%. Risk factors associated with the development or progression of spinal instability included older age, female gender, smoking history, and preoperative instability. These findings emphasize the importance of identifying patients at risk for postoperative spinal instability and implementing appropriate preventive measures to optimize surgical outcomes.

Shear stress induces not only platelet aggregation but also platelet-tumor cell interaction. Shear stress, a force exerted by flowing blood, has been shown to play a crucial role in various physiological processes, particularly in cardiovascular and cancer research. In the context of cancer progression, shear stress has been found to induce not only platelet aggregation but also platelet-tumor cell interaction. This phenomenon has significant implications for tumor metastasis and angiogenesis. The interaction between platelets and tumor cells can lead to the formation of platelet-tumor cell aggregates, facilitating the dissemination of cancer cells through the bloodstream and promoting their survival and growth in distant organs. Understanding the mechanisms underlying platelet-tumor cell interaction under shear stress can provide valuable insights into the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting tumor metastasis and angiogenesis. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific molecular pathways involved in this process and to explore potential therapeutic interventions to disrupt platelet-tumor cell interaction and impede cancer progression.

Induction of arthritis in rats by aqueous suspensions of mycobacteria without the use of oil. In experimental models of arthritis, induction methods often involve the use of oil-based adjuvants to enhance inflammatory responses. However, the use of oil-based adjuvants can introduce potential confounding factors and complicate the interpretation of results. In this study, we aimed to develop an arthritis induction model in rats using aqueous suspensions of mycobacteria without the use of oil. Rats were injected with an aqueous suspension of mycobacteria into the joint space, and arthritis development was evaluated based on clinical signs and histopathological analysis. Our results demonstrated successful induction of arthritis without the use of oil, providing a simplified and potentially more reliable model for studying arthritis pathogenesis and evaluating therapeutic interventions. This oil-free approach may contribute to a more accurate understanding of arthritis mechanisms and the development of targeted therapies.

Rectovulvar fistula in a child secondary to an unusual foreign body. We report a case of rectovulvar fistula in a 5-year-old girl secondary to an unusual foreign body insertion. The patient presented with symptoms of recurrent discharge and perineal irritation. Physical examination revealed a fistulous tract connecting the rectum and the vulva. Imaging studies confirmed the presence of the fistula. Surgical exploration was performed under general anesthesia, and a foreign body composed of a plastic toy was successfully retrieved from the rectum. The rectovulvar fistula was repaired using a layered closure technique. Postoperatively, the patient experienced complete resolution of symptoms and no recurrence of fistula was observed during a follow-up period of 12 months. This case highlights the importance of considering foreign body insertion as a potential cause of rectovaginal fistula in children, especially when unusual objects are involved. Prompt surgical intervention and thorough evaluation are essential for successful management of such cases.

The Dolenc technique for cavernous sinus exploration (cadaveric prosection). The cavernous sinus is a complex anatomical structure located in the middle cranial fossa, housing important neurovascular structures. The Dolenc technique is a surgical approach used to access the cavernous sinus for various pathologies. This cadaveric prosection study aimed to comprehensively outline the anatomical landmarks and surgical steps involved in the Dolenc technique. Six cadaveric heads were utilized to perform surgical dissections and identify the relevant anatomical structures involved in the approach. Key landmarks, such as the superior orbital fissure, foramen rotundum, and foramen ovale, were clearly delineated. The surgical steps involved in accessing the cavernous sinus through the Dolenc technique were meticulously described. Additionally, potential variations in the anatomy of the cavernous sinus and its surrounding structures were noted. This study provides a detailed anatomical roadmap for surgeons seeking to utilize the Dolenc technique for cavernous sinus exploration, facilitating safe and precise surgical intervention in this challenging anatomical region.

Tamm-Horsfall autoantibodies in interstitial cystitis.  Interstitial cystitis presents a diagnostic and therapeutic challenge. Tamm-Horsfall autoantibodies have been implicated in the pathogenesis of interstitial cystitis, a chronic inflammatory condition affecting the bladder wall. In this study, the presence of Tamm-Horsfall autoantibodies was investigated in patients with interstitial cystitis as compared to healthy controls. Serum samples from both groups were analyzed using immunoblotting, and the results demonstrated a significantly higher prevalence of Tamm-Horsfall autoantibodies in interstitial cystitis patients compared to controls. Furthermore, the severity of symptoms and disease duration correlated with the levels of Tamm-Horsfall autoantibodies. These findings suggest that Tamm-Horsfall autoantibodies may play a role in the development and progression of interstitial cystitis. Targeting these autoantibodies could potentially provide a novel therapeutic approach for the management of this challenging condition. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms by which Tamm-Horsfall autoantibodies contribute to the pathogenesis of interstitial cystitis and to explore their potential as biomarkers for disease diagnosis and monitoring.

Haemorheological changes in patients with retinal vein occlusion after isovolaemic haemodilution. Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is a common cause of vision loss, and its pathogenesis involves impaired retinal blood flow. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of isovolaemic haemodilution on haemorheological parameters in patients with RVO. Twenty-seven patients with RVO were included in the study and underwent isovolaemic haemodilution. Blood samples were collected before and after the procedure to assess haemorheological parameters, including whole blood viscosity, plasma viscosity, erythrocyte deformability, and aggregation. The results showed a significant reduction in both whole blood and plasma viscosity after isovolaemic haemodilution. Additionally, there was a significant improvement in erythrocyte deformability and a decrease in erythrocyte aggregation. These findings suggest that isovolaemic haemodilution positively influences haemorheological parameters in patients with RVO, potentially improving retinal blood flow and alleviating the ischemic burden on the retina. Further studies are warranted to explore the long-term benefits and clinical implications of isovolaemic haemodilution in patients with RVO.

Blood pressure response to dietary calcium intervention in humans. This study aimed to investigate the effect of dietary calcium intervention on blood pressure in humans. A total of 50 participants with mild hypertension were enrolled in a randomized controlled trial. The intervention group received a calcium-rich diet for 12 weeks, while the control group followed their usual diet. Blood pressure measurements were taken before and after the intervention period. 

Results showed that the intervention group had a significant decrease in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to the control group (p<0.05). Additionally, there was a positive correlation between the change in dietary calcium intake and the change in blood pressure (r=0.56, p<0.01). 

These findings suggest that increased dietary calcium intake may have a beneficial effect on blood pressure in individuals with mild hypertension. Further studies are needed to determine the long-term effects and mechanisms underlying this relationship.

Intraocular lens complications. Intraocular lens (IOL) implants are commonly used in cataract surgery to replace the natural lens of the eye. However, complications associated with IOLs can occur and may result in vision loss or other adverse effects. This study aims to review and analyze the various complications associated with IOL implants.

A comprehensive literature search was conducted, and relevant articles reporting on IOL complications were included. Common complications identified include posterior capsule opacification, which is the most frequent complication and can lead to visual impairment. Other complications include IOL dislocation, decentration, and iris capture, which can cause astigmatism or lens dislocation. Inflammation, glaucoma, and corneal edema were also reported as complications in some cases. Additionally, rare complications such as retinal detachment, endophthalmitis, and calcification of IOL material were identified.

Understanding the different complications associated with IOL implants is crucial for ophthalmologists to prevent and manage these adverse events effectively. Further research is needed to develop strategies to minimize these complications and improve patient outcomes in cataract surgery.

Prognosis and treatment of advanced squamous cell carcinoma secondary to epidermodysplasia verruciformis: a worldwide analysis of 11 patients. Epidermodysplasia verruciformis (EV) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a predisposition to develop cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in response to specific human papillomavirus (HPV) types. The prognosis and optimal treatment for advanced SCC in patients with EV remain poorly defined. In this worldwide analysis, we retrospectively reviewed the clinical and histopathological data of 11 patients with advanced SCC secondary to EV. The majority of patients presented with multiple and extensive lesions involving sun-exposed areas. The median age at diagnosis was 30 years. Despite various treatment modalities including surgery, radiotherapy, and systemic therapy, the overall prognosis was poor, with a median survival of only 8 months. Additionally, significant treatment-related morbidity was observed. This study highlights the challenges in managing advanced SCC in EV patients and emphasizes the need for further research and development of targeted therapies for this rare and aggressive malignancy.

Radiation-associated valvular disease.  The prevalence of radiation-associated cardiac disease is increasing due to prolonged survival following mediastinal irradiation. Radiation therapy plays a crucial role in the management of various cancers, including mediastinal malignancies. However, it is known to have detrimental effects on cardiac structures, leading to the development of radiation-associated valvular disease (RAVD). This study aims to determine the prevalence and characteristics of RAVD in patients who have undergone mediastinal irradiation.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who had received radiation therapy for mediastinal malignancies between 2000 and 2015. Clinical and echocardiographic data were collected to assess the presence and severity of RAVD. The study included 185 patients, with a median age of 58 years and a median follow-up period of 8 years.

Results revealed a high prevalence of RAVD within the study population, with 43% of patients showing evidence of valvular abnormalities. Tricuspid regurgitation was the most common finding, followed by aortic stenosis and mitral regurgitation. The severity of RAVD varied, with the majority of patients exhibiting mild to moderate valvular dysfunction.

In conclusion, this study highlights the growing burden of RAVD in patients who have undergone mediastinal irradiation. Long-term survivors are particularly vulnerable to developing valvular abnormalities, necessitating regular surveillance and appropriate management strategies to optimize their cardiovascular health.

Retro-orbicularis oculus fat (ROOF) resection in aesthetic blepharoplasty: a 6-year study in 63 patients Sixty-three nonconsecutive patients have undergone resection of the retro-orbicularis oculus fat (ROOF) in conjunction with aesthetic blepharoplasty. In this 6-year study, we evaluated the outcomes of retro-orbicularis oculus fat (ROOF) resection in conjunction with aesthetic blepharoplasty in 63 patients. The purpose of this procedure was to improve the aesthetic appearance of the upper eyelids by removing excess fat and reducing the appearance of puffiness. The results showed significant improvements in the overall aesthetics of the upper eyelids, with a reduction in the appearance of bags and a more rejuvenated and youthful look. Complications were minimal, with no reports of major complications such as infection or hematoma. Our findings suggest that ROOF resection can be an effective and safe technique for achieving satisfactory aesthetic outcomes in patients undergoing blepharoplasty.

Allopurinol and thiazide effects on new urinary stone formed after discontinued therapy in patients with urinary stones.  We treated 87 patients with calcium-containing urinary stones with either allopurinol alone (44 patients) or in combination with thiazide (43 patients) and studied new stone formation before, during, and after the discontinuation of the drug therapy. During the treatment period, the incidence of new stone formation was significantly lower in both the allopurinol alone group and the combination therapy group compared to the control group. However, after the discontinuation of drug therapy, the incidence of new stone formation increased significantly in both treatment groups. The rate of new stone formation was higher in the allopurinol alone group compared to the combination therapy group. These results suggest that both allopurinol alone and combination therapy with thiazide are effective in reducing the incidence of new stone formation in patients with calcium-containing urinary stones. However, continued therapy may be necessary to maintain the beneficial effects and prevent stone recurrence after discontinuation.

Safe performance of difficult laparoscopic cholecystectomies. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a common surgical procedure for the removal of the gallbladder. However, in some cases, the procedure can become difficult and pose risks to patient safety. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the safety of performing difficult laparoscopic cholecystectomies. 

We retrospectively analyzed the medical records of 100 patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, with 50 cases classified as difficult based on operative findings and intraoperative complications. Patient demographics, operative details, and postoperative outcomes were compared between the difficult and non-difficult groups. 

Our results showed that difficult laparoscopic cholecystectomies were associated with longer operative times and higher rates of conversion to open surgery. However, there were no significant differences in postoperative complications or length of hospital stay between the two groups. 

In conclusion, while difficult laparoscopic cholecystectomy poses challenges and may require conversion to open surgery, it can be performed safely with comparable postoperative outcomes to non-difficult cases.

Upper-airway obstruction after multilevel cervical corpectomy for myelopathy.  We reviewed the cases of seven patients who had had obstruction of the upper airway immediately after an anterior procedure on the cervical spine and had required reintubation. Upper-airway obstruction is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication following multilevel cervical corpectomy for myelopathy. We evaluated the cases of seven patients who experienced upper airway obstruction immediately after an anterior procedure on the cervical spine and required reintubation. The incidence of upper airway obstruction in this series was 4.2%. The mean number of levels treated was 2.9 (range, 2-4), and the mean duration of intubation postoperatively was 1.7 days (range, 1-3). All patients presented with symptoms of inspiratory stridor and oxygen desaturation, necessitating prompt intervention. The cause of the obstruction was identified as anterior soft tissue swelling in all cases, leading to compression of the upper airway. Management involved reintubation, airway assessment, and close monitoring. Early recognition and intervention are crucial in preventing serious complications associated with upper-airway obstruction in this patient population.

Gastroesophageal reflux and sclerotherapy strictures. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a common condition that can lead to the development of esophageal strictures. Sclerotherapy, a treatment option for esophageal varices, has also been associated with stricture formation. We present a case series of 10 patients who developed strictures following sclerotherapy for varices, with concurrent GERD. All patients presented with dysphagia and were diagnosed with stricture formation on endoscopy. Treatment consisted of proton pump inhibitors, esophageal dilation, and lifestyle modifications to manage reflux symptoms. Although medical therapy and dilation have been successful in relieving symptoms and improving dysphagia, long-term management of GERD is essential to prevent recurrent strictures. This case series highlights the importance of recognizing the association between sclerotherapy and GERD in patients with esophageal strictures.

Histologic investigation of vascular malformations of the face after transarterial embolization with ethibloc and other agents.  Twenty-one vascular malformations located in the facial area, 11 high-flow arteriovenous malformations and 10 slow-flow malformations, underwent combined treatment by embolization and later surgery. This study examines the histologic findings of vascular malformations in the face following transarterial embolization using ethibloc and other agents. A total of twenty-one vascular malformations in the facial area were included in the study, consisting of 11 high-flow arteriovenous malformations and 10 slow-flow malformations. All patients underwent a combination of embolization and subsequent surgical intervention. Histologic examination was performed on the excised tissue to evaluate the efficacy of the embolization agents in vascular occlusion and to assess the presence of any adverse effects. Preliminary analysis suggests that transarterial embolization with ethibloc and other agents effectively occludes the vascular malformations, providing a promising non-invasive treatment option for these complex lesions. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and explore potential long-term complications.

A clonal CD4-positive T-cell line established from the blood of a patient with Sezary syndrome. A clonal CD4-positive T-cell line was established from the blood of a patient diagnosed with Sezary syndrome. Sezary syndrome is a rare form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by generalized erythroderma, lymphadenopathy, and malignant cells with cerebriform nuclei in the skin. The T-cell line exhibited typical Sezary syndrome features, including aberrant T-cell receptor expression and loss of function of specific T-cell signaling pathways. This cell line provides a valuable tool for studying the pathogenesis and therapeutic approaches for Sezary syndrome.

Prophylaxis of deep venous thrombosis after acute abdominal operation. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is a common complication after abdominal surgery, which can lead to serious morbidity and mortality. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of prophylactic measures for DVT after acute abdominal operations. A total of 200 patients were randomly assigned to receive either low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or mechanical prophylaxis with intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC). The incidence of DVT was significantly lower in the LMWH group compared to the IPC group (5% vs. 12%). However, no significant difference was observed in the incidence of pulmonary embolism between the two groups. Adverse events were rare and similar in both groups. These findings suggest that LMWH is more effective than IPC in preventing DVT after acute abdominal surgery. Further research is warranted to determine the optimal prophylactic regimen for this patient population.

Management of urinary tract infections in children.  Urinary tract infection is common in children. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in children is crucial to prevent complications and recurrent infections. UTIs are most common in infancy and early childhood, with girls being more susceptible than boys. In febrile infants, urine culture should be obtained promptly, and empiric antibiotics should be started before obtaining results. For older children, urinalysis and urine culture should be performed if symptomatic. Imaging studies, such as renal ultrasound and voiding cystourethrogram, are indicated in select cases, especially if recurrent UTIs occur or there are abnormal findings on physical examination. Antibiotic therapy should be selected based on antibiotic susceptibility results, age, and clinical presentation. Duration of therapy typically ranges from 7 to 14 days; however, longer courses may be necessary in children with clinical or imaging abnormalities. Adequate hydration, proper hygiene, and voiding habits are important in preventing UTIs. Timely recognition and management of UTIs in children are essential to minimize the risk of renal scarring and long-term complications.

Pancreaticobiliary ductal union. The anatomical variations and clinical importance of the pancreaticobiliary ductal union were investigated in 100 consecutive patients undergoing endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for various biliary and pancreatic disorders. The ductal union was classified according to its configuration and evaluated for associated abnormalities, such as stone formation or dilatation. The most common configuration was the standard union (58%), followed by the pancreas divisum with separate ducts (25%). Other configurations included the pancreas divisum with a common channel (10%) and anomalous union (7%). Stone formation was significantly more prevalent in patients with pancreas divisum (p<0.01). Pancreatic and common bile duct dilatation were also more frequently observed in anomalous union cases (p<0.05). These findings suggest that the configuration of the pancreaticobiliary ductal union may have clinical implications, such as increased risk for stone formation or ductal dilatation. The identification and characterization of these variations could aid in the management of biliary and pancreatic disorders. Further studies are warranted to investigate the long-term outcomes and therapeutic implications of different ductal union configurations.

The role of ERCP in children and adolescents. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a valuable diagnostic and therapeutic tool for pancreaticobiliary disorders in adults, but its utility in the pediatric population remains unclear. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ERCP in children and adolescents. A total of 57 patients aged 1 to 18 years who underwent ERCP were included in the study. The main indications for ERCP included choledocholithiasis, congenital biliary anomalies, and pancreatitis. The success rate of ERCP was 89.5%, with effective therapeutic interventions performed for the majority of cases. Complications were observed in 8.8% of cases, but were generally minor and resolved with conservative management. Overall, ERCP appears to be a safe and effective procedure in the pediatric population, with potential benefits for various pancreaticobiliary disorders. Further prospective studies are needed to validate these findings and establish clear guidelines for ERCP use in children and adolescents.

Mitral valve disruption following percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty. Mitral valve disruption is a rare but potential complication following percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty. Understanding the incidence, risk factors, and management strategies for this complication is crucial for interventional cardiologists and cardiac surgeons. This abstract aims to review the available literature regarding mitral valve disruption post-percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty. Several case reports and case series have documented this complication, with varying degrees of severity. Risk factors associated with mitral valve disruption include calcified valves, residual mitral regurgitation, and excessive balloon inflation. Surgical intervention is often required to repair or replace the disrupted valve, with excellent outcome reported in patients who undergo timely intervention. However, some cases may be managed conservatively with anticoagulation and close monitoring. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology, risk factors, and optimal management strategies for mitral valve disruption following percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty.

Emergency laparoscopy.  Unnecessary abdominal explorations in severely injured patients can be reduced by employing emergent or urgent laparoscopy in blunt abdominal trauma and the obscured, acute abdominal cases. With advances in laparoscopic techniques, emergency laparoscopy has emerged as a valuable tool in the management of severely injured patients. This study aims to assess the effectiveness of emergent or urgent laparoscopy in reducing unnecessary abdominal explorations in cases of blunt abdominal trauma and acute abdominal presentations with obscured diagnoses. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 150 patients who underwent emergency laparoscopy at a tertiary trauma center. The results demonstrated a significant reduction in unnecessary explorations, with only 12.7% of cases requiring conversion to laparotomy. Furthermore, emergent or urgent laparoscopy facilitated timely and accurate diagnoses, leading to prompt initiation of appropriate interventions, thereby minimizing morbidity and mortality. These findings support the incorporation of emergency laparoscopy as a valuable adjunct to traditional diagnostic methods in critically ill patients, particularly in cases where the diagnosis is uncertain or when it enables less invasive interventions.

Gallbladder perforation and bile leakage: percutaneous treatment.  Three patients with spontaneous gallbladder perforation and one with an iatrogenic bile leak causing bile peritonitis were treated successfully by means of percutaneous catheter drainage. Gallbladder perforation and bile leakage are rare but serious complications that require prompt and effective management. We report the successful percutaneous treatment of three patients with spontaneous gallbladder perforation and one patient with an iatrogenic bile leak causing bile peritonitis. All patients presented with acute abdomen, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers. A prompt diagnosis was made using imaging studies, including ultrasound and computed tomography. Percutaneous catheter drainage was performed under local anesthesia to relieve the biliary obstruction and drain the infected fluid and bile. In all cases, the percutaneous drainage was successful in controlling the infection and restoring bile flow. The patients showed significant clinical improvement with resolution of symptoms and normalization of inflammatory markers. No major complications related to the percutaneous procedure were observed. We conclude that percutaneous catheter drainage is a safe and effective treatment option for gallbladder perforation and bile leakage, providing a minimally invasive alternative to surgery in selected cases.

Reconstruction of mandibular defects in irradiated patients.  In this prospective study, mandibular reconstruction using titanium plates was evaluated in 31 patients treated between July 1988 and January 1990.
