The outcomes of mandibular reconstruction using titanium plates in 31 irradiated patients were evaluated in a prospective study. These patients were treated between July 1988 and January 1990. Reconstruction of mandibular defects was performed using titanium plates as the primary method. The success of the reconstruction was assessed based on various factors including postoperative complications, functional outcomes, and patient satisfaction. The results showed that the use of titanium plates for mandibular reconstruction in irradiated patients was associated with a high success rate. The majority of patients had good functional outcomes and reported high satisfaction levels with the procedure. However, a small number of patients experienced postoperative complications that required additional interventions. Overall, the study highlights the effectiveness of titanium plates in mandibular reconstruction in irradiated patients.

Apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face associated with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. This case report describes a patient who presented with an apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face, accompanied by a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. The patient had no history of trauma or previous neurological conditions. Neurological examination revealed asymmetrical facial features with a smaller ipsilateral eye and a drooping corner of the mouth. Imaging studies showed a small haemorrhage in the retrosplenial region of the brain. The patient was managed conservatively with close monitoring and serial imaging, and over time, the facial asymmetry gradually resolved. This case highlights the importance of considering vascular lesions as a differential diagnosis for facial asymmetry, even in the absence of significant neurological symptoms or signs.

Work and power in gait of stroke patients. Stroke patients often experience difficulties with walking due to impairments in muscle strength and coordination. To understand the biomechanics of gait in stroke patients, it is important to analyze the work and power generated during walking. This study aimed to investigate the work and power patterns of stroke patients compared to healthy individuals.

A total of 20 stroke patients and 20 age-matched healthy controls participated in the study. Kinematic and kinetic data were collected during a 10-meter walk test using a motion capture system and force plates. Work and power were calculated using inverse dynamics equations.

The results showed that stroke patients had significantly reduced work and power generation during the gait cycle compared to healthy controls. Specifically, the affected lower limb exhibited lower work and power output during stance phase and push-off. In contrast, the unaffected lower limb showed compensatory increases in work and power to maintain gait performance.

Understanding the work and power patterns in stroke patients can provide valuable insights into the functional limitations and compensatory mechanisms during walking. This information can contribute to the development of targeted rehabilitation strategies to improve gait performance in stroke patients.

Aggressive granulomatous lesions in cementless total hip arthroplasty.  We describe six patients with aggressive granulomatous lesions around cementless total hip prostheses. Aggressive granulomatous lesions, although rare, can occur around cementless total hip prostheses. In this case series, we present six patients who developed these lesions following hip arthroplasty. The patients exhibited symptoms such as pain, swelling, and limited range of motion of the affected joint. Imaging studies revealed osteolysis and soft tissue abnormalities around the prosthesis. Histopathological examination of tissue samples showed the presence of granulomatous inflammation characterized by giant cells, macrophages, and lymphocytes. Treatment options included surgical excision of the affected tissue and replacement of the prosthesis. In some cases, antibiotic therapy was administered to manage possible infection. Despite aggressive management, two patients experienced persistent symptoms and required revision surgery. The underlying etiology of these lesions remains unknown, but it is hypothesized that immune reaction to wear particles or infection may play a role. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management strategies for aggressive granulomatous lesions in cementless total hip arthroplasty.

Can the blood urea nitrogen/creatinine ratio distinguish upper from lower gastrointestinal bleeding? We wanted to know if the blood urea nitrogen to creatinine (BUN/Cr) ratio could help distinguish upper from lower gastrointestinal bleeding.  We analyzed retrospectively patients admitted to our hospital for gastrointestinal bleeding over the past 5 years. We aimed to investigate whether the blood urea nitrogen to creatinine ratio (BUN/Cr) could serve as a reliable tool to differentiate between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients admitted to our hospital with gastrointestinal bleeding over a 5-year period. The BUN/Cr ratio was calculated for each patient upon admission. A total of 250 patients were included in the study, with 150 classified as having upper gastrointestinal bleeding and 100 classified as having lower gastrointestinal bleeding. Statistical analysis revealed a significantly higher BUN/Cr ratio in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding compared to those with lower gastrointestinal bleeding (p<0.001). Receiver operating characteristic curve analysis demonstrated that a BUN/Cr ratio cut-off value of 20 had a sensitivity of 78% and specificity of 72% for identifying upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Therefore, the BUN/Cr ratio shows promise as a potential diagnostic marker for distinguishing upper from lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis.  Six patients with evidence of secondary syphilis presented with visual loss in both eyes caused by large, placoid, yellowish lesions with faded centers at the level of the pigment epithelium in the macula and juxtapapillary areas. Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis is a rare ophthalmic manifestation seen in patients with secondary syphilis. This case series reports on six patients who presented with visual loss in both eyes. The patients exhibited large, placoid, yellowish lesions with faded centers located at the level of the pigment epithelium in the macula and juxtapapillary areas. These characteristic lesions were consistent with acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis. All patients had evidence of secondary syphilis, confirming the association between this ocular manifestation and syphilis infection. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent permanent visual impairment. Ophthalmologists should consider syphilis as a potential etiology in patients presenting with similar clinical findings.

Circadian variations in myocardial ischemia. Myocardial ischemia, a condition characterized by a reduced blood supply to the heart muscle, exhibits circadian variations in its occurrence. It has been observed that the frequency and severity of myocardial ischemia episodes tend to be higher during specific time periods of the day. This phenomenon is thought to be influenced by various factors, including the intrinsic circadian rhythm of cardiovascular physiology, as well as external factors such as physical and mental stress, diurnal variations in sympathetic activity, and changes in blood pressure. Several studies have investigated the relationship between circadian variations and myocardial ischemia, utilizing non-invasive techniques such as electrocardiography and ambulatory monitoring. Understanding the temporal patterns of myocardial ischemia is crucial for optimizing diagnostic and therapeutic strategies, as well as for providing personalized patient care. Future research should focus on elucidating the underlying mechanisms behind circadian variations in myocardial ischemia and developing interventions targeting specific time periods to improve outcomes and reduce the risk of cardiac events.

The immunoperoxidase localization of tumour markers in ovarian cancer: the value of CEA, EMA, cytokeratin and DD9. The accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of ovarian cancer rely on the identification of reliable tumour markers. This study aimed to determine the value of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), cytokeratin, and DD9 in localizing tumour markers in ovarian cancer using immunoperoxidase techniques. Sections from paraffin-embedded tissues of ovarian cancer patients were stained with monoclonal antibodies against these markers. The results showed that CEA, EMA, cytokeratin, and DD9 were positive in different cell populations within the tumour tissue, indicating their potential as diagnostic markers for ovarian cancer. Additionally, the staining patterns varied among the markers, suggesting their differential expression and potential utility in subclassifying ovarian cancer. Importantly, the DD9 marker showed the highest sensitivity and specificity compared to the other markers. These findings support the use of immunoperoxidase techniques for the localization and detection of tumour markers in ovarian cancer, with DD9 showing promise as a reliable indicator for accurate diagnosis and effective management of this disease.

Fibromyalgia in human immunodeficiency virus infection. Fibromyalgia is a chronic pain disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and cognitive impairment. It has been suggested that fibromyalgia may be associated with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, although the exact relationship is poorly understood. We present the case of a 52-year-old man with long-standing HIV infection who developed symptoms consistent with fibromyalgia. The patient reported widespread pain, fatigue, and sleep disturbances, which significantly impacted his quality of life. Laboratory investigations showed no evidence of active HIV replication or opportunistic infections. Despite conventional treatments, including analgesics and antiretroviral therapy optimization, the patient's symptoms persisted. This case highlights the need for further research into the potential association between fibromyalgia and HIV infection, as well as the management challenges faced in this patient population. Understanding the underlying mechanisms and developing targeted interventions are crucial for improving the quality of life for individuals with fibromyalgia and HIV infection.

Radical vulvectomy with partial rectal resection and temporary colostomy as primary therapy for selected patients with vulvar carcinoma. Vulvar carcinoma is a rare malignancy that often requires radical surgical intervention for effective treatment. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of primary therapy utilizing radical vulvectomy with partial rectal resection and temporary colostomy in selected patients with vulvar carcinoma. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent this treatment approach. The primary outcome measures included overall survival, disease-free survival, and post-operative complications. 

The results demonstrated favorable overall survival rates, with a median follow-up of 5 years. Disease-free survival rates were also encouraging, indicating successful eradication of the tumor in the majority of cases. However, post-operative complications were noted, most commonly including wound dehiscence and infections. Overall, these findings indicate that radical vulvectomy with partial rectal resection and temporary colostomy is a feasible and effective treatment option for selected patients with vulvar carcinoma. Further research is needed to better understand the long-term outcomes and potential complications associated with this approach.

Cytogenetic damage induced by folate deficiency in mice is enhanced by caffeine. Folate deficiency is known to lead to cytogenetic damage, which can have detrimental effects on health. In this study, we investigated the potential enhancement of folate deficiency-induced cytogenetic damage by caffeine in mice. Our findings suggest that caffeine amplifies the genotoxic effects of folate deficiency, leading to increased DNA damage and chromosomal abnormalities. This enhancement may be attributed to caffeine's ability to affect the folate cycle and interfere with DNA methylation processes. Understanding the mechanisms underlying this interaction is crucial for assessing the risks associated with caffeine consumption in individuals with folate deficiency, as well as for developing strategies to mitigate the harmful effects of cytogenetic damage.

Pericardial metastasis from testicular seminoma: appearance and disappearance by echocardiography. Pericardial metastasis from testicular seminoma is a rare occurrence, typically presenting as a late-stage manifestation of the disease. Echocardiography has been shown to be a valuable tool in the detection and monitoring of pericardial metastases. We present a case of a 32-year-old male with a testicular seminoma who developed pericardial metastasis. Echocardiography revealed a highly vascularized mass in the pericardium, along with pericardial effusion. The patient underwent chemotherapy, and repeat echocardiography showed a significant reduction in the size of the pericardial mass and resolution of the effusion. Serial echocardiography played a crucial role in monitoring the response to treatment in this patient. Echocardiography should be considered in the evaluation of patients with testicular seminoma for the early detection and management of pericardial metastasis.

Heart weights of white men 20 to 39 years of age.  An analysis of 218 autopsy cases. This study aimed to investigate the heart weights of white men aged 20 to 39 years through analysis of 218 autopsy cases. The results showed a mean heart weight of 336.4 grams, with a standard deviation (SD) of 37.6 grams. The range of heart weights observed in this population was 240 to 440 grams. When further stratified by age groups, it was found that heart weights increased slightly with age, albeit not significantly. Additionally, no significant difference in heart weights was observed between individuals with different body mass index (BMI) ranges. These findings contribute to our understanding of normal variations in heart weights among white men in this age group and provide important reference values for future studies on cardiac pathology and diseases.

Hypertension in African-Americans. Hypertension is a major health concern among African-Americans, with a higher prevalence compared to other racial and ethnic groups. This literature review aimed to explore the factors contributing to this disparity. Socioeconomic factors, genetic predisposition, lifestyle behaviors, and psychosocial stress were identified as potential contributors to the higher rates of hypertension in this population. Additionally, structural racism and healthcare disparities were noted to play a significant role. Interventions focusing on improving access to healthcare, promoting healthy lifestyle modifications, and addressing social determinants of health are essential in reducing the burden of hypertension in African-Americans. Further research is needed to better understand the complex interactions between these factors and develop targeted interventions to address this important public health issue.

The importance of calcium regulation in toxic cell injury. Calcium plays a crucial role in cell function and its dysregulation can result in various pathological conditions. This review aims to explore the importance of calcium regulation in toxic cell injury. Accumulating evidence suggests that excessive or abnormal calcium influx into cells can lead to cell damage and death. This is particularly evident in toxic insults where calcium overload disrupts cellular homeostasis, triggers oxidative stress, and activates various pro-apoptotic pathways. Additionally, dysregulated calcium signaling has been implicated in the development of chronic diseases such as neurodegenerative disorders, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer. Understanding the mechanisms underlying calcium dysregulation in toxic cell injury may provide novel therapeutic targets for the prevention and treatment of these conditions. Further research is warranted to unravel the intricate interplay between calcium signaling and toxic cell injury to develop effective therapeutic strategies.

Neurologic and psychiatric manifestations of HIV disease. Neurological and psychiatric manifestations are common in individuals with HIV disease. This review aims to summarize the diverse range of these manifestations and their implications for patient care. Neurological complications of HIV include cognitive impairment, motor dysfunction, peripheral neuropathy, and opportunistic infections. Psychiatric manifestations may include depression, anxiety, psychosis, and substance use disorders. The etiology of these manifestations is multifactorial, involving both direct effects of HIV on the central nervous system and indirect effects related to immunosuppression and inflammation. Early diagnosis and management of these complications are crucial, as they significantly impact patients' quality of life and treatment outcomes. Treatment options range from antiretroviral therapy to targeted interventions for specific symptoms, such as psychotherapy and psychopharmacological agents. A multidisciplinary approach involving neurologists, psychiatrists, and HIV specialists is often necessary for optimal management. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms underlying these manifestations and to develop more targeted interventions for affected individuals.

Carcinoid tumors.  The authors carried out a retrospective study of 32 patients (23 M, 9 F) with carcinoid tumors who were diagnosed and treated at Harlem Hospital Center, New York, from 1967 to 1988. The aim of this study was to analyze the clinical characteristics and outcomes of patients with carcinoid tumors treated at Harlem Hospital Center over a 21-year period. A total of 32 patients (23 males, 9 females) were included in the retrospective analysis. The age range was 27 to 77 years, with a median age of 54 years. The most common site of primary tumor was the gastrointestinal tract (21 cases), followed by the lung (7 cases), and other sites (4 cases). Twenty-eight patients presented with symptoms related to the tumor, including abdominal pain, diarrhea, flushing, and carcinoid syndrome. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, with 26 patients undergoing curative or palliative surgery. The median survival time was 63 months, with a 5-year survival rate of 67%. Our findings suggest that carcinoid tumors have diverse clinical manifestations and treatment approaches, and long-term survival can be achieved with proper management.

Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma of the brain after Hodgkin's disease. We present a case of a 45-year-old male who developed non-Hodgkin's lymphoma of the brain following treatment for Hodgkin's disease. The patient had been previously diagnosed with stage IV Hodgkin's disease at the age of 35 and underwent chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He achieved complete remission and remained disease-free for 10 years. However, he presented with recent onset of neurological symptoms including headaches, seizures, and cognitive decline. MRI revealed multifocal lesions within the brain, and a biopsy confirmed the presence of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This case highlights the rare occurrence of secondary neoplasms in survivors of Hodgkin's disease. Clinicians should be aware of the potential for late complications, such as secondary malignancies, in long-term survivors and consider appropriate surveillance and monitoring strategies.

Endoscopic management of early supraglottic cancer. The current standard treatment for early supraglottic cancer is transoral laser microsurgery (TLM) or external beam radiation therapy (EBRT). However, there is increasing interest in endoscopic management as a less invasive alternative. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of endoscopic management for early supraglottic cancer. A retrospective analysis was performed on patients treated with endoscopic resection between 2010 and 2020. The primary outcome measures were overall survival, disease-specific survival, and recurrence rates. Secondary outcomes included functional outcomes and complications. Among the 50 patients included in the study, the median follow-up was 36 months. The overall survival and disease-specific survival rates were 92% and 98%, respectively. The recurrence rate was 10%. Functional outcomes were excellent, with preserved voice quality in 92% of patients. Complications were minimal, including two cases of local hematoma and one case of temporary dysphonia. Endoscopic management of early supraglottic cancer offers excellent oncologic outcomes, preserved voice quality, and minimal complications. Further prospective studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm these findings and compare them with conventional treatment modalities.

Comparative efficacy of short-term versus long-term cefoxitin prophylaxis against postoperative infection after radical hysterectomy: a prospective study.  We report the results of a randomized, double-blind comparison of short-term versus long-term cefoxitin prophylaxis against infections after radical abdominal hysterectomy with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy. In this prospective study, we aimed to compare the efficacy of short-term versus long-term cefoxitin prophylaxis in preventing postoperative infections following radical hysterectomy. A randomized, double-blind approach was employed, with patients undergoing radical abdominal hysterectomy with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy being assigned to either short-term or long-term cefoxitin prophylaxis groups. The primary outcome was the incidence of postoperative infections, including surgical site infections and urinary tract infections. Secondary outcomes included length of hospital stay and adverse drug reactions. Preliminary results indicate that short-term cefoxitin prophylaxis demonstrated comparable efficacy to long-term prophylaxis in preventing postoperative infections. These findings may have important implications in optimizing antibiotic prophylaxis strategies for radical hysterectomy procedures.

Spindle and epithelioid cell nevus (Spitz nevus). Spindle and epithelioid cell nevus (Spitz nevus) is a benign melanocytic lesion that primarily affects children and young adults. It is characterized by a diverse histological appearance, including spindle-shaped and epithelioid cells with variable cytological atypia. The precise etiology and pathogenesis of Spitz nevus are not well understood, and differentiation from malignant melanoma can be challenging. Classical features of Spitz nevus include a symmetrical and well-circumscribed lesion with a dome-shaped silhouette and a symmetrical pagetoid spread of melanocytes. However, atypical variants with asymmetrical growth patterns and increased cytological atypia have been described, making it crucial to differentiate them from melanoma. Immunohistochemical markers such as BRAF, HMB45, and p16 can aid in distinguishing between Spitz nevus and melanoma. Close follow-up is recommended due to the potential for Spitz nevus to exhibit unpredictable behavior and rare cases of malignant transformation.

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score in patients with cerebrovascular disease and in patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors. The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is a marker of neutrophil activity and has been used to assess inflammatory processes in various disease states. In this study, we aimed to compare the LAP score in patients with cerebrovascular disease (CVD) and patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors. We analyzed data from 100 patients, including 50 with CVD and 50 with brain tumors. Our results showed that the LAP score was significantly higher in patients with CVD compared to those with primary and metastatic brain tumors (p<0.001). Furthermore, within the CVD group, there was a positive correlation between the LAP score and the severity of the disease (r=0.75, p<0.001). These findings suggest that the LAP score may serve as a useful marker in differentiating between CVD and primary/metastatic brain tumors, and could potentially aid in the diagnostic and prognostic evaluation of patients with these conditions.

Enhanced expression of c-myc and H-ras oncogenes in Letterer-Siwe disease. Letterer-Siwe disease (LSD) is a rare and severe form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), characterized by systemic involvement and poor prognosis. The present study aimed to investigate the expression of c-myc and H-ras oncogenes in LSD patients and evaluate their potential role in disease progression. The expression levels of c-myc and H-ras were analyzed using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from LSD patients and healthy controls. The results revealed significantly higher expression of c-myc and H-ras in LSD patients compared to controls. Additionally, LSD patients with pulmonary involvement exhibited even higher expression levels of these oncogenes. These findings suggest that enhanced expression of c-myc and H-ras may contribute to the pathogenesis and progression of LSD, possibly serving as potential therapeutic targets. Further investigations are warranted to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms and develop targeted therapies for LSD management.

Gastric contents retained in rat stomach following mild irritant exposure contribute to adaptive cytoprotection.  Fluid retained in the gastric lumen immediately preceding the administration of a damaging product will dilute that product and decrease its injurious capacity. In this study, we investigated the role of gastric contents retained in the rat stomach following exposure to a mild irritant in contributing to adaptive cytoprotection. Rats were subjected to a mild irritant and the gastric contents were collected and analyzed. It was found that the retained fluid in the gastric lumen prior to the administration of the damaging product contributed to the dilution of the irritant, thereby reducing its injurious capacity. This adaptive cytoprotection was observed through histological analysis and measurement of gastric mucosal integrity. Additionally, the presence of retained gastric contents was associated with increased mucus production, which further contributed to the protective effect. These findings suggest that the presence and retention of gastric contents play a significant role in adaptive cytoprotection and highlight the importance of understanding the mechanisms involved in gastric mucosal defense.

Non-vesicular release of glutamate from glial cells by reversed electrogenic glutamate uptake. Glutamate, the most abundant excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, is predominantly synthesized and released by neurons. However, recent studies have suggested that glial cells, specifically astrocytes, can also release glutamate through a process called non-vesicular release. In this study, we investigated the mechanism underlying this non-vesicular release of glutamate from glial cells.

Using a combination of pharmacological and electrophysiological approaches, we found that reversed electrogenic glutamate uptake by glial cells plays a key role in this process. This phenomenon involves the uptake of glutamate by glial cells, followed by its release through the same transporters in a reversed manner. Importantly, this non-vesicular release of glutamate was observed in both primary astrocyte cultures and in vivo experiments.

Furthermore, we demonstrated that this non-vesicular release of glutamate from glial cells can modulate synaptic transmission and contribute to neurophysiological processes such as long-term potentiation.

Overall, our findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of glutamate release in the brain and highlight the importance of glial cells in modulating synaptic activity. Further studies are warranted to fully understand the physiological and pathological implications of this non-vesicular release of glutamate in various neurological disorders.

Major histocompatibility complex antigen expression in the affected tissues in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.  Monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry was used to examine spinal cord and muscle in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis for changes that would indicate ongoing or potential immune activity. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by the progressive loss of motor neurons. Although the exact etiology of ALS remains unclear, growing evidence suggests that immune system dysregulation may play a role in disease pathogenesis. This study aimed to investigate the expression of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens in affected tissues of ALS patients, indicating potential immune activity.

Immunocytochemistry using monoclonal antibodies was performed on spinal cord and muscle tissue samples obtained from ALS patients. The expression patterns of MHC antigens were assessed and compared to control samples.

Results showed a significant upregulation of MHC antigen expression in the affected tissues of ALS patients compared to controls. Notably, MHC class I and class II antigens were prominently expressed in both spinal cord and muscle samples. These findings suggest ongoing immune activity in the affected tissues of ALS patients, indicating a possible role for immune-mediated mechanisms in disease progression.

Further studies are warranted to elucidate the specific immune pathways involved in ALS pathogenesis and explore potential therapeutic targets aimed at modulating immune responses in this devastating disease.

Management of selected cystic adnexal masses in postmenopausal women by operative laparoscopy: a pilot study.  Twenty-five postmenopausal patients were predicted to have benign masses by screening criteria that included ultrasonographic findings of a cystic adnexal mass less than 10 cm with distinct borders and no evidence of irregular solid parts, thick septa, ascites, or matted bowel, and a normal serum CA 125 value (less than 35 U/ml). All patients underwent operative laparoscopy for further evaluation and management of the adnexal masses. Of the 25 patients, 23 (92%) were found to have benign masses, while 2 (8%) were diagnosed with malignancy. The laparoscopic approach allowed for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment in all cases. No intraoperative or postoperative complications were reported. The results suggest that operative laparoscopy is a safe and effective method for managing selected cystic adnexal masses in postmenopausal women. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings and establish the role of operative laparoscopy in the management of adnexal masses in this specific patient population.

Perivascular innervation of the cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats--an immunohistochemical study. The innervation of cerebral arteries plays a crucial role in regulating vascular function and blood pressure. This study aimed to investigate the perivascular innervation of cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) using immunohistochemistry. We examined the distribution of neuropeptide Y (NPY) and tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) immunoreactive nerves in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) and basilar artery (BA) of SHRs. Compared to normotensive controls, SHRs exhibited a significant increase in perivascular NPY-immunoreactive fibers in both the MCA and BA. However, TH-immunoreactive fibers showed no significant difference between SHRs and normotensive controls. These findings suggest that increased NPY innervation in cerebral arteries may contribute to the pathogenesis of hypertension in SHRs. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets related to perivascular innervation in hypertension.

Lung injury in a surfactant-deficient lung is modified by indomethacin. This study investigates the effect of indomethacin on lung injury in surfactant-deficient lungs. Sprague-Dawley rats with surfactant deficiency induced by intratracheal administration of a detergent were used as the experimental model. Animals were randomly assigned into two groups: control and indomethacin-treated. The indomethacin-treated group received intraperitoneal injections of indomethacin 1 hour prior to lung injury induction. Lung injury was evaluated by measuring arterial blood oxygenation, lung wet-to-dry weight ratio, and histopathological changes. Compared to the control group, the indomethacin-treated group exhibited significantly improved arterial oxygenation, decreased lung wet-to-dry weight ratio, and reduced lung injury on histopathological examination. Indomethacin administration in surfactant-deficient lungs was found to ameliorate lung injury, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for indomethacin in the treatment of surfactant deficiency-related lung injury. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimize the dosage and timing of indomethacin administration.

The acute lupus hemophagocytic syndrome [published erratum appears in Ann Intern Med 1991 Jun 1;114(11):993] OBJECTIVE: To characterize an unusual mode of presentation of systemic lupus erythematosus: acute and severe pancytopenia related to reactive hemophagocytosis.  DESIGN: Retrospective case series. The authors of this study aimed to characterize an unusual presentation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) known as acute lupus hemophagocytic syndrome (ALHS), which is characterized by severe pancytopenia due to reactive hemophagocytosis. A retrospective case series was conducted to identify cases of ALHS among SLE patients. Among the 209 SLE patients included in the study, 7 cases of ALHS were identified. All ALHS patients presented with a rapid onset of severe pancytopenia and exhibited reactive hemophagocytosis on bone marrow examination. They also had significant organ involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly and neurologic symptoms. Treatment with high-dose corticosteroids and/or immunosuppressive agents resulted in improvement in most cases. The authors concluded that ALHS should be considered in SLE patients presenting with acute and severe pancytopenia associated with reactive hemophagocytosis and multi-organ involvement. Early recognition and prompt treatment are essential for favorable outcomes.

Early-onset dementia and extrapyramidal disease: clinicopathological variant of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker or Alzheimer's disease? A case of progressive dementia and extrapyramidal signs beginning at age 29, with a ten year course until death, is presented. This case report describes a unique presentation of progressive dementia and extrapyramidal signs in a young patient. The patient experienced symptom onset at the age of 29 and had a ten-year course until death. The primary question raised by this case is whether this presentation represents a clinicopathological variant of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease or Alzheimer's disease. Detailed clinical and pathological examinations were conducted to elucidate the underlying etiology. Future research is needed to further investigate the pathophysiological mechanisms and clarify the diagnostic criteria for this atypical presentation of early-onset dementia with extrapyramidal signs.

Plasma histamine in patients with chronic renal failure and nephrotic syndrome. Histamine is a biogenic amine involved in various physiological processes and has been implicated in inflammatory and allergic reactions. This study aimed to investigate the plasma histamine levels in patients with chronic renal failure (CRF) and nephrotic syndrome (NS). The study included 50 patients with CRF, 50 patients with NS, and 50 healthy controls. Plasma histamine levels were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Results showed that plasma histamine levels were significantly higher in patients with CRF and NS compared to the control group. Furthermore, patients with NS had significantly higher histamine levels compared to those with CRF. There was a positive correlation between plasma histamine levels and proteinuria in patients with NS. These findings suggest that histamine may play a role in the pathogenesis of renal diseases and may serve as a marker for disease severity. Further studies are needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms underlying the association between histamine and renal dysfunction in these patient populations.

Value of ventricular electrogram recordings in the diagnosis of arrhythmias precipitating electrical device shock therapy. The present study aimed to evaluate the value of ventricular electrogram (VEGM) recordings in diagnosing arrhythmias that precipitate electrical device shock therapy. A total of 50 patients who received implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) therapy were included in this retrospective analysis. VEGM recordings at the time of device shocks were analyzed and compared to baseline rhythm. The results showed that VEGM recordings provided valuable information in determining the underlying arrhythmias leading to device shocks. Ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (VF) were the most common arrhythmias identified, accounting for 70% and 20% of recorded events, respectively. Additionally, VEGM allowed for the identification of non-sustained VT and other rare arrhythmias that could not be detected by surface electrocardiogram. In conclusion, VEGM recordings proved to be a valuable diagnostic tool in identifying the arrhythmias responsible for electrical device shock therapy, allowing for better understanding and management of these events.

A controlled trial of psychological treatment for the irritable bowel syndrome. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of psychological treatment for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). A controlled trial was conducted on a sample of 50 IBS patients who were randomly assigned to either a psychological treatment group or a control group. The psychological treatment group received eight weekly sessions of cognitive behavioral therapy, while the control group received no psychological treatment. The primary outcome measure was the severity of IBS symptoms assessed using the IBS Symptom Severity Scale. Secondary outcome measures included psychological well-being, quality of life, and healthcare utilization. Results showed that patients in the psychological treatment group had significantly reduced IBS symptom severity compared to the control group. They also reported improved psychological well-being and quality of life. Furthermore, healthcare utilization was significantly lower in the psychological treatment group. These findings suggest that psychological treatment, specifically cognitive behavioral therapy, is effective in reducing symptoms and improving overall well-being in patients with IBS.

Clot-trapper device for transjugular thrombectomy from the inferior vena cava. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a commonly performed procedure for the management of portal hypertension. However, it carries a risk of thrombotic complications, including migration of thrombi from the hepatic veins into the inferior vena cava (IVC). We present a case series of three patients who developed IVC thrombus post-TIPS placement and were successfully managed with a novel clot-trapper device.

The clot-trapper device consists of a self-expanding stent covered with a fine-mesh filter designed to capture and retain thrombi. Under fluoroscopic guidance, the device is deployed across the thrombus, allowing for subsequent removal. All three patients underwent successful transjugular thrombectomy using the clot-trapper device, resulting in complete restoration of IVC patency.

The clot-trapper device provides a safe and effective means of managing post-TIPS IVC thrombosis, avoiding the need for invasive surgical interventions. Further studies are warranted to determine the long-term outcomes and efficacy of this device in a larger patient population.

Intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration in a neonate. Pulmonary sequestration refers to the presence of non-functioning lung tissue that does not communicate with the normal bronchopulmonary tree and receives its arterial blood supply from an anomalous systemic artery. Intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration is an extremely rare variant where the sequestrated lung tissue is located within the pericardium. We present a case of a neonate with intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration, which was incidentally discovered on prenatal ultrasound and confirmed postnatally by computed tomography. The patient underwent surgical resection of the sequestrated lung tissue without any complications. The pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of pulmonary sequestration. This case highlights the importance of prenatal ultrasound and further investigations, such as computed tomography, in diagnosing and managing pulmonary sequestration in neonates. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can lead to favorable outcomes in these rare cases. Further research is needed to understand the etiology, pathogenesis, and optimal management of intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration.

Comparison of four pulse oximeters: effects of venous occlusion and cold-induced peripheral vasoconstriction. This study aimed to compare four different pulse oximeters and assess the effects of venous occlusion and cold-induced peripheral vasoconstriction on their accuracy. Venous occlusion and cold-induced peripheral vasoconstriction are commonly encountered scenarios in clinical practice that can affect pulse oximetry readings. Four pulse oximeters were tested on 50 healthy volunteers, and their readings were compared before and after inducing venous occlusion and cold stimulation. The results showed significant variations in accuracy among the four devices, with some demonstrating increased error rates in these conditions. These findings highlight the importance of understanding the limitations of pulse oximetry in certain clinical contexts and selecting a device that performs reliably in such scenarios. Further research is needed to develop more accurate and robust pulse oximeters for accurate patient monitoring in diverse clinical settings.

Early carcinoma of the gallbladder: macroscopic features and US findings. Early carcinoma of the gallbladder is a rare but aggressive malignancy with poor prognosis. This review aims to provide an overview of the macroscopic features and ultrasonography (US) findings of early gallbladder carcinoma. Macroscopically, early gallbladder carcinoma often presents as a small, localized tumor that may appear as a papillary, nodular, or polypoid lesion. It is frequently associated with chronic cholecystitis and may exhibit features such as mucosal thickening, intraluminal masses, or wall thickening. US is the imaging modality of choice for the initial evaluation of gallbladder lesions. Although US findings can be nonspecific, there are certain characteristic features that may raise suspicion for early gallbladder carcinoma, such as gallbladder wall thickening, irregular luminal contour, intraluminal masses, and the presence of gallstones. High-resolution US and color Doppler techniques may improve the detection and characterization of early gallbladder carcinoma. Understanding the macroscopic features and US findings of early gallbladder carcinoma can aid in the early detection and management of this aggressive malignancy.

Intravenous immunoglobulin treatment in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by progressive weakness and sensory dysfunction. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) is a commonly used treatment for CIDP, but the optimal dose and duration of therapy remain unclear. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of IVIg treatment in patients with CIDP. A total of 50 patients with confirmed CIDP were included in the study and received IVIg treatment. Clinical assessments, including evaluation of muscle strength and sensory function, were performed at baseline and at regular intervals after treatment initiation. The results showed that IVIg treatment led to a significant improvement in muscle strength and sensory function in the majority of patients. Adverse events related to IVIg treatment were observed in a small number of patients, but these were generally mild and transient. In conclusion, IVIg treatment is an effective and safe option for patients with CIDP, providing significant clinical improvements in muscle strength and sensory function. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal dose and duration of IVIg therapy in CIDP.

Magnetic resonance imaging in neurological disorders. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has emerged as a valuable tool in the diagnosis and evaluation of various neurological disorders. This review aims to present an overview of the applications and utility of MRI in the assessment of a wide range of neurological conditions. MRI provides detailed anatomical imaging, allowing for the identification and characterization of lesions, such as tumors, infarctions, and demyelinating plaques. Additionally, MRI can assess functional changes in the brain, such as blood flow, metabolism, and neurotransmitter activity, through techniques like functional MRI (fMRI) and magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS). Furthermore, advancements in MRI technology have enabled the visualization of white matter tracts, offering insights into neuronal connectivity and integrity. Overall, MRI plays a pivotal role in the diagnosis, management, and understanding of neurological disorders.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. We present a case of a 45-year-old male with a history of dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. The patient had previously undergone an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis for ulcerative colitis. During routine surveillance, abnormal cellular changes were detected in the pouch mucosa, including dysplasia and aneuploidy. Histopathological examination showed features consistent with high-grade dysplasia, indicating an increased risk for pouch adenocarcinoma. Fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis revealed DNA aneuploidy, further supporting the malignant potential of the pouch mucosa. Due to the increased risk of malignancy, the patient underwent a total proctocolectomy with permanent ileostomy. Pathological examination of the resected specimen confirmed the presence of high-grade dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in the pouch mucosa. This case highlights the importance of regular surveillance and early detection of dysplasia in patients with pelvic pouches, as they are at an elevated risk for developing pouch adenocarcinoma.

Successful treatment of recurrent corneal erosion with Nd:YAG anterior stromal puncture I used a new technique to create anterior corneal stromal punctures for the treatment of traumatic recurrent corneal erosions that had not responded to conventional therapy. Recurrent corneal erosion (RCE) is a common complication of corneal trauma. Conventional treatment options, such as lubricating eye drops and bandage contact lenses, often fail to achieve satisfactory outcomes. In this study, we present a novel technique utilizing neodymium:yttrium-aluminum-garnet (Nd:YAG) laser to create anterior corneal stromal punctures. This method aims to promote epithelial adhesion in patients with RCE who have not responded to conventional therapy. The technique showed promising results, with a significant reduction in the frequency and severity of episodes of corneal erosion. Additional studies are warranted to validate the efficacy and safety of this approach.

DNA analysis of multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas.  The authors used retrospective quantitative DNA analysis to study interrelationships between multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas in seven patients. Multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas (RCC) are rare and little is known about the interrelationships between the tumors. In this study, the authors aimed to investigate the genetic changes underlying these tumors through retrospective quantitative DNA analysis. 
Seven patients with multiple synchronous RCC were included in the study. Tumor samples were obtained from each patient and subjected to DNA analysis. 
The results showed that all patients had genetic heterogeneity between the multiple tumors, suggesting independent clonal origins. In some cases, different tumors from the same patient displayed distinct genetic alterations, further supporting the notion of independent clonal evolution. 
Furthermore, the authors identified specific chromosomal alterations that were recurring across multiple patients, indicating potential driver genetic events. These recurrent alterations involved chromosomes 3p, 5q, 11q, and others. Importantly, these genetic changes were found in both the primary and metastatic tumors. 
Overall, this study provides important insights into the genetic basis of multiple synchronous RCC and highlights the need for personalized treatment strategies considering the clonal heterogeneity within these tumors. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and explore potential therapeutic targets.

Macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria preceding renal IgA deposition in patients with IgA nephropathy. The development of macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria prior to the deposition of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in the renal tissue of patients with IgA nephropathy is investigated in this study. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients diagnosed with IgA nephropathy. Out of 150 patients, 26 exhibited macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria preceding the renal IgA deposition. The mean time interval between the onset of macroscopic hematuria and renal biopsy was 4.2 months. Renal biopsy revealed IgA deposition predominantly in the mesangial area. Additionally, these patients had higher levels of urinary IgA and IgA/C3 ratio compared to patients without prior manifestation of hematuria and proteinuria. The findings suggest that the presence of macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria may serve as early indicators of IgA nephropathy development, allowing for timely intervention and management. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon.

Alanine aminotransferase in clinical practice.  A review. Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is a commonly used liver enzyme in clinical practice. It is primarily found in hepatocytes and is released into the blood when liver damage occurs. ALT levels are often used to assess liver function and diagnose various liver diseases, including hepatitis and cirrhosis. This review aims to provide an overview of the clinical utility of ALT in different scenarios.

In healthy individuals, normal ALT levels are low. However, elevated ALT levels are frequently observed in liver diseases, and its measurement is essential in monitoring disease progression and response to treatment. Additionally, ALT levels can aid in determining the severity of liver damage and predicting prognosis. Furthermore, ALT can serve as a screening tool for potential liver injury caused by medications or toxins.

Despite its clinical usefulness, there are certain limitations to consider when interpreting ALT levels. Factors such as age, sex, body mass index, and alcohol consumption can influence ALT levels, emphasizing the need for individualized interpretation. Overall, ALT is a valuable biomarker in clinical practice, but its interpretation should be done in the context of a comprehensive clinical assessment.

Botulinum treatment of childhood strabismus.  Four hundred thirteen children ranging in age from 2 months to 12 years were treated for strabismus by botulinum injection of extraocular muscles. We present the results of botulinum treatment for childhood strabismus in a large cohort of 413 patients. The patients ranged in age from 2 months to 12 years. Botulinum injections were administered into the extraocular muscles involved in the strabismus. Follow-up evaluations were conducted at regular intervals to assess the effectiveness of the treatment. The overall success rate of the botulinum treatment was 87%, with 360 patients achieving alignment of the eyes. Significant improvements in ocular alignment were observed across all age groups, with the highest success rate seen in patients aged 2-6 years. Transient side effects were observed in a small subset of patients, including ptosis and diplopia, but these were resolved spontaneously. In conclusion, botulinum treatment of childhood strabismus is an effective and safe alternative to surgical intervention.

Factors associated with soft- and hard-tissue compromise of endosseous implants. The success of endosseous implants is dependent on adequate soft- and hard-tissue support. This study aims to identify factors associated with compromised soft and hard tissues around endosseous implants. A retrospective analysis of patient records was conducted, including 200 patients with endosseous implants. Clinical parameters such as patient age, gender, smoking status, presence of systemic disease, implant location, and bone quality were evaluated. The results showed that advanced age, smoking, and systemic diseases such as diabetes were significantly associated with compromised soft- and hard-tissue support. Additionally, implant location in the posterior maxilla and poor bone quality were also identified as risk factors for tissue compromise. Understanding these factors can help in the identification and management of patients at risk for complications associated with endosseous implants.

Bilateral phrenic nerve palsy associated with open-heart surgery.  The incidence of phrenic nerve palsy after open-heart surgery has been estimated at 10%, but it is usually unilateral and does not cause symptoms. Bilateral phrenic nerve palsy is a rare complication of open-heart surgery. This case report describes a patient who developed bilateral phrenic nerve palsy following open-heart surgery. The incidence of phrenic nerve palsy after open-heart surgery is estimated to be around 10%, but it is typically unilateral and asymptomatic. In this case, the patient presented with respiratory distress and decreased lung volumes postoperatively. Diaphragmatic paralysis was confirmed through imaging studies and electrophysiological testing. The patient required mechanical ventilation and underwent diaphragmatic plication to restore adequate respiratory function. Bilateral phrenic nerve palsy is a rare but potentially serious complication of open-heart surgery that can lead to significant respiratory impairment. Clinicians should be aware of this possibility and consider it in the differential diagnosis of postoperative respiratory complications.

Rupture of atheromatous plaque as a cause of thrombotic occlusion of stenotic internal carotid artery. Thrombotic occlusion of the internal carotid artery (ICA) is a major cause of ischemic stroke. This study aims to investigate the role of rupture of atheromatous plaque in the occurrence of thrombotic occlusion of stenotic ICA. A total of 50 patients with symptomatic stenotic ICA were included in the study. All patients underwent carotid endarterectomy to remove the atherosclerotic plaque and the specimens were examined histologically. Results showed that 38 out of 50 patients had rupture of atheromatous plaque observed in the histological analysis. In these patients, the ruptured plaque was found to be associated with thrombus formation and subsequent occlusion of the ICA. Additionally, the presence of intraplaque hemorrhage was significantly correlated with plaque rupture. These findings suggest that plaque rupture plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of thrombotic occlusion of stenotic ICA, highlighting the importance of identifying and treating vulnerable plaques to prevent ischemic stroke.

Untying the gordian knot: the genetics of Tourette syndrome. Tourette syndrome (TS), a childhood-onset neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by multiple motor and vocal tics, is thought to have a complex genetic etiology. Despite extensive research efforts, the exact genetic basis of TS remains elusive. This review aims to summarize the current understanding of the genetics of TS, including the identification of risk genes and the potential mechanisms underlying its pathophysiology. Various candidate genes have been implicated in TS, including those involved in dopamine regulation and synaptic function. However, the contribution of individual genes is small, suggesting a polygenic model with multiple genetic and environmental factors interacting to increase susceptibility to TS. Future studies utilizing advanced genetic technologies are needed to unravel the complex genetic architecture of TS.

Prophylaxis of deep venous thrombosis after acute abdominal operation. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a common complication following acute abdominal operations. This study aims to evaluate the prophylaxis measures taken to prevent DVT in this population. A total of 240 patients who underwent acute abdominal operations were included in this retrospective study. The majority of patients (88%) received prophylactic measures such as pharmacological agents (48%) and mechanical methods (40%). However, only 52% of patients received appropriate prophylaxis based on their risk factors. The incidence of DVT was 6.7%, with pulmonary embolism occurring in 2.9% of cases. Patients who did not receive appropriate prophylaxis had a significantly higher rate of DVT compared to those who received appropriate prophylaxis (p<0.001). These findings emphasize the importance of implementing appropriate prophylactic measures to reduce the risk of DVT following acute abdominal operations.

Cytomegalovirus colitis and wasting. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis and wasting syndrome are common complications in immunocompromised patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 72 patients with confirmed CMV colitis and wasting syndrome. Clinical data, including age, sex, underlying conditions, and laboratory findings, were collected. The majority of patients were male (60%) and had a mean age of 55 years. Patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) were the most common underlying condition (65%), followed by solid organ transplantation (23%). Laboratory findings revealed severe lymphopenia and elevated C-reactive protein levels in all patients. All patients received antiviral therapy and supportive care. The overall mortality rate was 36%, with older age, higher CMV viral load, and longer duration of symptoms identified as predictors of poor prognosis. This study highlights the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive management of CMV colitis and wasting syndrome in immunocompromised patients.

Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma of the tongue. Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a rare and aggressive malignancy associated with human T-lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) infection. We present a case of ATLL involving the tongue in a 54-year-old male with a history of HTLV-1 infection. The patient initially presented with a painful ulcerative lesion on the ventral surface of his tongue. Histopathological examination revealed infiltrating atypical lymphoid cells with characteristic nuclear indentations and irregular nuclear chromatin. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positivity for CD3, CD4, and CD25, supporting the diagnosis of ATLL. Further investigations revealed systemic involvement, including lymphadenopathy and skin lesions. Treatment was initiated with a combination of chemotherapy and antiretroviral therapy directed against HTLV-1. However, the prognosis remains poor, with a median survival of less than one year. This case serves as a reminder of the potential involvement of the tongue in ATLL and highlights the importance of considering ATLL in the differential diagnosis of tongue lesions in HTLV-1-infected individuals.

Long-term outcome of massive small bowel resection.  The long-term outcome for seven patients 4-17 yr (mean 7. ) after massive small bowel resection was evaluated. The mean duration of follow-up was 5.6 years. Four patients had short bowel syndrome, and three had intestinal failure due to various etiologies. The patients were managed with parenteral nutrition, enteral feeding, and pharmacologic interventions. The long-term outcomes were assessed in terms of nutritional status, complications, and quality of life. Malnutrition was a common issue, with all patients experiencing some degree of malnutrition during the follow-up period. Complications such as infections, intestinal obstruction, and liver dysfunction were observed in some patients. However, overall quality of life was reasonably good, with most patients able to lead active and fulfilling lives with appropriate management strategies. This study highlights the challenges and achievements in managing patients with massive small bowel resection in the long term.

Long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. Incest, rape, and molestation are traumatic experiences that can have long-term medical consequences for the victims. These include physical injuries from the assault, such as lacerations, fractures, and sexually transmitted infections. However, the psychological and emotional consequences are often more significant and can lead to mental health disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, anxiety, and substance abuse. Victims may also develop trust issues, difficulty forming intimate relationships, and have sexual dysfunction. It is important for healthcare providers to recognize and address these long-term consequences, providing appropriate support, counseling, and referral to specialized services when necessary. Additionally, efforts should be made to prevent these forms of abuse and promote education and awareness to create a safer environment for individuals at risk.

Estimation of PR and ER by immunocytochemistry in breast cancer.  Comparison with radioligand binding methods. Immunocytochemistry (ICC) is a widely used method for the estimation of progesterone receptor (PR) and estrogen receptor (ER) status in breast cancer. This study aimed to compare the accuracy and reliability of ICC with radioligand binding methods for PR and ER estimation. A total of 120 breast cancer cases were included in the study. PR and ER status were determined by both ICC and radioligand binding methods, and the results were compared. The overall concordance rate between the two methods was found to be 88% for PR and 90% for ER. The sensitivity and specificity of ICC for PR estimation were 85% and 92%, respectively, while for ER estimation, they were 89% and 91%, respectively. These findings suggest that ICC is a reliable and accurate alternative to radioligand binding methods for PR and ER estimation in breast cancer.

LDH isoenzymes in cerebrospinal fluid in various brain tumours.  This study examined the isoenzymatic pattern of LDH in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as well as the ratio between the five fractions of LDH among patients with various brain tumours, carcinomatous meningitis and control groups. The purpose of this study was to analyze the isoenzymatic pattern of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and the ratio between the five fractions of LDH in patients with different brain tumors, carcinomatous meningitis, and control groups. CSF samples were obtained from 67 patients with brain tumors and 17 patients with carcinomatous meningitis, as well as from 20 control subjects without any neurological abnormalities. The LDH isoenzyme profiles were determined using electrophoresis techniques. The results showed significant differences in the LDH isoenzyme pattern between the different groups. The ratios of the five LDH fractions were also found to vary among the groups. These findings suggest that the analysis of LDH isoenzymes in CSF may provide valuable diagnostic information for differentiating various brain tumors and carcinomatous meningitis.

Analgesic use: a study of treatments used by patients for migraine prior to attending the City of London Migraine Clinic. This study aimed to investigate the current analgesic treatments used by patients for migraine prior to attending the City of London Migraine Clinic. A total of 100 patients with a diagnosis of migraine were included in the study. Information regarding the analgesic medications used, including over-the-counter medications, prescription medications, and alternative therapies, was collected through a questionnaire. The results showed that the majority of patients (70%) used over-the-counter analgesics as their primary treatment for migraines. Prescription medications were used by 25% of patients, while only a small proportion (5%) relied on alternative therapies. The findings highlight the need for improved management and access to appropriate migraine treatment options. Further research is warranted to evaluate the effectiveness of different treatment modalities and to develop better strategies for migraine management.

Biological correlates of mental activity studied with PET. Positron emission tomography (PET) has been increasingly utilized to study the biological correlates of mental activity in various psychiatric disorders. This review highlights recent advancements in the field, focusing primarily on studies investigating brain metabolism and receptor binding. PET imaging has revealed alterations in glucose metabolism and neurotransmitter receptor density in conditions such as major depressive disorder, schizophrenia, and Alzheimer's disease. Moreover, PET has been instrumental in elucidating the effects of psychotropic medications on brain function and providing insights into the mechanisms of action. However, challenges such as limited accessibility and high costs associated with PET imaging still need to be addressed. Future research should aim to further broaden our understanding of the neurobiology underlying mental disorders and inform clinical decision-making.

A model of pneumococcal pneumonia in chronically intoxicated rats. This study aimed to establish a model of pneumococcal pneumonia in chronically intoxicated rats and investigate the potential impact of alcohol intoxication on the severity of pneumococcal infection. Rats were subjected to chronic alcohol exposure for 4 weeks prior to infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae. The results showed that alcohol intoxication significantly increased the mortality rate and bacterial burden in the lungs of infected rats. Histopathological analysis revealed enhanced pulmonary inflammation and tissue damage in intoxicated rats compared to controls. Moreover, alcohol intoxication resulted in impaired neutrophil recruitment to the site of infection and reduced phagocytic activity of macrophages. These findings demonstrate that chronic alcohol intoxication exacerbates pneumococcal pneumonia and impairs immune response mechanisms, leading to increased susceptibility to infection. This model provides a valuable tool for further investigations into the pathogenesis and therapeutic interventions for pneumonia in individuals with alcohol use disorders. Understanding the underlying mechanisms and consequences of alcohol-induced immunosuppression during pneumococcal pneumonia will aid in the development of targeted interventions to improve outcomes in this high-risk population.

Combined hepatic and vena caval resection with autogenous caval graft replacement. Combined hepatic and vena caval resection, followed by autogenous caval graft replacement, is a complex surgical technique employed in cases of advanced primary or metastatic liver malignancies invading the vena cava. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and outcomes of this procedure in a cohort of patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 33 patients who underwent combined hepatic and vena caval resection with autogenous caval graft replacement between 2007 and 2019. The surgical procedure involved meticulous resection of the involved liver segments and en bloc resection of the vena cava, followed by interposition of an autogenous caval graft. The primary outcomes assessed were perioperative complications, overall survival, and disease-free survival. The results demonstrate that combined hepatic and vena caval resection with autogenous caval graft replacement is a feasible and safe procedure, with acceptable rates of perioperative complications. Moreover, it may lead to favorable long-term outcomes in select patients with liver malignancies invading the vena cava.

Effects of radiation therapy on skeletal growth in childhood. Radiation therapy is a common treatment modality for various types of childhood cancer. However, it is known to have detrimental effects on skeletal growth. This study aimed to investigate the effects of radiation therapy on long bone growth in pediatric patients with cancer.

A retrospective analysis of 50 patients who received radiation therapy during childhood was conducted. Longitudinal growth data of the affected limb were compared with the contralateral unaffected limb. The mean age at the start of radiation therapy was 8 years, and the mean follow-up period was 6 years.

Results showed that radiation therapy significantly affected skeletal growth, with a mean reduction of 30% in the affected limb compared to the contralateral limb. The growth deficit was more pronounced in patients who received higher doses of radiation and those who underwent radiation during periods of active bone growth.

In conclusion, radiation therapy in childhood cancer patients adversely affects skeletal growth, leading to a significant growth deficit in the affected limb. These findings highlight the need for close monitoring and proactive interventions to optimize long-term skeletal health in this population.

Clinical spectrum of leber's congenital amaurosis in the second to fourth decades of life. Leber's congenital amaurosis (LCA) is a rare inherited retinal disorder characterized by early-onset severe visual impairment. Typically, LCA manifests in childhood, but there have been reports of individuals presenting with LCA symptoms later in life. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical spectrum of LCA in the second to fourth decades of life. Ten patients with genetically confirmed LCA were included in the study. All patients underwent a comprehensive ophthalmic examination, including visual acuity assessment, fundus examination, electroretinography, and genetic testing. Results revealed considerable heterogeneity in the clinical presentation of LCA in this age range, with variations in visual acuity, fundus appearance, and electroretinographic responses. This study highlights the importance of considering LCA as a potential cause of visual impairment even in adulthood and underscores the need for genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis.

Quadriceps myopathy: forme fruste of Becker muscular dystrophy. Quadriceps myopathy, also known as a forme fruste of Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), is a rare presentation characterized by isolated weakness and wasting of the quadriceps muscles. We report a case of a 23-year-old male who presented with progressive difficulty in walking and bilateral quadriceps weakness without any other clinical features of BMD. Muscle biopsy revealed dystrophic changes consistent with BMD, and genetic analysis confirmed a dystrophin gene mutation associated with BMD. Quadriceps myopathy can present as the initial and predominant manifestation of BMD, often in adult males. It is important to consider this diagnosis in cases of isolated quadriceps weakness, as it can be easily overlooked. Early recognition and appropriate management, including orthopedic interventions and physical therapy, can improve functional outcomes and prevent complications associated with BMD. Further research is warranted to delineate the molecular mechanisms underlying this unique phenotype of BMD.

Response of spinal cord blood flow and motor and sensory evoked potentials to aortic ligation. The effects of aortic ligation on spinal cord blood flow and neurologic function were studied in 12 anesthetized dogs. Measurements were taken before and after aortic ligation at different time intervals. Spinal cord blood flow was measured using a laser Doppler flowmeter, while motor and sensory evoked potentials were recorded using electrodes implanted in the spinal cord and peripheral nerves. Aortic ligation resulted in a significant decrease in spinal cord blood flow and a corresponding decrease in motor and sensory evoked potentials. The extent of these changes correlated with the duration of aortic ligation. Reversal of aortic ligation led to partial recovery of spinal cord blood flow and neurologic function. These findings suggest that aortic ligation can cause significant impairment in spinal cord blood flow and neurologic function, and prompt intervention may be required to prevent irreversible damage.

Prediagnostic serum levels of carotenoids and vitamin E as related to subsequent cancer in Washington County, Maryland. This study aimed to investigate the association between prediagnostic serum levels of carotenoids and vitamin E and the subsequent risk of cancer in Washington County, Maryland. Participants included individuals aged 40-75 years who were free of cancer at baseline (n=15,678), with a median follow-up of 10 years. Serum levels of alpha-carotene, beta-carotene, beta-cryptoxanthin, lutein/zeaxanthin, lycopene, and alpha-tocopherol were measured using high-performance liquid chromatography. Cox proportional hazards models were used to estimate hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for the association between serum carotenoids/vitamin E and cancer risk, adjusting for age, sex, smoking status, body mass index, and other potential confounders. The analysis revealed that higher serum levels of alpha-carotene, beta-carotene, lycopene, and alpha-tocopherol were significantly associated with a decreased risk of overall cancer. However, no significant associations were found for beta-cryptoxanthin, lutein/zeaxanthin, or vitamin E. These findings suggest that certain carotenoids and vitamin E may play a role in the prevention of cancer development.

Recovery from vegetative state of six months' duration associated with Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). We report a case of a patient who showed remarkable recovery from a vegetative state of six months' duration following administration of Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). The patient, a 45-year-old male, suffered a traumatic brain injury resulting in a persistent vegetative state. Despite intensive medical management, the patient remained unresponsive and showed minimal signs of improvement. Subsequently, a trial of Sinemet was initiated based on the hypothesis that dopamine deficiency may contribute to the patient's clinical state. Surprisingly, within days of starting the medication, the patient demonstrated significant improvements in arousal, responsiveness, and cognitive function. This unexpected response suggests a potential therapeutic role for Sinemet in patients with prolonged vegetative states. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and to determine the efficacy and safety of Sinemet in this patient population.

Treatment of pyoderma gangrenosum with cyclosporine: results in seven patients. Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is a rare and challenging skin disorder characterized by painful ulcerations. The standard treatment options for PG often yield inconsistent results, highlighting the need for alternative therapeutic approaches. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy and safety of cyclosporine in the treatment of PG. Seven patients with refractory PG were included in the study and treated with cyclosporine for a period of six months. Significant improvements in ulcer healing and reduction in pain were observed in all patients. Additionally, there were no severe adverse effects associated with cyclosporine treatment. These findings suggest that cyclosporine may be a promising therapeutic option for the management of PG, providing relief to patients suffering from this debilitating skin condition. Further research with larger sample sizes is warranted to confirm these results and establish optimal dosing regimens.

Randomised single blind trial to compare the toxicity of subconjunctival gentamicin and cefuroxime in cataract surgery.  Comparatively little attention has been paid to the conjunctival toxicity of antibiotics administered at the time of cataract surgery. A randomized single-blind trial was conducted to compare the toxicity of subconjunctival gentamicin and cefuroxime in patients undergoing cataract surgery. The study aimed to assess the conjunctival toxicity of these antibiotics when administered during the surgical procedure. A total of 100 patients were randomly assigned to receive either gentamicin or cefuroxime subconjunctivally. The primary outcome measure was the occurrence of conjunctival toxicity, including redness, swelling, and discharge. Secondary outcomes included the development of conjunctivitis and corneal epithelial defects. Preliminary results suggest that both gentamicin and cefuroxime were well-tolerated without significant conjunctival toxicity. Further analysis is needed to fully evaluate the safety profile of these antibiotics in cataract surgery.

Neuropsychological aspects of learning disabilities in epilepsy. Learning disabilities are common in individuals with epilepsy and can significantly impact their academic and cognitive functioning. This study aimed to explore the neuropsychological aspects of learning disabilities in epilepsy. A comprehensive neuropsychological assessment was conducted on a sample of 50 individuals with epilepsy and learning difficulties. Results revealed a high prevalence of cognitive impairments, with deficits found in multiple domains including attention, memory, executive functions, and language skills. Furthermore, the severity of epilepsy and the age of onset were significantly associated with the severity of learning disabilities. These findings highlight the need for targeted interventions and support services for individuals with epilepsy and learning difficulties. Future research should focus on developing effective strategies to address these neuropsychological impairments and enhance educational outcomes for this population.

Longitudinal histopathologic assessment of rejection after bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation.
