This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of percutaneous angioplasty in correcting subclavian artery stenosis. Twenty-five patients with symptomatic subclavian artery stenosis underwent percutaneous angioplasty. Significant improvement in symptoms was observed in all patients post-procedure, with complete resolution of symptoms in 20 patients. Angiographic follow-up revealed successful dilatation of the stenotic segment in all cases. The procedure demonstrated a high technical success rate and a low complication rate. Percutaneous angioplasty is an effective and safe treatment modality for correcting subclavian artery stenosis, leading to significant improvement in patient symptoms and overall outcomes.

Angioplasty of occluded coronary arteries: use of thin shaft balloon over-the-wire system without pre-dilatation. Coronary artery disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Balloon angioplasty is a commonly used intervention for the treatment of occluded coronary arteries. However, pre-dilatation with a larger balloon is usually performed to facilitate the passage of a guidewire through the stenotic segment. In this case report, we present a successful angioplasty procedure using a thin shaft balloon over-the-wire system without pre-dilatation in a 55-year-old male with severe left anterior descending artery stenosis. This approach not only reduces the procedural time and cost but also avoids potential complications associated with pre-dilatation. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this technique in a larger patient population.

The role of infection in the morbidity and mortality of patients with head and neck cancer undergoing multimodality therapy.  Cancer of the head and neck is a common cancer worldwide. Infection is a significant contributor to the morbidity and mortality of patients with head and neck cancer undergoing multimodality therapy. This study aims to evaluate the role of infection in this patient population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 patients diagnosed with head and neck cancer and treated with surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy. Infections were classified as either local or systemic. Out of the 100 patients, 42% developed at least one infection during their treatment course. The most common site of infection was the surgical wound (35%), followed by the respiratory tract (26%) and urinary tract (19%). Systemic infections were observed in 18% of cases. Patients who developed infections had a higher rate of treatment complications, prolonged hospital stays, and increased mortality rates. In conclusion, infection significantly impacts the morbidity and mortality of patients with head and neck cancer undergoing multimodality therapy, emphasizing the importance of infection prevention and management in this patient population.

The epidemiology of cancer among Hispanic women. Hispanic women in the United States have a unique epidemiological profile of cancer compared to other racial and ethnic groups. This review aimed to provide a comprehensive overview of the epidemiology of cancer among Hispanic women using available data from population-based studies. The incidence and mortality rates of various cancer types were examined, along with risk factors and disparities in screening and treatment. 

Findings revealed that breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer among Hispanic women, followed by colorectal cancer, cervical cancer, and lung cancer. Incidence rates for breast and cervical cancer were found to be higher in Hispanic women compared to non-Hispanic white women, while colorectal and lung cancer rates were lower. 

Multiple factors contribute to the higher incidence rates of certain cancers among Hispanic women, including biological, cultural, and socioeconomic factors. Disparities in cancer screening and treatment utilization were also noted, with Hispanic women being less likely to undergo routine screenings and receive timely and appropriate treatment. 

In conclusion, the epidemiology of cancer among Hispanic women warrants further research and targeted interventions to address disparities in cancer prevention, early detection, and treatment outcomes.

Senile dementia and healthy aging: a longitudinal CT study. The prevalence of senile dementia, an age-related neurodegenerative disorder, is increasing as the global population ages. This longitudinal CT study aimed to investigate the structural changes in the brains of healthy elderly individuals compared to those with senile dementia. A total of 100 participants, aged 65-80 years, were recruited and underwent cranial CT scans at baseline and after a 5-year follow-up. At baseline, 50 participants were diagnosed with senile dementia based on clinical criteria, while the remaining 50 were considered cognitively healthy controls. The results showed that individuals with senile dementia had significantly higher rates of cortical atrophy and ventricular enlargement compared to healthy controls. Furthermore, the rates of atrophy and ventricular enlargement were significantly correlated with the severity of dementia as measured by standardized cognitive tests. These findings suggest that structural changes in the brain, such as cortical atrophy and ventricular enlargement, are associated with the development and progression of senile dementia.

Hemodynamic effects of lobar pulmonary artery occlusion in a porcine sepsis model. In this study, the hemodynamic effects of lobar pulmonary artery occlusion were investigated in a porcine model of sepsis. Ten pigs were subjected to induced sepsis using intravenous infusion of Escherichia coli. Following the induction of sepsis, lobar pulmonary artery occlusion was performed in five of the pigs, while the other five served as control subjects. Hemodynamic measurements including mean arterial pressure, heart rate, cardiac output, pulmonary artery pressure, and systemic vascular resistance were recorded at baseline and at various time points after lobar occlusion. The results showed that lobar pulmonary artery occlusion in the sepsis model resulted in significant hemodynamic alterations including a decrease in mean arterial pressure, an increase in pulmonary artery pressure, and an increase in systemic vascular resistance. These findings suggest that lobar pulmonary artery occlusion exacerbates the hemodynamic instability associated with sepsis, highlighting the importance of maintaining adequate perfusion in the lungs during septic conditions. Further studies are warranted to explore potential therapeutic interventions to improve outcomes in sepsis patients.

Prolonged confusion following convulsions due to generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus.  Among patients with a prolonged confusional state after convulsive seizure, we diagnosed 8 cases as generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus. Generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus (GNSE) is a condition characterized by a prolonged confusional state following convulsive seizures. In this study, we identified and diagnosed eight cases of GNSE among patients presenting with a prolonged confusional state. The diagnosis of GNSE was made based on electroencephalogram (EEG) findings and clinical manifestations.

The patients with GNSE exhibited a variety of symptoms during the confusional state, including altered level of consciousness, memory impairment, and cognitive dysfunction. EEG recordings showed abnormal electrical activity consistent with nonconvulsive seizure activity. Treatment with antiepileptic drugs, specifically benzodiazepines and second-line agents, led to resolution of the confusional state in all patients.

These findings highlight the importance of considering GNSE as a potential cause of prolonged confusion following convulsions. Early recognition and diagnosis of GNSE are crucial in order to initiate appropriate treatment and prevent potential long-term cognitive impairments. Further studies are needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and optimize management strategies for GNSE.

Flow cytometric determination of breast tumor heterogeneity. Breast tumor heterogeneity is a well-known phenomenon that poses significant challenges in diagnosis and treatment. Flow cytometry offers a potential solution to this problem by allowing for the simultaneous analysis of multiple parameters in individual tumor cells. In this study, we aimed to determine the heterogeneity of breast tumors using flow cytometry and explore its correlation with clinical outcomes. Tumor samples from a cohort of breast cancer patients were analyzed for various cellular characteristics, including cell size, DNA content, and expression of different surface markers. Our results demonstrated significant heterogeneity in the cellular parameters examined, indicating the presence of distinct subpopulations within the breast tumors. Furthermore, we observed a correlation between certain flow cytometric parameters and clinical outcomes, suggesting the potential utility of flow cytometry in predicting prognosis and tailoring treatment strategies for breast cancer patients.

Protective role of vitamin E in biological systems. Vitamin E has been recognized for its antioxidant properties and potential protective role in various biological systems. This review aims to summarize the current evidence regarding the protective effects of vitamin E on different organs and systems. Studies have shown that vitamin E can reduce oxidative stress and inflammation, inhibit lipid peroxidation, and enhance the immune response. In the cardiovascular system, vitamin E has been associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease and improved endothelial function. In the nervous system, it may have a neuroprotective effect against neurodegenerative diseases. Additionally, vitamin E has been found to protect against liver damage, kidney dysfunction, and lung injury. However, conflicting results have been reported in certain studies, and further research is needed to elucidate the optimal dosing and potential adverse effects of vitamin E supplementation. Overall, vitamin E appears to play a beneficial role in protecting various biological systems.

Primary care patients who refuse specialized mental health services. Primary care patients who refuse specialized mental health services pose a significant challenge to healthcare providers. It is well-established that untreated mental health conditions can lead to significant impairments in overall health and functioning. This abstract discusses the reasons why some patients may refuse specialized mental health services and the implications of their decision. Common barriers to seeking mental health treatment include stigma, lack of knowledge about available resources, financial constraints, and personal beliefs about mental health. Providers must have open and non-judgmental discussions with patients, addressing their concerns and providing education about the benefits of mental health treatment. Collaborative care models that integrate mental health services within primary care settings may also help bridge the gap between patients who refuse specialized services and the care they need.

The natural history of non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy.  Seventy one patients with non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy were studied retrospectively. Non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) is a common cause of sudden visual loss, characterized by optic disc swelling and subsequent optic atrophy. However, the natural history and long-term outcomes of NAION remain unclear. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the clinical course and visual outcomes of 71 patients with NAION.

Our findings reveal that NAION is often a self-limited condition, with the majority of patients experiencing spontaneous visual improvement within the first few weeks to months. However, a significant proportion of patients can suffer from persistent visual impairment or even complete loss of vision. Factors associated with a worse prognosis include older age, presence of disc atrophy at presentation, and more severe visual loss.

While there is no proven effective treatment for NAION, patients should be managed with regular visual monitoring and supportive measures, such as visual aids and rehabilitation. Additionally, addressing modifiable risk factors, such as controlling systemic hypertension and discontinuing tobacco use, may help reduce the risk of recurrence. Further prospective studies are needed to better understand the natural history and identify potential interventions for NAION.

The opposite pupil in herniation. Herniation is a serious neurological condition characterized by the displacement of brain tissue through openings in the skull. One of the most notable signs of herniation is the presence of an opposite pupil response, also known as anisocoria. This phenomenon occurs when the pupil on the side of the herniation becomes dilated, while the opposite pupil constricts. The underlying mechanism behind this pupil asymmetry is not fully understood, but it is believed to be related to the disruption of the oculomotor nerve that controls the constriction of the pupil. Understanding the significance of the opposite pupil in herniation can help in the early detection and diagnosis of this life-threatening condition, allowing for prompt medical intervention and management.

Upper gastrointestinal bleeding in relation to previous use of analgesics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  Catalan Countries Study on Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding To assess the risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeding associated with the use of individual non-narcotic analgesics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), a multicentre study of 875 cases of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and 2682 hospital controls was done.  With control for confounding factors, the overall odds ratio estimate for aspirin taken at least once during the week before the first symptom was 7. 2 (95% confidence interval 5. The study aimed to investigate the association between upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) and the use of analgesics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). A multicentre study was conducted with 875 cases of UGIB and 2682 hospital controls. After adjusting for confounding factors, it was found that the odds ratio estimate for aspirin use within a week before the first symptom of UGIB was 7.2 (95% confidence interval 5.2-10.0). Other individual non-narcotic analgesics and NSAIDs showed varying levels of risk for UGIB, with nonaspirin NSAIDs being associated with the highest risk. These findings highlight the potential role of analgesics and NSAIDs in the occurrence of UGIB, emphasizing the need for cautious use of these medications.

Mixed connective tissue disease with arterial thrombosis, antiphospholipid antibodies and heparin induced thrombocytopenia. Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of overlapping clinical features of systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. We report a case of a 45-year-old female with MCTD who developed arterial thrombosis, antiphospholipid antibodies, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Arterial thrombosis is an uncommon manifestation of MCTD, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies and HIT further complicates the management of this patient. We discuss the diagnostic challenges and treatment considerations in this complex case. This case highlights the need for heightened awareness of potential complications in MCTD and the importance of a multidisciplinary approach for optimal patient care. Further research is warranted to better understand the pathogenesis and management of arterial thrombosis in MCTD.

Superficial esophageal carcinoma.  Surgical treatment and the results.  We report 92 patients treated with esophagectomy for superficial esophageal carcinoma (SEC; 9. 2% of all treated esophageal carcinomas). The majority of patients (85%) presented with early-stage disease (T1a or T1b). 
Surgical treatment consisted of en bloc esophagectomy with lymphadenectomy. Reconstruction was performed using a gastric conduit or colon interposition. 
Postoperative complications occurred in 37% of patients, with the most common being anastomotic leakage (13%) and pneumonia (10%). The overall 30-day mortality rate was 5%. 
The median follow-up time was 43 months. The 5-year overall survival rate was 74%, and the 5-year disease-specific survival rate was 86%. 
Among patients with T1a tumors, the 5-year overall survival rate was 90%, compared to 70% for T1b tumors. 
In conclusion, surgical treatment of SEC yields favorable survival outcomes, particularly for patients with early-stage disease. However, postoperative complications should be closely monitored and managed to improve overall patient outcomes.

The recalcitrant perineal wound after rectal extirpation.  Applications of muscle flap closure. The recalcitrant perineal wound is a common postoperative complication following rectal extirpation. Conventional wound management techniques such as wound dressings and topical therapies often fail to achieve satisfactory wound healing. In such cases, muscle flap closure has emerged as a promising solution. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of muscle flap closure in the management of recalcitrant perineal wounds. A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent rectal extirpation with subsequent muscle flap closure for perineal wound management was conducted. The results revealed that muscle flap closure led to successful wound healing in the majority of cases, with minimal recurrence rates and improved patient outcomes. Furthermore, complications associated with muscle flap closure were found to be minimal. These findings highlight the potential of muscle flap closure as a viable option for clinicians facing the challenge of recalcitrant perineal wounds following rectal extirpation. Further studies are warranted to validate these results and optimize the technique.

Prostate specific antigen for assessing response to ketoconazole and prednisone in patients with hormone refractory metastatic prostate cancer. Hormone refractory metastatic prostate cancer is a lethal disease with limited treatment options. Ketoconazole and prednisone have been shown to have antitumor activity in this setting, but there is a need for reliable markers to assess treatment response. We evaluated the use of prostate specific antigen (PSA) as a marker of response to ketoconazole and prednisone in 63 patients with hormone refractory metastatic prostate cancer. Serial PSA measurements were obtained before and during treatment. PSA response was defined as a 50% or greater decline from baseline. Of the 63 patients, 23 (37%) had a PSA response. A PSA response was associated with longer survival (median 14 vs 7 months, p<0.0001) and improved palliation of symptoms. These findings suggest that PSA can be utilized as a valuable marker for assessing response to ketoconazole and prednisone in patients with hormone refractory metastatic prostate cancer. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and explore the use of other biomarkers in this population.

Intravascular ultrasound: a new potential modality for angioplasty guidance. Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) is emerging as a promising tool for guiding angioplasty procedures. This technique provides real-time images of the arterial wall and lumen, allowing for more accurate assessment of the vessel morphology and disease extent. IVUS can aid in determining the appropriate balloon size, guiding stent placement, and evaluating the results of the intervention.

Multiple studies have demonstrated the utility of IVUS in improving procedural outcomes and reducing rates of restenosis and revascularization. IVUS allows for better visualization of plaque burden, identification of vulnerable plaques, and assessment of stent apposition and expansion. It also aids in identifying complications, such as dissections or plaque rupture, during the procedure.

Despite the potential benefits, IVUS has not yet been widely adopted due to its higher cost and procedural complexity. However, with advancements in technology and increasing evidence supporting its effectiveness, IVUS may become a standard tool in angioplasty procedures, leading to improved patient outcomes. Further research and clinical trials are needed to fully establish the role of IVUS in guiding angioplasty and its impact on long-term outcomes.

Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions of the head and neck. Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions (TFILs) in the head and neck region are rare, and their diagnosis can be challenging. This study presents a series of five cases of TFILs in the head and neck, including two cases of multifocal involvement. The patients presented with progressive swelling, pain, and/or functional impairment. Imaging features showed infiltrative soft tissue masses, often with bone erosion. Histopathological examination revealed dense fibrosis, chronic inflammation, and spindle cell proliferation. Immunohistochemical staining showed positivity for CD68, smooth muscle actin, and/or vimentin, suggesting a myofibroblastic phenotype. Treatment involved surgical excision, and no recurrences were observed during follow-up. TFILs should be considered in the differential diagnosis of head and neck masses to guide appropriate management.

Reversal of cardiac dysfunction secondary to type 1 primary hyperoxaluria after combined liver-kidney transplantation. Type 1 primary hyperoxaluria is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the overproduction and deposition of calcium oxalate crystals in multiple organs, including the heart. We present a case of a 47-year-old male with type 1 primary hyperoxaluria who developed severe cardiac dysfunction refractory to medical therapy. The patient underwent combined liver-kidney transplantation, which resulted in significant improvement in cardiac function. Serial echocardiograms showed a gradual reversal of left ventricular hypertrophy and improvement in ejection fraction. Histopathological examination of the explanted heart revealed extensive calcium oxalate crystal deposition in the myocardium, which resolved after transplantation. This case highlights the potential reversibility of cardiac dysfunction associated with type 1 primary hyperoxaluria through combined liver-kidney transplantation.

Unsuspected syphilitic hepatitis in a patient with low-grade proteinuria and abnormal liver function A 25-year-old patient was found to have cholestatic liver enzyme abnormalities during assessment for asymptomatic low-grade proteinuria at the US Naval Hospital in Portsmouth, Virginia. This case report highlights the importance of considering syphilitic hepatitis as a possible etiology in patients presenting with abnormal liver function tests. The patient's initial evaluation included serologic testing for infectious and autoimmune causes, which was negative. However, subsequent evaluation revealed positive treponemal and non-treponemal tests for syphilis. Liver biopsy demonstrated evidence of hepatitis consistent with the spirochetal infection. The patient was promptly treated with intramuscular benzathine penicillin, resulting in improvement of liver enzyme abnormalities. This case emphasizes the need for a high index of suspicion for syphilis in patients with unexplained liver function abnormalities, especially when other common causes have been excluded. Early recognition and treatment can prevent significant morbidity and mortality associated with syphilitic hepatitis.

Percutaneous balloon dilatation of benign biliary strictures. Percutaneous balloon dilatation (PBD) is a widely used minimally invasive technique for the management of benign biliary strictures. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of PBD in a cohort of patients with benign biliary strictures. A total of 50 patients with various types of benign biliary strictures, including postoperative strictures and strictures secondary to biliary stones or chronic pancreatitis, were included in the study. PBD was performed under fluoroscopic guidance using a balloon catheter. Technical success, defined as successful dilation of the stricture, was achieved in 96% of cases. Clinical success, defined as resolution of symptoms and improvement in liver function tests, was achieved in 92% of cases. Adverse events were observed in 8% of patients, including minor bleeding and pancreatitis, which were managed conservatively. In conclusion, PBD is a safe and effective treatment option for patients with benign biliary strictures, offering high rates of technical and clinical success. Further prospective studies are needed to confirm these findings.

Results of transsphenoidal extirpation of craniopharyngiomas and Rathke's cysts.  Fourteen patients undergoing transsphenoidal extirpation of craniopharyngiomas or Rathke's cysts underwent endocrinological evaluation before and after surgery. The results of transsphenoidal extirpation of craniopharyngiomas and Rathke's cysts were evaluated in 14 patients. Endocrinological evaluations were performed before and after surgery to assess hormonal changes. Preoperatively, all patients exhibited pituitary dysfunction to varying degrees. Postoperatively, there was a significant improvement in pituitary function in 11 out of the 14 patients (79%). Three patients (21%) experienced worsening or stable pituitary function after surgery. Visual field defects improved or resolved in all patients with preoperative visual disturbances. None of the patients developed cerebrospinal fluid leakage, meningitis, or other major complications related to the surgical procedure. The results highlight the effectiveness of transsphenoidal extirpation in improving pituitary function and visual outcomes in patients with craniopharyngiomas and Rathke's cysts. However, careful postoperative monitoring is necessary to detect and manage any persistent or worsening hormonal deficiencies.

Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome. Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome (PMPS) is a rare mitochondrial disorder characterized by bone marrow failure and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. We present a case report of a 4-year-old boy who presented with severe anemia, neutropenia, and failure to thrive. The diagnosis of PMPS was made based on clinical findings, bone marrow biopsy showing vacuolization of hematopoietic precursors, and molecular genetic testing confirming the presence of a mitochondrial DNA deletion. This case highlights the importance of considering PMPS in the differential diagnosis of bone marrow failure and pancreatic insufficiency in children, especially those with a history of consanguinity. Management of PMPS is supportive and includes blood transfusions, pancreatic enzyme supplementation, and nutritional support. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may be considered in selected cases. Given the potential multisystem involvement and variable clinical presentation, early recognition and intervention are crucial to optimize outcomes in patients with PMPS. Further research is needed to elucidate the pathogenesis and explore potential targeted therapies for this rare disorder.

Retinal arterial macroaneurysms: risk factors and natural history.  A case control study was conducted to identify the systemic and ocular risk factors for retinal arterial macroaneurysms.  Forty-three patients with 52 photographically confirmed macroaneurysms were located. The purpose of this case control study was to determine the risk factors and natural history of retinal arterial macroaneurysms. A total of 43 patients with 52 photographically confirmed macroaneurysms were included in the study. Baseline demographic information, medical history, and ophthalmic examination findings were collected for each participant. The results revealed several significant risk factors for the development of retinal arterial macroaneurysms, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking history. Additionally, the study found that patients with arterial macroaneurysms had a higher prevalence of systemic vascular diseases compared to controls. Furthermore, long-term follow-up examinations demonstrated that the majority of macroaneurysms remained stable or showed minimal change over time without intervention. This study provides valuable insights into the risk factors and course of retinal arterial macroaneurysms, highlighting the importance of early detection and management of associated systemic vascular conditions.

Mechanical restraint use among residents of skilled nursing facilities. Mechanical restraint use among residents of skilled nursing facilities is a significant concern due to its potential adverse effects on resident well-being. This study aimed to examine the prevalence and associated factors of mechanical restraint use in skilled nursing facilities. A total of 803 residents were included in the analysis, and it was found that 14.2% of residents had been subjected to mechanical restraints. Factors associated with higher likelihood of restraint use included advanced age, cognitive impairment, behavioral symptoms, and physical disability. These findings highlight the need for proactive strategies to reduce the use of mechanical restraints and promote person-centered care in skilled nursing facilities.

Computed tomography for evaluation of puerperal infections. Puerperal infections are a common postpartum complication that can lead to serious morbidity and mortality if not promptly diagnosed and treated. This study aimed to evaluate the role of computed tomography (CT) in the diagnosis and management of puerperal infections. A retrospective analysis was performed on 50 postpartum women who presented with clinical suspicion of puerperal infections and underwent CT scanning as part of their diagnostic workup. CT images were evaluated for signs of pelvic inflammation, abscess formation, and other complications. The results showed that CT was highly sensitive in detecting pelvic inflammatory changes, including thickened uterine walls, fluid collections, and inflammatory stranding. It was also able to identify abscesses within the pelvic cavity and provide guidance for percutaneous drainage procedures. Furthermore, CT helped identify associated complications, such as thrombophlebitis or deep vein thrombosis. Overall, CT proved to be a valuable imaging modality for the evaluation and management of puerperal infections, allowing for early diagnosis and appropriate intervention.

Central nervous system involvement in patients with facial palsy due to borrelial infection. Facial palsy can be caused by borrelial infection, with central nervous system (CNS) involvement being a potential complication. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and characteristics of CNS involvement in patients with facial palsy due to borrelial infection. Forty-eight patients with facial palsy were enrolled, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain were performed. Eighteen patients (37.5%) demonstrated CNS involvement based on abnormal CSF findings and/or MRI abnormalities. CSF analysis revealed pleocytosis in 11 patients and elevated protein levels in 7 patients. MRI abnormalities were observed in 9 patients, including meningeal enhancement, parenchymal lesions, and cranial nerve enhancement. Patients with CNS involvement tended to have more severe facial palsy symptoms and longer recovery times compared to those without CNS involvement. These findings suggest that CNS involvement should be considered in patients with facial palsy due to borrelial infection, particularly in cases with more severe symptoms or prolonged recovery.

Driving in Parkinson's disease.  Altered motor or mental skills in Parkinson's disease (PD) could adversely affect driving ability. Driving ability in Parkinson's disease (PD) is a topic of concern due to the potential adverse effects of altered motor and mental skills associated with the disease. This study aimed to evaluate driving performance in individuals with PD compared to healthy controls. A comprehensive assessment of driving skills, including on-road driving tests and cognitive assessments, was conducted on a sample of PD patients and age-matched controls. The results revealed significant impairments in various driving measures among PD patients, including reduced driving speed, increased driving errors, and longer reaction times. In addition, cognitive impairments, particularly in attention and executive functioning, were found to be significantly associated with poor driving performance in PD patients. These findings highlight the need for regular driving assessments in individuals with PD to ensure road safety and determine appropriate interventions for driving cessation when necessary.

Standard v lightweight wheelchair propulsion in spinal cord injured patients.  Twenty-six male SCI subjects (six quadriplegics, eight "high paraplegics," and 12 "low paraplegics") propelled both standard and lightweight wheelchairs at a "sprint pace" (Sp) for 400 feet, and at a "duration pace" (Du) for four continuous minutes. This study aimed to compare the performance of standard and lightweight wheelchairs in spinal cord injured (SCI) patients during sprint and duration pace tests. Twenty-six male SCI subjects, categorized as quadriplegics, high paraplegics, and low paraplegics, participated in the study. The subjects propelled both standard and lightweight wheelchairs for a distance of 400 feet at a sprint pace and continuously for four minutes at a duration pace. The results revealed significant differences in propulsion performance between the two types of wheelchairs. The lightweight wheelchair demonstrated superior sprinting abilities compared to the standard wheelchair, particularly in low paraplegics. However, no significant differences were observed in the duration pace test. These findings suggest that lightweight wheelchairs may offer advantages in terms of mobility and efficiency for SCI patients, particularly in scenarios requiring higher speeds.

Comparative yield of Salmonella typhi from blood and bone marrow cultures in patients with fever of unknown origin. The diagnosis of typhoid fever is challenging due to its nonspecific clinical presentation. Blood culture has traditionally been used as the gold standard for diagnosing this disease. However, recent studies have suggested that bone marrow culture may have a higher yield in patients with fever of unknown origin. This retrospective study aimed to compare the yield of Salmonella typhi from blood and bone marrow cultures in patients presenting with fever of unknown origin. The results showed that bone marrow culture had a significantly higher yield compared to blood culture (p<0.05). These findings suggest that bone marrow culture should be considered as a valuable diagnostic tool in cases where conventional blood culture fails to identify the etiological agent.

Systemic hypertension in sleep apnea syndrome. Sleep apnea syndrome is a common disorder characterized by recurrent partial or complete cessation of airflow during sleep, leading to intermittent hypoxia and sleep disruption. Systemic hypertension is a well-known comorbidity of sleep apnea syndrome, occurring in up to 50% of patients. This review article aims to provide an overview of the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying this association and the impact of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy on blood pressure control. The relationship between sleep apnea syndrome and systemic hypertension is bidirectional, with sleep apnea contributing to the development and worsening of hypertension, and hypertension exacerbating sleep apnea severity. CPAP therapy has been shown to effectively reduce blood pressure in hypertensive patients with sleep apnea, emphasizing the importance of diagnosing and treating this comorbidity. Further research is needed to better understand the complex interplay between sleep apnea syndrome and systemic hypertension.

Measurement of resistance versus flow in assessing efficiency of aortocoronary bypass grafts.  Measurement of flow in saphenous bypass grafts with an electromagnetic flowmeter is complicated and poorly reproducible. In the evaluation of aortocoronary bypass grafts, the measurement of resistance and flow is crucial in assessing the efficiency of these grafts. However, the measurement of flow in saphenous bypass grafts using an electromagnetic flowmeter is challenging and lacks reproducibility. This abstract aims to discuss the difficulties associated with flow measurement in saphenous bypass grafts and propose alternative methods to evaluate graft efficiency.

The complex anatomy and variable flow patterns within saphenous bypass grafts make accurate flow measurement difficult. Factors such as graft diameter, stenosis, and distal resistance impact the flow dynamics. Additionally, technical limitations of electromagnetic flowmeters, such as susceptibility to noise, inaccurate calibration, and inadequate contact with the graft, further contribute to measurement inaccuracies.

To overcome these challenges, alternative methods like invasive pressure measurement, Doppler ultrasound, and angiography are being explored to assess graft function. These techniques offer complementary information and can provide a more comprehensive evaluation of graft efficiency.

In conclusion, while flow measurement using electromagnetic flowmeters in saphenous bypass grafts is problematic and lacks reproducibility, alternative methods should be considered for accurate assessment of graft efficiency. Further research and advancements in measurement techniques are necessary to improve the evaluation of aortocoronary bypass grafts.

Changes in physician practice for the prevention of cardiovascular disease.  To determine recent changes in physicians' practices for cardiovascular disease risk reduction, a randomly selected sample of practicing primary care physicians in the upper Midwest was interviewed by telephone in 1987 and again in 1989 (response rates, greater than 90%; N = 241). The aim of this study was to assess the changes in physicians' practices for the prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD). A total of 241 primary care physicians in the upper Midwest were interviewed by telephone in 1987 and again in 1989. The response rates for both interviews were greater than 90%. The results showed that there were significant changes in physicians' practices for CVD risk reduction during this time period. The use of lipid-lowering medications increased from 42% to 74%, while the use of low-dose aspirin for primary prevention increased from 32% to 58%. Additionally, there was an increase in the number of physicians recommending lifestyle modifications such as exercise and diet changes. These findings suggest that there has been a positive shift in physicians' practices towards more aggressive prevention of CVD.

Orbital compartment syndrome.  Direct measurement of orbital tissue pressure: 1. Orbital compartment syndrome is a serious condition that occurs due to an increase in pressure within the orbit, resulting in impaired blood flow to the eye and surrounding tissues. This study aimed to assess the feasibility of directly measuring orbital tissue pressure as a diagnostic tool for orbital compartment syndrome. 

A prospective study was conducted on 32 patients presenting with signs and symptoms suggestive of orbital compartment syndrome. Orbital tissue pressure was measured using a modified needle-tip pressure sensor. 

The results showed that direct measurement of orbital tissue pressure was feasible and reliable. All patients with a confirmed diagnosis of orbital compartment syndrome had elevated orbital tissue pressure compared to normal values. The mean orbital tissue pressure was significantly higher in these patients (mean  standard deviation: 44.7  6.8 mmHg) compared to the control group (mean  standard deviation: 17.2  4.3 mmHg). 

In conclusion, direct measurement of orbital tissue pressure is a valuable diagnostic tool for orbital compartment syndrome. Early detection and intervention based on this measurement can significantly improve patient outcomes.

The neuromuscular pathology of the Eosinophilia-Myalgia syndrome.  The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a recently reorganized disorder in patients ingesting pharmacologic doses of L-tryptophan. EMS is a rare disorder that emerged in the late 1980s in patients consuming pharmaceutical doses of L-tryptophan. It is characterized by eosinophilia (increased eosinophil count) and myalgia (muscle pain). The exact cause of EMS is unknown, but it is believed to result from the consumption of contaminated L-tryptophan products. Neuromuscular pathology plays a crucial role in the manifestation of EMS symptoms. Histopathological studies have demonstrated abnormalities in the muscle biopsies of EMS patients, including inflammation, vacuolar myopathy, and interstitial changes. Additionally, peripheral neuropathy and myelopathy have been observed in some cases. The pathology appears to be multifactorial, involving immune system activation, toxic effects of contaminants, and alterations in collagen metabolism. Understanding the neuromuscular pathology of EMS is essential for developing effective treatments and preventing future outbreaks of this debilitating syndrome.

Survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest: recommendations for uniform definitions and data to report. Survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) vary widely depending on different reporting methods and definitions used. To address this issue, recommendations for uniform definitions and data to report have been proposed. These recommendations aim to standardize the reporting of OHCA survival rates, facilitating accurate comparisons and meta-analyses across studies. The key recommendations include clearly defining the population at risk, specifying the denominator used to calculate survival rates, and distinguishing between different survival outcomes such as return of spontaneous circulation and survival to hospital discharge. Additionally, it is recommended to report survival rates at specific time intervals, such as at hospital admission, 24 hours, and one month after the event. These recommendations will help improve the accuracy and comparability of survival rate data, ultimately enhancing our understanding of OHCA outcomes and guiding the development of effective strategies to improve survival rates.

Delayed death from aortic root trauma. Delayed death from aortic root trauma is a rare but potentially fatal complication. We report a case of a 45-year-old male who presented with sudden chest pain after a motor vehicle collision. Initial evaluation revealed a small mediastinal hematoma and a non-displaced fracture of the sternum. The patient was discharged with conservative management. However, two weeks later, he experienced sudden cardiac arrest and was found to have a ruptured aortic root. Despite immediate surgical intervention, the patient succumbed to multi-organ failure. This case highlights the importance of considering aortic root injury in patients with chest trauma, even in the absence of initial significant findings, and the potential for delayed presentation leading to catastrophic outcomes. Timely diagnosis and intervention are crucial for improved patient outcomes in cases of aortic root trauma.

Acute epididymitis: why patient and consort must be investigated. Acute epididymitis is a common inflammatory condition that affects the epididymis and is typically caused by a bacterial infection. While the condition is well-known and understood, there is a lack of awareness regarding the importance of investigating both the patient and their sexual partner. This abstract emphasizes the need for comprehensive evaluation of both individuals in cases of acute epididymitis.

It is crucial to recognize that partners of patients with acute epididymitis can also harbor the infectious agent, even if they are asymptomatic. Failure to screen and treat both partners can lead to persistent infection, recurrent episodes, and potential transmission to future sexual partners. This abstract highlights the importance of a thorough clinical assessment and recommends routine testing and treatment of both the index patient and their sexual partner.

Furthermore, the abstract discusses the potential consequences of untreated or recurrent infections, including chronic epididymitis, infertility, and increased risk of acquiring and transmitting sexually transmitted infections. The abstract concludes by emphasizing the need for healthcare providers to educate patients and their partners about the importance of joint investigation and treatment in cases of acute epididymitis.

Mucosal characteristics of pelvic ileal pouches. Pelvic ileal pouches are commonly used as a surgical treatment for patients with ulcerative colitis or familial adenomatous polyposis. However, the mucosal characteristics of these pouches have not been extensively studied. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the histopathological features of mucosal biopsies taken from 50 patients who underwent pelvic ileal pouch surgery. The most common finding was chronic inflammation, which was observed in 82% of the patients. Other histopathological findings included acute inflammation, architectural distortion, and cryptitis. Additionally, 24% of the patients showed evidence of dysplasia in the mucosa. These findings highlight the importance of regular surveillance and follow-up in patients with pelvic ileal pouches, as they may be at risk for developing dysplasia or other complications. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology and progression of these mucosal changes and to optimize the management of patients with pelvic ileal pouches.

Diabetic retinopathy in blacks. Diabetic retinopathy is a leading cause of blindness in individuals with diabetes. While there has been extensive research on this condition, limited studies have focused specifically on its impact on black individuals. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and severity of diabetic retinopathy in a sample of black patients with diabetes.

A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted on 300 black patients with diabetes who had undergone retinal examination. The findings revealed that 45% of the participants had diabetic retinopathy, with the majority exhibiting signs of moderate to severe stages of the disease. Notably, a significant association was found between the duration of diabetes and the severity of retinopathy.

Additionally, co-existing hypertension was observed in a high proportion of patients with diabetic retinopathy. This study emphasizes the need for targeted interventions and regular retinal screening in black individuals with diabetes to prevent the progression of diabetic retinopathy and reduce the burden of visual impairment in this population. further research is needed in order to investigate additional risk factors and potential racial disparities that may contribute to the development and progression of diabetic retinopathy.

Microdochectomy for discharge from a single lactiferous duct. We present a case of a 34-year-old female who presented with persistent nipple discharge from a single lactiferous duct. After comprehensive evaluation and imaging, a diagnosis of intraductal papilloma was made. The patient underwent a microdochectomy, which involved the excision of the affected lactiferous duct, under local anesthesia. The procedure was completed successfully with minimal morbidity. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of benign intraductal papilloma without any evidence of malignancy. The patient experienced complete resolution of nipple discharge postoperatively and remained symptom-free during the follow-up period. Microdochectomy is an effective and minimally invasive procedure for the treatment of symptomatic discharge from a single lactiferous duct. It provides a definitive diagnosis, alleviates patient discomfort, and preserves breastfeeding function.

1990 AcroMed Award in basic science.  Cauda equina anatomy. The cauda equina is a group of nerve roots that extend from the bottom of the spinal cord. Despite its clinical importance, there is a lack of detailed anatomical knowledge about this structure. This study aimed to provide a comprehensive description of the cauda equina anatomy using ultra-high-field MRI. Twelve human cadaveric specimens were scanned using a 7T MRI scanner. Detailed imaging sequences were obtained to visualize the cauda equina and its surrounding structures. The results revealed a complex and variable anatomy of the cauda equina, including variations in nerve root arrangement and branching patterns. Additionally, the study identified previously unreported anatomical features, such as the presence of accessory nerve roots and the association of arachnoid cysts with the cauda equina. This improved understanding of cauda equina anatomy can have significant clinical implications, particularly in surgical procedures involving this region. It can aid in precise localization of nerve root pathology and help prevent potential complications during surgery.

Retrospective application of prognostic indices to pancreatitis discovered at necropsy. The retrospective application of prognostic indices to pancreatitis discovered at necropsy provides valuable insights into the disease outcome and patient prognosis. We conducted a comprehensive review of medical records and necropsy reports from a cohort of patients diagnosed with pancreatitis. Prognostic indices, including the Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II (APACHE II) score and the Bedside Index for Severity in Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP), were calculated for each patient. The patients were divided into low-risk and high-risk groups based on these indices. The overall mortality rate in this cohort was found to be 30%. High-risk patients, as determined by both APACHE II and BISAP scores, had a significantly higher mortality rate compared to low-risk patients. This retrospective analysis highlights the importance of utilizing prognostic indices in predicting patient outcomes and informing clinical management decisions in pancreatitis. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and refine the prognostic models for pancreatitis.

Ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue: a comparison of 65 patients. Impotence is a common condition, with various etiologies including vascular, neurogenic, endocrine, and psychological causes. However, the ultrastructural changes in penile tissue associated with impotence remain poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate the ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue and compare these changes among 65 patients. Penile biopsies were obtained from patients with erectile dysfunction undergoing penile prosthesis implantation. The specimens were analyzed using electron microscopy techniques. The results revealed significant alterations in the ultrastructure of the impotent penile tissue, including decreased smooth muscle content, collagen deposition, and fibrosis. Additionally, degenerative changes in the endothelial cells and perivascular cells were observed. These findings provide valuable insights into the pathophysiology of impotence and may aid in the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting the underlying ultrastructural alterations.

Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis after M-VAC (methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin) chemotherapy. Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) is a common type of bladder cancer that can metastasize to various sites, including the central nervous system. M-VAC chemotherapy, which consists of methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin, is a commonly used treatment for advanced TCC. However, the occurrence of carcinomatous meningitis as a complication of M-VAC chemotherapy is extremely rare. 
In this case report, we present a patient with TCC who developed meningitis after receiving M-VAC chemotherapy. The patient initially presented with symptoms of headache, neck stiffness, and confusion. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed malignant cells consistent with TCC, confirming the diagnosis of carcinomatous meningitis. Despite aggressive treatment with intrathecal chemotherapy and supportive measures, the patient's condition rapidly deteriorated, leading to a fatal outcome. 
This case highlights the need for vigilance when administering M-VAC chemotherapy, as carcinomatous meningitis can occur as a rare but potentially life-threatening complication. Healthcare providers should be aware of this possibility and consider appropriate diagnostic and treatment measures in patients presenting with neurological symptoms after receiving M-VAC chemotherapy.

Safe use of codeine in the recovering alcoholic or addict. Codeine is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain management. However, its use in patients with a history of alcohol or drug addiction is controversial due to the potential for abuse and dependence. This study aimed to evaluate the safety of codeine in individuals in recovery from alcohol or drug addiction. A comprehensive literature review was conducted, focusing on studies that examined the use of codeine in this population. The results suggest that codeine can be used safely in individuals with a history of addiction, provided certain precautions are taken. These precautions include close monitoring, consideration of alternative analgesics when possible, and the involvement of an addiction specialist in the treatment plan. Additional research is needed to further assess the specific risks and benefits of codeine use in this population.

Surgical complications with the cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant: experience at Hannover and Melbourne. This study aimed to evaluate the occurrence and management of surgical complications associated with the cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant at two specialized centers in Hannover and Melbourne. A total of 50 patients who underwent cochlear implantation between January 2010 and December 2015 were included in the study. The surgical complications were documented and analyzed retrospectively. Out of the 50 patients, 12 (24%) experienced surgical complications, including electrode malposition (8%), electrode dislocation (6%), and cochlear fluid leakage (4%). The majority of complications (83%) were minor and managed conservatively without the need for revision surgery. Only two patients (4%) required implant revision due to severe electrode malposition or dislocation. These complications did not result in long-term adverse effects on hearing outcomes. In conclusion, the incidence of surgical complications with the cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant is relatively low, and most complications can be effectively managed conservatively.

Incidence and survival rates of children and young adults with osteogenic sarcoma.  Gender-specific and race-specific incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma over a 14-year period are presented for persons aged 0 to 24 years from eight Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) registries. This study aimed to investigate the incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma among children and young adults aged 0 to 24 years. Data were obtained from eight Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) registries over a 14-year period. Gender-specific and race-specific rates were analyzed and compared. The findings revealed that the overall incidence of osteogenic sarcoma was higher among males than females, with a higher incidence observed among White individuals compared to non-White individuals. Furthermore, survival rates varied based on gender and race, with better survival rates observed among females and White individuals. These results provide valuable insights into the epidemiology and prognosis of osteogenic sarcoma in children and young adults, highlighting the importance of early detection and targeted interventions for improved outcomes.

Racial differences in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease. This study aimed to investigate racial differences in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease (CVD). A total of 100 patients with confirmed CVD were included in the study, consisting of 50 Caucasian and 50 African American patients. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used to evaluate the anterior circulation including the carotid arteries, middle cerebral arteries, and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence and severity of stenosis or occlusion were analyzed and compared between the two racial groups.

Results showed that African American patients had a higher prevalence of anterior circulation stenosis or occlusion compared to Caucasian patients. Specifically, 70% of African American patients had significant stenosis or occlusion in at least one vessel, while only 40% of Caucasian patients had similar findings. Furthermore, the severity of stenosis or occlusion was greater in African American patients compared to Caucasian patients.

These findings suggest that racial differences exist in the anterior circulation in CVD, with African Americans showing a higher prevalence and greater severity of stenosis or occlusion. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying factors contributing to these racial disparities.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy are important risk factors for the development of neoplastic changes in the pelvic pouch after restorative proctocolectomy for ulcerative colitis. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical significance of dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in pelvic pouches. A total of 56 patients who underwent pouchoscopy and biopsies were included in the study. Dysplasia was identified in 12 (21.4%) patients, with three (5.4%) patients showing high-grade dysplasia. DNA aneuploidy was detected in 15 (26.8%) patients. Patients with dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy had a significantly higher risk of developing pouch adenomas compared to those without these risk factors. Furthermore, patients with dysplasia or DNA aneuploidy had a higher risk of disease progression and pouch failure. These findings highlight the importance of surveillance and early intervention in patients with dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in order to prevent neoplastic changes and improve long-term outcomes in pelvic pouch patients.

Survival after hypertonic saline resuscitation from hemorrhage.  There has been recent increased interest in hypertonic saline resuscitation from shock and hemorrhage. This study aimed to evaluate the survival outcomes following hypertonic saline resuscitation in patients with hemorrhage. A total of 240 patients who received hypertonic saline resuscitation were included in the analysis. Survival rates were compared between patients who received hypertonic saline early in the resuscitation process and those who received it later. Additionally, the impact of hypertonic saline on the incidence of organ failure and the need for blood transfusion was assessed. Results showed that early administration of hypertonic saline was associated with significantly higher survival rates compared to late administration (81% vs. 65%). Furthermore, patients who received hypertonic saline had a lower incidence of organ failure and a reduced need for blood transfusion. This study highlights the potential benefits of early hypertonic saline resuscitation in improving survival outcomes and mitigating complications in patients with hemorrhage. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimize the timing and dosage of hypertonic saline administration.

The cellular composition of basal cell adenoma of the parotid gland: an immunohistochemical analysis. The cellular composition of basal cell adenoma of the parotid gland was investigated using immunohistochemical analysis. Thirty-five cases of basal cell adenoma were included in this study. Immunohistochemical staining was performed to examine the expression of cytokeratin 5/6, p63, and SMA in the tumor cells. The results revealed that the majority of tumor cells showed positive staining for cytokeratin 5/6 (94%), p63 (86%), and SMA (89%). In addition, a subset of tumor cells also exhibited positive staining for S100 protein (40%). These findings suggest that basal cell adenoma of the parotid gland is composed of a heterogeneous cellular population, including myoepithelial cells and luminal epithelial cells. Furthermore, the presence of S100-positive cells indicates the potential involvement of neural components in the pathogenesis of basal cell adenoma. This immunohistochemical analysis provides valuable insights into the cellular composition and histogenesis of basal cell adenoma of the parotid gland.

Mammographic measurements before and after augmentation mammaplasty. This study aimed to evaluate the changes in mammographic measurements before and after augmentation mammaplasty. A total of 50 patients who underwent silicone gel-filled breast implant surgery were included in this retrospective analysis. Mammographic measurements, including breast thickness, nipple-to-implant distance, and implant edge distance from the chest wall, were measured preoperatively and at 6 months postoperatively. The results revealed a significant increase in breast thickness and nipple-to-implant distance after augmentation mammaplasty (p < 0.001). Additionally, the implant edge distance from the chest wall showed a statistically significant decrease (p < 0.001). These findings indicate that augmentation mammaplasty results in measurable changes in mammographic measurements. Radiologists and plastic surgeons should be aware of these changes when interpreting postoperative mammograms to avoid misinterpretation and optimize patient management. Further studies are warranted to explore the long-term effects of breast augmentation on mammographic measurements.

Postoperative hypertension: a prospective, placebo-controlled, randomized, double-blind trial, with intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride.  Nicardipine hydrochloride, a new calcium channel blocker for intravenous use, has been compared with placebo in a prospective, randomized, double-blind trial on postoperative hypertension. We conducted a prospective, placebo-controlled, randomized, double-blind trial to evaluate the efficacy of intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride in the management of postoperative hypertension. Patients with postoperative hypertension were randomized to receive either nicardipine hydrochloride or placebo. Blood pressure measurements were obtained at regular intervals during the study period. The primary outcome measure was the achievement of target blood pressure levels within a specified time frame. Secondary outcome measures included the need for additional antihypertensive medications, adverse events, and length of hospital stay. Our results showed that nicardipine hydrochloride was more effective than placebo in achieving target blood pressure levels and had a favorable safety profile.

Two-dimensional echocardiographic features of double outlet left ventricle. Double outlet left ventricle (DOLV) is a rare congenital heart defect characterized by both great arteries arising predominantly or exclusively from the left ventricle. This study aims to determine the two-dimensional echocardiographic features of DOLV and their correlation with clinical outcomes. A total of 46 patients diagnosed with DOLV were included in the study. The most common associated anomalies were ventricular septal defect (73.9%), pulmonary stenosis (67.4%), and aortic stenosis (34.7%). Echocardiographic findings showed aortic override (89.1%), subaortic ventricular septal defect (76.1%), and malalignment ventricular septal defect (67.4%). The mean follow-up duration was 55  32 months, and the overall mortality rate was 19.6%. In conclusion, two-dimensional echocardiography is a valuable tool for the diagnosis and evaluation of DOLV, which can aid in predicting clinical outcomes and guiding management strategies.

Cholecystectomy and right colon cancer in Puerto Rico. The relationship between cholecystectomy and right colon cancer in Puerto Rico is explored in this study. Retrospective data from 2000 to 2015 was analyzed and a total of 642 cases with right colon cancer were identified. Among these cases, 112 patients had a history of cholecystectomy. The prevalence of right colon cancer was found to be significantly higher in patients with a history of cholecystectomy compared to those without (17.45% vs. 7.59%). Further analysis revealed that cholecystectomy was associated with an increased risk of developing right colon cancer, with an odds ratio of 2.61 (95% confidence interval: 1.98-3.44). These findings suggest a potential link between cholecystectomy and the development of right colon cancer in Puerto Rico and may have implications for screening and surveillance strategies in this population. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and establish appropriate preventive measures.

Late cholangitis after successful surgical repair of biliary atresia.  Bacterial cholangitis is a frequent complication of successful surgical repair of biliary atresia, occurring in 93% of patients before the age of 1 year, but thought to be rare after 2 years of age. However, there have been limited studies investigating late cholangitis in older children who have undergone successful surgical repair of biliary atresia. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the occurrence of late cholangitis in 65 patients who had undergone successful surgical repair of biliary atresia and were followed up until the age of 5 years or more. We found that late cholangitis occurred in 23% of patients, with an average onset age of 3.4 years. The most common causative organisms were gram-negative bacteria, similar to early cholangitis. Patients with late cholangitis had a higher incidence of complications, including hepatolithiasis and liver abscesses. Our findings suggest that late cholangitis should be considered as a potential long-term complication in older children who have undergone successful surgical repair of biliary atresia. Improved surveillance and prophylactic measures may be necessary to reduce the incidence and complications of late cholangitis in this population.

Hyperplastic polyps seen at sigmoidoscopy are markers for additional adenomas seen at colonoscopy.  Asymptomatic individuals undergoing screening flexible sigmoidoscopy were prospectively studied. A total of 350 asymptomatic individuals who underwent screening flexible sigmoidoscopy were included in this prospective study. Hyperplastic polyps identified during sigmoidoscopy were further assessed for the presence of additional adenomas during subsequent colonoscopy. Out of the 350 participants, 75 (21.4%) had hyperplastic polyps detected during sigmoidoscopy. Among these individuals, 42 (56%) were found to have additional adenomas during colonoscopy. The majority of these additional adenomas were small in size and tubular in morphology. Age, gender, and family history of colorectal cancer did not significantly influence the occurrence of additional adenomas in individuals with hyperplastic polyps. The presence of hyperplastic polyps during sigmoidoscopy should therefore raise suspicion for additional adenomas, warranting further evaluation through colonoscopy. This information can aid in the identification and subsequent management of individuals at higher risk for colorectal neoplasms.

Interventional radiology of the biliary tract. Interventional radiology plays a significant role in the management of various biliary tract disorders. This includes the treatment of benign and malignant biliary strictures, as well as the management of biliary stones and leaks. The minimally invasive nature of interventional radiology procedures, such as percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and biliary drainage, offers numerous advantages over traditional surgical approaches. These interventions can be performed percutaneously, transcatheterly, or endoscopically under fluoroscopic guidance. The use of advanced imaging techniques, such as magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography and computed tomography, aids in accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. Overall, interventional radiology offers a safe and effective alternative for the management of biliary tract disorders, resulting in improved patient outcomes and reduced morbidity.

Does age affect outcomes of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation? We examined the relation between age and outcomes in patients treated for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in Seattle, Wash. We analyzed data from the Seattle out-of-hospital cardiac arrest database to determine the impact of age on the outcomes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). A total of 542 patients were included in the study, ranging in age from 18 to 95 years. Our results showed a significant association between age and survival to hospital discharge. Specifically, older age was associated with decreased odds of survival, with each decade increase in age resulting in a 10% decrease in the odds of survival. However, among the survivors, there was no significant difference in neurological outcomes based on age. These findings suggest that age should be considered as a prognostic factor in determining the potential benefits of out-of-hospital CPR, but age alone should not be the sole determinant in decision-making regarding resuscitation efforts.

Increased microvascular permeability in vivo in response to intradermal injection of neutrophil-activating protein (NAP-2) in rabbit skin. This study aimed to investigate the effect of neutrophil-activating protein (NAP-2) on microvascular permeability in vivo. Ten rabbits were subjected to intradermal injection of NAP-2, while another ten received saline as a control. Microvascular permeability was assessed by measuring the extravasation of Evans blue dye. The results showed a significant increase in microvascular permeability in the NAP-2 group compared to the control group (p less than 0.05). Histological analysis revealed neutrophil infiltration and edema in the NAP-2 injected sites. Furthermore, immunohistochemical staining demonstrated upregulation of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in the NAP-2 group. These findings suggest that NAP-2 induces microvascular permeability in rabbit skin, potentially through the activation of neutrophils and upregulation of VEGF. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore the clinical implications of these findings.

Beta-carotene's effects on serum lipoproteins and immunologic indices in humans. The objective of this study was to investigate the effects of beta-carotene supplementation on serum lipoproteins and immunologic indices in humans. A total of 60 healthy volunteers were randomized into two groups: the intervention group receiving 30 mg/day of beta-carotene for 12 weeks, and the control group receiving placebo. Serum lipoproteins, including total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), and triglycerides, were measured at baseline and post-intervention. Immunologic indices, including serum levels of immunoglobulin A (IgA), immunoglobulin G (IgG), and immunoglobulin M (IgM), were also assessed. 

The results showed a significant decrease in LDL-C levels (p < 0.05) and an increase in HDL-C levels (p < 0.05) in the intervention group compared to the control group after 12 weeks of beta-carotene supplementation. However, there were no significant changes in total cholesterol and triglyceride levels between the two groups. 

Regarding immunologic indices, there were no significant differences in serum levels of IgA, IgG, and IgM between the intervention and control groups after the intervention period. 

In conclusion, beta-carotene supplementation demonstrated beneficial effects on serum lipoproteins by decreasing LDL-C levels and increasing HDL-C levels in healthy individuals. However, no significant changes were observed in immunologic indices. Further studies are needed to explore the potential mechanisms underlying these effects and to determine optimal dosages for beta-carotene supplementation in different populations.

Pulmonary malakoplakia in a patient with the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. Malakoplakia is a rare chronic granulomatous disease that primarily affects the urinary tract. It has rarely been reported in extrarenal locations, with pulmonary involvement being particularly uncommon. This case report describes a patient with the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) who presented with pulmonary malakoplakia. The patient had a history of recurrent respiratory infections and was found to have multiple pulmonary nodules on computed tomography (CT) scan. Biopsy of one of the nodules revealed the characteristic histopathological findings of malakoplakia, including the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. The patient was started on antimicrobial therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, leading to substantial improvement in his respiratory symptoms and radiological findings. This case highlights the importance of considering malakoplakia in the differential diagnosis of pulmonary nodules in patients with AIDS, especially those presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. Early recognition and appropriate treatment with antimicrobial therapy are essential to improve outcomes in these patients. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of pulmonary malakoplakia.

Rigid spine syndrome with respiratory failure. Rigid spine syndrome (RSS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive rigidity of the spine and skeletal muscle weakness. Respiratory failure is a serious complication of RSS, leading to high morbidity and mortality rates. However, the underlying pathophysiology of respiratory failure in RSS remains uncertain. In this case study, we present a 32-year-old male with RSS who developed acute respiratory distress and required mechanical ventilation. Extensive investigation revealed no structural abnormalities or neurological deficits that could explain the respiratory failure. Instead, we propose that respiratory failure in RSS may be due to impaired respiratory muscle function, including weakness of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles. Further studies are needed to explore the exact mechanisms underlying respiratory failure in RSS and to develop appropriate management strategies for this potentially life-threatening complication.

Use of plasmid profiles in the investigation of a patient with Helicobacter pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease. Plasmid profiles have been widely used in the determination of bacterial strain relatedness and identification of virulence factors. In this study, we investigated the plasmid profiles of a patient with Helicobacter pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease to evaluate the potential association between plasmid content and disease severity. A total of ten H. pylori isolates were analyzed, and plasmid DNA was extracted and characterized. Our findings revealed the presence of diverse plasmid profiles among the isolates, suggesting a high level of genetic diversity within the patient's infection. Further investigation is warranted to determine the role of plasmids in the pathogenesis of H. pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease.

Microspectrophotometric DNA analysis in ulcerative colitis with special reference to its application in diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia.  The deoxyribonucleic (DNA) content was measured by microspectrophotometry in 100 specimens from 60 patients with ulcerative colitis, including six patients in whom the colitis was associated with carcinoma. Microspectrophotometric DNA analysis has shown promise in the diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia in patients with ulcerative colitis. In this study, we analyzed the DNA content in 100 specimens from 60 patients with ulcerative colitis, including six patients with concomitant carcinoma. The results revealed significant differences in DNA content between patients with carcinoma and those without. Patients with carcinoma exhibited higher DNA content, indicating increased cellular proliferation and genomic instability. Furthermore, microspectrophotometric DNA analysis was able to detect dysplastic changes in patients without carcinoma, suggesting its potential as a diagnostic tool for early detection of pre-cancerous lesions. Overall, our findings support the utility of microspectrophotometric DNA analysis in the diagnosis and monitoring of carcinoma and dysplasia in patients with ulcerative colitis. Further studies are warranted to validate its clinical applicability.

Limitation of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization using iodized oil for small hepatocellular carcinoma. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) using iodized oil is a commonly used treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). However, its efficacy for small HCCs remains uncertain. This study aimed to evaluate the limitations of TACE using iodized oil for small HCCs. A total of 80 patients with small HCCs ( 3 cm) who underwent TACE were enrolled. The treatment response and survival outcomes were assessed. The results showed that TACE with iodized oil had limited efficacy for small HCCs, with a complete response rate of only 12.5% and a median survival time of 14.6 months. Furthermore, the adverse events associated with TACE were more frequent and severe in patients with small HCCs. In conclusion, TACE using iodized oil may not be an optimal treatment option for small HCCs due to its limited efficacy and increased risk of adverse events.

Long-term results of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation in relation to the severity of esophagitis A retrospective analysis of the results of the Belsey Mark IV operation has been conducted, relating these to the degree of esophagitis present preoperatively.  Analysis of 89 patients showed a 91. A retrospective analysis was conducted to evaluate the long-term outcomes of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation in relation to the severity of preoperative esophagitis. A total of 89 patients were included in the study. The results showed that 91.0% of patients experienced improvement in their symptoms postoperatively. Patients with severe esophagitis prior to surgery had a slightly lower improvement rate (89.2%) compared to those with mild to moderate esophagitis (91.8%). However, overall, the Belsey Mark IV operation was found to be an effective treatment option for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with favorable long-term outcomes, regardless of the severity of esophagitis. Further studies are warranted to better understand the factors influencing postoperative outcomes in patients with varying degrees of esophagitis.
