Expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens and lymphocyte infiltration in human gastric nonmalignant and malignant tissues: an immunohistochemical study. In this study, the expression of HLA-DR and secretory component (SC) antigens and lymphocyte infiltration in human gastric nonmalignant and malignant tissues was investigated using immunohistochemical techniques. A total of 48 gastric tissue samples including nonmalignant gastric mucosa (n=16), gastric ulcer (n=16), and gastric adenocarcinoma (n=16) were examined. The results revealed a significant increase in the expression of HLA-DR and SC antigens in gastric adenocarcinoma compared to nonmalignant gastric mucosa and gastric ulcer tissues. Moreover, lymphocyte infiltration was more prominent in gastric adenocarcinoma tissues. These findings suggest that alterations in the expression of HLA-DR and SC antigens and increased lymphocyte infiltration may play a role in the development and progression of gastric adenocarcinoma. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential diagnostic and therapeutic implications of these findings.

Elevated serum tumor markers in patients with testicular cancer after induction chemotherapy due to a reservoir of markers in cystic differentiated mature teratoma. This study aimed to investigate the presence of elevated serum tumor markers in patients with testicular cancer after induction chemotherapy. A total of 36 patients with testicular cancer who received induction chemotherapy were included in this study. Out of the 36 patients, 5 (13.9%) showed elevated serum tumor markers after chemotherapy. Further analysis revealed that these elevated tumor markers were due to the presence of cystic differentiated mature teratoma, a common finding in patients with testicular cancer. This suggests that the presence of this reservoir of tumor markers in the cystic differentiated mature teratoma can lead to false-positive results in the monitoring of testicular cancer patients after chemotherapy. Therefore, careful interpretation of serum tumor marker levels is essential in the management of testicular cancer patients.

Repetitive conservative surgery for recurrence of endometriosis.  We evaluated the recovery of fertility and the relief of pain symptoms in a long-term follow-up of 42 women undergoing repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis.  The mean age of the patients was 31. The aim of this study was to assess the outcomes of repetitive conservative surgery in women with recurrent endometriosis, including fertility recovery and relief of pain symptoms. A total of 42 women with a mean age of 31 underwent repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis. The patients were followed up over a long-term period. 

The results showed that 25 out of 42 women (59.5%) were able to achieve pregnancy after repetitive conservative surgery. Among these women, 16 (64%) conceived spontaneously, while 9 (36%) required assisted reproductive techniques. Furthermore, there was a significant reduction in pain symptoms following the surgery, with 36 out of 42 women (85.7%) reporting relief from pain.

In conclusion, repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis appears to be an effective approach in terms of both fertility recovery and pain symptom relief. These findings suggest that this surgical intervention may offer a promising solution for women seeking to preserve their fertility and alleviate the burdensome symptoms associated with endometriosis.

Human atherosclerotic coronary artery xenografts: a model for investigation of transluminal recanalization. Atherosclerosis is a leading cause of coronary artery disease (CAD), and transluminal recanalization procedures, such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), are commonly performed to restore blood flow in occluded arteries. However, the success rates of these procedures can vary, and there is a need for better understanding of the underlying pathophysiology. This study aimed to establish a model for investigating transluminal recanalization using human atherosclerotic coronary artery xenografts in pigs. The xenograft model successfully replicated key features of human CAD, including plaque morphology, and allowed for assessment of various recanalization techniques. This model has the potential to enhance our understanding of recanalization strategies and guide the development of more effective treatments for CAD.

Cervical screening with cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear in women with genital condylomata.  Cervicography has been shown to be a very sensitive screening tool in the general population. This study investigated the use of cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear as screening tools for genital condylomata in women. A total of 250 women diagnosed with genital condylomata were enrolled in the study. Cervicography, a non-invasive imaging technique, was found to have a high sensitivity of 93% in detecting genital condylomata. The Papanicolaou smear, on the other hand, had a slightly lower sensitivity of 87%. However, when the two tests were used in combination, the sensitivity increased to 98%. These findings suggest that cervicography, in conjunction with the Papanicolaou smear, can be a valuable screening tool for the detection of genital condylomata in women. Further research is warranted to validate these results in larger populations.

Surgical treatment of low rectovaginal fistulas.  Forty women with low rectovaginal fistulas were operated upon over a 9-year period. This study presents the outcomes of surgical treatment for low rectovaginal fistulas in forty women over a 9-year period. The patients' mean age was 38 years. Fistulas were caused by obstetric trauma in 82.5% of cases and by inflammatory bowel disease in the remaining 17.5%. Surgical repair was performed using a transvaginal approach in all cases. The success rate of the transvaginal repair technique was 85%, with 34 patients achieving complete resolution of symptoms. Four patients required additional surgeries, including one patient who underwent a colostomy. The mean time to fistula closure was 9.5 weeks. Complications were observed in five patients, including one case of urinary retention and two cases of vaginal stenosis requiring intervention. In conclusion, transvaginal repair is an effective treatment option for low rectovaginal fistulas, with a high success rate and relatively low complication rate.

Contiguous enlarged dental follicles with histologic features resembling the WHO type of odontogenic fibroma Defective odontogenesis and/or retarded eruption of teeth can be associated with histologic features akin to odontogenic fibroma in the dental follicles. This case report describes two patients with contiguous enlarged dental follicles that exhibited histologic features resembling the World Health Organization (WHO) type of odontogenic fibroma. Both patients presented with delayed eruption of teeth and showed radiographic evidence of extensive follicular enlargement. Histologically, the dental follicles demonstrated features consistent with the WHO type of odontogenic fibroma, including spindle-shaped cells in a loose collagenous stroma with variable cellularity and vascularity. There was no evidence of mitotic activity, atypia or invasive growth. Immunohistochemical staining showed positive staining for vimentin and negative staining for cytokeratin, confirming the mesenchymal nature of the lesions. These findings suggest that defective odontogenesis and/or retarded eruption of teeth can lead to the development of dental follicles with histologic features reminiscent of odontogenic fibroma.

Selenium in forage crops and cancer mortality in U. S. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between selenium levels in forage crops and cancer mortality rates in the United States. A total of 50 states were included in the analysis, and selenium levels in forage crops were obtained from the National Resources Inventory survey. Cancer mortality rates were obtained from the National Center for Health Statistics. Statistical analyses were performed to determine the correlation between selenium levels and cancer mortality rates.

The results showed a significant inverse correlation between selenium levels in forage crops and cancer mortality rates (p < 0.05). States with higher selenium levels in forage crops had lower cancer mortality rates, while states with lower selenium levels had higher cancer mortality rates. This association was particularly strong for specific types of cancer, such as lung, colorectal, and prostate cancer.

These findings suggest that selenium levels in forage crops may have a protective effect against cancer mortality. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and evaluate the potential benefits of selenium supplementation in high-risk populations.

Abnormal epidermal changes after argon laser treatment. Argon laser treatment is commonly used for various dermatological conditions, including vascular lesions and pigmented lesions. While the treatment is generally considered safe, there have been reports of abnormal epidermal changes following argon laser therapy. This case series aims to characterize these changes and assess their clinical significance. We studied a cohort of 30 patients who underwent argon laser treatment for different skin conditions. Dermoscopic and histopathological evaluations were performed to examine the epidermal changes. We found that 12 out of the 30 patients (40%) developed abnormal epidermal changes, including epidermal necrosis, dyskeratosis, and epidermal atrophy. These changes were observed more frequently in patients with higher laser energy settings or prolonged exposure. While most of these changes resolved within weeks, long-term follow-up is required to determine if any late complications or sequelae arise. Understanding and recognizing these abnormal epidermal changes is crucial for appropriate patient selection and counseling prior to argon laser treatment.

An angiographic technique for three-dimensional determination of arterial supply patterns in cadaver soft tissue. We present a novel angiographic technique for the three-dimensional determination of arterial supply patterns in cadaver soft tissue. The method involves injecting radiopaque contrast material into the arterial system of fresh cadaveric specimens and performing computed tomography angiography (CTA) scans. The CTA scans are then reconstructed using advanced imaging software to generate highly detailed three-dimensional images of the arterial vasculature. This technique allows for the precise visualization and analysis of arterial supply patterns, including identification of anatomical variations and potential collateral pathways. The accuracy and reliability of this method were validated through comparison with traditional anatomical dissection. This angiographic technique provides a valuable tool for anatomical research, surgical planning, and education in various medical specialties.

Prolonged paralysis following suxamethonium and the use of neostigmine. Prolonged paralysis after suxamethonium administration is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication. We present two cases of prolonged paralysis following suxamethonium administration, where the use of neostigmine was initially considered to reverse the effects. Both patients experienced persistent paralysis despite neostigmine administration, leading to prolonged mechanical ventilation and intensive care unit stays. Subsequent investigation revealed an underlying genetic predisposition, specifically a deficiency of pseudocholinesterase enzyme activity. This case series highlights the importance of recognizing and managing prolonged paralysis after succinylcholine administration, as the use of neostigmine may not be effective in these cases. Genetic testing should be considered in patients with unexplained prolonged paralysis to guide future anesthetic management.

Rectal mucosal dysplasia in Crohn's disease.  Serial sections of 812 rectal biopsy specimens from 356 Crohn's disease patients were analysed for mucosal epithelial dysplasia. Rectal mucosal dysplasia is a known complication of Crohn's disease, characterized by abnormal changes in the epithelial lining of the rectum. In this study, 812 rectal biopsy specimens from 356 patients with Crohn's disease were examined for the presence of mucosal epithelial dysplasia. Our findings indicate that rectal mucosal dysplasia is relatively common in patients with Crohn's disease, with an overall prevalence of 21.3%. The severity of dysplasia ranged from mild to severe, with the majority of cases classified as low-grade dysplasia (62.5%). High-grade dysplasia was observed in 19.8% of cases, while 17.7% showed no evidence of dysplasia. There was a positive correlation between the duration of Crohn's disease and the presence of mucosal dysplasia. These findings highlight the importance of routine surveillance and monitoring for rectal mucosal dysplasia in Crohn's disease patients to aid in early detection and management of this potentially precancerous condition.

Synergism of herpes simplex virus and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines in cell transformation. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines (TSNAs) are both known to have carcinogenic effects on human cells. However, the potential synergistic interactions between these two risk factors in cell transformation have not been thoroughly explored. In this study, we investigated the combined effects of HSV infection and TSNAs on cell transformation using in vitro models. Our results demonstrate that the co-exposure of human cells to HSV and TSNAs significantly enhances cell transformation compared to individual exposures. Mechanistically, this synergistic effect is attributable to the upregulation of oncogenic signaling pathways and the dysregulation of tumor suppressor genes. These findings shed light on the potential mechanisms underlying the increased risk of carcinogenesis in individuals exposed to both HSV and TSNAs, providing insights into the development of targeted therapeutic strategies for preventing or treating HSV-associated cancer.

Corpus callosotomy for intractable seizures in the pediatric age group. Corpus callosotomy is a surgical procedure performed to alleviate intractable seizures in pediatric patients. However, there is limited data on the long-term prognosis and outcomes of this procedure in this specific age group. Hence, a retrospective study was conducted to assess the efficacy and safety of corpus callosotomy in pediatric patients with refractory seizures. 

The study included 50 patients aged 1-18 years who underwent corpus callosotomy as a treatment for intractable seizures. Follow-up evaluations were conducted at 6 months, 1 year, and 5 years post-surgery. 

The results demonstrated a significant reduction in seizure frequency in the majority of patients. At 6 months post-surgery, 72% of patients experienced a reduction of more than 50% in seizure frequency, while at 5 years post-surgery, this percentage increased to 86%. 

Furthermore, quality of life assessments showed significant improvements in neurodevelopmental outcomes, cognitive function, and social integration in the long term. Adverse events were minimal, with no serious complications reported during the follow-up period.

In conclusion, corpus callosotomy is an effective and safe treatment option for pediatric patients with refractory seizures, offering substantial reduction in seizure frequency and improvement in quality of life. Further long-term studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Low incidence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with renal cell carcinoma.  Brain metastases from renal cell carcinoma are uncommon. We conducted a retrospective analysis to determine the incidence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). A total of 320 patients diagnosed with RCC were included in this study. Brain imaging, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), was performed on all patients as part of routine staging. Among the 320 patients, only 7 (2.2%) were found to have asymptomatic brain metastases on imaging. The mean time from RCC diagnosis to detection of brain metastases was 14 months. Interestingly, all 7 patients with brain metastases had clear cell RCC, while none of the other histological types showed evidence of brain metastases. Furthermore, all patients with brain metastases had advanced stage disease at diagnosis. Our results suggest that the incidence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with RCC is low, particularly in non-clear cell histological types and early stage disease. Therefore, routine brain imaging may not be warranted in all patients with RCC, but rather reserved for those with specific risk factors such as clear cell histology or advanced stage disease.

The use of ultrasound in evaluating neurologic diseases of childhood. This paper discusses the use of ultrasound as a diagnostic tool for evaluating neurologic diseases in pediatric patients. The benefits and limitations of ultrasound in this context are explored, along with specific applications in various neurologic conditions such as hydrocephalus, brain tumors, and congenital malformations. The advantages of ultrasound include its non-invasive nature, real-time imaging capabilities, and cost-effectiveness compared to other imaging modalities. However, its limitations include limited penetration in certain areas and operator dependence. The potential for ultrasound to improve diagnostic accuracy and guide treatment decisions in pediatric neurology warrants further research and consideration in clinical practice.

Expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies: endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. Expandable biliary metal stents have become a widely used option for the palliative treatment of malignant biliary obstructions. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth in patients with biliary malignancies. A total of 50 patients with malignant biliary obstructions were included in this retrospective analysis. Endoscopic insertion of expandable biliary metal stents was performed successfully in all patients without any major complications. The mean stent patency duration was 6.2 months, with 68% of patients experiencing tumor ingrowth during follow-up. Diathermic cleaning was performed in 92% of patients with tumor ingrowth, leading to a successful reopening of the stent and restoration of biliary flow. No procedure-related complications or mortality were observed. In conclusion, endoscopic insertion of expandable biliary metal stents is a safe and effective method for the palliative treatment of malignant biliary obstructions. The utilization of diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth allows for successful reopening of the stent and provides long-term patency.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: an initial report.  Sixty consecutive patients underwent an elective attempt at laparoscopic cholecystectomy between March 15 and July 31, 1990 at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. This study presents the initial experience with laparoscopic cholecystectomy in sixty consecutive patients at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. The patients underwent this elective procedure between March 15 and July 31, 1990. The surgical technique involved using a laparoscope to access the gallbladder and perform its removal. The study evaluated various parameters including operative time, intraoperative complications, conversion rate to open cholecystectomy, hospital stay, and postoperative complications. 

The results showed that laparoscopic cholecystectomy was successfully performed in all sixty patients without any operative mortality. The mean operative time was found to be 90 minutes. Intraoperative complications occurred in 6.7% of the cases, requiring no conversions to open cholecystectomy. The mean hospital stay was significantly shorter compared to traditional open cholecystectomy. Postoperative complications were observed in 10% of the patients, with minor complications being the most common.

Based on these findings, laparoscopic cholecystectomy appears to be a safe and effective alternative for gallbladder removal. It offers advantages such as shorter hospital stay, minimal scarring, and less postoperative pain. Overall, these initial results warrant further investigation and support the use of laparoscopic cholecystectomy as a standard procedure for elective gallbladder removal.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy using intracorporeal lithotripsy.  Over a 13-month period (November 1988 to December 1989), we performed our first 104 laparoscopic cholecystectomies using an intracorporeal ultrasonic lithotripsy technique. During a 13-month period from November 1988 to December 1989, a total of 104 laparoscopic cholecystectomies were performed using an intracorporeal ultrasonic lithotripsy technique. The aim of this study was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this approach. All procedures were completed successfully without the need for open conversion. Intraoperative cholangiograms were obtained in 96 cases, revealing common bile duct stones in 26 patients. These stones were successfully removed using the intracorporeal lithotripsy technique. Postoperative complications occurred in 8 patients, including bile leakage, wound infection, and pancreatitis, with an overall complication rate of 7.7%. In conclusion, laparoscopic cholecystectomy using intracorporeal lithotripsy is a safe and effective alternative to the traditional open approach, offering improved visualization and management of difficult bile duct stones.

In vitro and in vivo consequences of VLA-2 expression on rhabdomyosarcoma cells. This study investigates the in vitro and in vivo consequences of VLA-2 (integrin 21) expression on rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) cells. In vitro, RMS cells with high VLA-2 expression exhibited increased adhesion to collagen and enhanced cell migration compared to cells with low VLA-2 expression. Additionally, high VLA-2 expression was associated with elevated levels of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and an enhanced ability to invade through a matrigel-coated membrane. In vivo, RMS cells with high VLA-2 expression formed larger tumors with increased angiogenesis in a xenograft model. Furthermore, inhibition of VLA-2 using a specific antibody reduced tumor size and angiogenesis. These findings suggest that VLA-2 plays a significant role in the invasive behavior and angiogenic potential of RMS cells, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic target in RMS treatment.

Plasma epinephrine levels in resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass.  Since the highest plasma epinephrine levels have been recorded during resuscitation, we evaluated the isolated effect of cardiac arrest upon adrenomedullary secretion. The aim of this study was to investigate the plasma epinephrine levels during resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass and to examine the isolated effect of cardiac arrest on adrenomedullary secretion. A total of 50 patients who underwent resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass were included in the study. Blood samples were collected at various time points during the resuscitation process. The results showed a significant increase in plasma epinephrine levels during resuscitation, reaching their highest levels immediately after the initiation of cardiopulmonary bypass. However, when comparing these levels to patients who experienced cardiac arrest without cardiopulmonary bypass, it was found that the isolated effect of cardiac arrest alone did not lead to a significant increase in plasma epinephrine levels. These findings suggest that the use of cardiopulmonary bypass may have a synergistic effect on adrenomedullary secretion during resuscitation, leading to higher plasma epinephrine levels.

Recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy after dental procedures. We present a case series of four patients who experienced recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy following dental procedures. All patients had a history of previous episodes of facial nerve palsy unrelated to dental treatment. The onset of symptoms occurred within hours to days following the dental procedures, including extractions and root canals. Facial nerve palsy resolved spontaneously in three patients within 6 weeks, while one patient required corticosteroid treatment. All patients underwent thorough neurological examination and imaging studies, which did not reveal any underlying structural abnormalities or lesions. Dental procedures should be considered as a potential trigger for recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy in patients with a history of previous episodes. Further investigation is warranted to uncover the underlying mechanism behind this phenomenon.

Brain stem tuberculoma in adult patients: diagnosis and treatment. Brain stem tuberculoma is a rare manifestation of tuberculosis in adults. A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate the diagnosis and treatment of this condition. The study included 35 adult patients with brain stem tuberculoma. The most common presenting symptoms were cranial nerve deficits and focal neurologic deficits. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) provided the most accurate diagnosis, with characteristic tuberculoma patterns. All patients received antitubercular therapy, and most showed clinical improvement. Surgical intervention was required in some cases to relieve mass effect or obtain a tissue diagnosis. The overall response to treatment was favorable, with a high rate of complete resolution of symptoms. Early diagnosis and prompt initiation of antitubercular therapy are crucial for achieving good outcomes in adult patients with brain stem tuberculoma.

Prognostic factors in acute renal failure following aortic aneurysm surgery. Acute renal failure (ARF) is a serious complication following aortic aneurysm surgery, with significant implications for patient morbidity and mortality. This study aimed to identify prognostic factors associated with ARF in this specific surgical population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 218 patients who underwent aortic aneurysm surgery at a tertiary care center. ARF occurred in 32 patients (14.7%), with a mortality rate of 46.9%. Multivariate analysis revealed that preoperative renal dysfunction (odds ratio [OR] 8.42, p<0.001), prolonged operative time (OR 1.04, p=0.006), and intraoperative hypotension (OR 2.36, p=0.03) were independently associated with the development of ARF. Furthermore, patients who required postoperative renal replacement therapy had a significantly higher mortality rate (OR 5.82, p=0.005). These findings highlight the importance of preoperative renal assessment and optimal intraoperative hemodynamic management in minimizing the risk of ARF following aortic aneurysm surgery. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and explore potential interventions to reduce the incidence and impact of ARF in this patient population.

Association of acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie's syndrome) with herpes zoster. We report a case of a 72-year-old male presenting with acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (ACPO), also known as Ogilvie's syndrome, which was associated with herpes zoster infection. ACPO is a rare condition characterized by massive dilation of the colon without mechanical obstruction. Herpes zoster, caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, typically presents with a vesicular rash and pain along a dermatomal distribution. The association between ACPO and herpes zoster is extremely rare, with only a few cases reported in the literature. In our case, the patient developed ACPO shortly after the onset of herpes zoster infection, suggesting a possible causative relationship. Clinicians should be aware of this rare association when managing patients with ACPO and consider herpes zoster as a potential precipitant. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms linking these two conditions.

Autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Despite advances in pharmacological treatment, many patients continue to experience motor fluctuations and dyskinesias. Autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla has been proposed as a potential therapeutic option for these patients.

In this study, 15 patients with advanced Parkinson's disease underwent autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla. Follow-up ranged from 12 to 36 months. Motor function was assessed using the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) and the Hoehn and Yahr staging scale.

Overall, patients demonstrated a significant improvement in motor function following transplantation. The mean UPDRS score decreased from 56.7 preoperatively to 32.5 postoperatively, indicating a 43% improvement. The mean Hoehn and Yahr stage improved from 3.7 to 2.1.

Complications included transient hypertension and vasomotor symptoms, which resolved spontaneously. No major adverse events were reported.

These findings suggest that autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla holds promise as a potential treatment for advanced Parkinson's disease. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these results and determine long-term outcomes.

Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults. Unilateral hydrocephalus is a rare condition in adults and is often associated with various etiologies including tumors, vascular malformations, infections, or prior trauma. This article presents a case of unilateral hydrocephalus in a 45-year-old patient with no history of head injury, infection, or other known causes. The patient presented with progressive cognitive decline, gait disturbances, and urinary incontinence. Imaging studies revealed dilation of the right lateral ventricle with associated transependymal resorption, consistent with hydrocephalus. Ventriculoperitoneal shunting was performed, resulting in significant improvement of the patient's symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering unilateral hydrocephalus as a differential diagnosis in adult patients with progressive neurological symptoms.

Bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia, in an 8-yr-old boy. An 8-year-old boy presented with lower gastrointestinal bleeding and was found to have a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon. This lesion appeared endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia. The patient underwent colonoscopy and the lesion was successfully treated using argon plasma coagulation. Follow-up colonoscopies showed resolution of the lesion without evidence of recurrent bleeding. Bleeding ectatic vascular lesions, although rare in children, should be considered in the differential diagnosis of gastrointestinal bleeding. It is important to differentiate these lesions from other causes of bleeding such as angiodysplasia to guide appropriate management. This case highlights the successful use of argon plasma coagulation in treating a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon in a pediatric patient, resulting in resolution of symptoms and avoidance of more invasive interventions. Further long-term studies are needed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this treatment modality for similar cases.

Pulmonary vascular steal in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.  After pulmonary thromboendarterectomy, performed for relief of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension, perfusion lung scans have frequently disclosed new perfusion defects in segments served by undissected pulmonary arteries. These new perfusion defects have been attributed to pulmonary vascular steal, a phenomenon where the blood flow is redirected from the lung segments with surgical-induced normal pulmonary artery pressure to the segments with remaining high pulmonary vascular resistance. This article presents a retrospective analysis of 50 patients who underwent pulmonary thromboendarterectomy for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension and developed pulmonary vascular steal. The clinical characteristics, perioperative factors, and postoperative outcomes of these patients are analyzed. The incidence, location, and severity of the steal phenomenon are documented through ventilation-perfusion lung scans and pulmonary angiography. The impact of pulmonary vascular steal on hemodynamics, exercise capacity, and quality of life is discussed. Potential mechanisms contributing to the development of steal and the current management strategies to mitigate its effects are outlined. Further research is warranted to explore preventive and therapeutic approaches for pulmonary vascular steal in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.

Controlled trial of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease.  Clofazimine versus placebo. Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the gastrointestinal tract with a potential association with Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP) infection. We conducted a controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease. Thirty-four patients with active Crohn's disease were randomized to receive either clofazimine, a known antimycobacterial agent, or placebo for 16 weeks. The primary endpoint was clinical remission at week 16, defined as a Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) score of less than 150. Secondary endpoints included endoscopic and histologic remission, changes in CDAI score, and adverse events. At week 16, the proportion of patients achieving clinical remission in the clofazimine group was significantly higher compared to the placebo group (59% vs 24%, p=0.04). Furthermore, endoscopic and histologic remission rates were also significantly higher in the clofazimine group. No serious adverse events were reported. These results suggest that antimycobacterial therapy with clofazimine may be a potential treatment option for Crohn's disease. Further larger studies are warranted to confirm these findings.

Recurrent herpetic keratitis: failure to detect herpes simplex virus infection using the Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 direct specimen identification/typing test. Recurrent herpetic keratitis is a challenging condition to manage due to its potential for vision loss and the difficulty in diagnosing active viral infection. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the performance of the Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 direct specimen identification/typing test in detecting herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in patients with recurrent herpetic keratitis.

A total of 50 patients with clinically diagnosed recurrent herpetic keratitis were enrolled in the study. Conjunctival swabs were collected from each patient and tested using the Syva MicroTrak test. The results were compared to the gold standard viral culture method.

Surprisingly, none of the samples tested positive for HSV infection using the Syva MicroTrak test, while 25% of the samples showed positive results with viral culture. This indicates a significant failure of the Syva MicroTrak test to detect active HSV infection in patients with recurrent herpetic keratitis.

In conclusion, our findings suggest that the Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 direct specimen identification/typing test is not reliable in diagnosing HSV infection in patients with recurrent herpetic keratitis. Alternative diagnostic methods, such as viral culture or polymerase chain reaction, should be considered for accurate detection of active HSV infection in these patients.

Obstructive sleep apnea presenting with nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common sleep disorder characterized by repeated partial or complete cessation of airflow during sleep. This abstract presents a case of OSA presenting with unusual symptoms such as nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. A 58-year-old male with a history of hypertension and obesity was admitted to the emergency department after experiencing severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations during sleep. Investigations revealed a significant decrease in oxygen saturation levels and an ECG suggestive of myocardial ischemia. Further evaluation, including polysomnography, confirmed a diagnosis of severe OSA with an apnea-hypopnea index of 50 per hour. The patient was initiated on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy, which resulted in a significant improvement in symptoms and a resolution of nocturnal angina and heart failure. This case emphasizes the importance of considering OSA as a potential cause of nocturnal angina and heart failure, especially in patients with risk factors such as obesity and hypertension. Early recognition and management of OSA can prevent serious complications and near-miss sudden death.

Late metastases of cutaneous melanoma: case report and literature review.  The development of delayed metastases, although rare, is well documented in patients with invasive cutaneous melanoma. We present a case of a 45-year-old patient with a history of cutaneous melanoma who developed late metastases, 15 years after the initial diagnosis and successful treatment of the primary tumor. The patient presented with pulmonary symptoms and imaging studies revealed multiple metastatic lesions in the lungs. A literature review identified similar cases of late metastases occurring in cutaneous melanoma patients, with various sites of metastasis reported including the lungs, liver, bone, and brain. The mechanisms underlying the development of late metastases in cutaneous melanoma patients are not fully understood, but it is thought to be related to the ability of melanoma cells to remain dormant for extended periods before becoming reactivated and disseminating. Early detection and surveillance of cutaneous melanoma patients are crucial in order to detect and manage late metastases.

Resolved and unresolved issues in the prevention and treatment of coronary artery disease: a workshop consensus statement. Coronary artery disease (CAD) continues to be a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. This workshop consensus statement aims to identify both resolved and unresolved issues in the prevention and treatment of CAD. Resolved issues include the benefits of risk factor modification, particularly through lifestyle interventions such as smoking cessation, increased physical activity, and a healthy diet. Additionally, the use of medication, such as statins and antiplatelet agents, has been well-established in preventing CAD progression and reducing cardiovascular events. However, unresolved issues remain in several areas. These include the optimal treatment strategies for individuals with high-risk features, such as diabetes or chronic kidney disease, the efficacy and safety of novel therapies, the role of genetics and personalized medicine in CAD prevention and treatment, and the identification and management of non-obstructive coronary artery disease. Further research and clinical trials are needed to address these unresolved issues and improve outcomes in CAD prevention and treatment.

Audit of results of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in a district general hospital Because of the proposal that infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis should only be treated by surgeons with an interest in paediatric surgery, we carried out a retrospective study to audit our experience in a district general hospital. A retrospective audit was conducted to evaluate the outcomes of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in a district general hospital, in light of the suggestion that specialized pediatric surgeons should exclusively manage this condition. The study included a review of the hospital's experience in treating hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. A total of [insert number] operations were performed over the study period. The audit aimed to assess the surgical outcomes and identify any potential areas for improvement. The findings of this audit will provide valuable insights into the management of infantile pyloric stenosis and help inform decision-making regarding the appropriate allocation of surgical responsibilities in this hospital setting.

Cup containment and orientation in cemented total hip arthroplasties.  We reviewed the radiographs of 864 Charnley and STH (Zimmer) cemented total hip arthroplasties with a mean follow-up of seven years (maximum 16 years). The aim of this study was to evaluate the cup containment and orientation in cemented total hip arthroplasties using Charnley and STH (Zimmer) prostheses. A total of 864 radiographs were reviewed, with a mean follow-up of seven years and a maximum follow-up of 16 years. Cup containment was assessed using the criteria of Lewinnek et al., which categorizes the cup position as either "good," "acceptable," or "unacceptable." The cup orientation was evaluated based on the inclination angle and anteversion angle. The results showed that 82% of the cups had good or acceptable containment, while 18% had unacceptable containment. Regarding cup orientation, 72% had accurate inclination angles and 59% had accurate anteversion angles. These findings highlight the importance of proper cup containment and orientation for successful cemented total hip arthroplasties.

Inner ear cholesteatoma and the preservation of cochlear function. Cholesteatoma is a destructive and potentially debilitating disease of the middle ear. This study aimed to investigate the impact of inner ear cholesteatoma on cochlear function and the role of surgical management in preserving hearing. A total of 45 patients with inner ear cholesteatoma were included in the study. Pure tone audiometry and distortion product otoacoustic emissions (DPOAE) were used to assess hearing function preoperatively and at follow-up visits. Surgical procedures included removal of the cholesteatoma and reconstruction of the ossicular chain. The results revealed that inner ear cholesteatoma had a significant detrimental effect on cochlear function, as evidenced by a decline in pure tone thresholds and reduction in DPOAE levels. However, surgical intervention resulted in cochlear functional improvement in a substantial number of cases. These findings highlight the importance of early detection and prompt surgical management in preserving cochlear function in patients with inner ear cholesteatoma.

Urodynamic morbidity and dysuria prophylaxis. Urodynamic procedures are commonly performed to evaluate lower urinary tract function. However, these procedures can be associated with various complications, including urodynamic morbidity and dysuria. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of prophylactic measures in reducing urodynamic morbidity and dysuria. A total of 80 patients undergoing urodynamic procedures were randomized into two groups: one receiving prophylactic measures, including preprocedure antibiotics and local anesthetic gel, and the other receiving standard care. The incidence of urodynamic morbidity and dysuria was compared between the two groups. The results showed a significantly lower incidence of urodynamic morbidity and dysuria in the prophylactic group compared to the standard care group (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that prophylactic measures can effectively reduce urodynamic morbidity and dysuria in patients undergoing urodynamic procedures.

Indium-111-antimyosin scintigraphy after doxorubicin therapy in patients with advanced breast cancer Indium-111-antimyosin (111In-antimyosin) scans were performed in 20 women with advanced breast cancer after 10 cycles of chemotherapy consisting of cyclophosphamide, 5-fluorouracil and doxorubicin (total cumulative dose of doxorubicin of 500 mg/m2).  Antimyosin uptake in the myocardium was quantified by means of a heart-to-lung ratio (HLR).  Antimyosin uptake in the myocardium was observed in 17/20 (85%) patients, and HLR after chemotherapy was 1. This study aimed to evaluate the utility of Indium-111-antimyosin (111In-antimyosin) scintigraphy in assessing myocardial damage after doxorubicin therapy in patients with advanced breast cancer. Twenty women who received 10 cycles of chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, 5-fluorouracil, and doxorubicin were included. The myocardial uptake of antimyosin was quantified using a heart-to-lung ratio (HLR). The results showed that 85% of patients exhibited antimyosin uptake in the myocardium after chemotherapy, with an average HLR of 1. This suggests that doxorubicin therapy may cause myocardial damage, as indicated by the presence of antimyosin uptake. Further studies are needed to investigate the long-term cardiac effects of doxorubicin in breast cancer patients.

Prevention of hypotension following spinal anaesthesia for elective caesarean section by wrapping of the legs.  Twenty-four parturients undergoing elective Caesarean section were allocated randomly to have the legs wrapped with elasticated Esmarch bandages immediately following spinal anaesthesia or to serve as controls. This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of wrapping the legs with elasticated Esmarch bandages in preventing hypotension following spinal anesthesia for elective caesarean section. Twenty-four parturients were randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group had their legs wrapped with elasticated Esmarch bandages immediately after spinal anesthesia, while the control group did not receive any leg wrapping. The incidence and severity of hypotension were compared between the two groups. The results showed that the leg wrapping group had a significantly lower incidence and severity of hypotension compared to the control group. Therefore, the use of leg wrapping with elasticated Esmarch bandages can be considered as an effective preventive measure against hypotension following spinal anesthesia for elective caesarean section.

Fatal sepsis following intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin administration for bladder cancer.  Intravesical administration of bacillus Calmette-Guerin has been shown to be highly effective treatment of superficial bladder cancer. However, this therapy is not without risk, as evidenced by the rare but potentially fatal complication of sepsis. We present a case of a 65-year-old male with a history of superficial bladder cancer who developed septic shock shortly after receiving intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin therapy. Despite aggressive resuscitation and antibiotic therapy, the patient deteriorated rapidly and ultimately succumbed to multi-organ failure. This case highlights the importance of recognizing and promptly treating this rare but life-threatening complication of intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin administration. Clinicians should be vigilant for symptoms of sepsis in patients receiving this therapy and should promptly initiate appropriate interventions. Additional research is needed to further understand the pathogenesis and risk factors associated with this complication in order to develop strategies for early detection and prevention.

Intravesical condyloma acuminatum with progression to verrucous carcinoma. Condyloma acuminatum is a common sexually transmitted infection caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and typically manifests as genital warts. Although considered a benign condition, it can rarely progress to malignancy, known as verrucous carcinoma. We report a case of a 46-year-old male who presented with multiple intravesical condyloma acuminatum lesions. Despite initial successful treatment with transurethral resection, the patient developed recurrent lesions with progressive enlargement and invasion of the bladder wall. Subsequent histological examination revealed features consistent with verrucous carcinoma. This case highlights the potential for malignant transformation of condyloma acuminatum and underscores the importance of close follow-up and surveillance in high-risk individuals. A multidisciplinary approach involving urologic, dermatologic, and oncologic expertise is crucial in the management of such cases to ensure timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Fatal pulmonary embolism caused by streptokinase treatment of deep venous thrombosis of the leg? During the last 10 years, four of 150 (2. During the last 10 years, four out of 150 patients treated with streptokinase for deep venous thrombosis of the leg were found to have developed fatal pulmonary embolism. This study aimed to assess the risk of pulmonary embolism associated with streptokinase treatment in this patient population. The study included a retrospective analysis of medical records of all patients who received streptokinase for deep venous thrombosis of the leg at our institution. The incidence of fatal pulmonary embolism was found to be 2.7%, with three out of four cases occurring within 48 hours of streptokinase administration. This suggests that streptokinase treatment for deep venous thrombosis of the leg carries a potential risk of fatal pulmonary embolism and caution should be exercised when considering this therapy. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings and explore potential preventive measures.

Plasma thrombin-antithrombin III complexes in the diagnosis of primary hepatocellular carcinoma complicating liver cirrhosis. The diagnosis of primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with liver cirrhosis remains a challenge. Current biomarkers lack sensitivity and specificity, leading to the need for additional diagnostic tools. We examined the utility of plasma thrombin-antithrombin III (TAT) complexes in the diagnosis of HCC complicating liver cirrhosis. 

A total of 75 patients with liver cirrhosis, including 35 with HCC and 40 without HCC (control group), were enrolled in this study. Plasma TAT levels were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Receiver operating characteristic analysis was performed to determine the optimal cutoff value for plasma TAT in diagnosing HCC. 

We found that plasma TAT levels were significantly higher in patients with HCC compared to those without HCC (p<0.001). The area under the curve for plasma TAT in diagnosing HCC was 0.828 (95% confidence interval: 0.746-0.914), with a sensitivity of 71.4% and specificity of 82.5% at the optimal cutoff value of 2.58 ng/mL. 

In conclusion, plasma TAT level is a promising biomarker for the diagnosis of HCC complicating liver cirrhosis. Further validation studies are warranted to confirm its clinical utility.

Dwarf locus mutants lacking three pituitary cell types result from mutations in the POU-domain gene pit-1. Mutations in the POU-domain gene pit-1 have been found to result in dwarf locus mutants lacking three pituitary cell types. These mutants display severe deficiencies in growth hormone, prolactin, and thyroid-stimulating hormone. The pit-1 gene is expressed exclusively in the pituitary gland and plays a critical role in the differentiation and development of somatotrophs, lactotrophs, and thyrotrophs. The loss of these specific pituitary cell types leads to the observed phenotype of the dwarf locus mutants. This discovery provides important insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying pituitary development and hormone production, and has implications for understanding and treating pituitary disorders in humans.

Steroid anabolic drugs and arterial complications in an athlete--a case history. This case report presents the development of arterial complications in an athlete following the use of steroid anabolic drugs. A 29-year-old male professional weightlifter developed symptoms of severe pain and numbness in his left arm. Subsequent investigations revealed the presence of a subclavian artery thrombosis and an aneurysm at the axillary artery. The patient underwent surgical intervention, including graft replacement of the affected arterial segment. The occurrence of arterial complications in this athlete suggests a potential link between the use of steroid anabolic drugs and vascular pathologies. Healthcare professionals should be aware of the potential risks associated with these drugs, particularly in the athletic population. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and to establish appropriate preventive strategies.

The "numb cheek-limp lower lid" syndrome. The "numb cheek-limp lower lid" syndrome is a recently recognized clinical entity characterized by numbness in the cheek and a drooping of the lower eyelid. This syndrome has been predominantly reported in patients with significant trauma to the face, particularly those who have sustained fractures involving the infraorbital rim or maxillary sinus. The exact pathophysiology of this syndrome remains uncertain, but it is hypothesized to be due to injury or compression of the infraorbital nerve. Early recognition of this syndrome is crucial, as prompt intervention, such as surgical decompression or nerve repair, may lead to improved outcomes and prevention of long-term sequelae. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimal management strategies for this rare syndrome.

Epidemiology of primary osteogenic sarcoma in the San Francisco Bay Area of California. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the epidemiology of primary osteogenic sarcoma (OS) in the San Francisco Bay Area of California. Data from the California Cancer Registry between 2005 and 2015 were analyzed, and a total of 274 cases of primary OS were identified. 

The mean age at diagnosis was 19.4 years, with a slight male predominance (53.3%). The annual age-adjusted incidence rate was found to be 0.8 per million population. The most commonly affected site was the femur (46.4%), followed by the tibia (18.2%) and pelvis (16.4%). 

A significant association was observed between race and incidence, with higher rates observed among Hispanics compared to Whites (p<0.001). Additionally, a higher incidence was noted among individuals aged 15-19 years compared to younger or older age groups (p=0.03). 

Overall, the 5-year relative survival rate for primary OS in the San Francisco Bay Area was 61.9%. Stage at diagnosis was significantly associated with survival, with localized disease demonstrating the highest survival rate (p<0.001). These findings provide valuable insights into the epidemiology and prognosis of primary OS in this region and may aid in the development of targeted prevention and treatment strategies.

A prospective randomized evaluation of chronic peritoneal catheters.  Insertion site and intraperitoneal segment. In this prospective randomized study, we evaluated the outcomes of chronic peritoneal catheters based on the insertion site and intraperitoneal segment. A total of 120 patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis were randomly assigned to either a conventional insertion site (n=60) or an alternative insertion site (n=60). The alternative insertion site involved a 2-cm left subcostal incision and tunneling of the catheter to an intraperitoneal segment positioned in the upper abdomen. 

At the 12-month follow-up, the overall catheter survival rate was 84.2% in the alternative insertion site group compared to 71.7% in the conventional insertion site group. Moreover, the alternative insertion site group demonstrated significantly lower rates of catheter-related complications, including tunnel infections and exit-site infections. Additionally, patients in the alternative insertion site group reported improved quality of life measures, including reduced pain and increased daily activity levels.

In conclusion, our findings suggest that an alternative insertion site with an intraperitoneal segment positioned in the upper abdomen may offer superior outcomes and improved quality of life for patients undergoing chronic peritoneal catheter placement. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these results and explore long-term outcomes.

Neurofibromatosis type 2: report of a family and review of current evaluation and treatment. Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple tumors in the central nervous system, particularly in the cranial and spinal nerves. This case report describes a family affected by NF2 and provides an overview of the current evaluation and treatment options for this condition. NF2 is caused by mutations in the NF2 gene, resulting in the loss of function of the tumor suppressor protein Merlin. Clinical manifestations of NF2 include bilateral vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, spinal tumors, and other benign nervous system tumors. Diagnosis is established based on clinical criteria, genetic testing, and imaging studies. Management involves a multidisciplinary approach, including surveillance for tumor growth, surgical resection, radiation therapy, and targeted therapies such as bevacizumab. Genetic counseling and family screening are essential in managing NF2 cases. Further research is needed to develop more effective therapeutic strategies for this challenging condition.

Dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. We present a case of a 56-year-old female who presented with a 2-month history of dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome. Neurological examination revealed an asymmetrical smile with crocodile tears and gustatory sweating on the affected side. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain demonstrated a cerebellopontine angle meningioma compressing the facial nerve. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor, and histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of meningioma. Postoperatively, the patient's dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome completely resolved. The phenomenon of dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome is a rare but recognized complication of cerebellopontine angle tumors involving the facial nerve. The exact mechanism behind this phenomenon remains unclear, but it is thought to involve aberrant reinnervation of the autonomic fibers of the facial nerve. This case emphasizes the importance of considering cerebellopontine angle meningiomas in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with gustatory sweating, crocodile tears syndrome, and dysgeusia. Early recognition and surgical intervention can lead to complete resolution of symptoms and improved quality of life for affected individuals.

Low-dose aspirin does not influence the clinical course of women with mild pregnancy-induced hypertension. A randomized controlled trial was conducted to evaluate the effect of low-dose aspirin on the clinical course of women with mild pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH). A total of 120 women were enrolled in the study and randomly assigned to receive either low-dose aspirin or placebo. The primary outcome measure was the progression to severe PIH. Secondary outcomes included gestational age at delivery, birth weight, and neonatal outcomes. The results showed no significant difference in the progression to severe PIH between the aspirin and placebo groups (p=0.532). There were also no significant differences in secondary outcomes between the two groups. Therefore, low-dose aspirin does not appear to influence the clinical course of women with mild PIH. Further research is needed to explore alternative therapeutic options for this patient population.

Prolonged response to carboplatin in an infant with brain stem glioma.  Adults and children with brain stem gliomas have a mean survival time of 15 months after radiation therapy (XRT). Carboplatin, a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent, has shown efficacy in the treatment of various types of malignancies. However, its use in brain stem gliomas is limited and the response duration remains uncertain. We report a case of an infant with a brain stem glioma who exhibited a prolonged response to carboplatin therapy. The patient initially presented with symptoms of cranial nerve deficits and was diagnosed with a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma, a highly aggressive and treatment-resistant tumor. Conventional treatment options were limited due to its location and the patient's age. Carboplatin was administered as a single agent, and a remarkable clinical and radiographic response was observed. The patient remained stable without disease progression for a period of 26 months. This case highlights the potential benefit of carboplatin in the treatment of brain stem gliomas and suggests further investigation into its use as a therapeutic option in this challenging population.

Pyogenic spinal sepsis in adults.  Twenty adult patients presented with bacteriologically and histologically proven nontuberculous spinal sepsis. Pyogenic spinal sepsis in adults is a rare but serious condition that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment. In this study, twenty adult patients with bacteriologically and histologically proven nontuberculous spinal sepsis were evaluated. The patients presented with a variety of symptoms, including severe back pain, fever, and neurological deficits. The causative organisms were predominantly Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli. All patients underwent surgical debridement and received appropriate antibiotic therapy based on the sensitivity of the isolated organisms. The outcome was favorable with complete resolution of symptoms and eradication of infection in all patients. However, complications such as wound infections and persistent neurological deficits were observed in a small number of cases. This study highlights the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of pyogenic spinal sepsis in order to achieve successful outcomes. Further research is needed to optimize treatment strategies and prevent long-term complications in these patients.

Plaque morphology and pathologic changes in arteries from patients dying after coronary balloon angioplasty Morphologic correlates of pathologic success or failure were studied at autopsy in 28 patients with 40 coronary arteries that had been subjected to balloon angioplasty.  The presence of the following histologic features was evaluated: plaque concentricity or eccentricity, calcification, fibrous or fibropultaceous plaque, medial disruption, luminal thrombus and inflammation. The study aimed to analyze the morphologic characteristics and pathologic changes in arteries of patients who underwent coronary balloon angioplasty. The autopsies of 28 patients with 40 coronary arteries were examined to evaluate histologic features associated with the success or failure of the procedure. These features included plaque concentricity or eccentricity, calcification, fibrous or fibropultaceous plaque, medial disruption, luminal thrombus, and inflammation. The findings revealed a correlation between the success of the procedure and certain morphologic characteristics. Plaque morphology, calcification, and the presence of inflammation were identified as significant factors affecting the outcome of balloon angioplasty. These findings provide valuable insights into the pathological mechanisms and potential risk factors related to this interventional procedure. Further research should focus on understanding these associations and developing strategies to improve the efficacy of coronary balloon angioplasty.

Embryologic fusion planes and the spread of cutaneous carcinoma: a review and reassessment. Cutaneous carcinoma is the most common type of cancer worldwide, with its spread often leading to poor patient outcomes. Embryologic fusion planes have been suggested as a potential pathway for the metastasis of cutaneous carcinoma. These fusion planes represent areas of embryologic tissue fusion during development and are known to persist into adulthood. However, the role of these fusion planes in the spread of cutaneous carcinoma is still not fully understood. In this review, we reassess the current evidence regarding the involvement of embryologic fusion planes in the metastasis of cutaneous carcinoma. We discuss the embryologic basis of fusion planes, their anatomical locations, and their potential implications in tumor progression and spread. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms by which cutaneous carcinoma cells utilize embryologic fusion planes, which may open new avenues for targeted therapies and improved patient outcomes.

Duodenal ulcer is associated with low dietary linoleic acid intake.  It has been suggested that the falling incidence and virulence of duodenal ulcer is related to increased dietary polyunsaturated essential fatty acid intake. Duodenal ulcer is a common gastrointestinal disorder characterized by the erosion of the lining of the duodenum. Recent studies have suggested that low dietary intake of linoleic acid, an essential polyunsaturated fatty acid, may be associated with the development of duodenal ulcers. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that as dietary intake of linoleic acid has increased over the years, the incidence and severity of duodenal ulcer have significantly declined. Furthermore, supplementation with linoleic acid has been shown to have therapeutic benefits in the treatment of duodenal ulcers. These findings highlight the potential role of dietary interventions in preventing and managing duodenal ulcers.

Epidemiologic risk factors for children with acute lower respiratory tract infection in Buenos Aires, Argentina: a matched case-control study. Acute lower respiratory tract infections (ALRTIs) are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children worldwide. This matched case-control study aimed to identify epidemiologic risk factors associated with ALRTIs in children in Buenos Aires, Argentina. The study included 200 cases of children aged 6 months to 5 years diagnosed with ALRTIs, matched with 200 controls without ALRTIs. Data on potential risk factors, including demographics, household characteristics, child's medical history, and environmental factors, were collected using standardized questionnaires. Logistic regression analysis was performed to assess the association between the identified risk factors and ALRTIs. The results showed that several factors were significantly associated with an increased risk of ALRTIs, including low parental education level, crowded living conditions, exposure to environmental tobacco smoke, lack of exclusive breastfeeding, and presence of siblings. These findings highlight the importance of addressing social determinants and implementing interventions to mitigate the risk of ALRTIs in children, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds.

De novo carcinoma of the lower urinary tract in renal allograft recipients. Renal transplantation is a well-established treatment option for patients with end-stage renal disease. However, immunosuppressive therapy required to prevent allograft rejection is known to increase the risk of certain malignancies, including de novo carcinoma of the lower urinary tract. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the incidence and characteristics of de novo carcinoma in renal allograft recipients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 236 renal allograft recipients who underwent transplantation between 2000 and 2015. Six patients (2.5%) were identified with de novo carcinoma of the lower urinary tract. The median time from transplantation to diagnosis was 6 years. The most common histological subtype was urothelial carcinoma. Our findings suggest that renal allograft recipients are at increased risk for developing de novo carcinoma of the lower urinary tract, highlighting the importance of long-term surveillance and early detection strategies in this population.

Orthostatic hypotension after spinal cord injury: treatment with fludrocortisone and ergotamine. Orthostatic hypotension is a common complication following spinal cord injury (SCI), resulting in significant morbidity and impaired quality of life. Various treatment options have been explored, including the use of fludrocortisone and ergotamine. In this study, we investigated the effectiveness of these medications in managing orthostatic hypotension in SCI patients.

A total of 20 SCI patients with orthostatic hypotension were included in the study. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either fludrocortisone, ergotamine, or placebo. Blood pressure measurements were recorded at baseline and after 4 weeks of treatment.

Results showed that both fludrocortisone and ergotamine significantly improved orthostatic hypotension compared to placebo. Fludrocortisone effectively increased blood pressure and reduced the frequency and severity of symptoms, while ergotamine showed similar but less pronounced effects.

Overall, our findings suggest that both fludrocortisone and ergotamine can be effective in managing orthostatic hypotension following SCI. Further studies are warranted to explore the long-term effects and optimal dosing regimens of these medications in this population.

Longitudinal histopathologic assessment of rejection after bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. Pancreas transplantation is an established treatment for end-stage pancreatic disease. However, rejection remains a significant concern, especially in bladder-drained grafts. This study aimed to assess the longitudinal histopathologic changes associated with rejection in canine pancreas allograft transplantation. Six dogs underwent pancreas transplantation, with bladder drainage as the preferred method. Weekly bladder biopsies were obtained for 12 weeks post-transplantation, and histological evaluations were conducted.

Histopathologic findings revealed varying degrees of rejection in all dogs, with evidence of interstitial inflammation, lymphocytic infiltrates, and tissue fibrosis. The rejection process had a progressive pattern, with inflammation peaking at 2 to 4 weeks post-transplantation. By week 12, fibrosis was observed in most biopsies. Notably, vascular changes, including vasculitis and luminal occlusion, were observed during rejection.

These findings demonstrate the longitudinal histopathologic changes associated with rejection in bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. Understanding the time course and patterns of rejection can help guide interventions and optimize monitoring strategies in clinical pancreas transplantation. Further research is needed to investigate immunosuppressive strategies to prevent or halt rejection and improve long-term graft survival.

Insulinoma after streptozotocin therapy for metastatic gastrinoma: natural history or iatrogenic complication? Islet cell carcinoma frequently produces more than one chemical product, although its clinical expression is usually restricted to a single hormone. Insulinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that causes excessive production of insulin. It is typically a solitary tumor, but in some cases, it can be associated with gastrinomas, which are tumors that produce gastrin. We present a case of a patient with metastatic gastrinoma who developed an insulinoma after receiving streptozotocin therapy. This raises the question of whether the development of insulinoma in this patient was a natural progression of the disease or an iatrogenic complication of the treatment. Further investigation is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and potential implications for the management of patients with metastatic gastrinoma.

Survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest: recommendations for uniform definitions and data to report. Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) remains a major public health concern, with survival rates varying widely across different regions and healthcare systems. In order to accurately compare and analyze outcomes, uniform definitions and reporting of data are necessary. This article presents recommendations for defining and reporting survival rates from OHCA, based on a consensus statement from a global multidisciplinary task force. The key components include defining the population at risk, determining the time frame for assessing survival, and specifying the outcome measures. Recommendations also address reporting of other important factors, such as pre-arrest factors, bystander CPR rates, and time intervals. Implementing uniform definitions and data reporting in OHCA research is essential to facilitate meaningful comparisons and improve the quality of evidence-based guidelines. These recommendations will aid researchers, clinicians, and healthcare systems in accurately assessing and benchmarking OHCA survival rates, ultimately leading to improvements in resuscitation strategies and patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to evaluate the impact of these recommendations on data consistency and subsequent advances in OHCA management.

The Hastings bipolar hemiarthroplasty for subcapital fractures of the femoral neck. Subcapital fractures of the femoral neck are common amongst elderly patients and often require surgical intervention. The current gold standard treatment is total hip arthroplasty, however, this procedure is associated with high complication rates, particularly in elderly patients. The Hastings bipolar hemiarthroplasty has been proposed as an alternative treatment option. This study aims to evaluate the clinical outcomes and complications associated with the Hastings bipolar hemiarthroplasty in patients with subcapital fractures of the femoral neck. A retrospective analysis of medical records from a single institution was conducted. Preliminary results indicate favorable clinical outcomes with the Hastings bipolar hemiarthroplasty, including improved pain relief and functional recovery. The incidence of complications was relatively low, and no dislocation or revision surgeries were reported. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and compare the outcomes with other treatment modalities.

A case-control study of Alzheimer's disease in Australia. This case-control study aimed to investigate the association between various risk factors and the development of Alzheimer's disease in Australia. A total of 250 cases diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease and 250 age- and sex-matched controls without the disease were included in the study. Data on demographic characteristics, lifestyle factors, medical history, and genetic markers were collected through structured interviews and medical records review.

Results revealed several significant risk factors associated with Alzheimer's disease. Advanced age (65 years) was found to be a strong predictor, with individuals in this age group having a significantly higher risk compared to younger individuals (p<0.001). Other significant risk factors included family history of dementia (p=0.012), cardiovascular disease (p=0.034), and presence of the ApoE 4 allele (p=0.006).

These findings highlight the importance of age, genetic factors, and cardiovascular health in the development of Alzheimer's disease. Further research is needed to explore potential interventions and strategies for disease prevention and management.

Thirty-six month follow-up of a contemporary phakic intraocular lens for the surgical correction of myopia.  Twenty-three eyes underwent implantation of a glass anterior chamber phakic myopic intraocular lens by one of the surgeon co-authors. The purpose of this study was to assess the long-term outcomes of a contemporary phakic intraocular lens (IOL) for the surgical correction of myopia. Twenty-three eyes of 17 patients underwent implantation of a glass anterior chamber phakic myopic IOL by one of the surgeon co-authors. Follow-up examinations were conducted at 1, 6, 12, 24, and 36 months postoperatively. The mean logMAR uncorrected visual acuity improved significantly from preoperative values at all follow-up visits. Refractive stability was achieved within the first month postoperatively, with minimal changes observed thereafter. No significant complications or adverse events were reported throughout the study period. The authors conclude that the contemporary phakic IOL is a safe and effective option for the long-term surgical correction of myopia, with excellent visual outcomes and refractive stability. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings.

Ki-67 immunostaining in uveal melanoma.  The effect of pre-enucleation radiotherapy. Uveal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignant tumor in adults. Pre-enucleation radiotherapy (PERT) has been used as an adjuvant treatment to decrease the risk of tumor dissemination and local recurrence. However, the effect of PERT on proliferative activity in uveal melanoma has not been extensively studied. In this study, we investigated the expression of Ki-67, a marker of cellular proliferation, in uveal melanoma after PERT. Immunostaining for Ki-67 was performed on tumor specimens from 25 patients who underwent enucleation after receiving PERT. The staining intensity and proportion of positively stained tumor cells were evaluated. Our results showed that the average proportion of Ki-67 positive cells was significantly decreased in uveal melanoma tumors treated with PERT compared to untreated tumors. This suggests that PERT may have an inhibitory effect on the proliferative activity of uveal melanoma cells. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms and assess the clinical significance of these findings.

Sympathomimetics for acute severe asthma: should only beta 2-selective agonists be used? Sympathomimetics have become a mainstay of the treatment of acute asthma. Sympathomimetics, specifically beta 2-selective agonists, have long been the preferred treatment option for acute severe asthma due to their bronchodilatory effects. However, recent studies have questioned the sole use of beta 2-selective agonists and raised concerns about potential adverse effects. This review aims to evaluate the current evidence for using only beta 2-selective agonists in the treatment of acute severe asthma.

Multiple randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses were analyzed to assess the efficacy and safety of beta 2-selective agonists compared to non-selective sympathomimetics in the management of acute severe asthma. The results revealed that while beta 2-selective agonists effectively relieved bronchospasm, they were not superior to non-selective sympathomimetics in terms of overall clinical outcomes, including hospitalization rates and patient-reported symptoms.

Furthermore, concerns were raised regarding potential cardiotoxicity associated with beta 2-selective agonists, especially in high doses or in patients with underlying cardiovascular diseases. In contrast, non-selective sympathomimetics demonstrated comparable effectiveness with a potentially lower risk of adverse events.

In conclusion, the use of only beta 2-selective agonists may not be optimal for the management of acute severe asthma. Further research is needed to determine the safety and efficacy of non-selective sympathomimetics in this population.
