Femoral arteriovenous fistula as a complication of percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty.  A report of five cases. Femoral arteriovenous fistula (FAVF) is a rare but known complication of percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA). This report presents five cases of FAVF detected in patients who underwent PTCA. The aim of this report is to highlight the importance of recognizing this potential complication and to discuss its management. All five cases involved male patients with a history of coronary artery disease who underwent PTCA with the use of femoral access for arterial cannulation. Post-procedural examination revealed the presence of an arteriovenous fistula at the femoral puncture site. Clinical presentation varied among the cases, with some patients being asymptomatic while others experienced symptoms such as pulsatile groin mass, lower limb edema, or limb ischemia. Management options included conservative observation, endovascular treatment, or surgical repair, depending on the severity of symptoms and characteristics of the fistula. It is crucial for clinicians to be aware of the possibility of FAVF following PTCA and promptly identify and manage this complication to prevent potential complications such as limb ischemia or heart failure.

Monitoring of spinal cord stimulation evoked potentials during thoracoabdominal aneurysm surgery. Thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair surgery is a complex procedure associated with the risk of spinal cord ischemia and subsequent neurologic deficits. Intraoperative monitoring of spinal cord function is crucial to identify early signs of spinal cord ischemia and initiate prompt interventions. In this study, we investigated the utility of spinal cord stimulation evoked potentials (SSEP) monitoring during thoracoabdominal aneurysm surgery. Our results demonstrate that SSEP can reliably detect changes in spinal cord function and provide real-time feedback to the surgical team. Early intervention based on SSEP monitoring led to favorable outcomes and reduced the incidence of postoperative neurologic complications. SSEP monitoring should be considered standard practice during thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair surgery.

Comparison of pulse oximeters: accuracy at low arterial pressure in volunteers. Accurate measurement of arterial oxygen saturation (SpO2) is crucial in clinical practice. However, the reliability of pulse oximeters at low arterial pressure remains uncertain. This study aimed to compare the accuracy of different pulse oximeters in volunteers with low arterial pressure. A total of twenty healthy volunteers were enrolled in the study. Arterial pressure was artificially reduced using a well-established protocol, and SpO2 was continuously monitored using four different pulse oximeters. The measurements obtained from the pulse oximeters were compared against the reference method, which was arterial blood gas analysis. Results showed that all four pulse oximeters underestimated SpO2 at low arterial pressure, with significant differences compared to the reference method. These findings suggest that caution should be exercised when interpreting SpO2 readings obtained from pulse oximeters, especially in individuals with low arterial pressure. Further research is warranted to improve the accuracy of pulse oximeters in low-pressure conditions.

Foreign bodies in the throat: a prospective study of 388 cases. A prospective study was conducted to assess the frequency and characteristics of foreign bodies in the throat among a cohort of 388 patients. The study aimed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the epidemiology, clinical presentation, management, and outcomes associated with this condition. Results showed that foreign bodies in the throat were more common in children (54.6%) compared to adults (45.4%). The most frequently encountered foreign bodies were fish bones (42.5%), followed by chicken bones (26.8%). Symptoms at presentation included dysphagia (62.1%), odynophagia (51.8%), and choking (37.4%). Flexible endoscopy was the main modality used for diagnosis (89.7%) and successful removal (92.5%). Complications occurred in 16.5% of cases, with the most significant being perforation (4.6%). The study highlights the importance of prompt and accurate diagnosis as well as appropriate management of foreign bodies in the throat to minimize complications and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

Surgical voice restoration with the Blom-Singer prosthesis following laryngopharyngoesophagectomy and pharyngogastric anastomosis. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of surgical voice restoration using the Blom-Singer prosthesis in patients who have undergone laryngopharyngoesophagectomy and pharyngogastric anastomosis. The study included 15 patients who received the prosthesis for voice rehabilitation. Outcomes were assessed based on voice quality, intelligibility, and patient satisfaction. Postoperative voice quality was evaluated using a subjective rating scale and objective acoustic analysis. Intelligibility was assessed through speech perception testing. Patient satisfaction was measured using a visual analog scale. Results showed that surgical voice restoration with the Blom-Singer prosthesis achieved significant improvements in voice quality, intelligibility, and overall patient satisfaction. The mean subjective rating for voice quality increased from 2.1 preoperatively to 4.6 postoperatively. Acoustic analysis confirmed these subjective improvements, showing significant increases in fundamental frequency and harmonics-to-noise ratio. This study highlights the effectiveness of the Blom-Singer prosthesis in achieving successful voice restoration in patients following laryngopharyngoesophagectomy and pharyngogastric anastomosis.

Dexamethasone increases plasma levels of albendazole. Albendazole is an antiparasitic drug commonly used in the treatment of helminth infections. However, its oral bioavailability is limited and variable, mainly due to extensive metabolism by liver enzymes. In this study, we aimed to investigate the effect of dexamethasone, a glucocorticoid with anti-inflammatory properties, on plasma levels of albendazole. A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial was conducted in 40 healthy volunteers. Participants were divided into two groups, with one group receiving dexamethasone and the other receiving placebo. Plasma levels of albendazole were measured at various time points after administration. Results showed a significant increase in plasma levels of albendazole in the dexamethasone group compared to the placebo group. These findings suggest that dexamethasone may enhance the systemic exposure of albendazole, potentially leading to improved therapeutic outcomes in patients with helminth infections. Further studies are warranted to explore the clinical implications of this interaction.

Underlying illness associated with failure to thrive in breastfed infants. Failure to thrive in breastfed infants can be caused by various factors, including underlying illnesses. This study aimed to identify the specific underlying illnesses associated with failure to thrive in breastfed infants. A total of 87 infants who presented with failure to thrive were included in the study. Comprehensive medical evaluations were conducted to determine the underlying illnesses. The results showed that the most common underlying illnesses were gastrointestinal disorders, followed by infectious diseases and endocrine disorders. Additionally, infants with failure to thrive due to underlying illnesses had lower weight and height percentiles compared to those without underlying illnesses. These findings highlight the importance of early identification and appropriate management of underlying illnesses in breastfed infants with failure to thrive.

Headache.  Public health problem. Headache is a significant public health problem, with a high global prevalence and considerable impact on individuals and society at large. It is estimated that almost half of the global adult population experiences headache in any given year. Headaches can range in severity and frequency, with some individuals experiencing chronic and disabling forms of the condition.

Primary headaches, such as tension-type headache and migraine, are the most common types of headache and are often associated with significant disability and reduced quality of life. Secondary headaches, caused by underlying medical conditions or other factors, also contribute to the overall burden of headache.

The management of headaches requires a comprehensive approach that includes accurate diagnosis, patient education, lifestyle modifications, and pharmacological interventions when necessary. In addition, addressing the social and economic impact of headaches is essential to minimize the burden on individuals and society.

Public health interventions aimed at reducing the prevalence and impact of headaches should focus on improving access to healthcare, promoting awareness and education, and implementing effective prevention strategies. Efforts to reduce the stigma associated with headaches and increase support for those affected can also contribute to better management and outcomes for individuals with this common and often debilitating condition.

Outcome of patients with chronic affective disorder: a five-year follow-up. We conducted a five-year follow-up study to evaluate the outcome of patients with chronic affective disorder. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with chronic affective disorder were included in the study. The patients were assessed using standardized psychiatric interviews and scales at baseline and at regular intervals during the follow-up period. The results showed that 30% of the patients achieved full remission, 20% had partial remission, and 50% had persistent symptoms. The remission rates were higher in patients with bipolar disorder compared to those with unipolar disorder. Factors associated with better outcome included younger age, shorter duration of illness, and good social support. Our findings highlight the importance of early intervention and social support in the management of chronic affective disorder.

Irritant and sensitizing potential of copper, mercury and tin salts in experimental contact stomatitis of rat oral mucosa. Contact stomatitis is a commonly observed condition characterized by inflammation of the oral mucosa caused by exposure to various irritants or allergens. The aim of this study was to investigate the irritant and sensitizing potential of copper, mercury, and tin salts in an experimental rat model of contact stomatitis. Male Wistar rats were subjected to intraoral administration of copper chloride, mercury chloride, or tin chloride at different concentrations. Histopathological examination revealed significant signs of inflammation, including epithelial ulceration, hyperkeratosis, and infiltration of inflammatory cells, in the oral mucosa of rats exposed to copper and mercury salts. Additionally, sensitization reactions were observed in some animals, characterized by an increased inflammatory response upon re-exposure to the same allergen. However, no significant signs of inflammation or sensitization were observed in rats exposed to tin salts. These findings suggest that copper and mercury salts possess irritant and sensitizing potential in the rat oral mucosa, highlighting the importance of avoiding exposure to these substances in dental materials and oral care products.

A frameshift mutation leading to type 1 antithrombin deficiency and thrombosis. Type 1 antithrombin deficiency is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a reduced level of functional antithrombin, resulting in an increased risk of thrombosis. We report a case of a 45-year-old male patient with recurrent deep vein thrombosis and a personal and family history of thrombotic events. Genetic testing revealed a novel frameshift mutation in the SERPINC1 gene, leading to a premature stop codon and a truncated antithrombin protein. Functional analysis confirmed the reduced antithrombin activity in the patient's plasma compared to controls. This case highlights the importance of genetic testing in patients with unexplained thrombotic events, especially when there is a strong family history. The identification of this frameshift mutation expands the spectrum of mutations associated with type 1 antithrombin deficiency and underscores the need for genetic counseling and appropriate anticoagulation therapy in affected individuals and their family members.

Factors related to treatment resistance in hypertension. This study aims to identify factors associated with treatment resistance in hypertension. A total of 500 patients with hypertension were enrolled in the study. Baseline characteristics, including age, sex, body mass index, smoking status, alcohol consumption, comorbidities, medication use, and blood pressure levels, were recorded. Treatment resistance was defined as failure to achieve target blood pressure despite a three-drug regimen, including a diuretic. Logistic regression analysis was performed to identify predictors of treatment resistance. Results showed that older age, male sex, higher body mass index, smoking, and comorbidities such as diabetes and chronic kidney disease were significantly associated with treatment resistance. Additionally, higher baseline systolic and diastolic blood pressure levels were found in patients with treatment resistance. These findings suggest that specific patient characteristics and comorbid conditions may contribute to treatment resistance in hypertension, highlighting the importance of individualized treatment approaches in this population.

Intraoperative protection of cranial nerves and perforating arteries by silicone rubber sheets. Intraoperative protection of cranial nerves and perforating arteries is crucial during surgical procedures involving the skull base. Silicone rubber sheets have been utilized as a protective barrier to minimize iatrogenic injury to these critical structures. This study presents a novel technique using silicone rubber sheets for cranial nerve and perforating artery protection in 25 consecutive patients undergoing skull base surgery. The silicone rubber sheets were placed between the surgical instruments and the exposed cranial nerves and perforating arteries, providing a physical barrier and preventing inadvertent damage. Postoperative outcomes were evaluated, and no cases of cranial nerve palsy or vascular injury were observed. The use of silicone rubber sheets for intraoperative protection has proven to be safe and effective, potentially reducing postoperative morbidity and improving surgical outcomes in skull base surgeries.

Tumor factors predicting for prognosis in metastatic breast cancer.  The presence of P24 predicts for response to treatment and duration of survival. Metastatic breast cancer remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality despite advancements in treatment. Predicting prognosis in metastatic breast cancer patients is crucial for optimal management and patient counseling. This study aimed to investigate tumor factors that may predict treatment response and survival duration in metastatic breast cancer patients.

A retrospective analysis of 120 patients diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer was conducted. Tumor samples were examined for the presence of P24, a known marker of tumor aggressiveness. Treatment response was assessed using objective response criteria, and survival duration was determined from the time of metastatic diagnosis.

Our results demonstrated a significant association between the presence of P24 and treatment response (p<0.001) as well as survival duration (p=0.005). Patients with P24-positive tumors showed a higher response rate to treatment and prolonged survival compared to patients with P24-negative tumors.

These findings highlight the value of P24 as a predictive biomarker in metastatic breast cancer patients. Further studies incorporating P24 into treatment algorithms may lead to more personalized and effective therapeutic strategies for this patient population.

Immunohistochemical interpretation of early epithelial disorders of pyriform sinus. Early epithelial disorders of the pyriform sinus pose a diagnostic challenge, as their clinical and histopathological features can overlap with other pathologies. This study aimed to assess the utility of immunohistochemical markers in distinguishing these disorders. 

A total of 50 cases with early epithelial disorders of the pyriform sinus were analyzed. Immunohistochemical staining was performed for p53, Ki-67, CK7, CK20, and CDX2. The staining patterns were evaluated and compared to the histopathological findings. 

The results revealed differential expression patterns of these markers in the different epithelial disorders. p53 and Ki-67 demonstrated increased nuclear staining in dysplasia and carcinoma cases compared to benign lesions. CK7 showed diffuse cytoplasmic staining in dysplasia and carcinoma, while CK20 showed patchy cytoplasmic staining in a subset of cases. CDX2 exhibited focal nuclear staining in some dysplasia and carcinoma cases. 

Immunohistochemical analysis of these early epithelial disorders of the pyriform sinus provides valuable adjunctive information in their diagnosis and can aid in distinguishing benign lesions from dysplasia and carcinoma. However, further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings.

T cell receptor peptide therapy triggers autoregulation of experimental encephalomyelitis. Experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) is an animal model of multiple sclerosis (MS) that is mediated by autoreactive T cells. The pathogenesis of MS and EAE involves the breakdown of immune tolerance and activation of autoreactive T cells against myelin antigens. In this study, we investigated the therapeutic potential of T cell receptor (TCR) peptide therapy in regulating the immune response in EAE.

We found that administration of a TCR peptide derived from a myelin antigen significantly ameliorated EAE symptoms in mice. This therapeutic effect was associated with the induction of regulatory T cells (Tregs) and the suppression of autoreactive T cell responses. TCR peptide therapy also promoted the expansion of antigen-specific Tregs, which correlated with the amelioration of EAE symptoms.

Further analysis revealed that TCR peptide therapy induced a state of immune tolerance characterized by decreased pro-inflammatory cytokine production and increased anti-inflammatory cytokine production in the central nervous system. Additionally, we found that TCR peptide therapy induced the upregulation of inhibitory receptors on autoreactive T cells, further contributing to immune regulation.

Overall, our findings demonstrate that TCR peptide therapy can effectively regulate autoreactive T cell responses and induce immune tolerance in EAE. These results provide valuable insights into the development of novel immunotherapies for MS and other autoimmune diseases.

Modeling human performance in running.  This paper focuses on the characteristics of a model interpreting the effect of training on athletic performance. This paper presents a model that captures the complex relationship between training and athletic performance in running. The model incorporates various factors such as physiological changes, biomechanics, and psychological factors that influence running performance. By simulating the effects of different training regimens on these factors, the model can provide insights into optimal training strategies for improving performance.

The model was validated using data from a cohort of elite runners, and the results showed a strong correlation between the predicted and observed performance improvements. The model also demonstrated the importance of individualized training strategies, highlighting the need to consider factors such as age, gender, and baseline fitness level when designing training programs.

Overall, this model provides a valuable tool for coaches, sports scientists, and athletes to optimize training plans and maximize performance gains in running.

Decreased local toxicity with subcutaneous diamorphine (heroin): a preliminary report. This preliminary report aims to evaluate the potential benefits of subcutaneous diamorphine (heroin) administration in reducing local toxicity. A total of 35 patients with chronic pain conditions were included in the study. The patients were administered subcutaneous diamorphine daily for a period of six weeks. Pain intensity, side effects, and local toxicity were assessed at regular intervals. The results showed a significant reduction in pain intensity in the study population. Moreover, the incidence of local toxicity was remarkably low, with only two cases of mild erythema reported. Overall, subcutaneous diamorphine administration appears to be a promising approach in reducing local toxicity and managing chronic pain conditions. Further research is warranted to validate these findings.

Comparison of methods for checking surgical margins. The assessment of surgical margins is critical for ensuring complete excision of malignant tumors and reducing the risk of local recurrence. Various techniques have been developed to evaluate surgical margins, including frozen section analysis, touch imprint cytology, and permanent section analysis. However, there is currently no consensus on the optimal method for margin assessment. This study aims to compare the accuracy and effectiveness of different methods for evaluating surgical margins in a cohort of patients. A total of 100 patients undergoing a wide range of surgical procedures were included in the study. The results showed that frozen section analysis had the highest sensitivity and specificity in identifying positive margins, followed by touch imprint cytology and permanent section analysis. These findings suggest that frozen section analysis is a reliable method for assessing surgical margins and should be considered the gold standard.

Hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma in Pendred's syndrome. Pendred's syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter. Rarely, patients with Pendred's syndrome may develop hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma. We report a case of a 43-year-old female with Pendred's syndrome who presented with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and a large goiter. Fine needle aspiration of the thyroid gland revealed features consistent with follicular thyroid carcinoma. Further imaging studies confirmed metastatic spread to regional lymph nodes and distant sites. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy and lymph node dissection followed by radioactive iodine therapy. Despite the aggressive nature of the disease, the patient achieved a complete response to treatment and is currently disease-free. This case emphasizes the importance of considering follicular thyroid carcinoma in patients with Pendred's syndrome presenting with thyroid enlargement or metastatic disease.

Premature menopause because of an inherited deletion in the long arm of the X-chromosome.  A family is described in which both a mother and an infertile daughter had premature menopause at the ages of 31 and 28 years, respectively. We report a family in which premature menopause occurred in both a mother and her infertile daughter. The mother experienced menopause at the age of 31, while her daughter experienced menopause at the age of 28. Genetic analysis revealed an inherited deletion in the long arm of the X-chromosome, which was hypothesized to be responsible for the early onset of menopause. This deletion may disrupt genes involved in ovarian function and follicle development, leading to premature ovarian failure. This case emphasizes the importance of genetic testing in cases of early menopause, as it can provide valuable information about the underlying cause and potential implications for other family members.

The effects of rate, sequencing, and memory on auditory processing in the elderly. Age-related decline in auditory processing abilities can significantly impact communication and overall quality of life in the elderly. This study aimed to investigate the effects of rate, sequencing, and memory on auditory processing in this population. Participants included 50 elderly individuals aged 65 to 80 years. Auditory processing measures were obtained using a comprehensive battery of tests, including pitch discrimination, temporal processing, and speech perception tasks.

Results revealed that the elderly participants exhibited significant impairments in all auditory processing domains compared to a control group of younger adults. Specifically, they demonstrated decreased pitch discrimination abilities, reduced temporal processing accuracy, and increased difficulty in speech perception tasks.

Furthermore, analysis indicated that processing speed, sequencing ability, and working memory significantly contributed to these deficits in the elderly population. These findings highlight the importance of considering multiple cognitive factors when assessing and addressing auditory processing difficulties in the elderly.

Further research is necessary to develop targeted interventions that can effectively improve auditory processing abilities in this population, thus enhancing their communication skills and overall well-being.

A possible role for antiphospholipid antibodies in acquired cardiac valve deformity. Antiphospholipid antibodies (aPL) have been implicated in the pathogenesis of acquired cardiac valve deformity. This review article examines the potential role of aPL in the development of valvular lesions and explores the underlying mechanisms involved. A comprehensive search of databases was conducted to identify relevant studies published in English. A total of 25 articles met the inclusion criteria and were included in the analysis. The findings suggest that aPL may contribute to valvular lesions through various mechanisms, including immune complex deposition, endothelial dysfunction, and platelet activation. Additionally, aPL has been associated with the upregulation of proinflammatory cytokines and matrix metalloproteinases, leading to extracellular matrix remodeling and valve damage. However, further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms by which aPL induces valvular abnormalities and to identify potential therapeutic targets for their prevention and treatment.

The "numb cheek-limp lower lid" syndrome. The "numb cheek-limp lower lid" syndrome is a rare neurological condition characterized by facial numbness and weakness of the lower eyelid. This syndrome has only been reported in a few case studies in the literature. We present a case of a 45-year-old male who presented with these symptoms. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a lesion in the facial nerve nucleus. Electromyography (EMG) confirmed facial nerve dysfunction. The patient was treated with corticosteroids and showed improvement in symptoms over time. This syndrome is believed to be caused by inflammation or compression of the facial nerve nucleus, but the exact etiology remains unknown. Further research is needed to better understand this rare condition and optimize treatment strategies.

Bleeding gastroesophageal varices: gastric vein embolization after partial portal decompression. Gastroesophageal variceal bleeding is a life-threatening complication of portal hypertension and often requires urgent intervention. In cases where partial portal decompression is performed, gastric vein embolization has been proposed as a potential treatment option. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of gastric vein embolization in the management of bleeding gastroesophageal varices following partial portal decompression in 48 patients. Technical success was achieved in all cases, with complete variceal obliteration in 42 patients (87.5%). Immediate hemostasis was achieved in 45 patients (93.8%), and rebleeding occurred in only 6 patients (12.5%) during a mean follow-up period of 26.5 months. There were no procedure-related complications or mortalities observed. These findings suggest that gastric vein embolization is a safe and effective technique for achieving hemostasis and preventing rebleeding in patients with bleeding gastroesophageal varices following partial portal decompression. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these results.

Nitrite from inflammatory cells--a cancer risk factor in ulcerative colitis? Elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a lowered luminal pH were found in 77 percent of patients with acute ulcerative colitis. The aim of this study was to investigate the presence of elevated levels of luminal nitrite and lowered luminal pH in patients with acute ulcerative colitis (UC) and its potential as a risk factor for cancer development. Biopsies were obtained from 100 patients with acute UC and luminal nitrite and pH levels were measured. Elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a lowered luminal pH were observed in 77% of patients. These findings suggest that nitrite from inflammatory cells may contribute to the development of cancer in patients with UC. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for preventing cancer in this patient population.

Open reduction and fixation of proximal humeral fractures and fracture-dislocations. Proximal humeral fractures and fracture-dislocations are common injuries, and their management can be challenging. This study aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of open reduction and fixation in these cases. From January 2000 to December 2010, a total of 256 patients with proximal humeral fractures and fracture-dislocations underwent open reduction and internal fixation. Among them, 215 patients were available for long-term follow-up, with an average follow-up period of 15 years.

The results showed satisfactory outcomes in 168 patients (78%) based on the Constant-Murley score. A total of 32 patients (15%) developed complications, including avascular necrosis, infection, and implant failure. Eight patients required revision surgery due to poor fracture healing or fixation failure. The overall patient satisfaction rate was 86%.

In conclusion, open reduction and internal fixation of proximal humeral fractures and fracture-dislocations can achieve favorable long-term outcomes in the majority of patients. However, the possibility of complications should be considered, and careful patient selection and surgical technique are crucial to ensure successful outcomes.

Local failure and related complications after definitive treatment of carcinoma of the prostate by irradiation or surgery. Local failure and complications are common after definitive treatment of carcinoma of the prostate by irradiation or surgery. These failures can include biochemical recurrence, persistent or recurrent disease in the prostate or surrounding tissues, or the development of distant metastases. Complications can range from urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction to rectal toxicity and urinary obstruction. Various factors contribute to the risk of local failure and complications, including the stage and grade of the tumor, the type of treatment modality used, and individual patient characteristics. This review summarizes the current evidence on local failure rates and complications following definitive treatment of prostate cancer, and discusses potential strategies for reducing these adverse outcomes. These include the use of advanced imaging techniques for treatment planning, the development of new radiation techniques, and the incorporation of adjuvant therapies into treatment regimens.

In vivo rheologic effects of lipid apheresis techniques: comparison of dextran sulfate LDL adsorption and heparin induced LDL precipitation. Lipid apheresis techniques have been widely used in the management of patients with severe hyperlipidemia. However, the in vivo rheologic effects of these techniques have not been well studied. In this study, we compared the effects of two lipid apheresis techniques, dextran sulfate LDL adsorption and heparin-induced LDL precipitation, on blood rheology.

Twenty patients with severe hyperlipidemia were enrolled in the study. Ten patients underwent dextran sulfate LDL adsorption and the other ten underwent heparin-induced LDL precipitation. Blood samples were obtained before and after the procedures, and measurements of blood viscosity, erythrocyte deformability, and platelet aggregation were performed.

Our results showed that both techniques significantly improved blood rheology parameters compared to baseline values. However, there were significant differences between the two techniques. Dextran sulfate LDL adsorption resulted in a greater decrease in blood viscosity and platelet aggregation compared to heparin-induced LDL precipitation. In contrast, heparin-induced LDL precipitation demonstrated a greater improvement in erythrocyte deformability.

These findings suggest that both dextran sulfate LDL adsorption and heparin-induced LDL precipitation can effectively improve blood rheology in patients with severe hyperlipidemia. However, the choice of technique may depend on the specific needs of the patient, considering the differential effects on blood viscosity, erythrocyte deformability, and platelet aggregation. Further studies are warranted to optimize the selection and customization of lipid apheresis techniques for individual patients.

Magnetic resonance imaging in motor neuron disease. Motor neuron disease (MND) is a progressive and debilitating neurodegenerative disorder affecting the motor neurons in the spinal cord and brain. This study aimed to investigate the utility of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and evaluation of MND. MRI scans were performed on a cohort of 45 patients diagnosed with MND and 40 control subjects. Various MRI sequences were analyzed, including T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted imaging. The results revealed significant abnormalities in the motor pathway, including atrophy and signal intensity changes in the motor cortex, brainstem, and spinal cord in patients with MND compared to controls. These abnormalities correlated with clinical measures of disease severity, such as the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Functional Rating Scale. Thus, MRI can serve as a valuable tool for detecting and assessing the extent of neurodegeneration in MND, aiding in early diagnosis and disease monitoring.

The medical necessity of evaluation and treatment of port-wine stains. Port-wine stains (PWS) are common vascular birthmarks that can cause significant psychological and physical distress to affected individuals. Evaluation and treatment of PWS have become increasingly important due to their potential for associated complications, including hypertrophy, ulceration, and the development of Sturge-Weber syndrome. This review aims to assess the medical necessity of evaluating and treating PWS in order to improve patient outcomes and quality of life. Current treatment options, including laser therapy and surgical excision, are discussed, along with their efficacy and potential risks. The importance of early intervention and multidisciplinary collaboration in managing PWS is emphasized. Together, this review highlights the need for comprehensive evaluation and treatment of PWS to optimize patient care and minimize long-term complications.

Rotavirus-specific antibody response in saliva of infants with rotavirus diarrhea. The rotavirus-specific antibody response was evaluated in saliva samples collected from infants who had suffered from rotavirus diarrhea. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was used to measure the antibody concentrations. The results demonstrated that infants with rotavirus diarrhea had significantly higher levels of rotavirus-specific antibodies in their saliva compared to healthy controls. The antibody response in saliva was found to be more pronounced in infants with more severe diarrhea symptoms. These findings suggest that the local production of antibodies in the saliva plays a crucial role in the immune response against rotavirus infection. Further investigation is warranted to explore the potential of saliva-based antibody detection as a diagnostic tool and to elucidate its role in immune protection against rotavirus.

Fresnel prisms improve visual perception in stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect. Visual field deficits, such as homonymous hemianopia and unilateral visual neglect, can significantly impair daily activities and quality of life in stroke patients. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Fresnel prisms in improving visual perception in these patients. 
A total of 25 stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect were included in the study. Each patient underwent a comprehensive visual assessment before and after the application of Fresnel prisms on their spectacles. Visual acuity, visual field extent, and spatial awareness were measured using standardized tests. 
Results showed a significant improvement in visual perception following the use of Fresnel prisms. Visual field extent was expanded, and spatial awareness was enhanced, leading to better overall visual functioning in daily life activities. These findings suggest that Fresnel prisms can effectively alleviate the visual impairments associated with stroke-induced visual field deficits and contribute to the rehabilitation of stroke patients. Further research is warranted to establish long-term benefits and optimize prism prescription guidelines in this patient population.

Echocardiographic diagnosis of a ruptured aneurysm of the sinus of Valsalva: operation without catheterisation in seven patients. This abstract presents a case series of seven patients with ruptured aneurysm of the sinus of Valsalva, diagnosed using echocardiography, who underwent surgical repair without catheterisation. The patients ranged in age from 24 to 54 years, and all presented with symptoms of acute heart failure. Echocardiography revealed aortic regurgitation and a dilated aortic root in all cases. Surgical repair was performed using a median sternotomy approach, with reimplantation of the coronary arteries and closure of the Valsalva sinus defect. Intraoperative transesophageal echocardiography was utilized to guide the surgical procedure and confirm successful repair. Follow-up echocardiograms showed no residual aortic regurgitation in all patients, with improvement in left ventricular function. None of the patients experienced any major postoperative complications or required reoperation. This case series highlights the importance of echocardiography in the diagnosis and treatment planning of ruptured aneurysm of the sinus of Valsalva, and suggests that surgical repair can be successfully performed without the need for catheterisation.

Gross motor patterns in children with cerebral palsy and spastic diplegia. This study aimed to examine gross motor patterns in children with cerebral palsy (CP) and spastic diplegia. A total of 45 children with CP (mean age 7.5 years) participated in the study. Gross motor function was assessed using the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS). The results showed that the majority of children with spastic diplegia were classified as GMFCS level II (35.6%) or level III (42.2%). The most common motor patterns observed were plantigrade (58.8%), equinus (31.1%), and crouch (26.7%). Moreover, a strong correlation was found between GMFCS level and motor pattern, with higher GMFCS levels associated with more severe motor abnormalities. These findings suggest that specific motor patterns are associated with different levels of motor impairment in children with CP and spastic diplegia, which may have implications for treatment planning and intervention strategies.

Detection of hepatitis B virus DNA by polymerase chain reaction in plasma of volunteer blood donors negative for hepatitis B surface antigen. Routine screening for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection in blood donors involves the detection of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) in serum. However, it has been reported that a small percentage of blood donors who test negative for HBsAg may still carry HBV DNA in their plasma. In this study, we aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical significance of detectable HBV DNA in plasma of volunteer blood donors negative for HBsAg.

A total of 500 volunteer blood donors were included in this study. All donors tested negative for HBsAg using routine serological assays. Plasma samples from these donors were subjected to polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification for the detection of HBV DNA. A total of 10 donors (2%) were found to have detectable HBV DNA in their plasma.

Further analysis revealed that the levels of HBV DNA in these donors varied widely, ranging from 10 to 1,000 copies/mL. Interestingly, none of these donors displayed any clinical symptoms or signs of active HBV infection. These findings suggest that a small subset of blood donors who test negative for HBsAg may still harbor low levels of HBV DNA in their plasma.

In conclusion, our study demonstrates the presence of detectable HBV DNA in plasma of volunteer blood donors negative for HBsAg. Although the clinical significance of this finding remains unclear, it highlights the need for more sensitive screening methods to ensure the safety of blood transfusions and prevent potential transmission of HBV.

Stroke rehabilitation: a geropsychological perspective. Stroke rehabilitation is a crucial factor in the recovery of individuals who have experienced a stroke. This article provides a geropsychological perspective on stroke rehabilitation, with a focus on older adults. It reviews the current literature on the psychological aspects of stroke rehabilitation, including the impact of stroke on cognitive, emotional, and social functioning, as well as the role of neuropsychological assessment in guiding rehabilitation interventions. The article also discusses the unique challenges and considerations in providing stroke rehabilitation to older adults, such as age-related changes in cognition and the presence of comorbidities. It emphasizes the importance of a multidisciplinary approach, including the collaboration of psychologists, rehabilitation specialists, and other healthcare professionals, in order to optimize the outcomes of stroke rehabilitation in older adults.

A placebo-controlled, double-blind, randomized, two-center, pilot trial of Cop 1 in chronic progressive multiple sclerosis.  We found Cop 1 to be effective and relatively safe in a previous (exacerbating-remitting) clinical trial.  This current trial involves 106 chronic-progressive patients. This pilot trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Cop 1 in patients with chronic progressive multiple sclerosis (MS). Cop 1 is a potential treatment for MS, previously shown to be effective in patients with exacerbating-remitting MS. The double-blind, randomized trial was conducted across two centers and included a total of 106 chronic-progressive MS patients. Participants were randomly assigned to receive either Cop 1 or placebo for a duration of 12 months. The primary outcome measure was the change in disability, assessed using the Expanded Disability Status Scale. Secondary outcome measures included changes in MRI lesion burden and relapse rate. Preliminary analysis suggests that Cop 1 may be efficacious in modifying disease progression and reducing disability in chronic progressive MS patients. Adverse events were similar between the Cop 1 and placebo groups. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings.

Pharmacokinetics of paracetamol after cardiac surgery. The pharmacokinetics of paracetamol were investigated in patients who underwent cardiac surgery. Thirty-one patients received intravenous paracetamol following the surgery. Blood samples were collected at various time points up to 24 hours after administration. The pharmacokinetic parameters, including maximum concentration (Cmax), time to reach Cmax (Tmax), and area under the concentration-time curve (AUC), were calculated using non-compartmental analysis. The mean Cmax was observed at 1.02 hours (Tmax), with a value of 24.1 mg/L. The AUC was 271.4 mgh/L. The half-life of paracetamol was found to be 4.1 hours. The renal clearance was 8.7 mL/min/kg. No significant adverse events were reported during the study. These findings suggest that intravenous paracetamol has a predictable pharmacokinetic profile in patients undergoing cardiac surgery and can be safely administered for postoperative pain management. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of higher doses of intravenous paracetamol in this population.

Transcranial stab wounds: morbidity and medicolegal awareness. Transcranial stab wounds pose significant morbidity and legal challenges in clinical practice. Despite advancements in neurosurgical techniques, the management of such injuries remains complex and requires a multidisciplinary approach. This retrospective study aims to analyze the clinical characteristics, complications, and outcomes of patients with transcranial stab wounds. Additionally, medicolegal aspects related to these cases are explored. A total of XX patients were included in the study, with XX% experiencing neurological deficits postoperatively. Furthermore, legal implications and challenges were identified, emphasizing the importance of collaboration between medical teams and legal authorities to ensure appropriate management and mitigate potential medicolegal issues. Further research in this area is warranted to improve patient outcomes and enhance medicolegal awareness.

US-assisted aspiration thrombectomy: in vitro investigations. US-assisted aspiration thrombectomy (USAT) is a promising technique for the treatment of acute ischemic stroke. However, there is limited knowledge regarding the optimal parameters for successful thrombus removal. This study aimed to investigate the efficacy of USAT using various parameters in an in vitro model. Thrombi were created using whole blood and placed in a flow system mimicking the cerebral vasculature. USAT was performed using different power settings, probe sizes, and aspiration pressures. Thrombus size reduction and recanalization rates were assessed. The results showed that higher power settings and larger probe sizes were associated with improved thrombus size reduction and recanalization rates. However, excessively high power settings led to increased fragmentation of the thrombus. In terms of aspiration pressure, there was a threshold beyond which further increases did not improve thrombus removal. These findings provide valuable insights into the optimization of USAT parameters, which can guide future clinical implementation and improve patient outcomes in acute ischemic stroke management.

Conservation surgery for glomus jugulare tumors: the value of early diagnosis.  The results of lateral cranial base surgery for glomus jugulare tumors are gratifying when normal anatomy and function can be preserved. Glomus jugulare tumors are rare neoplasms that arise from the jugular bulb and paraganglion tissue in the skull base. Early diagnosis of these tumors is crucial as it allows for conservation surgery, which aims to preserve normal anatomy and function. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the outcomes of lateral cranial base surgery in patients with glomus jugulare tumors. Our results demonstrate that early diagnosis and timely intervention significantly improve overall surgical outcomes. Preservation of cranial nerves, including the facial nerve and lower cranial nerves, was achieved in the majority of cases. Furthermore, patients experienced minimal postoperative morbidity and reported excellent functional outcomes. Therefore, early diagnosis plays a vital role in optimizing the success of conservation surgery for glomus jugulare tumors.

Itraconazole therapy for nonmeningeal coccidioidomycosis: clinical and laboratory observations.  Itraconazole, a new oral triazole antifungal agent, was administered in 75 courses to patients with chronic coccidioidomycosis at dosages of 50 to 400 mg/day for a median duration of 10 months. The clinical and laboratory observations of itraconazole therapy for nonmeningeal coccidioidomycosis are presented. A total of 75 courses of itraconazole were administered to patients with chronic coccidioidomycosis, with dosages ranging from 50 to 400 mg/day. The median duration of treatment was 10 months. The therapeutic response was evaluated based on clinical signs, symptoms, and laboratory parameters. Overall, itraconazole therapy resulted in significant clinical improvement in 90% of patients, with resolution of symptoms and reduction in lesion size. Adverse effects were observed in 15% of patients, including mild gastrointestinal symptoms and elevated liver enzymes. Laboratory analysis revealed a decrease in serologic markers of disease activity, such as complement-fixing antibodies. These findings suggest that itraconazole is an effective and well-tolerated treatment option for nonmeningeal coccidioidomycosis.

Delayed subcapsular hematoma after percutaneous liver biopsy as a manifestation of warfarin toxicity.  Guidelines for the management of patients receiving chronic anticoagulation therapy who require liver biopsy are not clearly defined. This study presents a case of delayed subcapsular hematoma as a manifestation of warfarin toxicity following percutaneous liver biopsy. The patient was a 62-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation on warfarin therapy. The liver biopsy was performed due to abnormal liver function tests. Three days following the procedure, the patient developed severe abdominal pain and hypotension. CT scan revealed a large subcapsular hematoma. The patient underwent emergent laparotomy with evacuation of the hematoma and hemostasis. The post-operative course was complicated by renal failure, requiring hemodialysis. This case highlights the importance of close monitoring and cautious management of patients on chronic anticoagulation therapy undergoing invasive procedures. Further research and clear guidelines are needed in order to optimize the management of these high-risk patients.

Long-term results of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation in relation to the severity of esophagitis A retrospective analysis of the results of the Belsey Mark IV operation has been conducted, relating these to the degree of esophagitis present preoperatively.  Analysis of 89 patients showed a 91. retrospective analysis of the long-term outcomes of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation has been performed, focusing on the severity of esophagitis prior to surgery. A total of 89 patients were included in the analysis, and the results showed a 91.0% overall success rate after the operation. Amongst patients with mild esophagitis, the success rate was 94.3%, while for those with moderate and severe esophagitis, the success rates were 88.9% and 85.7%, respectively. These findings suggest that the effectiveness of the Belsey Mark IV operation in achieving successful outcomes may be influenced by the severity of esophagitis, with better results observed in patients with milder forms of the condition.

Patterns of resource consumption in medical intensive care Intensive care is being scrutinized as a major factor in increasing health care costs. This study aimed to investigate the patterns of resource consumption in a medical intensive care unit (ICU). A retrospective analysis of data from 300 patients admitted to the ICU over a period of one year was conducted. The primary outcomes measured were length of ICU stay, duration of mechanical ventilation, and total cost of ICU care. The mean length of ICU stay was found to be 9.6 days, with a range of 1-60 days. The average duration of mechanical ventilation was 6.8 days, with a range of 1-29 days. The total cost of ICU care ranged from $1,000 to $100,000, with a mean cost of $30,000. The study also identified several factors associated with higher resource consumption, including older age, comorbidities, and the need for invasive procedures. These findings highlight the need for efficient resource allocation and optimization of care delivery in the ICU to reduce healthcare costs.

Preanaesthetic medication with clonidine.  The purpose of this study was to evaluate oral clonidine in a dose of 0. The aim of this study was to investigate the efficacy of oral clonidine at a dose of 0.1 mg as preanesthetic medication. A total of 100 patients scheduled for elective surgical procedures were randomly assigned to receive either clonidine or placebo one hour before surgery. The patients' heart rate, blood pressure, and anxiety levels were monitored preoperatively and postoperatively. The results showed that the clonidine group had significantly lower heart rates and blood pressures compared to the placebo group. In addition, the clonidine group exhibited reduced anxiety levels compared to the placebo group. No significant adverse effects were reported in either group. In conclusion, oral clonidine at a dose of 0.1 mg is an effective preanesthetic medication for reducing heart rate, blood pressure, and anxiety levels in patients undergoing elective surgery. Further studies are needed to assess its long-term safety and efficacy.

Clinical analyses and short-term prognoses of neonates with subependymal cysts.  Twenty-one neonates with subependymal cysts detected by neurosonography soon after birth were prospectively examined. The neonates were followed for a median duration of 12 months. The clinical characteristics and short-term prognoses of these neonates were analyzed. It was found that 17 of the 21 neonates had no neurodevelopmental abnormalities. Among the four neonates with abnormalities, two had a diagnosis of neurodevelopmental delay, one had cerebral palsy, and one had epilepsy. There were no cases of mortality in this cohort. The presence and size of subependymal cysts did not correlate with the presence or severity of neurodevelopmental abnormalities. These findings suggest that most neonates with subependymal cysts have favorable short-term prognoses and do not experience significant neurodevelopmental impairments. However, further long-term follow-up studies are needed to fully understand the implications of subependymal cysts on neurodevelopment.

Magnetic resonance imaging in neurological disorders. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has emerged as a valuable tool in diagnosing and understanding various neurological disorders. This review aimed to summarize the current literature on the application of MRI in different neurological conditions. MRI has proven to be highly sensitive and specific in detecting structural abnormalities, such as tumors, vascular malformations, and neurodegenerative changes, providing crucial information for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. Additionally, advanced MRI techniques, including diffusion tensor imaging, functional MRI, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy, have expanded our understanding of the underlying pathophysiology and functional alterations in neurological disorders. Furthermore, the advent of machine learning algorithms has enabled automated analysis of MRI data, aiding in early diagnosis and prediction of disease progression. Despite some limitations, MRI remains an indispensable tool in the evaluation and management of neurological disorders.

Evaluation of current extrication orthoses in immobilization of the unstable cervical spine.  An experiment was designed to evaluate the comparative stabilizing efficacy of several widely used semi-rigid orthoses applied to unstable fresh cadaver cervical spines subject to load. Current extrication orthoses are commonly used in the immobilization of unstable cervical spine injuries, but their stabilizing efficacy remains a subject of debate. This experimental study aimed to evaluate and compare the stabilizing efficacy of various widely used semi-rigid orthoses in unstable fresh cadaver cervical spines under load conditions. The study utilized a rigorous experimental design, applying different orthoses to the unstable cervical spines and subjecting them to controlled loads. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the comparative effectiveness of these orthoses in providing stability to unstable cervical spine injuries. Such findings will aid in the selection and design of orthoses for the immobilization and management of patients with unstable cervical spine injuries, ultimately improving patient outcomes in cases of cervical spine trauma.

Femorofemoral bypass: a profile of graft failure. Femorofemoral bypass is a surgical procedure commonly used to treat peripheral arterial occlusive disease. While it is generally effective, graft failure can occur and lead to poor outcomes for patients. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the characteristics and predictors of graft failure in femorofemoral bypass. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 100 patients who underwent femorofemoral bypass surgery and identified 15 cases of graft failure. The majority of graft failures were attributed to thrombosis or stenosis at the anastomotic site. Our findings highlight the importance of careful surveillance and early detection of graft failure in order to implement appropriate interventions and improve patient outcomes.

Pulmonary embolism presenting as exercise-induced hypotension. Pulmonary embolism (PE) is known to present with a wide range of symptoms, but exercise-induced hypotension as the sole manifestation is rare and challenging to diagnose. We present a case of a 42-year-old male who presented with exercise-induced hypotension, which was initially attributed to his underlying asthma. However, due to persistent symptoms and clinical suspicion, further evaluation was performed, revealing a massive PE. This case highlights the importance of considering PE as a potential cause of exercise-induced hypotension, especially in patients with risk factors such as recent surgery or immobilization. Prompt recognition and appropriate management of PE are crucial to prevent life-threatening complications. Clinicians should maintain a high index of suspicion for PE in patients presenting with exercise-induced hypotension, even in the absence of typical respiratory symptoms.

Problems of resistant dermatophytes. Dermatophytes are fungal pathogens that infect the skin, hair, and nails, causing various dermatophytosis or superficial fungal infections. While many dermatophytosis cases respond well to standard antifungal treatments, a subset of patients presents with resistant dermatophytes that are resistant to standard therapies. This abstract presents a review of the problems encountered in managing resistant dermatophytes.

Resistance to antifungal agents can occur due to intrinsic resistance, acquired resistance, or poor antifungal penetration into the infected site. Factors contributing to the development of resistance include improper use of antifungals, prolonged treatments, immunocompromised status, and the emergence of resistant strains. The challenges of managing resistant dermatophytes include limited treatment options, prolonged duration of therapy, and potential side effects of alternative antifungal agents.

Efforts to address these issues include the development of novel antifungal agents with different mechanisms of action, combination therapies, and improved diagnostic methods for early detection of resistance. Increased awareness among healthcare professionals about appropriate antifungal use and patient education regarding treatment adherence are crucial to prevent the emergence and spread of resistant dermatophytes.

Overall, the management of resistant dermatophytes poses significant challenges, requiring a multi-disciplinary approach involving dermatologists, microbiologists, and pharmacists to optimize treatment outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms of resistance and develop effective strategies to combat resistant dermatophytes.

Computed tomography for evaluation of puerperal infections. Puerperal infections, also known as postpartum infections, are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in women following childbirth. Early detection and prompt treatment are crucial in improving outcomes. Computed tomography (CT) has emerged as a valuable imaging modality for the evaluation of puerperal infections. This study aimed to assess the efficacy of CT in the diagnosis and management of puerperal infections.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of women with suspected or confirmed puerperal infections who underwent CT imaging. CT findings were correlated with clinical, laboratory, and surgical/pathological findings. The results demonstrated that CT imaging accurately identified the extent and severity of puerperal infections, including endometritis, pelvic abscesses, and septic thrombophlebitis. It provided valuable information for appropriate treatment planning, including drainage procedures or surgical interventions. Moreover, CT findings correlated well with clinical outcomes, and no major adverse events related to CT imaging were observed.

In conclusion, CT imaging is a valuable tool in the evaluation and management of puerperal infections, allowing for early diagnosis and appropriate treatment, thus reducing the associated morbidity and mortality.

Imaging modalities in recurrent head and neck tumors. Head and neck tumors often recur and require frequent monitoring for early detection and effective management. Various imaging modalities have been employed to evaluate these recurrent tumors, including computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), and ultrasound. CT provides detailed anatomical information and is useful for assessing tumor size and extent. MRI, on the other hand, offers excellent soft tissue contrast and is particularly valuable in evaluating tumor invasion into nearby structures. PET imaging with radioactive tracers, such as fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), allows for the assessment of tumor metabolism and can aid in distinguishing between scar tissue and active tumor. Additionally, ultrasound can be used for real-time imaging and to guide procedures such as biopsies. The choice of imaging modality depends on the clinical question and the specific characteristics of the tumor. Integration of these imaging modalities can provide a comprehensive evaluation of recurrent head and neck tumors, aiding in treatment planning and monitoring treatment response.

Fucosylated oligosaccharides of human milk protect suckling mice from heat-stabile enterotoxin of Escherichia coli.  Human milk protects suckling mice from the diarrheagenic effects of heat-stabile enterotoxin of Escherichia coli (ST). The aim of this study was to investigate the protective effects of fucosylated oligosaccharides present in human milk against the heat-stabile enterotoxin (ST) produced by Escherichia coli. Suckling mice were used as an experimental model to assess the impact of fucosylated oligosaccharides on ST-induced diarrhea. Three groups of mice were included: control group, ST-treated group, and ST-treated group supplemented with fucosylated oligosaccharides. The results showed that mice in the ST-treated group exhibited severe diarrhea, while mice supplemented with fucosylated oligosaccharides had a significantly reduced incidence and severity of diarrhea. Furthermore, histological analysis revealed less damage to the intestinal epithelium in the fucosylated oligosaccharide-supplemented group compared to the ST-treated group. These findings suggest that fucosylated oligosaccharides present in human milk have a protective effect against ST-induced diarrhea, highlighting their potential as a therapeutic intervention for enterotoxin-mediated diarrheal diseases.

Intrathoracic fibrin glue for postoperative pleuropulmonary fistula.  Twenty cases of persistent pleuropulmonary fistula after a thoracic surgical procedure were successfully treated with fibrin glue injection into the thoracic cavity through a drainage tube. This study presents the use of intrathoracic fibrin glue injection as a successful treatment for postoperative pleuropulmonary fistula. Twenty cases with persistent fistulas following thoracic surgery were included in the study. Fibrin glue was injected into the thoracic cavity through a drainage tube, resulting in the closure of the fistula in all cases. 

The mean time of closure after fibrin glue injection was 11 days. No complications related to the procedure were observed. The patients experienced significant improvement in symptoms and radiographic findings, indicating successful closure of the fistula. 

This minimally invasive technique offers a promising alternative to more invasive surgical interventions for pleuropulmonary fistula. It provides an effective and safe treatment option, particularly for patients who are not suitable candidates for surgery or those who have failed previous interventions. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are needed to confirm these findings and evaluate long-term outcomes.

The long-distance effects of brain lesions: visualization of myelinated pathways in the human brain using polarizing and fluorescence microscopy. This study aimed to visualize the long-distance effects of brain lesions by examining myelinated pathways in the human brain using polarizing and fluorescence microscopy. A total of 25 patients with brain lesions and 25 healthy controls were enrolled in the study. The brains of all participants were sliced and stained with Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) to visualize the myelin sheaths and counterstained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) to visualize general tissue structures. Polarizing microscopy was used to detect the alterations in myelin distribution, while fluorescence microscopy was utilized to identify specific myelinated pathways. 

The results showed that brain lesions had significant effects on the organization and distribution of myelinated pathways. The affected regions exhibited decreased myelin density and disrupted myelin structure compared to healthy controls. Additionally, fluorescence microscopy revealed altered connectivity and decreased integrity of specific myelinated pathways in the presence of brain lesions. These findings provide valuable insights into the long-distance effects of brain lesions and highlight the importance of myelin integrity in brain function and connectivity.

Mitral valve disruption following percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty. Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is an effective non-surgical method for the treatment of mitral valve stenosis. However, mitral valve disruption can be a rare but serious complication of this procedure. In this retrospective study, we analyzed data from 42 patients who underwent percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty between January 2010 and December 2015. Mitral valve disruption occurred in 4 patients, with a prevalence rate of 9.5%. All cases of mitral valve disruption were diagnosed during the procedure or within 24 hours post-procedure. Three patients required immediate surgical intervention, while one patient underwent conservative management with subsequent mitral valve replacement. Factors associated with mitral valve disruption included severe mitral valve calcification, suboptimal balloon positioning, and patient-related factors such as older age and comorbidities. Our study highlights the importance of careful patient selection, precise balloon positioning, and close monitoring during and after percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty to minimize the risk of mitral valve disruption.

Traditional versus laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a minimally invasive procedure whereby the gallbladder is removed using laparoscopic techniques. Background: Cholecystectomy is a commonly performed surgical procedure for the management of symptomatic gallstones. The traditional open approach has been widely utilized, but laparoscopic cholecystectomy has gained popularity due to its minimally invasive nature. This study aims to compare the outcomes of traditional and laparoscopic cholecystectomy in terms of operative time, postoperative pain, hospital stay, conversion rate, and complications.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of medical records of patients who underwent cholecystectomy between January 2015 and December 2019 was conducted. The patients were categorized into two groups based on the surgical approach: traditional open cholecystectomy or laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Data on operative time, postoperative pain scores, length of hospital stay, conversion rate to open procedure, and postoperative complications were collected and analyzed.

Results: A total of 300 patients were included in the study, with 150 in each group. The mean operative time was significantly shorter in the laparoscopic group compared to the traditional group (p<0.001). Postoperative pain scores were significantly lower in the laparoscopic group during the first 24 hours postoperatively (p<0.001). The laparoscopic group had a significantly shorter hospital stay compared to the traditional group (p<0.001). The conversion rate to open procedure was 5% in the laparoscopic group. The laparoscopic group had a significantly lower overall complication rate compared to the traditional group (p=0.023).

Conclusion: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy offers advantages over the traditional open approach in terms of shorter operative time, less postoperative pain, shorter hospital stay, and lower complication rate. Therefore, it should be considered as the preferred surgical approach for cholecystectomy, whenever feasible.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and cough.  Prevalence in an outpatient medical clinic population. We conducted a retrospective study to investigate the prevalence of cough associated with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors in an outpatient medical clinic population. A total of 500 patients were included in the study, with a mean age of 62 years. Of these, 150 patients were on ACE inhibitors for various indications. Among the ACE inhibitor users, 20% reported experiencing a chronic cough. The prevalence of cough varied depending on the specific ACE inhibitor, with lisinopril being associated with the highest frequency of cough (27%), followed by enalapril (20%), ramipril (18%), and captopril (15%). No significant gender differences were observed in the prevalence of ACE inhibitor-induced cough. Our findings highlight the importance of recognizing the potential side effect of cough associated with ACE inhibitors, which can have a substantial impact on patient quality of life and treatment compliance. Clinicians should be vigilant in monitoring patients on ACE inhibitors for the development of cough and consider alternative antihypertensive medications if necessary.

Management of perineal wounds following abdominoperineal resection with inferior gluteal flaps. Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is a commonly performed surgical procedure for the treatment of rectal cancer. However, postoperative perineal wound healing can be challenging due to the inherent anatomical complexity and limited blood supply in the perineal region. Inferior gluteal flaps have been shown to be effective in promoting perineal wound healing after APR. In this study, we evaluated the outcomes of 30 patients who underwent APR with the use of inferior gluteal flaps for perineal wound management. We found that the use of inferior gluteal flaps resulted in successful wound closure and satisfactory cosmetic outcomes in the majority of patients. Complications such as flap necrosis and wound infection were minimal. Our findings suggest that inferior gluteal flaps are a reliable option for perineal wound management following APR.

Cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid, as revealed by fine-needle aspiration biopsy. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) is commonly used for the preoperative evaluation of thyroid nodules. However, the cytologic features of poorly differentiated "insular" carcinoma (PDIC) of the thyroid are not well characterized. This study aimed to identify the cytologic features of PDIC through FNAB. 

A total of 20 cases of PDIC were included in this study. The FNAB specimens were evaluated by two experienced cytopathologists for various cytologic features, including cellular composition, nuclear characteristics, and architectural patterns. 

The cytologic examination revealed distinct features of PDIC, including high cellularity with tightly packed clusters, large pleomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli, and a high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio. In addition, nuclear grooves, irregular nuclear membranes, and multinucleated giant cells were frequently observed. 

Furthermore, the architectural patterns observed in PDIC included solid sheets and clusters of cells, as well as occasional true papillae formation. 

In conclusion, this study identified a unique set of cytologic features of PDIC through FNAB, which can aid in the preoperative diagnosis of this aggressive form of thyroid carcinoma. These findings can improve the accuracy of FNAB in identifying PDIC and guide the appropriate management and treatment strategies for patients with this malignancy.

Magnetic resonance imaging of facial nerve neuromas. Facial nerve neuromas are rare benign tumors that arise from the facial nerve and can cause facial paralysis and deformity. The diagnosis of these tumors has traditionally relied on imaging modalities such as computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). This study aimed to evaluate the utility of MRI in the diagnosis and characterization of facial nerve neuromas. A retrospective analysis of 27 patients with histopathologically confirmed facial nerve neuromas who underwent MRI between 2005 and 2015 was conducted. The MRI findings were compared with the surgical and pathological findings. The results showed that MRI had a sensitivity of 92.6% and a specificity of 97.8% in diagnosing facial nerve neuromas. Additionally, MRI allowed for accurate characterization of tumor size, location, and involvement of adjacent structures. In conclusion, MRI is a valuable imaging modality for the diagnosis and characterization of facial nerve neuromas.

Treatment of advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the skin with cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil, and bleomycin. Advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a challenging condition to treat due to its aggressive nature and high potential for metastasis. This study investigates the efficacy and safety of a combination chemotherapy regimen consisting of cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and bleomycin in the management of this disease. Fifty patients diagnosed with advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the skin were enrolled in the study and received the chemotherapy regimen. The response to treatment was evaluated based on tumor size reduction, complete or partial remission, and progression-free survival. The results showed that the combination chemotherapy regimen was effective in achieving tumor regression, with 70% of patients experiencing a significant reduction in tumor size. Moreover, complete remission was achieved in 40% of patients, while partial remission was observed in 30% of cases. The median progression-free survival was 12 months. Adverse effects were manageable and consisted mainly of hematological and gastrointestinal toxicity. Overall, these findings suggest that the cisplatin, 5-FU, and bleomycin combination chemotherapy regimen is a promising therapeutic option for patients with advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.

Localization of the human angiogenin gene to chromosome band 14q11, proximal to the T cell receptor alpha/delta locus. Angiogenin is a potent angiogenic factor that has been implicated in various physiological and pathological processes, including angiogenesis, inflammation, and tumor progression. In this study, we report the localization of the human angiogenin gene to chromosome band 14q11, proximal to the T cell receptor alpha/delta locus. Utilizing fluorescence in situ hybridization, we determined that the angiogenin gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 14, specifically within the band 14q11. This finding provides important insight into the genomic organization of angiogenin and its potential regulatory elements. Furthermore, this localization places angiogenin in close proximity to the T cell receptor alpha/delta locus, suggesting potential functional interactions between these two genes. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the significance of this genomic proximity and its implications for angiogenin expression and function. Understanding the precise genomic context of angiogenin may shed light on its role in various diseases, particularly those involving angiogenesis and immune regulation.

Use of H2-receptor antagonists in children. H2-receptor antagonists are commonly prescribed for the treatment of gastrointestinal conditions in adults, but their use in children has been less established. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of H2-receptor antagonists in children through a systematic review of available literature. A total of 15 studies involving 1,200 pediatric patients were included in the analysis. The results showed that H2-receptor antagonists were effective in the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux disease, peptic ulcer disease, and other gastrointestinal conditions in children. Adverse events were generally rare and mild, with no serious adverse effects reported. However, further large-scale studies are needed to establish optimal dosing regimens and long-term safety profiles in pediatric patients.

Serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the tunica vaginalis of the testis with metastasis. Serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the tunica vaginalis is a rare malignant tumor originating from the mesothelial lining of the testicular tunica vaginalis. It typically presents as a painless scrotal mass and can rarely metastasize to regional lymph nodes or distant sites. We present a case of a 55-year-old male who presented with a painless scrotal mass and was diagnosed with serous papillary adenocarcinoma of the tunica vaginalis. Imaging studies revealed retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. The patient underwent radical inguinal orchiectomy followed by retroperitoneal lymph node dissection. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis with positive immunohistochemical staining for D2-40 and Calretinin. This case illustrates the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive surgical management in order to improve outcomes in this rare and potentially aggressive neoplasm.

Historical review of pancreaticoduodenectomy. Pancreaticoduodenectomy, also known as the Whipple procedure, is a complex surgical procedure involving the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, the gallbladder, and a portion of the stomach.
