Further evaluation indicated that the sensory ataxic hemiparesis syndrome arises due to disruption of sensory pathways within the thalamus, affecting both motor coordination and sensation.

Understanding the mechanism and clinical presentation of sensory ataxic hemiparesis in thalamic hemorrhage is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of these patients. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for this rare neurological syndrome.

IgD immune complex vasculitis in a patient with hyperimmunoglobulinemia D and periodic fever. We present a case of IgD immune complex vasculitis in a patient with hyperimmunoglobulinemia D and periodic fever. A 39-year-old male with a history of recurrent fever episodes and elevated serum IgD levels presented with skin lesions characterized by palpable purpura and livedo reticularis. Skin biopsy revealed leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgD immune complexes deposition in the vessel walls. Further evaluation revealed mutations in the mevalonate kinase gene, confirming the diagnosis of hyperimmunoglobulinemia D and periodic fever. Treatment with colchicine and corticosteroids resulted in a significant improvement of the skin lesions and resolution of fever episodes. This case highlights the association between IgD immune complex vasculitis and hyperimmunoglobulinemia D and periodic fever, suggesting a possible role of immune dysregulation in the pathogenesis of vasculitis in these patients. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimize treatment strategies for this rare manifestation.

Repetitive conservative surgery for recurrence of endometriosis.  We evaluated the recovery of fertility and the relief of pain symptoms in a long-term follow-up of 42 women undergoing repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis.  The mean age of the patients was 31. Twenty-seven patients with advanced oral cancer underwent primary mandibular replacement with metal reconstruction plates without the use of bone. The majority of patients (78%) achieved successful reconstruction with primary soft tissue healing, while only six patients required removal of the plate during the postoperative period. Among these six patients, two had their reconstruction plates replaced in a secondary procedure after soft tissue healing. As a result, 23 out of the 27 patients (85%) achieved final mandibular reconstruction and were followed for an average of 19 months. The functional and cosmetic outcomes were satisfactory. In comparison to microvascular transfer, this technique offers favorable operating time and results in a smaller donor defect for patients with advanced disease. Although plate exposure posed some challenges, the initial success rate of 78% and overall success rate of 85% make the use of reconstruction plates a reasonable choice for immediate reconstruction in patients with challenging tumors.

A study was conducted to assess the fertility recovery and pain symptom relief in 42 women who underwent repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis. The patients had a mean age of 31 years.

The single-breath nitrogen test, mortality, and cancer.  The relationship between indices of the single-breath nitrogen test and mortality, overall cancer incidence, and respiratory cancer incidence was examined in a cohort of 876 men, 46 to 69 yr of age, examined in 1974 and followed until June 1985. The single-breath nitrogen test is commonly used to assess pulmonary function and gas exchange. In this study, the relationship between the single-breath nitrogen test and mortality, overall cancer incidence, and respiratory cancer incidence was investigated in a cohort of 876 men aged 46 to 69 years. The men underwent the test in 1974 and were followed until June 1985. Statistical analysis revealed a significant association between impaired single-breath nitrogen test results and increased mortality, overall cancer incidence, and respiratory cancer incidence. These findings suggest that the single-breath nitrogen test can serve as a useful prognostic tool for assessing the risk of mortality and cancer in middle-aged to older men. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore potential mechanisms underlying this association.

How long can a coronary reperfusion catheter be placed in acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty? A case report. Coronary reperfusion catheters are commonly used in the management of acute coronary occlusion, particularly following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty (TCA). However, the optimal duration of catheter placement in this setting remains unclear. In this case report, we present the case of a 62-year-old male who experienced acute coronary occlusion during TCA and subsequently underwent placement of a coronary reperfusion catheter. The catheter remained in place for an extended period of 72 hours due to persistent occlusion and inability to achieve revascularization. Despite the prolonged catheterization time, the patient did not experience any complications such as infection or vascular injury. This case highlights the potential for an extended duration of coronary reperfusion catheter placement in cases of acute coronary occlusion when revascularization cannot be achieved. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal duration of catheterization in this context and to assess potential complications associated with prolonged placement.

Ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease. Ventricular arrhythmias are a common and potentially life-threatening complication of ischemic heart disease (IHD). IHD refers to inadequate blood supply to the heart due to the narrowing or blockage of coronary arteries. Ventricular arrhythmias can occur as a result of myocardial ischemia, scar tissue formation, or electrical remodeling in the damaged myocardium.

This review aims to summarize the current understanding of ventricular arrhythmias in IHD, including their pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management. Patients with IHD who experience ventricular arrhythmias are at increased risk of sudden cardiac death. Therefore, accurate risk stratification and timely intervention are essential.

Various non-invasive and invasive diagnostic tools, such as electrocardiography, exercise stress testing, Holter monitoring, and electrophysiological studies, can aid in the identification and characterization of ventricular arrhythmias. Anticoagulant therapy, beta-blockers, antiarrhythmic drugs, and implantable cardioverter-defibrillators are commonly used in the management of ventricular arrhythmias in IHD patients.

Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms underlying ventricular arrhythmias in IHD and to develop novel therapeutic strategies for their prevention and treatment.

The acute and insidious onset of pulmonary metastatic transitional cell carcinoma. Pulmonary metastatic transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) is a rare but aggressive form of cancer that presents with both acute and insidious onset. This abstract aims to provide an overview of the clinical characteristics, diagnosis, and treatment options for this condition. Patients with pulmonary metastatic TCC often present with symptoms such as cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and dyspnea, which can mimic other respiratory conditions. Imaging studies, particularly computed tomography (CT) scans, and pathological examination of biopsy samples are crucial in establishing the diagnosis. Treatment options for pulmonary metastatic TCC include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. Despite advancements in treatment modalities, the prognosis for patients with this disease remains poor. Further research is needed to improve our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying this aggressive form of cancer and to develop more effective therapeutic strategies.

Using a state cancer registry to increase screening behaviors of sisters and daughters of breast cancer patients. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of using a state cancer registry as a tool to increase screening behaviors in sisters and daughters of breast cancer patients. A total of 250 women were recruited and randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which received targeted information and reminders from the state cancer registry, or the control group, which received usual care. Results showed that the intervention group had significantly higher rates of mammography and clinical breast examinations compared to the control group (p<0.05). These findings suggest that utilizing a state cancer registry can effectively increase screening behaviors in high-risk individuals, thereby improving early detection and potentially reducing breast cancer mortality.

A tongue force measurement system for the assessment of oral-phase swallowing disorders. Oral-phase swallowing disorders can significantly impact a person's ability to safely consume food and liquids. However, current assessment methods for these disorders have limitations in terms of accuracy and objectivity. In this study, a tongue force measurement system was developed and evaluated for its effectiveness in assessing oral-phase swallowing disorders. The system utilized pressure sensors embedded in a custom mouthpiece to measure tongue forces during swallowing tasks. Preliminary results from healthy participants demonstrated the system's ability to accurately capture tongue forces and provide objective measurements. This innovative tool has the potential to improve the diagnosis and treatment planning for individuals with oral-phase swallowing disorders, leading to more personalized and effective interventions.

Misdiagnosis of the Zollinger-Ellison syndrome due to hyperlipidemia. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a rare disorder characterized by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors, resulting in gastric acid hypersecretion and peptic ulcers. We present a case of a 55-year-old male with recurrent peptic ulcers and laboratory findings suggestive of ZES. However, further evaluation revealed that the patient's symptoms were actually caused by hyperlipidemia-induced acute pancreatitis, mimicking ZES. This case highlights the importance of carefully considering differential diagnoses in patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of ZES, as misdiagnosis can lead to unnecessary and potentially harmful interventions. Clinicians should rely on a comprehensive assessment, including thorough clinical evaluation and appropriate laboratory and radiographic investigations, to establish an accurate diagnosis and ensure proper management of patients with suspected ZES.

Heart transplantation in patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased pulmonary vascular resistance.  Irreversibly increased pulmonary vascular resistance is a contraindication for cardiac transplantation. This study examines the outcomes of heart transplantation in patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and elevated pulmonary vascular resistance. Traditionally, a high pulmonary vascular resistance has been considered a contraindication for cardiac transplantation due to poor post-transplant outcomes. However, recent advancements in surgical techniques and perioperative management have prompted a reevaluation of this contraindication. A retrospective analysis of patient data from a single center reveals that heart transplantation can be successfully performed in select patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased pulmonary vascular resistance. These patients exhibit favorable long-term survival rates comparable to those without pulmonary hypertension. Furthermore, improvements in post-transplant pulmonary hemodynamics and functional capacity were observed. These findings suggest that heart transplantation may be a viable treatment option for carefully selected patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased pulmonary vascular resistance.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections among Guatemalan ambulatory preschool children.  Acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) were studied during a 2-year period in 521 preschool children living in a marginal area of Guatemala City. The objective of this study was to determine the epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) among ambulatory preschool children in a marginalized area of Guatemala City. A total of 521 children were followed for a 2-year period. The incidence of ARI was found to be high, with an average of 3.4 episodes per child-year. The most common pathogens identified were respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), influenza A and B viruses, and parainfluenza viruses. The highest incidence of ARI was observed in children aged 12 to 24 months, and there was a seasonal variation with peak incidence during the rainy season. Factors associated with increased risk of ARI included household overcrowding, low socioeconomic status, lack of exclusive breastfeeding, and exposure to smoking within the household. These findings highlight the burden of ARI in this population and identify potential risk factors that could be targeted for intervention strategies to reduce the morbidity associated with ARI in Guatemalan preschool children.

Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis for sternal tumor defect: an autopsy report. We present a case report of a 65-year-old male who underwent a radical resection of a sternal tumor and subsequent reconstruction using a dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis. Following the procedure, the patient experienced an uneventful recovery and was discharged home. However, six months later, he presented with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Despite aggressive medical management, the patient succumbed to his symptoms and underwent an autopsy to determine the cause of death. Examination revealed that the dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis had become infected and had eroded into the underlying mediastinal structures, leading to fatal mediastinitis. The autopsy findings highlight the importance of close postoperative monitoring and early detection of complications in patients undergoing sternal tumor resection and reconstruction. It also raises concerns regarding the long-term durability and safety of dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prostheses in this patient population. Further research is warranted to explore alternative materials and techniques for sternal tumor defect reconstruction.

Recovery of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocyte subpopulation after autologous bone marrow transplantation and chemotherapy. Autologous bone marrow transplantation (ABMT) is a therapeutic approach used in the treatment of various hematological malignancies. However, ABMT is associated with a profound suppression of the immune system, leading to an increased risk of infection and disease relapse. The recovery of specific lymphocyte subpopulations, such as CD3+ and CD5- lymphocytes, plays a crucial role in reestablishing immune function post-ABMT. This study aimed to investigate the kinetics of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocyte recovery following ABMT and chemotherapy in patients with hematological malignancies. Our findings demonstrate that CD3+ lymphocytes recover at a faster rate than CD5- lymphocytes, suggesting a potential differential impact on immune reconstitution in ABMT recipients. Further research is warranted to explore the mechanisms underlying these observations and their clinical implications for optimizing post-ABMT immune recovery.

MRI findings in neuro-Behcet's disease. Neuro-Behcet's disease (NBD) is a rare and serious manifestation of Behcet's disease involving the central nervous system. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) plays a crucial role in the diagnosis and monitoring of NBD. In this study, we present the MRI findings in a cohort of patients with NBD. We performed brain and spinal cord MRI on 30 patients with clinically suspected or confirmed NBD. The most common finding on brain MRI was parenchymal lesions, including white matter hyperintensities and cortical/subcortical lesions. Brainstem and basal ganglia involvement were also observed. Spinal cord involvement manifested as longitudinal and transverse hyperintensities on T2-weighted images. In conclusion, MRI is a valuable tool in the diagnosis and assessment of disease activity in NBD, showing characteristic findings of parenchymal lesions and spinal cord involvement. Further studies are needed to explore the correlation between MRI findings and clinical manifestations in NBD.

Dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. This case report presents a rare presentation of a cerebellopontine angle meningioma leading to the development of three distinct cranial nerve dysfunctions. The patient initially presented with dysgeusia, experiencing a persistent metallic taste in the mouth. Furthermore, she developed gustatory sweating, where episodes of facial sweating were triggered by eating. Lastly, the patient experienced crocodile tears syndrome, characterized by excessive lacrimation during meals. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a cerebellopontine angle meningioma compressing the facial and glossopharyngeal nerves. Surgical resection of the tumor resulted in complete resolution of all three dysfunctions. 

Although cerebellopontine angle meningiomas are known to cause cranial nerve dysfunctions, this case demonstrates a unique combination of symptoms that have not previously been reported. The exact pathophysiological mechanisms underlying these symptoms remain uncertain. Further studies and research are warranted to elucidate the complex interplay between the tumor and the cranial nerves, which may provide valuable insights into the diagnosis and management of similar cases.

Islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas presenting as bleeding from isolated gastric varices.  Report of a case and review of the literature. Islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can present with various clinical manifestations. We report a case of a 60-year-old male who presented with upper gastrointestinal bleeding secondary to bleeding gastric varices. Imaging studies revealed a hypervascular pancreatic mass, and subsequent biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of islet cell carcinoma. This case highlights the importance of considering islet cell carcinoma as a potential cause of gastrointestinal bleeding, especially in patients with a known pancreatic mass. Furthermore, a review of the literature reveals limited reports on the association between islet cell carcinoma and bleeding gastric varices. A high index of suspicion and prompt diagnosis are crucial for optimal management of this rare presentation.

The long-term effects of radiation therapy on patients with ovarian dysgerminoma.  A retrospective chart review and questionnaire study was undertaken to look at the long-term effects of radiation therapy in ovarian dysgerminoma patients. The study included 35 patients diagnosed with ovarian dysgerminoma who received radiation therapy as part of their treatment. Medical records were reviewed to collect data on treatment regimens, follow-up care, and any reported long-term side effects. Additionally, questionnaires were sent to all participants to gather subjective information regarding their quality of life and any chronic health issues. 

Preliminary analysis revealed that all patients received a median radiation dose of 45 Gy, with the majority treated using a combination of external beam radiation and brachytherapy. Follow-up ranged from 5 to 20 years post-treatment. 

The results of the study indicated that radiation therapy for ovarian dysgerminoma led to favorable oncological outcomes, with no reported disease recurrences. However, several patients reported long-term side effects, including gastrointestinal and genitourinary complications, as well as secondary malignancies. The questionnaire responses highlighted impaired fertility and emotional distress as common concerns among survivors. 

In conclusion, while radiation therapy effectively treats ovarian dysgerminoma, careful consideration of long-term side effects is necessary. Further research is warranted to refine treatment approaches and mitigate potential complications in this patient population.

Adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder. Adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder is a benign condition characterized by hyperplasia of the gallbladder wall, resulting in the formation of intramural diverticula. We present a retrospective analysis of 10 cases diagnosed with adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder. Patients presented with clinical symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, dyspepsia, and gallstones. Imaging studies revealed characteristic findings, including the presence of Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses and a honeycomb appearance on ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis, showing hypertrophy of the smooth muscle layer and invagination of the mucosal layer into the muscularis propria. Differential diagnosis includes gallbladder adenocarcinoma, cholesterol polyps, and gallbladder wall thickening secondary to inflammation. Surgical resection is the treatment of choice in symptomatic patients or in cases where malignancy cannot be ruled out. Awareness of this condition is crucial to avoid unnecessary interventions.

Evidence of heterogeneous mechanisms in lipoprotein lipid alterations in hyperandrogenic women. Hyperandrogenic women are known to have alterations in lipoprotein lipid levels, however, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. This study aimed to investigate the heterogeneity of these mechanisms by analyzing the lipoprotein lipid profiles of hyperandrogenic women. 

A total of 50 hyperandrogenic women and 50 age-matched controls were included in the study. Lipoprotein lipid levels were measured using standard biochemical methods, and the data was analyzed using multivariate statistical techniques.

Results showed that hyperandrogenic women had significantly higher levels of total cholesterol, triglycerides, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and apolipoprotein B compared to controls. Furthermore, they exhibited lower levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol and apolipoprotein A1. 

Subgroup analysis revealed three distinct lipid profiles within the hyperandrogenic group, suggesting heterogeneous mechanisms underlying the lipid alterations. These subgroups differed in terms of insulin resistance, body mass index, and hormonal parameters.

In conclusion, this study provides evidence of heterogeneous mechanisms in lipoprotein lipid alterations in hyperandrogenic women. Understanding these mechanisms may help identify personalized treatment strategies for this population.

Brain abscess associated with congenital pulmonary arteriovenous fistula. Congenital pulmonary arteriovenous fistulas (CPAVFs) are rare vascular anomalies that can lead to various complications. We present a case of a 32-year-old male who presented with a brain abscess. Further investigation revealed the presence of a CPAVF. The patient underwent surgical intervention to repair the fistula and was subsequently treated with appropriate antimicrobial therapy. The patient's symptoms improved, and a repeat imaging study showed resolution of the brain abscess. This case highlights the importance of considering CPAVFs in the differential diagnosis of brain abscesses, particularly in patients with no known risk factors. Early diagnosis and timely intervention can lead to favorable outcomes in these patients.

Impaired awareness of behavioral limitations after traumatic brain injury.  Sixty-four traumatically brain injured patients were divided into three groups. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and characteristics of impaired awareness of behavioral limitations in individuals with traumatic brain injury (TBI). Sixty-four TBI patients were divided into three groups based on their level of awareness: intact awareness (IA, n = 25), partially impaired awareness (PIA, n = 19), and severely impaired awareness (SIA, n = 20). Participants completed the Dysexecutive Questionnaire (DEX), which assesses executive dysfunction and awareness of behavioral limitations. Results revealed that both the PIA and SIA groups reported significantly higher levels of executive dysfunction compared to the IA group. The SIA group also exhibited significantly lower levels of awareness of behavioral limitations compared to the PIA group. Moreover, impaired awareness was found to be correlated with greater injury severity and poorer neuropsychological performance. These findings highlight the importance of assessing awareness of behavioral limitations in individuals with TBI to better understand their cognitive and functional abilities, as well as to inform rehabilitation strategies and treatment planning.

Beneficial effects of colestipol-niacin on coronary atherosclerosis.  A 4-year follow-up. This study aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of colestipol-niacin therapy on coronary atherosclerosis. A total of 150 patients with documented coronary artery disease were enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either colestipol-niacin or placebo. All patients underwent coronary angiography at baseline and after 4 years of treatment. The primary endpoint was the change in percent diameter stenosis in the target coronary artery. Secondary endpoints included changes in plaque volume, total atheroma volume, and clinical events such as myocardial infarction and cardiovascular death. 

After 4 years, the colestipol-niacin group showed a significant reduction in percent diameter stenosis compared to the placebo group (p < 0.001). The mean change in percent diameter stenosis was -7.2% in the colestipol-niacin group and +2.1% in the placebo group. Similarly, colestipol-niacin therapy was associated with a significant reduction in plaque volume (p = 0.003) and total atheroma volume (p = 0.002) compared to placebo.

Furthermore, the colestipol-niacin group had a lower incidence of clinical events, including myocardial infarction and cardiovascular death, compared to the placebo group. The incidence of myocardial infarction was 5.3% in the colestipol-niacin group and 12.7% in the placebo group (p = 0.042). Cardiovascular death occurred in 2.7% of patients in the colestipol-niacin group and 7.3% in the placebo group (p = 0.089).

In conclusion, long-term colestipol-niacin therapy is associated with beneficial effects on coronary atherosclerosis, including a reduction in percent diameter stenosis, plaque volume, and total atheroma volume. Additionally, colestipol-niacin therapy is associated with a lower incidence of clinical events, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic option for coronary artery disease management.

Mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is characterized by the presence of an abnormal electrical connection known as an accessory pathway between the atria and ventricles. This accessory pathway, also called the bundle of Kent, allows for the occurrence of preexcitation, leading to dysrhythmias such as paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. Intermittent preexcitation, where there are periods of normal conduction alternating with periods of preexcitation, can pose diagnostic challenges. 

This study aimed to elucidate the mechanism of intermittent preexcitation by analyzing intracardiac electrograms obtained during electrophysiological studies in patients with WPW syndrome. Sixteen patients with intermittent preexcitation were included in the study. The analysis revealed that intermittent preexcitation was primarily caused by the intermittent conduction block within the accessory pathway. This blockage was attributed to refractoriness and decremental conduction properties of the accessory pathway. Additionally, the presence of competing pathways and differing refractory periods in both the atria and ventricles contributed to the intermittent preexcitation seen in these patients.

Understanding the mechanism behind intermittent preexcitation in WPW syndrome can aid in accurate diagnosis and appropriate management strategies for affected individuals.

The reproducibility of intravascular ultrasound imaging in vitro. Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) has become an important tool in the evaluation and management of cardiovascular diseases. This study aims to assess the reproducibility of IVUS measurements in vitro. Ten human arterial segments were harvested and placed within custom-designed phantoms to simulate vessel anatomy. IVUS imaging was performed multiple times on each segment using a commercially available system. Measurements including lumen diameter, plaque thickness, and vessel area were obtained and compared between scans. The intra-observer and inter-observer variabilities were analyzed using coefficient of variation (CV) and intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). The results showed excellent reproducibility with low CVs and high ICCs for most measurements. However, some parameters such as plaque burden exhibited higher variability. This study confirms the reliability and reproducibility of IVUS measurements in vitro, supporting its use as a valuable tool for assessing intravascular pathology.

Window operation: an alternative treatment method for Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses Recently, we developed the "window operation" as a more effective way to treat Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses. Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses are common gynecological conditions that can cause significant discomfort and pain in affected individuals. Current treatment options include incision and drainage, marsupialization, and excision. However, these techniques may have limitations in terms of recurrence rates, healing time, and patient satisfaction. In this study, we present the "window operation" as a novel and effective alternative treatment method for Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses. This technique involves creating a small window in the cyst or abscess wall, allowing for continuous drainage and preventing re-accumulation of fluid. Preliminary results from a case series of ten patients showed favorable outcomes, with complete resolution of symptoms and no recurrence observed during follow-up. The window operation offers a promising approach to improve the management of Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses, providing enhanced patient outcomes and satisfaction. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and establish the long-term effectiveness of this technique.

Hepatitis B virus nucleocapsid/pre-S2 fusion proteins expressed in attenuated Salmonella for oral vaccination.  Hybrid HBV nucleocapsid-pre-S(2) fusion proteins were stably expressed in several aromatic-dependent attenuated Salmonella typhimurium and Salmonella dublin strains. Oral vaccination is an effective and convenient method for preventing Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. In this study, attenuated strains of Salmonella typhimurium and Salmonella dublin were used to express hybrid HBV nucleocapsid-pre-S(2) fusion proteins. The expression of these fusion proteins was found to be stable in multiple strains of these bacteria. The ability of these proteins to induce an immune response was evaluated in animal models, and promising results were obtained. The use of attenuated Salmonella as a delivery system for HBV antigens offers several advantages, such as easy administration and the potential for mucosal immune response. Further research is needed to optimize and validate this oral vaccination approach for the prevention of HBV infection.

Lateral medullary infarction: prognosis in an unselected series.  We describe the acute and long-term prognosis in 43 patients with lateral medullary infarction (LMI) collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. The study aimed to investigate the prognosis of lateral medullary infarction (LMI) in an unselected series of patients. A total of 43 patients with LMI were included in the study, which was conducted from 1982 to July 1988. The acute and long-term prognosis of these patients was analyzed using data from a population-based stroke registry. The results revealed varying outcomes for the patients, with some experiencing partial or complete recovery while others had persistent symptoms. Additionally, the study identified specific factors that were associated with a poorer prognosis, such as older age and the presence of comorbidities. These findings provide important insights into the prognosis of LMI and may aid in the development of more targeted treatment and rehabilitation strategies.

Why are autism and the fragile-X syndrome associated? Conceptual and methodological issues. The association between autism and fragile-X syndrome has been well documented, but the underlying reasons for this association remain unclear. This review examines the conceptual and methodological issues surrounding this relationship. It is hypothesized that genetic factors play a significant role, as both conditions are believed to be caused by mutations in specific genes. Additionally, there may be shared neural pathways and neurodevelopmental abnormalities that contribute to the overlapping symptoms observed in individuals with autism and fragile-X syndrome. However, the complex nature of these conditions makes it difficult to tease apart the exact mechanisms underlying their association. Further research is needed to better understand the genetic and neurobiological factors linking autism and fragile-X syndrome.

The modified superior based pharyngeal flap. The modified superior based pharyngeal flap is a surgical procedure used in the treatment of velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI). VPI is characterized by the inability to close the velopharyngeal port during speech, leading to hypernasal speech and air escape through the nose. The modified superior based pharyngeal flap has been shown to effectively improve velopharyngeal closure and speech outcomes in patients with VPI. The procedure involves harvesting a flap of tissue from the posterior pharyngeal wall, which is then rotated and sutured in place to partially close the velopharyngeal port. This technique allows for greater customization and control of the flap, resulting in improved functional outcomes and reduced complications compared to traditional techniques. The modified superior based pharyngeal flap offers a valuable treatment option for patients with VPI, leading to improved speech and quality of life.

Upper gastrointestinal pathology in familial adenomatous polyposis: results from a prospective study of 102 patients.  Multiple gastric and duodenal biopsy specimens from 102 asymptomatic patients with familial adenomatous polyposis, taken during a prospective endoscopic screening programme were examined. The aim of this study was to evaluate the upper gastrointestinal pathology in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). A total of 102 asymptomatic patients with FAP underwent endoscopic screening, and multiple gastric and duodenal biopsy specimens were obtained. Histological analysis revealed significant abnormalities in the upper gastrointestinal tract, including gastric fundic gland polyps (FGPs) in 78% of patients, gastric adenomas in 21%, and duodenal adenomas in 34%. Dysplasia was observed in 9% of FGPs, 33% of gastric adenomas, and 69% of duodenal adenomas. The presence of duodenal adenomas was significantly associated with the age and extent of colonic polyposis in these patients. These findings highlight the importance of routine endoscopic screening in patients with FAP to detect and manage upper gastrointestinal lesions, particularly duodenal adenomas, which have a higher risk of dysplasia.

Influence of otitis media on the correlation between rectal and auditory canal temperatures.  In a noninterventional, controlled, single-blinded trial, 251 children were examined in a university hospital emergency department setting to study the influence of acute otitis media on the relationship between rectal and auditory canal temperatures. The accuracy of noninvasive temperature measurement methods, such as the use of infrared thermometers on the auditory canal, may be affected by various factors, including the presence of otitis media. This study aimed to evaluate the influence of acute otitis media on the correlation between rectal and auditory canal temperatures in children presenting to a university hospital emergency department. A total of 251 children were included in this controlled, single-blinded trial. The results showed that the presence of acute otitis media significantly decreased the correlation between rectal and auditory canal temperatures, suggesting that otitis media can affect the accuracy of noninvasive temperature measurements in children. These findings emphasize the importance of considering potential factors that may impact temperature measurement accuracy in clinical practice.

Systolic Hypertension of the Elderly Program (SHEP).  Part 10: Analysis. The Systolic Hypertension of the Elderly Program (SHEP) was a multicenter randomized controlled trial designed to assess the efficacy of antihypertensive drug therapy in reducing the risk of stroke in elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension. A total of 4,736 participants were enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either active treatment with chlorthalidone-based therapy or placebo. The mean follow-up period was 4.5 years. The analysis of the trial data revealed a significant reduction in the incidence of stroke in the active treatment group compared to the placebo group (relative risk reduction of 36%). Additionally, there were also significant reductions in the rates of major cardiovascular events and all-cause mortality in the active treatment group. The SHEP trial supports the use of antihypertensive drug therapy in elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension to reduce the risk of stroke and other cardiovascular events.

Chronic arterial occlusion with PGE1-resistant skin lesions treated by glycosaminoglycan compound--case reports. Chronic arterial occlusion can lead to various complications, including skin lesions that are resistant to treatment with prostaglandin E1 (PGE1). This case report highlights the successful management of PGE1-resistant skin lesions in two patients with chronic arterial occlusion using a glycosaminoglycan compound.

The first patient presented with multiple painful skin ulcers and non-healing wounds on the lower extremities. Despite previous treatment with PGE1, the skin lesions remained resistant and showed no signs of improvement. A glycosaminoglycan compound, administered topically, was found to significantly accelerate wound healing and alleviate pain.

In the second case, a patient with chronic arterial occlusion experienced severe skin necrosis in the foot that was unresponsive to PGE1 therapy. The application of the glycosaminoglycan compound promoted granulation tissue formation and facilitated wound closure.

These cases demonstrate the potential benefits of using a glycosaminoglycan compound as an adjunctive therapy for PGE1-resistant skin lesions associated with chronic arterial occlusion. Further research is warranted to explore the mechanisms of action and efficacy of this treatment approach.

Recurrence rate after discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy in alveolar echinococcosis (preliminary results).  The recurrence rate was investigated in 19 patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuation of a long-term therapy with mebendazole (average treatment 4. The aim of this study was to determine the recurrence rate of alveolar echinococcosis in patients who had discontinued long-term mebendazole therapy. Nineteen patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis were included in the study. The average duration of mebendazole treatment was 4.5 years. Patients were followed up for a mean duration of 2.5 years after discontinuation of mebendazole. Recurrence of alveolar echinococcosis was assessed using imaging modalities such as ultrasound and computed tomography. Preliminary results showed that 4 out of the 19 patients experienced recurrence of alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuing mebendazole therapy. This corresponds to a recurrence rate of 21.1%. These findings suggest that the presence of residual parasites or the inability of mebendazole to completely eradicate the infection may contribute to the recurrence of alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuation of long-term therapy. Further research with a larger sample size and longer follow-up duration is needed to confirm these preliminary results.

Life-threatening complications during anaesthesia in a patient with a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):241] A 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt is described. We present a case of a 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt and subsequently experienced life-threatening complications during anesthesia due to pulmonary hypertension. The patient developed severe hypoxemia and hemodynamic instability, requiring immediate intervention and resuscitation. Despite the precarious nature of the situation, successful management was achieved through prompt recognition and appropriate therapeutic strategies. This case highlights the importance of careful monitoring and tailored anesthesia management in patients with ventriculo-atrial shunts and pulmonary hypertension to minimize the risk of perioperative complications.

Increase in native valve endocarditis caused by coagulase negative staphylococci: an Anglo-French clinical and microbiological study. Native valve endocarditis caused by coagulase negative staphylococci (CoNS) is an emerging clinical concern. This study aimed to investigate the increasing prevalence of CoNS-related native valve endocarditis and compare the clinical and microbiological characteristics between Anglo and French populations.

A retrospective analysis of patients diagnosed with native valve endocarditis between 2005 and 2015 was conducted in two major medical centers in England and France. Data on demographics, clinical presentation, predisposing factors, microbiological profiles, and outcomes were collected.

Among 287 cases of native valve endocarditis, 74 (25.8%) were caused by CoNS, representing a significant increase compared to previous studies. The Anglo population demonstrated a higher proportion of CoNS-related cases compared to the French population (36.5% vs. 15.7%, p < 0.001). Patients with CoNS-related endocarditis were older, had more comorbidities, and a higher prevalence of intravenous drug use.

Microbiological analyses revealed different susceptibility patterns of CoNS isolates between the two populations, with a higher prevalence of methicillin resistance among Anglo patients. In-hospital mortality rates did not significantly differ between the two groups.

The increasing prevalence of CoNS-related native valve endocarditis suggests the need for heightened awareness and appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy. Understanding the differences in clinical and microbiological characteristics between populations may aid in tailoring treatment strategies and improving patient outcomes.

Endoscopic laser surgery.  A single-center comprehensive experience. Endoscopic laser surgery has become a widely utilized technique for various medical interventions. This study presents a comprehensive experience of a single-center in performing endoscopic laser surgery. The aim of the study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this technique in a diverse range of medical conditions. A retrospective analysis of all patients who underwent endoscopic laser surgery at the center between a specified period was conducted. Data regarding patient demographics, indications for surgery, intraoperative findings, surgical outcomes, complications, and follow-up were analyzed. The results showed that endoscopic laser surgery was successfully performed in a variety of medical conditions including urologic, gynecologic, and gastrointestinal diseases. The procedure demonstrated high efficacy with minimal intraoperative complications. However, post-operative complications such as bleeding and infection were identified, indicating the need for proper patient selection and post-operative care. Overall, the comprehensive experience presented in this study highlights the potential of endoscopic laser surgery as a valuable technique in minimally invasive surgery.

T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. In this study, the authors aimed to investigate T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in the peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis (AH). Peripheral blood samples were obtained from 30 patients with AH and 20 healthy controls. Flow cytometry analysis was used to determine the percentages and absolute numbers of T cell subsets, including cytotoxic T cells (Tc), helper T cells (Th), suppressor T cells (Ts), and activated T cells (Tsi), as well as IL2 receptor-bearing cells. The results showed that patients with AH had significantly lower percentages and absolute numbers of Tc, Th, Ts, and Tsi compared to the control group (p < 0.05). Furthermore, IL2 receptor-bearing cells were significantly increased in AH patients compared to controls (p < 0.05). These findings suggest an altered immune response and dysfunction of T cell subsets in patients with AH, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of the disease.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia in the Chiari type II malformation. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a common clinical finding in patients with Chiari type II malformation. This study aimed to investigate the characteristics and clinical significance of INO in this population. A total of 42 patients with Chiari type II malformation were included in the study. Among them, 26 (61.9%) patients presented with INO. The mean age at the time of diagnosis was 5.9 years. The most common manifestation of INO was bilateral adduction deficit, followed by abducting nystagmus. MRI showed that the ponto-mesencephalic junction was compressed and displaced posteriorly in all INO patients. In conclusion, INO is a common neurological finding in patients with Chiari type II malformation and may serve as an important diagnostic clue. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential treatment options for INO in this population.

Xeroderma pigmentosum: review and report of a case. Xeroderma pigmentosum is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in DNA repair mechanisms, leading to extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and an increased risk of developing skin cancers. This article provides a comprehensive review of xeroderma pigmentosum, including its clinical features, pathogenesis, and management strategies. Additionally, a case report of a 16-year-old male patient with xeroderma pigmentosum is presented. The patient exhibited classical cutaneous findings, such as exaggerated freckling, telangiectasias, and multiple skin cancers. Various treatment modalities, including strict photoprotection, regular skin surveillance, and surgical excision of malignancies, were employed to manage the patient's condition. Despite adherence to preventive measures, the patient experienced recurrent skin cancers. This case highlights the challenges associated with the management of xeroderma pigmentosum and emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and comprehensive care in improving patient outcomes. Further research is needed to explore novel therapeutic approaches for this rare and debilitating disorder.

Radiation therapy for intraductal carcinoma.  Is it an equal alternative? Of 213 consecutive patients with intraductal carcinoma, 109 were selectively treated with mastectomy and 104 with radiation therapy. The purpose of this study was to compare the efficacy of mastectomy and radiation therapy as treatment options for intraductal carcinoma. A total of 213 consecutive patients with intraductal carcinoma were included in the study, with 109 patients undergoing mastectomy and 104 patients receiving radiation therapy. 

The median follow-up time was 5 years. The results showed that the overall survival rate at 5 years was 95% for the mastectomy group and 92% for the radiation therapy group (p=0.56). The local recurrence rate was 2% in the mastectomy group and 4% in the radiation therapy group (p=0.34). 

There were no significant differences in terms of distant metastasis or contralateral breast cancer between the two treatment groups. The cosmetic outcome was evaluated as excellent or good in 95% of the mastectomy group and 87% of the radiation therapy group (p=0.02). 

In conclusion, both mastectomy and radiation therapy are viable treatment options for intraductal carcinoma. While mastectomy may provide a better cosmetic outcome, radiation therapy can be considered an equal alternative in terms of overall survival and local recurrence rates. Further studies with longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings.

Antibiotic pharmacokinetics in surgery Pharmacokinetics is the study of variables that affect drug concentrations at the effector site. Understanding the pharmacokinetics of antibiotics in surgical patients is crucial for ensuring optimal dosing regimens and therapeutic outcomes. This review examines the factors that can influence antibiotic concentrations at the site of infection, including absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination. Surgical procedures can alter drug absorption and distribution, leading to unpredictable drug concentrations in tissues. Furthermore, changes in organ function and blood flow during surgery can affect drug metabolism and elimination. This knowledge is particularly important for selecting appropriate antibiotic regimens, considering drug-drug interactions, and adjusting doses based on individual patient characteristics. Ultimately, a comprehensive understanding of antibiotic pharmacokinetics in surgical patients can help optimize treatment efficacy and minimize the risk of adverse events, supporting improved patient outcomes.

The use of molecular probes to distinguish new primary tumors from recurrent tumors in gynecologic malignancies. The accurate identification of primary tumors versus recurrent tumors is critical in the management of gynecologic malignancies. Molecular probes have emerged as a promising tool for this purpose, allowing for the detection of specific genetic alterations that can differentiate between primary and recurrent tumors. This review explores the current knowledge on the use of molecular probes in gynecologic malignancies, focusing on their application in distinguishing new primary tumors from recurrent tumors. Various molecular markers, including mutations, gene amplifications, and chromosomal aberrations, have been identified and validated as potential targets for molecular probe-based detection. The ability to accurately discriminate between primary and recurrent tumors could have significant implications for treatment decisions, prognosis assessment, and patient outcomes in gynecologic malignancies. Further research is warranted to optimize the use of molecular probes in clinical practice.

Reinforcement of incontinent stools in the treatment of encopresis. Encopresis, a condition characterized by incontinent stools, can have a significant impact on a patient's quality of life. Traditional treatment methods for encopresis often focus on improving bowel habits and addressing underlying constipation. However, in some cases, reinforcement techniques may be necessary to facilitate successful treatment outcomes. In this study, we examined the effectiveness of reinforcing incontinent stools as part of the treatment for encopresis. Our results demonstrate that incorporating reinforcement techniques led to a significant reduction in the frequency and severity of incontinent stools. Additionally, patients reported improved self-esteem and a greater sense of control over their bowel movements. These findings highlight the importance of considering reinforcement approaches as part of a comprehensive treatment plan for encopresis.

Articulatory impairment associated with tardive dyskinesia. Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a movement disorder characterized by abnormal, involuntary, repetitive movements. This study aimed to investigate the presence and characteristics of articulatory impairment in patients with TD. Forty-two patients with TD and 30 healthy controls were included. Articulatory impairment was assessed using the Dysarthria Examination for Tardive Dyskinesia (DETD) and compared between the two groups. The results showed that patients with TD had significantly higher scores on the DETD compared to the control group, indicating a presence of articulatory impairment. The most commonly affected articulatory features were imprecise consonants and distorted vowels. These findings highlight the need for early detection and management of articulatory impairment in patients with TD to improve communication and quality of life.

Comparison of pulse oximeters: accuracy at low arterial pressure in volunteers. Pulse oximeters are widely used to measure arterial oxygen saturation (SpO2) in clinical settings. However, their accuracy at low arterial pressure remains uncertain. This study aimed to compare the accuracy of different pulse oximeters at low arterial pressure in volunteers. Forty healthy volunteers were enrolled, and low arterial pressure was induced using controlled hypotension. Three different pulse oximeters were used to measure SpO2 at different low arterial pressure levels. The results showed that all three pulse oximeters underestimated SpO2 at low arterial pressure. The degree of underestimation varied among the different devices, with some being more accurate than others. These findings suggest that caution should be exercised when interpreting SpO2 measurements at low arterial pressure, as the accuracy of pulse oximeters may be compromised in such situations.

Ovarian granulosa-stromal cell tumors are characterized by trisomy 12. Ovarian granulosa-stromal cell tumors (OGSCTs) are rare neoplasms that exhibit various genetic abnormalities. One notable genetic alteration observed in these tumors is trisomy 12. Trisomy 12 refers to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 12 in the tumor cells. This genetic abnormality has been consistently identified in OGSCTs and is considered a hallmark of these tumors. The role of trisomy 12 in the pathogenesis of OGSCTs is not fully understood but is believed to contribute to the dysregulated cell proliferation and tumor development observed in these tumors. Molecular studies exploring the specific genes and pathways affected by trisomy 12 in OGSCTs may provide valuable insights into the underlying mechanisms of tumor formation and potentially identify therapeutic targets for the management of this rare ovarian neoplasm.

Pharmacodynamics in cancer therapy. Cancer therapy has evolved significantly with the introduction of targeted therapies that directly interfere with specific molecular pathways involved in tumor growth and progression. Pharmacodynamics, the study of drug effects and their mechanisms of action, plays a crucial role in the development and optimization of these therapies. By understanding the pharmacodynamics of anticancer drugs, clinicians can personalize treatment regimens and improve patient outcomes. In this review, we discuss the principles of pharmacodynamics in cancer therapy, highlighting the importance of drug-target interaction, dose-response relationships, and biomarker identification. We also explore the challenges faced in predicting and assessing drug efficacy, as well as strategies to overcome drug resistance. Overall, a comprehensive understanding of pharmacodynamics in cancer therapy is essential for guiding drug selection, dose optimization, and combination therapy approaches to maximize treatment efficacy and minimize toxicity for patients diagnosed with cancer.

Delayed presentation of intrapericardial diaphragmatic hernia, an unusual cause of colon obstruction. Intrapericardial diaphragmatic hernia (IPDH) is an extremely rare condition, with only a few reported cases to date. We present a case of a 60-year-old male who presented with features of acute abdomen and was found to have a delayed presentation of IPDH causing colonic obstruction. The patient had a history of blunt chest trauma four years prior, which was initially managed conservatively. However, he developed progressive dyspnea and abdominal distension in the recent months. Imaging studies revealed a herniated colon into the pericardial cavity through a diaphragmatic defect. Surgical exploration confirmed the diagnosis and repair was successfully performed. This case highlights the importance of considering IPDH as a differential diagnosis in patients with previous history of chest trauma presenting with vague abdominal symptoms.

Polyneuropathy, ophthalmoplegia, leukoencephalopathy, and intestinal pseudo-obstruction: POLIP syndrome. POLIP syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by the combination of polyneuropathy, ophthalmoplegia, leukoencephalopathy, and intestinal pseudo-obstruction. We present a case report of a middle-aged male patient who presented with progressive muscle weakness, double vision, cognitive decline, and recurrent episodes of vomiting and abdominal pain. Neurological examination revealed bilateral external ophthalmoplegia and symmetric distal muscle weakness. Laboratory investigations showed elevated lactate and pyruvate levels in cerebrospinal fluid, confirming mitochondrial dysfunction. Brain magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated white matter abnormalities consistent with leukoencephalopathy. Gastrointestinal studies revealed impaired bowel motility and pseudo-obstruction. Genetic testing confirmed a heterozygous mutation in the POLG gene, which encodes for the catalytic subunit of mitochondrial DNA polymerase . This case highlights the importance of considering POLIP syndrome in patients with a combination of peripheral neuropathy, ophthalmoplegia, leukoencephalopathy, and gastrointestinal dysfunction. Early recognition and diagnosis are crucial for appropriate management and genetic counseling. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and develop targeted therapies for this rare syndrome.

A case of classical mycosis fungoides associated with human T-cell lymphotropic virus type I. Classical mycosis fungoides (MF) is a rare, chronic lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by cutaneous involvement. In this case report, we present a 46-year-old male patient with classical MF who tested positive for human T-cell lymphotropic virus type I (HTLV-I). HTLV-I is a retrovirus associated with adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) and HTLV-I-associated myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP). The diagnosis of classical MF with HTLV-I infection was confirmed based on histological examination, immunohistochemistry, and detection of HTLV-I proviral DNA. The patient had no clinical features of ATLL or HAM/TSP. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of classical MF associated with HTLV-I infection. This case highlights the importance of considering HTLV-I in the differential diagnosis of classical MF, particularly in endemic areas. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the potential role of HTLV-I in the pathogenesis of MF.

Indigenous cases of Lyme disease diagnosed in North Carolina. Lyme disease is typically associated with tick bites and is commonly diagnosed in regions with high tick populations. However, in recent years, indigenous cases of Lyme disease have been reported in areas where ticks are not prevalent. We report on a cluster of 12 cases of Lyme disease diagnosed in North Carolina, a region not traditionally considered endemic for Lyme disease. Patients presented with typical symptoms such as erythema migrans, fever, headache, and fatigue. Laboratory testing confirmed the presence of Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease, in all cases. Further investigation revealed possible exposure to infected ticks during travel to endemic regions or exposure to infected animals. This highlights the importance of considering Lyme disease in the differential diagnosis, even in regions with lower tick populations, to ensure timely diagnosis and appropriate management.

Photosensitive epilepsies and photoconvulsive responses in Arabs. Photosensitive epilepsies and photoconvulsive responses are neurologic disorders characterized by abnormal brain responses to specific visual stimuli, such as flickering lights or patterns. These conditions have been reported to occur more frequently in certain ethnic groups, including Arabs. This abstract presents a review of the literature on the prevalence, clinical features, and management of photosensitive epilepsies and photoconvulsive responses in Arabs. The exact mechanisms underlying these conditions in this population are not well understood, but genetic factors are believed to play a significant role. Management strategies include avoiding triggering stimuli, using specific anti-epileptic medications, and, in severe cases, considering surgical interventions. Awareness of these conditions and their specific features in the Arab population is important for diagnosis and appropriate management. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal treatment approaches for photosensitive epilepsies and photoconvulsive responses in this ethnic group.

Embryo reduction in multifetal pregnancies after infertility therapy: obstetrical risks and perinatal benefits are related to operative strategy.  To assess the benefits that can be expected from embryo reduction of multiple pregnancies after infertility therapy, we report 58 consecutive cases of selective termination using either a transcervical or a transabdominal approach. The study aimed to evaluate the obstetrical risks and perinatal benefits associated with embryo reduction in multifetal pregnancies after infertility therapy. A total of 58 cases of selective termination were analyzed, using either a transcervical or a transabdominal approach. The results showed that both techniques were effective in reducing the number of fetuses in multiple pregnancies. Obstetrical risks, such as preterm labor and premature rupture of membranes, were observed in both groups, with no significant differences between the two approaches. However, the transabdominal approach was associated with a higher rate of complications, including placental abruption and uterine atony. Despite these risks, the perinatal outcomes were favorable, with a high rate of healthy live births. These findings suggest that embryo reduction can be a beneficial strategy in managing multifetal pregnancies after infertility therapy, but careful consideration of the operative approach is crucial to minimize complications.

Management decisions in laryngeal carcinoma in situ. Laryngeal carcinoma in situ (CIS) poses management challenges due to its potential for progression to invasive carcinoma. This study aims to evaluate the outcomes and decision-making process in the management of laryngeal CIS. A retrospective analysis of patients diagnosed with laryngeal CIS between 2010 and 2018 was conducted. Treatment strategies included endoscopic resection, laser therapy, and radiotherapy. Follow-up evaluations were performed to assess recurrence rates and disease progression. Out of the 120 included patients, 85 underwent endoscopic resection, 25 received laser therapy, and 10 underwent radiotherapy. The overall recurrence rate was 15%, with a median time to recurrence of 18 months. Disease progression occurred in 25% of cases, primarily within the first 2 years. Factors associated with higher risk of recurrence and progression included multifocal lesions and involvement of the anterior commissure. In conclusion, a tailored approach incorporating endoscopic resection and adjuvant therapy is crucial in the management of laryngeal CIS. Close surveillance is warranted, particularly during the first 2 years, to detect any signs of disease progression.

Third ventricle cavernous angioma: report of two cases. Cavernous angiomas located in the third ventricle are rare vascular malformations. We report two cases of third ventricle cavernous angioma, diagnosed based on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings and confirmed by histopathological examination after surgical resection. In both cases, the patients presented with headaches, visual disturbances, and neurological deficits. MRI showed well-defined, round lesions with hypointense areas surrounded by a hyperintense rim on T2-weighted images. Digital subtraction angiography revealed vascular lesions with calcifications. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of cavernous angioma, characterized by thin-walled vascular channels with intraluminal thrombi and hemosiderin deposition. These cases highlight the importance of MRI in the diagnosis and management of third ventricle cavernous angiomas.

Psychological characteristics of children with Shwachman syndrome. Shwachman syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by pancreatic dysfunction, skeletal abnormalities, and bone marrow failure. While physical manifestations of the syndrome have been well-documented, little is known about the psychological characteristics of affected individuals, particularly children. This study aimed to explore the psychological profiles of children with Shwachman syndrome and identify any associated psychiatric symptoms. Twenty children diagnosed with Shwachman syndrome between the ages of 5 and 12 years underwent comprehensive psychological assessments using standardized measures. Results revealed a higher prevalence of emotional and behavioral difficulties compared to normative data. Specifically, children with Shwachman syndrome demonstrated elevated rates of anxiety, depression, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, and social communication difficulties. These findings highlight the importance of comprehensive multidisciplinary care for children with Shwachman syndrome, including regular psychological assessment and appropriate interventions to support their emotional and behavioral well-being. Greater awareness of the psychological impact of Shwachman syndrome can contribute to improved quality of life and overall management of affected individuals.

Murine erythroleukemia cell line GM979 contains factors that can activate silent chromosomal human gamma-globin genes. Gamma-globin genes play a crucial role in the production of fetal hemoglobin, which is important for the transport of oxygen during embryonic development. Silencing of these genes in adult humans is a barrier to the potential use of fetal hemoglobin for treating hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell disease and beta-thalassemia. In this study, we investigated the potential of the murine erythroleukemia cell line GM979 to activate silent chromosomal human gamma-globin genes. We found that conditioned media from GM979 cells contained factors that could induce gamma-globin expression in primary human erythroid progenitor cells derived from healthy donors. Furthermore, we demonstrated that treatment with this conditioned media resulted in increased gamma-globin mRNA levels and gamma-globin protein expression. Our findings suggest that the factors present in the GM979 cell line could be utilized to induce gamma-globin gene activation in therapeutic approaches aimed at enhancing fetal hemoglobin production in patients with hemoglobinopathies.

Access to cancer prevention, detection, and treatment. Cancer is a major global health concern, and access to prevention, detection, and treatment strategies is crucial in reducing the burden of this disease. This abstract aims to highlight the importance of ensuring equitable access to these interventions.

Prevention strategies, such as vaccination against human papillomavirus and hepatitis B, as well as lifestyle modifications, have significantly contributed to reducing the incidence of certain cancers. However, disparities in access to these preventive measures exist, especially in low-income countries.

Early detection through screening programs can greatly improve cancer outcomes by enabling early treatment initiation. However, barriers such as lack of infrastructure, limited awareness, and financial constraints impede access to screening for many individuals, particularly those in underserved populations.

Access to effective cancer treatments, including surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapies, and immunotherapy, is crucial for improving survival rates. However, disparities in access to these treatments exist globally, with limited availability of essential drugs and high treatment costs posing significant barriers to care.

Urgent action is needed to address these inequities in access to cancer prevention, detection, and treatment. This includes implementing comprehensive cancer control programs, improving healthcare infrastructure and workforce capacity, increasing financial protection mechanisms, and promoting international collaborations to ensure the equitable availability of cancer interventions for all individuals, regardless of their socioeconomic status or geographical location. Addressing these challenges is key to achieving global cancer control goals and reducing the global burden of this devastating disease.

Point mutation in the exoplasmic domain of the erythropoietin receptor resulting in hormone-independent activation and tumorigenicity. Mutations in the erythropoietin receptor (EPOR) have been identified in several hematological malignancies, contributing to aberrant signaling and disease progression. Here, we report a novel point mutation in the exoplasmic domain of the EPOR, resulting in hormone-independent activation and tumorigenicity. This mutation, identified in a patient with refractory anemia, led to constitutive activation of downstream signaling pathways, including JAK2/STAT5 and PI3K/AKT. Functional studies revealed increased cell proliferation, survival, and enhanced erythroid differentiation in cells expressing the mutant receptor compared to wild type. In vivo xenograft studies demonstrated tumor formation in immunocompromised mice injected with cells expressing the mutant receptor. Furthermore, pharmacological inhibition of JAK2 or AKT signaling blocked the proliferation and survival of cells harboring the mutant EPOR. Our findings highlight the significance of this novel EPOR mutation in promoting hormone-independent activation and tumorigenicity in hematological malignancies and suggest potential therapeutic strategies targeting JAK2 and AKT signaling for patients with refractory anemia harboring this mutation.

How selective is selective posterior rhizotomy? Although selective posterior rhizotomy has become an increasingly utilized surgical treatment for spasticity, the procedure is unstandardized and is performed differently at various medical centers. Selective posterior rhizotomy (SPR) has gained popularity as a surgical intervention for the management of spasticity. However, there is a lack of standardization in the procedure, and variations exist among different medical centers. This article aims to provide a comprehensive review of the current literature pertaining to the selectivity of SPR. Several studies have reported varying degrees of selectivity achieved with SPR, ranging from highly selective to non-selective. Factors influencing selectivity include the surgical technique, surgeon experience, and patient characteristics. Although the primary objective of SPR is to target and selectively ablate the hyperactive nerve fibers, concerns regarding the collateral damage to adjacent neural structures and the potential for functional deficits remain. Further research is needed to elucidate the optimal technique and parameters for achieving selectivity in SPR, ensuring the balance between clinical effectiveness and minimizing adverse outcomes. Standardization of SPR procedures can promote better comparability and reproducibility of outcomes among different medical centers.

An objective score to predict upper tract deterioration in myelodysplasia.  Bladder dysfunction in myelodysplasia may present a significant hazard to the upper tract and a threat to kidney function. In patients with myelodysplasia, the presence of bladder dysfunction can lead to upper tract deterioration and potential kidney dysfunction. This study aimed to develop an objective score that can predict the likelihood of upper tract deterioration in this population. A total of 78 patients with myelodysplasia were included in the study and followed up for a mean duration of 3 years. Various clinical, urodynamic, and radiological parameters were assessed to determine their predictive value. The developed objective score included factors such as age, bladder capacity, maximum detrusor pressure, and presence of upper tract dilation. This score demonstrated good discriminatory power and can serve as a useful tool for identifying patients at high risk for upper tract deterioration, allowing for early intervention to preserve kidney function.

Cerebrospinal fluid eicosanoid levels: endogenous PGD2 and LTC4 synthesis by antigen-presenting cells that migrate to the central nervous system. This study aimed to investigate the levels of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) eicosanoids, particularly prostaglandin D2 (PGD2) and leukotriene C4 (LTC4), and their association with antigen-presenting cells (APCs) migration to the central nervous system (CNS). CSF samples were collected from patients with various neurological disorders, and eicosanoid levels were measured using enzyme immunoassays. Results showed that endogenous synthesis of PGD2 and LTC4 occurred within the CNS by APCs. The levels of these eicosanoids correlated positively with the presence of migrating APCs in the CSF. These findings imply that local synthesis of eicosanoids by APCs within the CNS may play a role in immune modulation and neuroinflammatory processes. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the specific mechanisms involved.

Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract.  Report of a case and literature review. Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract is an extremely rare entity, with only a few cases reported in the literature. We report a case of a 62-year-old male who presented with persistent cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the bronchus of the right lower lobe. Bronchoscopy with biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of primary malignant melanoma. The patient underwent a right pneumonectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy. Histopathological examination revealed a malignant melanoma with no evidence of metastasis. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and remains disease-free at the 2-year follow-up. We also provide a comprehensive review of the literature on primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract, discussing its clinical presentation, diagnosis, treatment options, and prognosis. Awareness of this rare entity is crucial for early detection and appropriate management.

Solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants in the thyroid. The ultimobranchial body (UBB) is an embryonic structure located in the thyroid gland and is involved in the development of the parafollicular C-cells. Solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants (UBRs) in the thyroid are rare and their clinical significance is not well understood. In this study, we report three cases of UBRs in the thyroid gland, diagnosed using histopathological examination. Two cases presented as solid UBRs, while one case presented as a cystic UBR. All cases were incidentally discovered on imaging studies performed for unrelated reasons. The patients did not have any symptoms related to the UBRs, and no further treatment was necessary. The histological examination showed characteristic features of UBRs, including nests or cords of cells with clear or eosinophilic cytoplasm, surrounded by fibrovascular septa. These cases highlight the importance of considering UBRs as a potential differential diagnosis in thyroid nodules and cysts, especially when presenting as incidental findings on imaging studies. Further studies are required to determine the clinical significance and management of UBRs in the thyroid gland.

New active analogues of vitamin D with low calcemic activity. Vitamin D analogues with low calcemic activity have been developed in order to minimize the adverse effects associated with high levels of circulating calcium. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of new active analogues of vitamin D in terms of their therapeutic potential and safety profile. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who received treatment with these novel analogues. Preliminary results indicate that the analogues exhibit promising therapeutic effects, including their ability to regulate cell growth and differentiation. Furthermore, the incidence of hypercalcemia, a common complication of vitamin D therapy, was significantly reduced with the use of these low calcemic analogues. Continued investigation is warranted to determine the long-term clinical outcomes and potential applications of these novel vitamin D analogues.

Meropenem pharmacokinetics and penetration into an inflammatory exudate.  The pharmacokinetics and penetration into a cantharidine-induced inflammatory exudate of meropenem was studied in six volunteers following a single 1-g intravenous dose. The study aimed to evaluate the pharmacokinetics and penetration of meropenem into an inflammatory exudate induced by cantharidine. Six healthy volunteers received a single intravenous dose of 1 g of meropenem. Blood samples were collected at various time points, and inflammatory exudate fluid was drained from the exudate chamber. Meropenem concentrations in both blood and exudate fluid were measured using a validated HPLC assay. The pharmacokinetic parameters were calculated using non-compartmental analysis. The results demonstrated that meropenem exhibited rapid distribution and elimination kinetics in the blood. Furthermore, it was shown that meropenem rapidly penetrated into the inflammatory exudate, with concentrations exceeding the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) for susceptible pathogens. These findings suggest that meropenem has the potential to effectively treat infections associated with inflammatory exudates.

Granulomatous prostatitis and poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma. Granulomatous prostatitis is a rare benign inflammatory condition of the prostate that can mimic prostate cancer clinically and histologically.
