The coexistence of granulomatous prostatitis with prostate carcinoma is extremely rare, with only a few cases reported in the literature. We present a case of a 65-year-old male who underwent a transurethral resection of the prostate for urinary obstruction. Histopathological examination revealed coexistence of granulomatous prostatitis and poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma. The granulomatous inflammation showed typical features with noncaseating granulomas surrounded by lymphocytes and histiocytes. The prostate carcinoma showed aggressive features with high-grade cytologic atypia, nuclear pleomorphism, and extensive lymphovascular invasion. Immunohistochemical staining revealed positivity for prostate-specific antigen and negative staining for CD68 in the carcinoma cells, confirming their malignant nature. This case highlights the importance of recognizing the coexistence of granulomatous prostatitis and prostate carcinoma, as the two entities can have overlapping clinical and histological features. Proper diagnosis and management of these cases are crucial to optimize patient outcomes.

Multiple gunshot wounds of the head: an anthropological view.  A decomposed body was judged at the scene to have two gunshot wounds of the thorax and three of the head. This study presents a unique anthropological perspective on a case involving multiple gunshot wounds of the head. The remains of a decomposed body were examined, and a total of three gunshot wounds were identified in the head region. Additionally, two gunshot wounds were observed in the thorax. The aim of this study was to analyze the characteristics and patterns of these gunshot wounds to aid in the forensic investigation. Detailed documentation of the wounds, including their locations, sizes, and depths, was carried out. The findings from this case highlight the importance of forensic anthropology in establishing the cause and manner of death in cases involving multiple gunshot wounds.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory infections in young children from Thailand. Acute respiratory infections (ARI) are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in young children worldwide. This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology of ARI in young children from Thailand. A prospective cohort study was conducted, including children aged 0-5 years who presented with symptoms of ARI to primary care clinics in a rural area of Thailand. Data on patient demographics, clinical characteristics, and laboratory results were collected. The incidence rate of ARI was estimated using person-time methods. A total of 500 children were included in the study, with a mean age of 2.5 years. The overall incidence rate of ARI was 20.6 cases per 100 person-years. The highest incidence rate was observed in children aged 0-1 year (40.8 cases per 100 person-years). Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) was the most common viral pathogen detected, accounting for 54.2% of cases. Other common pathogens included influenza viruses, rhinovirus, and human metapneumovirus. The majority of ARI cases were mild to moderate in severity, with only a small proportion requiring hospitalization. These findings provide valuable insights into the epidemiology of ARI in young children from Thailand and can aid in the development of targeted prevention and control strategies.

Arterial responses during migraine headache. Migraine headache is a complex neurological disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe head pain. The pathophysiology of migraine is not completely understood, but it is believed to involve abnormal arterial responses in the brain. This study aimed to investigate the changes in arterial responses during a migraine headache episode. A total of 20 patients with diagnosed migraine were enrolled, and their arterial responses were assessed using transcranial Doppler ultrasound. The results showed significant alterations in arterial blood flow velocity and vasomotor reactivity during the headache period compared to the interictal period. These findings suggest that there is a dynamic vasoconstriction and vasodilation of cerebral arteries during a migraine headache, highlighting the importance of targeting these arterial responses in the management and treatment of migraines. Further research is warranted to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications.

Expression of P-glycoprotein in adult T-cell leukemia cells. Adult T-cell leukemia (ATL) is a highly aggressive form of leukemia associated with human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) infection. P-glycoprotein (P-gp) is an efflux pump that is overexpressed in many cancer cells and is associated with multidrug resistance. This study aimed to investigate the expression of P-gp in ATL cells and its impact on drug resistance. 

Using flow cytometry analysis, we found that P-gp was overexpressed in ATL cells compared to normal T cells. Moreover, immunofluorescence staining confirmed the localization of P-gp on the plasma membrane of ATL cells. To assess the functional role of P-gp in drug resistance, we performed drug efflux assays using P-gp inhibitors. Our results demonstrated that inhibition of P-gp enhanced the sensitivity of ATL cells to chemotherapeutic agents.

In conclusion, our findings indicate that P-gp is expressed in ATL cells and contributes to drug resistance. Targeting P-gp may represent a potential therapeutic strategy to overcome multidrug resistance in ATL patients.

Effect of indomethacin on the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis in rabbits. This study aimed to investigate the effect of indomethacin on the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis in rabbits. Thirty rabbits were randomly divided into three groups: control, meningitis, and meningitis plus indomethacin. Indomethacin was administered intraperitoneally to the rabbits in the latter group. The results showed that indomethacin treatment significantly reduced cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) levels of proinflammatory cytokines and inflammatory cells in the meningitis group compared to the control and meningitis-only groups. Furthermore, indomethacin-treated rabbits exhibited improved blood-brain barrier integrity, reduced brain edema, and decreased mortality rate compared to the meningitis-only group. Therefore, indomethacin may have a potential therapeutic role in the management of meningitis.

Anti-Kveim monoclonal antibody.  New monoclonal antibody reacting to epithelioid cells in sarcoid granulomas. Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic granulomatous disease characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas. The diagnosis of sarcoidosis relies on clinical and histopathological evidence, with the Kveim test historically used as a confirmatory tool. Here, we present a case report of a patient with biopsy-proven sarcoidosis who underwent Kveim testing using a novel anti-Kveim monoclonal antibody. The antibody specifically recognized epithelioid cells within sarcoid granulomas and showed a high sensitivity and specificity in our patient. This new monoclonal antibody provides a more reliable and standardized method for diagnosing sarcoidosis, as it eliminates the need for the preparation and administration of the traditional Kveim test material. Additionally, it allows for easier interpretation of results, reducing inter-observer variability. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of this antibody in larger cohorts of sarcoidosis patients, but our findings suggest that it could be a valuable tool in the diagnosis and monitoring of sarcoidosis.

Speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing before and after orthognathic surgery.  Articulation, voice, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function were examined in 34 patients before and 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after orthognathic surgery. In this study, we evaluated the effects of orthognathic surgery on speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing in 34 patients. Assessments were conducted before surgery and at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months postoperatively. 

Results revealed significant improvements in articulation and speech quality at all follow-up time points. Voice quality and resonance also showed gradual improvements over the 12-month period. Additionally, hearing sensitivity remained stable throughout the follow-up period, suggesting that orthognathic surgery did not negatively impact auditory function. Middle ear function showed some variability, with a slight decline immediately after surgery but subsequent improvement over time. 

These findings indicate that orthognathic surgery can lead to positive outcomes in speech and velopharyngeal function. Patients can expect improvements in articulation, voice quality, and resonance, while hearing sensitivity remains unchanged. Further research is warranted to explore long-term effects and identify factors that may influence the outcomes of orthognathic surgery on speech and hearing.

Effect of hydrocele on testis and spermatogenesis. Hydrocele is a common condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid within the scrotum, resulting in swelling. This study aimed to investigate the impact of hydrocele on testis function and spermatogenesis. A retrospective analysis of 85 patients with hydrocele was conducted, evaluating the clinical findings and laboratory parameters. Testicular atrophy was observed in 30% of the patients, while impaired semen quality was noted in 45% of cases. Sperm count, motility, and morphology were significantly reduced in patients with hydrocele compared to controls. Moreover, the levels of serum testosterone and follicle-stimulating hormone were found to be significantly lower in hydrocele patients. These findings suggest that hydrocele can have a detrimental effect on testicular function and is associated with impaired spermatogenesis. Strategies for early detection and management of hydrocele should be considered to preserve testicular health and fertility.

Lymph node metastasis from papillary-follicular thyroid carcinoma in young patients.  A total of 117 patients under 20 years of age with papillary and/or follicular thyroid cancer presented to the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center between 1970 and 2006. Among them, 12 patients (10.3%) were found to have lymph node metastasis at initial presentation. The mean age at diagnosis was 16 years, with a slight female predominance. All patients underwent total thyroidectomy with or without cervical lymph node dissection. The histopathological examination revealed papillary carcinoma in 10 patients and follicular carcinoma in 2 patients. Of the 12 patients with lymph node metastasis, 7 had only microscopic involvement while 5 had macroscopic disease. The median number of positive lymph nodes was 2. During a mean follow-up period of 9.5 years, 5 patients experienced disease recurrence, 4 of whom had distant metastasis. The presence of lymph node metastasis at initial presentation was associated with a significantly higher risk of disease recurrence (p = 0.02). In conclusion, lymph node metastasis is not uncommon in young patients with papillary-follicular thyroid carcinoma, and it is associated with a higher risk of disease recurrence. Therefore, aggressive surgical management with lymph node dissection should be considered in these patients. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and to identify prognostic factors that may help guide treatment decisions.

Urogenital dysfunction after abdominoperineal resection for carcinoma of the rectum. Abdominoperineal resection (APR) for rectal carcinoma has been associated with urogenital dysfunction, including urinary and sexual impairments. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and risk factors for urogenital dysfunction in patients undergoing APR. A systematic review and meta-analysis of relevant studies were conducted. Pooled analysis showed that urinary dysfunction occurred in 42% of patients, with urinary incontinence being the most common complaint. Sexual dysfunction was reported in 63% of patients, with erectile dysfunction being the most prevalent issue in males. Risk factors for urogenital dysfunction included older age, male gender, neoadjuvant therapy, and extended resection. These findings emphasize the importance of preoperative counseling and postoperative urogenital rehabilitation strategies to optimize patient outcomes and quality of life following APR. Further research is needed to identify effective interventions and improve functional outcomes in this population.

A blood-liquid interface for prolonged extracorporeal oxygenation with excellent antithrombogenicity. Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a life-saving therapy for patients with severe acute respiratory distress. However, the need for continuous anticoagulation poses a risk of bleeding complications. A new blood-liquid interface for prolonged ECMO was developed, leveraging the excellent antithrombogenicity of a perfluorocarbon-based liquid. In an animal study comparing this interface to traditional gas-liquid interfaces, the perfluorocarbon-based interface showed significantly reduced thrombosis formation and improved oxygenation efficiency. Furthermore, the interface remained stable without degradation or gas exchange limitations for up to 48 hours. This novel blood-liquid interface holds promise for minimizing clotting complications and improving outcomes in patients requiring prolonged ECMO support.

A topographical relationship between Helicobacter pylori and gastritis: quantitative assessment of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa.  A topographical relationship between the number of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa and the histological severity of gastritis was studied in 902 pairs of biopsy specimens taken from 314 patients. The study aimed to investigate the topographical relationship between the quantity of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa and the severity of gastritis. A total of 902 biopsy specimens from 314 patients were analyzed. Histological assessment of gastritis was carried out, and the number of Helicobacter pylori was quantitatively measured in each specimen. The results revealed a significant correlation between the number of Helicobacter pylori and the severity of gastritis, with higher bacterial loads associated with more severe inflammation. Furthermore, a distinct topographical relationship was observed, with an increased Helicobacter pylori density in the antrum compared to the corpus of the stomach. These findings highlight the importance of assessing Helicobacter pylori burden in different regions of the gastric mucosa when evaluating gastritis.

Evaluation of argon laser surgery in children under 13 years of age. Argon laser surgery is a commonly used technique in various medical fields, but there is limited research on its efficacy and safety in children under 13 years of age. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications of argon laser surgery in this specific pediatric population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 54 children who underwent argon laser surgery for various indications. The surgical procedure was successfully performed in all cases, with satisfactory outcomes observed in terms of visual acuity improvement and reduction in symptoms. Complications were minimal, with only two cases experiencing transient postoperative corneal edema. These findings highlight the effectiveness and safety of argon laser surgery in children under 13 years of age and support its continued use in pediatric ophthalmology. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these results and explore long-term outcomes.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. Portal vein resection is a complex surgical procedure used in the treatment of various liver diseases. However, postoperative thrombosis of the portal vein remains a significant concern, leading to complications such as hepatic ischemia and liver failure. In an attempt to address this issue, a new antithrombogenic catheter has been developed for use during portal vein resection. This catheter is designed to prevent thrombus formation and maintain the patency of the portal vein.

A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this new catheter in 50 patients who underwent portal vein resection. The catheter was successfully placed in all patients and no intraoperative complications were observed. Postoperatively, none of the patients developed portal vein thrombosis during the follow-up period of 6 months. Additionally, there were no instances of catheter-related infections or thromboembolic events. These promising results suggest that the use of the new antithrombogenic catheter may significantly reduce the incidence of portal vein thrombosis following portal vein resection. However, further prospective studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings and establish the catheter as a standard tool in portal vein resection procedures.

Pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with pseudosarcomatous mural nodules.  A report of a case with immunohistochemical study. Pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is a rare neoplasm characterized by the presence of pseudosarcomatous mural nodules. We present a case of a 58-year-old female with a well-demarcated cystic tumor of the pancreas, measuring 6 cm in diameter. Microscopic examination revealed an epithelial lining composed of mucinous cells. Within the cyst wall, multiple nodular areas displayed spindle cell proliferation, reminiscent of sarcoma. Immunohistochemical studies were performed to further characterize the tumor. The pseudosarcomatous nodules showed positive staining for vimentin and negative staining for cytokeratin, consistent with a mesenchymal origin. The mucinous lining exhibited positive staining for mucin, CA19-9, and cytokeratin, indicative of its epithelial nature. These findings support the diagnosis of pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with pseudosarcomatous mural nodules. Awareness of this entity is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of patients with pancreatic cystic lesions. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying pathogenesis and potential prognostic implications of pseudosarcomatous mural nodules in this uncommon tumor.

Argon green (514 nm) versus krypton red (647 nm) modified grid laser photocoagulation for diffuse diabetic macular edema. A randomized controlled trial was conducted to compare the efficacy of argon green (514 nm) versus krypton red (647 nm) modified grid laser photocoagulation in the treatment of diffuse diabetic macular edema (DME). Fifty-four patients with DME were divided into two groups, with one group receiving argon green laser and the other receiving krypton red laser treatment. Both groups underwent three laser sessions over a period of three months. 

The primary outcome measure was the change in best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) at six months compared to baseline. Secondary outcomes included central macular thickness (CMT) and occurrence of adverse events. 

After six months, both treatment groups showed significant improvement in BCVA and reduction in CMT from baseline. However, there was no statistically significant difference between the two groups in terms of BCVA improvement or reduction in CMT. Adverse events were minimal and comparable between the two groups. 

In conclusion, both argon green and krypton red laser photocoagulation are effective in treating diffuse DME, with similar visual and anatomical outcomes. Further studies with larger sample sizes are required to confirm these findings.

The febrile alcoholic in the emergency department. Febrile alcoholics presenting to the emergency department (ED) pose a unique challenge for healthcare providers, as their clinical presentation can be complicated by alcohol-related factors. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the clinical characteristics and outcomes of febrile alcoholic patients in the ED. A total of 187 patients were included, with an average age of 45 years and a male predominance (83.0%). The most common presenting symptoms were fever (89.8%), altered mental status (52.4%), and respiratory distress (34.2%). Laboratory investigations revealed leukocytosis (68.4%) and elevated liver enzymes (63.6%). Bacterial pneumonia was the most frequent diagnosis (43.3%), followed by urinary tract infection (20.3%) and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (16.6%). Mortality was significantly higher in patients with a delay in antibiotic administration (>6 hours), advanced age, and higher Charlson Comorbidity Index scores (p < 0.05). This study highlights the importance of prompt recognition and early initiation of appropriate therapy in febrile alcoholics to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Effect of felbamate on plasma levels of carbamazepine and its metabolites.  Felbamate (FBM) is a novel antiepileptic drug (AED) currently undergoing clinical evaluation in the United States. The co-administration of multiple antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) is often necessary to achieve optimal seizure control in patients with refractory epilepsy. However, drug interactions between AEDs can lead to alterations in plasma drug concentrations and potential adverse effects. This study aimed to investigate the effect of felbamate (FBM) on plasma levels of carbamazepine (CBZ) and its metabolites in patients with epilepsy. Twenty-four adult patients receiving stable doses of CBZ were enrolled in a single-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study. Plasma samples were collected at baseline and after 4 weeks of treatment with FBM or placebo. Analysis of plasma drug concentrations showed a significant increase in CBZ levels (p < 0.001) and a significant decrease in the levels of its active metabolite, carbamazepine-10,11-epoxide (CBZE) (p = 0.003), in patients treated with FBM compared to placebo. These findings suggest that FBM may inhibit the metabolism of CBZ, potentially increasing its therapeutic efficacy and the risk of toxicity. Further studies are warranted to determine the clinical implications of this drug-drug interaction.

Cortical tremor: a variant of cortical reflex myoclonus. Cortical tremor, a variant of cortical reflex myoclonus, is a rare movement disorder characterized by rhythmic oscillations of specific body parts. We present a case series of six patients with cortical tremor who presented with involuntary tremors involving the upper limbs. Clinical examination revealed a characteristic pattern of jerky, irregular, and moderately amplitude tremors, predominantly affecting the distal parts of the limbs. Electromyography studies demonstrated rhythmic activity with a frequency of approximately 8-12 Hz, consistent with cortical origin. Neuroimaging studies showed no structural abnormalities in the brain. The patients responded well to treatment with antiepileptic drugs targeting corticosteroid activity. Cortical tremor should be considered in the differential diagnosis of movement disorders presenting with rhythmic tremors, and appropriate treatment can lead to significant improvement in symptoms.

Angioedema from angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors: a cause of upper airway obstruction. Angioedema is a known complication of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, commonly used for hypertension management. Upper airway obstruction due to angioedema is a potentially life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and intervention. We present a case series of five patients who presented to the emergency department with acute upper airway obstruction secondary to ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema. These patients required immediate intervention including administration of intravenous antihistamines, corticosteroids, and in some cases, intubation or tracheostomy. Prompt recognition of angioedema as a potential side effect of ACE inhibitors is crucial in order to initiate appropriate management and prevent potentially fatal outcomes. Awareness among healthcare providers and patients regarding this complication is of utmost importance to ensure timely intervention and prevent unnecessary morbidity and mortality.

Transbronchial biopsies in children after heart-lung transplantation.  Sixty transbronchial biopsies have been performed in eight children after heart-lung transplantation. Transbronchial biopsies have proven to be a useful diagnostic tool in the evaluation of lung allograft rejection. This study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of transbronchial biopsies in children who have undergone heart-lung transplantation. A retrospective analysis was conducted on eight pediatric patients who underwent a total of sixty transbronchial biopsies. The biopsies were performed for the evaluation of acute rejection episodes and monitoring of chronic rejection. The results showed that the procedure was well-tolerated, with no major complications observed. Histopathological analysis of the biopsies revealed varying degrees of acute cellular rejection in thirty-two cases, while chronic rejection was identified in thirteen cases. These findings highlight the importance of transbronchial biopsies in the management of pediatric heart-lung transplant recipients, providing crucial information for optimizing immunosuppressive therapy and improving long-term outcomes. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine the predictive value of transbronchial biopsies in this population.

Optimal interpretation of the supine exercise electrocardiogram in patients with right bundle branch block. Right bundle branch block (RBBB) is a common finding in the general population and can pose challenges in electrocardiogram (ECG) interpretation, particularly during exercise testing. This study aimed to determine the optimal interpretation of the supine exercise ECG in patients with RBBB. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 200 patients with RBBB who underwent supine exercise testing. The ECGs were reviewed by two experienced cardiologists and classified into three categories: normal exercise response, abnormal exercise response, and equivocal exercise response. The results showed that 56% of the patients had a normal exercise response, 34% had an abnormal exercise response, and 10% had an equivocal exercise response. The abnormal exercise response was associated with a higher prevalence of underlying cardiac pathology, such as coronary artery disease and left ventricular dysfunction. In conclusion, the interpretation of the supine exercise ECG in patients with RBBB should take into account the patient's baseline ECG, exercise performance, symptoms, and clinical presentation to accurately assess cardiovascular function and detect any underlying cardiac pathology.

Use of a knee-brace for control of tibial translation and rotation. The use of a knee brace for control of tibial translation and rotation is a common practice in the treatment of various knee pathologies. This abstract presents a case series of three patients who underwent knee stabilization surgery and were subsequently fitted with a knee brace for post-operative management. The knee braces were custom-made and designed to limit tibial translation and rotation while allowing for appropriate joint mobility. Follow-up evaluations were conducted at regular intervals to assess the effectiveness of the knee brace in preventing excessive tibial movements and promoting functional recovery. All three patients demonstrated improved stability, decreased pain, and increased range of motion with the use of the knee brace. The findings suggest that a knee brace can be an effective adjunct to surgical intervention in promoting optimal knee function and preventing further injury.

Limitation of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization using iodized oil for small hepatocellular carcinoma. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) using iodized oil has been widely used as a treatment option for small hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). However, its limitations and prognostic indicators remain unclear. In this retrospective study, we aimed to evaluate the limitations of TACE using iodized oil in patients with small HCC. A total of 134 patients were included, and their clinical and pathological data were analyzed. The main limitation of this treatment modality was the number of tumors, with a higher number being associated with a worse prognosis. Additionally, tumor size, vascular invasion, and liver cirrhosis were also found to be significant prognostic indicators. These findings suggest that TACE using iodized oil may not be suitable for patients with multiple tumors or advanced disease. Further studies are needed to explore alternative treatment modalities for this patient population.

Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction presenting as ascites: the importance of clinically assessing central venous pressure. Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction (LVDD) is a common cause of ascites, but it is often overlooked due to the absence of typical symptoms. We report a case of a 55-year-old male with ascites as the initial presentation of LVDD. Clinically, the patient had signs of fluid overload and elevated jugular venous pressure, prompting further investigation. Echocardiography revealed LVDD with preserved ejection fraction and increased left atrial size. The patient responded well to diuretic therapy and had resolution of ascites. This case emphasizes the importance of considering LVDD as a potential cause of ascites and the necessity of evaluating central venous pressure as part of the clinical assessment.

Cutaneous manifestations of multiple myeloma. Cutaneous manifestations of multiple myeloma are rare but can be clinically significant. This study aimed to characterize the different types of skin lesions associated with multiple myeloma and evaluate their clinical and histopathological features. A retrospective analysis of 50 cases with cutaneous involvement of multiple myeloma was conducted. The most common type of skin lesion observed was nodular lesions (52%), followed by papular (30%) and plaques (18%). The histopathological examination revealed plasma cell infiltrates, amyloid deposits, and vasculitis in various cases. Additionally, the presence of cutaneous involvement was often associated with advanced stages of multiple myeloma and poor prognosis. Therefore, early recognition and proper management of cutaneous manifestations are essential for improving patient outcomes.

Dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea: optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. Acute childhood diarrhea is a common condition that is associated with significant morbidity and mortality, particularly in resource-limited settings. Adequate dietary management is crucial in preventing complications and optimizing recovery. This review aims to assess the optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets in the management of acute childhood diarrhea. Several studies have suggested early refeeding, as early as 4-6 hours after dehydration correction, to be safe and effective in improving outcomes. The composition of the diet is also important, with evidence supporting the use of breast milk or age-appropriate, easily digestible milks as a first-line option. Mixed diets that include locally available, culturally acceptable food may be introduced gradually as tolerated. Overall, a tailored approach considering individual factors such as age, nutritional status, and cultural practices should guide the dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea.

Autoimmune enteropathy and colitis: is there a generalised autoimmune gut disorder? Children with protracted diarrhoea, circulating enterocyte autoantibodies, and an enteropathy showing features of inappropriate HLA molecule expression on the jejunal crypt epithelium, often present with persistent blood and mucus in their stools. Autoimmune enteropathy and colitis are conditions characterized by inflammation in the gut, but their relationship and underlying mechanisms remain unclear. In this study, we investigated whether there is a generalized autoimmune gut disorder by examining children with protracted diarrhea, circulating enterocyte autoantibodies, and an enteropathy showing features of inappropriate HLA molecule expression on the jejunal crypt epithelium. These children commonly presented with persistent blood and mucus in their stools. Our findings suggest a potential association between autoimmune enteropathy and colitis, indicating the existence of a broader autoimmune disorder in the gastrointestinal tract. Further research is warranted to understand the pathogenesis and develop targeted treatments for these conditions.

Renal effects of cyclosporine. Cyclosporine is a potent immunosuppressive medication commonly used in solid organ transplantation. However, its use is limited by its nephrotoxicity. This study aimed to assess the renal effects of cyclosporine in renal transplant recipients. A total of 50 patients were included in the study and followed up for 12 months. The patients were divided into two groups: Group A received cyclosporine as part of their immunosuppressive regimen, while Group B received an alternative immunosuppressive drug. The renal function of both groups was assessed through various parameters including serum creatinine, glomerular filtration rate, and urine protein excretion. The results revealed a significant decline in renal function in Group A compared to Group B, indicating a pronounced nephrotoxic effect of cyclosporine. Further investigations are warranted to explore strategies to minimize cyclosporine-induced renal damage.

Indications of the carbon dioxide laser in tracheobronchial pathology of the infant and young child: 14 cases.  Fourteen children aged between 6 months and 7 years (mean age = 3. The carbon dioxide laser is increasingly being used in the management of tracheobronchial pathology in infants and young children. This retrospective study presents 14 cases where the carbon dioxide laser was utilized for various indications in this patient population. The mean age of the patients was 3.6 years, with a range of 6 months to 7 years. The primary indications for carbon dioxide laser treatment included subglottic stenosis, tracheal granulation tissue, and tracheomalacia. The carbon dioxide laser demonstrated excellent efficacy in treating these conditions, with successful resolution of symptoms and improvements in airway function observed in the majority of cases. No major complications or adverse events were reported. These findings support the use of carbon dioxide laser as a safe and effective treatment modality for tracheobronchial pathology in infants and young children.

Ciliary motility in two patients with yellow nail syndrome and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. We present two cases of yellow nail syndrome (YNS) characterized by yellowish, thickened nails, lymphedema, and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. In addition to these typical features, both patients exhibited impaired ciliary motility. Ciliary motility was assessed using high-speed video microscopy of nasal brush biopsies, and the results showed a significant reduction in ciliary beat frequency (CBF) and abnormal ciliary beat patterns in both patients. This finding suggests that ciliary dysfunction may be a contributing factor to the increased susceptibility to respiratory infections seen in YNS. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms of ciliary dysfunction in YNS and its potential role in the pathogenesis of sinopulmonary infections.

Interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress in young adults.  The interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was studied in white and black young adults aged 18-23 years. The aim of this study was to investigate the interaction between sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity in young adults. A total of 200 participants, including both white and black individuals aged 18-23 years, were included in the study. Sodium sensitivity was determined through a standardized dietary sodium intake protocol and measurement of blood pressure response. Stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was assessed through a laboratory stress test. Results showed that individuals with higher sodium sensitivity exhibited greater cardiovascular reactivity to stress compared to those with lower sodium sensitivity. This relationship was observed in both white and black participants. These findings suggest that sodium sensitivity may play a role in the physiological response to stress in young adults.

Familial trigeminal neuralgia and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy. Trigeminal neuralgia is a chronic neuropathic disorder characterized by severe facial pain. While it typically occurs sporadically, there have been rare cases reported of familial trigeminal neuralgia. In this study, we present a case of a patient with both familial trigeminal neuralgia and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy. The patient, a 45-year-old male, reported a family history of trigeminal neuralgia, with his mother and sister also affected. Additionally, he exhibited clinical signs and symptoms consistent with Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy, including muscle weakness and atrophy, as well as sensory loss in the lower extremities. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22) gene, which is associated with the development of Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy. This case highlights the rare co-occurrence of familial trigeminal neuralgia and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy and suggests a potential genetic connection between these two conditions. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and genetic factors involved in this unique association.

Clinical significance of intratesticular arterial anatomy. The arterial blood supply to the testes is crucial for their proper function and vascular abnormalities can lead to testicular dysfunction and infertility. Understanding the intratesticular arterial anatomy is important in the diagnosis and management of certain conditions such as testicular torsion, varicocele, and testicular tumors.

This study aimed to investigate the clinical significance of intratesticular arterial anatomy through a retrospective analysis of medical records and imaging studies of 100 male patients. The results demonstrated variations in the number, origin, and branching pattern of the intratesticular arteries. Additionally, aberrant arterial anatomy was associated with higher rates of testicular disorders, including testicular torsion and varicocele.

These findings highlight the importance of assessing intratesticular arterial anatomy in the diagnostic workup of patients with testicular pathology. By identifying and understanding these variations, clinicians can make informed decisions about appropriate treatment strategies and potential surgical interventions. Further research is warranted to better characterize the relationship between intratesticular arterial anatomy and specific testicular pathologies.

Impact of active immunisation against enteritis necroticans in Papua New Guinea. Enteritis necroticans (EN) is a severe and often fatal gastrointestinal disease prevalent in Papua New Guinea (PNG). This study aims to assess the impact of active immunisation against EN in a population in PNG. A total of 500 individuals were enrolled in a vaccination program, receiving three doses of an inactivated vaccine against Clostridium perfringens type C toxin. The vaccine was well-tolerated with no severe adverse events reported. Serologic analysis showed a significant increase in antibody titers against the toxin after vaccination. Over a 2-year follow-up period, only 3 cases of EN were reported in the vaccinated group, compared to 30 cases in a control group of similar size and demographics. This demonstrates the effectiveness of active immunisation in reducing the incidence of EN in PNG and supports the implementation of vaccination programs in high-risk populations.

Increased MEPP frequency as an early sign of experimental immune-mediated motoneuron disease. Immune-mediated motoneuron disease (IMMD) is a complex disorder characterized by progressive degeneration of motoneurons. Early detection of IMMD is crucial for timely treatment and better patient outcomes. In this study, we investigated the potential of increased miniature endplate potential (MEPP) frequency as an early sign of IMMD. Experimental models were used to induce immune-mediated damage to motoneurons in mice. Electrophysiological recordings were performed to assess MEPP frequency before and after disease induction. Results showed a significant increase in MEPP frequency in the early stages of IMMD, indicating heightened synaptic activity at neuromuscular junctions. Further analysis revealed a correlation between MEPP frequency and disease severity, suggesting its potential as a predictive marker for disease progression. Our findings highlight the importance of monitoring MEPP frequency as a non-invasive and early diagnostic tool for IMMD. Early intervention based on this marker could potentially delay disease progression and improve patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings in human patients.

Definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates.  Mandibular defects following radical cancer surgery continue to provide challenges to head and neck surgeons. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates in patients with mandibular defects following radical cancer surgery. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 35 patients who underwent mandibular reconstruction using reconstruction plates between 2010 and 2015. The primary outcome measure was the rate of implant failure or complications related to the reconstruction plates. Secondary outcomes included functional outcomes, such as ability to eat and speak, and aesthetic outcomes, as assessed by both patients and clinicians. Results showed a low rate of implant failure and complications, with 85% of patients achieving satisfactory functional and aesthetic outcomes. These findings suggest that definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates is a viable option for patients with mandibular defects following radical cancer surgery, providing satisfactory functional and aesthetic outcomes. Further research is needed to compare this technique with other available options and to assess long-term outcomes.

Auras and subclinical seizures: characteristics and prognostic significance. This study aimed to investigate the characteristics and prognostic significance of auras and subclinical seizures in patients with epilepsy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 150 patients diagnosed with epilepsy and who experienced auras or subclinical seizures. The clinical features and electroencephalogram (EEG) findings were analyzed in detail. The results showed that auras and subclinical seizures were common in this patient population, with approximately 80% of patients experiencing these events. The most common aura types were visual, followed by somatosensory and auditory auras. EEG findings revealed interictal epileptiform discharges in the majority of patients experiencing auras or subclinical seizures. Furthermore, patients with a higher frequency of auras and subclinical seizures were found to have a higher risk of developing clinical seizures and poor prognosis. This study highlights the importance of recognizing and monitoring auras and subclinical seizures in patients with epilepsy, as they may provide valuable prognostic information. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of these events.

Auditory-evoked responses in benign intracranial hypertension syndrome. In order to investigate the auditory function in patients with benign intracranial hypertension (BIH) syndrome, auditory-evoked responses were measured in 30 patients with BIH and compared to a control group of 30 healthy individuals. The mean age of the BIH group was 32.6  8.4 years, and 23 were female. A significantly prolonged latency of wave III (p=0.001) and wave V (p=0.004) was observed in the BIH group compared to the control group. The interwave interval I-III was also significantly prolonged (p=0.003). However, there was no significant difference in the absolute and interpeak latencies between the two groups. These findings suggest that BIH syndrome may have an effect on the auditory pathway, potentially due to increased intracranial pressure. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of these auditory-evoked response abnormalities in BIH patients.

Results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy. Displaced patellar fractures are a common orthopedic injury that can lead to significant functional impairment and pain. The treatment options for such fractures include conservative management with immobilization and surgical intervention. 

Partial patellectomy, the surgical removal of a portion of the patella, has been proposed as a treatment modality for displaced patellar fractures. This procedure aims to restore joint function and alleviate pain, especially in cases where other surgical options may not be feasible.

This retrospective study aims to evaluate the outcomes of patients who underwent partial patellectomy for displaced patellar fractures. The study population consists of patients who underwent this procedure between 2010 and 2015 in a tertiary orthopedic center. Clinical and radiological outcomes, including pain levels, knee function, range of motion, and radiographic evidence of patellar height and alignment, were assessed.

Preliminary results suggest that partial patellectomy can provide satisfactory outcomes in terms of pain reduction and restoration of knee function. However, further analysis is underway to determine the long-term effects and potential complications associated with this procedure.

Prolonged confusion following convulsions due to generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus.  Among patients with a prolonged confusional state after convulsive seizure, we diagnosed 8 cases as generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus. Prolonged confusion following convulsions is a common sequelae of seizures, but the underlying etiology is often unclear. In this study, we identified eight patients who presented with a prolonged confusional state after convulsive seizures, and upon further investigation, we diagnosed them with generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE). NCSE is a subtle form of status epilepticus characterized by altered mental status without convulsive activity. The diagnosis of NCSE in these patients was confirmed through electroencephalography (EEG), which demonstrated continuous epileptic discharges. The clinical presentation of NCSE can mimic other conditions, leading to delays in diagnosis and management. Therefore, increased awareness of this condition among healthcare providers is essential for accurate diagnosis and timely treatment. Prompt recognition and initiation of appropriate antiepileptic therapy can lead to improved outcomes and resolution of the prolonged confusion in these patients.

Clinical and manometric aspects of diffuse esophageal spasm in a cohort of subjects evaluated for dysphagia and/or chest pain. Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a motor disorder that affects the esophagus and can lead to dysphagia and/or chest pain. This study aimed to investigate the clinical and manometric aspects of DES in a cohort of subjects presenting with these symptoms. A total of 80 subjects were included in the study, all of whom underwent esophageal manometry testing. The results showed that 36% of the subjects had a diagnosis of DES, with a higher prevalence in female individuals (63%). The most common symptom reported was chest pain, followed by dysphagia. Manometric analysis revealed abnormalities in esophageal motility, including simultaneous contractions and failed peristalsis. These findings highlight the importance of considering DES as a possible etiology for dysphagia and chest pain. Further research is warranted to explore effective diagnostic and management strategies for this condition.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. Portal vein thrombosis is a rare but serious complication of liver transplantation that can lead to graft loss and patient mortality. Current strategies for preventing and treating portal vein thrombosis are limited. This study presents a novel technique utilizing a new antithrombogenic catheter for portal vein resection in liver transplantation. The catheter, coated with a thin layer of heparin, was designed to inhibit thrombus formation and reduce the risk of thrombotic events. In a retrospective analysis of 50 liver transplant recipients who underwent portal vein resection with the new catheter, the incidence of portal vein thrombosis was significantly lower compared to a control group (2% vs. 16%, p < 0.01). Furthermore, there were no significant differences in operative time, length of hospital stay, or postoperative complications between the two groups. These findings suggest that the use of the new antithrombogenic catheter may be a promising strategy for preventing portal vein thrombosis in liver transplantation. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings.

T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. The aim of this study was to investigate the distribution of T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in the peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. A total of 45 patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis and 45 healthy controls were enrolled in this study. Flow cytometry analysis was used to determine the percentages of T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in peripheral blood samples. 

The results showed that the percentages of Tc, Th, Ts, and Tsi cells were significantly lower in patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis compared to healthy controls. Additionally, the percentage of IL2 receptor-bearing cells was significantly higher in patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis compared to healthy controls. 

These findings suggest that the immune response is altered in patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis, characterized by decreased T cell subsets and increased IL2 receptor-bearing cells in the peripheral blood. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for patients with alcoholic hepatitis.

Biology of basal cell carcinoma (Part I). Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, mainly affecting individuals with fair skin and prolonged sun exposure. This article aims to provide an overview of the biology of BCC. BCC arises from the basal cells of the epidermis and exhibits various growth patterns such as nodular, infiltrative, and superficial types. The key driver mutations involved in BCC development are alterations in the hedgehog signaling pathway, including activating mutations in the Patched 1 (PTCH1) gene and inactivating mutations in the Suppressor of Fused (SUFU) gene. These mutations lead to the dysregulation of downstream pathway components, resulting in uncontrolled cell proliferation and impaired apoptosis. Understanding the underlying biology of BCC is crucial for the development of targeted therapies and improved management of this prevalent form of skin cancer. Part II of this review will focus on the clinical features, diagnosis, and treatment options for BCC.

Ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging in Leigh disease. Leigh disease, also known as subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy, is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder primarily affecting infants and children. This abstract presents a case study involving the use of ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and monitoring of Leigh disease. The patient, a 3-year-old male, presented with developmental regression, muscle weakness, and respiratory difficulties. Ultrasonography revealed bilateral symmetric hyperechogenic lesions in the basal ganglia and thalamus, suggestive of Leigh disease. Subsequent MRI confirmed the presence of these lesions, along with additional findings such as brainstem involvement and ventricular enlargement. Follow-up imaging demonstrated disease progression with increasing lesion size and involvement of additional brain regions. This case highlights the value of ultrasonography and MRI in the diagnosis and monitoring of Leigh disease, aiding in early detection and treatment planning.

Subtrochanteric fractures treated with interlocking nailing.  In a prospective study of 31 subtrochanteric fractures treated with Grosse-Kempf interlocking nails with a followup period of at least 1 year, there was a 87. 1% (27/31) union rate, and a union period of 4. 92.9 months. Four patients developed nonunion and required revision surgery. The mean time to weight-bearing was 12.83.5 weeks. Postoperative complications included one case of deep infection and five cases of proximal locking screw cut-out. There were no cases of implant breakage or implant-related pain. Functional outcomes, as measured by the Harris Hip Score at the final follow-up, were excellent in 22 cases, good in six cases, fair in two cases, and poor in one case. Based on these results, Grosse-Kempf interlocking nails appear to be a reliable and effective method for the treatment of subtrochanteric fractures, with a high union rate, acceptable complication rate, and good functional outcomes.

Isolated calf venous thrombosis: diagnosis with compression US. Isolated calf venous thrombosis (ICVT) is a common vascular condition that often goes undiagnosed due to its subtle clinical presentation. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of compression ultrasound (US) in detecting ICVT. A total of 126 patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) were included in the study. Compression US was performed on all patients using a standardized protocol. The results were compared with contrast venography, which served as the gold standard for ICVT diagnosis. The overall sensitivity of compression US in detecting ICVT was found to be 93%, with a specificity of 98%. The positive predictive value was 95% and the negative predictive value was 97%. These findings demonstrate that compression US is a highly accurate and reliable method for diagnosing ICVT, making it an essential tool in the management of patients with suspected lower limb DVT.

Life-threatening complications during anaesthesia in a patient with a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):241] A 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt is described. We present a case of a 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus and a ventriculo-atrial shunt who developed life-threatening complications during anesthesia due to pulmonary hypertension. This rare and challenging scenario requires careful perioperative management, including optimization of hemodynamic parameters and ventilation strategies. Prompt recognition and intervention are crucial in preventing adverse outcomes. This case underscores the importance of thorough preoperative evaluation and close monitoring during anesthesia in patients with complex medical conditions and high-risk comorbidities.

Resting metabolic rate and energy balance in amenorrheic and eumenorrheic runners. The aim of this retrospective cohort study was to evaluate and compare the resting metabolic rate (RMR) and energy balance in amenorrheic and eumenorrheic runners. A total of 45 female runners were included in the study, with 25 classified as amenorrheic and 20 as eumenorrheic. RMR was measured using indirect calorimetry, and energy balance was calculated by subtracting energy expenditure from reported energy intake. Results showed that amenorrheic runners had significantly lower RMR compared to eumenorrheic runners (p<0.001). Energy intake was similar between the two groups, but amenorrheic runners had significantly higher energy expenditure (p=0.003) and negative energy balance (p<0.001) compared to eumenorrheic runners. These findings suggest that amenorrheic runners may have a decreased RMR and a greater energy deficit, which could contribute to the persistence of amenorrhea and potentially affect overall health and performance. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential interventions for this population.

Periurethral colonic-type polyp simulating urethral caruncle. We present a case of a periurethral colonic-type polyp that mimicked a urethral caruncle in a 56-year-old female patient. The patient presented with symptoms of urinary frequency and discomfort during urination. Physical examination revealed a smooth, polypoid lesion at the urethral meatus. Initial diagnosis of urethral caruncle was made based on clinical findings. However, subsequent biopsy and histopathological examination revealed the presence of a colonic-type polyp. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of a periurethral colonic-type polyp mimicking a urethral caruncle. This case highlights the importance of considering alternative diagnoses and performing histopathological evaluation to confirm the nature of periurethral lesions, especially in cases with atypical clinical features.

Achieving pH control in the critically ill patient: the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. The management of pH control is crucial in critically ill patients, and continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists has been suggested as a potential option. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists in achieving pH control in critically ill patients. Twenty-five patients were included in the study and received continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. The results showed that pH control was successfully achieved in all patients, with a significant improvement in acid-base parameters. Furthermore, there were no significant adverse effects associated with the continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. This study highlights the potential benefits of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists in achieving pH control in critically ill patients.

Fatal pulmonary venoocclusive disease secondary to a generalized venulopathy: a new syndrome presenting with facial swelling and pericardial tamponade. We present a case of fatal pulmonary venoocclusive disease (PVOD) secondary to a generalized venulopathy in a patient who initially presented with facial swelling and pericardial tamponade. PVOD is a rare and life-threatening condition characterized by occlusion of the small pulmonary veins, leading to increased pulmonary arterial pressures and subsequent right ventricular failure. Our patient had diffuse involvement of the venous system, including the facial veins and pericardium, resulting in severe facial edema and cardiac tamponade. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of PVOD presenting with these manifestations. The underlying etiology and pathophysiology of this new syndrome are discussed. Early recognition and prompt intervention are crucial in improving outcomes for patients with PVOD.

Complications in hyperthermia treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.  Of 435 patients treated with local hyperthermia to the prostate 27 had 29 complications, for an over-all complication rate of 6. We retrospectively reviewed the medical records of 435 patients who underwent local hyperthermia treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and identified 29 complications in 27 patients, resulting in an overall complication rate of 6%. The most common complications were urinary retention (34.5%), urinary tract infection (20.7%), and hematuria (17.2%). Other less frequent complications included urethral stricture, bladder neck contracture, and rectal injury. Patients who experienced complications were older and had larger prostate volumes compared to those without complications. Our findings highlight the potential risks associated with hyperthermia treatment for BPH and emphasize the need for careful patient selection and monitoring to minimize complications. Further studies are warranted to identify risk factors and develop strategies to prevent and manage complications in this patient population.

Leukemias of indeterminant lineage. Leukemias of indeterminant lineage are a rare and heterogeneous group of hematological malignancies that pose significant challenges in diagnosis and management. Historically, these leukemias were poorly understood and often misclassified, leading to ineffective treatment strategies. However, advancements in immunophenotyping techniques and molecular diagnostics have improved our understanding of these diseases. The World Health Organization (WHO) classification system now recognizes various subtypes of leukemias of indeterminant lineage, each with distinct clinical and prognostic features. Treatment approaches for these leukemias have evolved, incorporating multi-agent chemotherapy, targeted therapies, and stem cell transplantation. Despite these advances, the overall prognosis for patients with leukemias of indeterminant lineage remains poor, highlighting the need for further research to unravel the underlying mechanisms and develop novel therapeutic strategies.

Thyrotoxicosis induced by topical iodine application. Iodine has been extensively used as an antiseptic in a variety of medical settings. However, hypothyroidism is a well-known complication of iodine exposure when administered systemically or in excessive amounts. We report a case of thyrotoxicosis induced by topical iodine application for the treatment of a skin infection. A 45-year-old female presented with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including palpitations, weight loss, and heat intolerance. Laboratory findings revealed suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone levels and elevated free thyroxine and triiodothyronine levels. The patient's symptoms resolved after discontinuing the topical iodine treatment. This case highlights the importance of considering iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis as a potential diagnosis when evaluating patients with hyperthyroidism symptoms, especially in those with ongoing iodine exposure.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome associated with L-tryptophan ingestion. Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) is a rare and serious condition associated with the ingestion of L-tryptophan, an essential amino acid. This study aimed to further evaluate the clinical features and outcomes of EMS related to L-tryptophan ingestion. The authors conducted a retrospective analysis of 20 patients with confirmed EMS following L-tryptophan consumption. The most common presenting symptoms were myalgia (100%), followed by eosinophilia (95%) and skin involvement (85%). Other manifestations included fever, respiratory symptoms, and neurological abnormalities. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated eosinophils and peripheral blood lymphocyte abnormalities. Diagnosis of EMS was confirmed by exclusion of other causes and demonstration of eosinophilia. The majority of patients required hospitalization and treatment with corticosteroids. Long-term follow-up showed resolution of symptoms and normalization of eosinophil count in most cases. However, some patients experienced chronic sequelae, including neurological impairment and skin changes. This study highlights the need for awareness of EMS as a potential complication of L-tryptophan ingestion and emphasizes the importance of early recognition and prompt treatment to improve outcomes.

Growth velocity before sudden infant death. Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) remains a significant cause of mortality in infants worldwide. This study aimed to investigate the growth velocity before sudden infant death to identify potential risk factors or associations. A retrospective review of medical records was conducted for infants who experienced sudden infant death within the first year of life. Growth parameters, including weight, length, and head circumference, were analyzed at regular intervals leading up to the event. Preliminary findings suggest that infants who later succumbed to SIDS had a lower growth velocity compared to the general population. However, further analysis is required to determine if this association is significant and if growth velocity can be considered a potential predictive factor for SIDS. Understanding any potential links may provide valuable insights for preventive strategies or early interventions in high-risk infants.

Palliation of malignant esophageal obstruction. Malignant esophageal obstruction is a common complication in patients with advanced esophageal cancer. Palliation of this condition is crucial to improve quality of life and alleviate symptoms such as dysphagia and weight loss. Various treatment modalities have been employed, including endoscopic stent placement, laser therapy, and bypass surgery. In recent years, self-expandable metallic stents (SEMS) have become the preferred treatment option due to their ease of placement and minimal invasiveness. SEMS provide immediate relief of dysphagia and allow oral intake, thus enhancing nutritional status. Furthermore, SEMS can be easily removed or replaced if necessary. However, concerns regarding stent migration and tumor overgrowth have been reported. Thus, careful patient selection and regular surveillance are essential for successful long-term palliation of malignant esophageal obstruction.

How long can a coronary reperfusion catheter be placed in acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty? A case report. Coronary reperfusion catheters are commonly used to achieve myocardial reperfusion in cases of acute coronary occlusion. However, there is limited information available regarding the duration for which these catheters can be safely left in place following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty (TCA). This case report presents the successful use of a coronary reperfusion catheter for an extended period of time in a patient with acute coronary occlusion that occurred during TCA. The catheter was left in place for 72 hours, during which time the patient remained hemodynamically stable and showed improvements in myocardial perfusion. This case highlights the potential benefit of leaving a coronary reperfusion catheter in place for an extended duration following failed TCA, suggesting that longer durations may be safe and effective in achieving myocardial reperfusion. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal duration for catheter placement in these cases.

Molecular and hematologic characterization of Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia. Thalassemia is a genetic disorder characterized by defective synthesis of globin chains, resulting in abnormal hemoglobin formation and subsequent anemia. The Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia is a rare subtype that has not been extensively studied. In this study, the molecular and hematologic characteristics of this thalassemia variant were investigated. DNA analysis revealed a deletion of the epsilon, gamma, delta, and beta globin genes, resulting in complete absence of these globin chains. Hematologic analysis showed severe anemia, microcytosis, and hypochromia, consistent with a thalassemic phenotype. These findings provide important insights into the pathophysiology and clinical manifestations of this rare thalassemia subtype, which may aid in its diagnosis and management. Further studies are warranted to explore potential therapeutic approaches for individuals with Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia.

Diagnostic significance of carcinoembryonic antigen in the differential diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma. Malignant mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive tumor that is often challenging to diagnose due to its similar clinical and radiological features to other thoracic malignancies. This study aims to assess the diagnostic significance of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) in distinguishing malignant mesothelioma from other malignancies. A total of 68 patients with histologically confirmed malignant mesothelioma were included in the study, along with 42 patients with other thoracic malignancies as the control group. Serum CEA levels were measured in all patients using a commercial enzyme immunoassay. The results showed that the mean serum CEA level in patients with malignant mesothelioma was significantly higher compared to the control group (p < 0.001). At a cutoff value of 5 ng/mL, CEA had a sensitivity of 76.5% and a specificity of 85.7% in distinguishing malignant mesothelioma from other thoracic malignancies. Therefore, CEA can serve as a valuable biomarker in the differential diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the potential use of CEA in clinical practice.

The anatomy and physiology of nerve injury. Nerve injury is a common and debilitating condition that can lead to severe functional impairment and chronic pain. Understanding the anatomy and physiology of nerve injury is crucial for the development of effective therapeutic strategies. This review highlights the key aspects of nerve injury, including the different mechanisms of injury, the cellular and molecular events that occur following injury, and the subsequent changes in the nervous system.

The anatomy of nerve injury involves the disruption or compression of nerve fibers, leading to impaired signal transmission. Depending on the location and severity of the injury, various symptoms may arise, such as numbness, tingling, weakness, or loss of function.

Following nerve injury, a cascade of cellular and molecular events is initiated. This includes inflammation, activation of immune cells, and release of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. These events contribute to the recruitment and activation of glial cells, such as microglia and astrocytes, which further perpetuate the inflammatory response and contribute to tissue damage.

Additionally, changes occur in the injured nerve itself. Wallerian degeneration, a process involving the breakdown and clearance of damaged nerve fibers, occurs distal to the injury site. Axon regeneration attempts to restore connectivity, but the process is often impeded by factors such as scar formation and inhibitory molecules in the surrounding tissue.

In conclusion, understanding the complex interplay between the anatomy and physiology of nerve injury is essential for developing targeted therapeutic interventions. Further research is needed to uncover the underlying mechanisms and identify novel strategies to enhance nerve regeneration and functional recovery.

Combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion for spinal canal surgery in children and adolescents. Surgical treatment of spinal canal stenosis in children and adolescents can pose unique challenges due to the growing spine and potential risks of long-term complications. The combination of laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion has emerged as an effective technique for achieving decompression and stabilization in this population. We present a retrospective analysis of 20 patients who underwent this combined procedure for spinal canal surgery. The mean age of the patients was 14 years, and the most common indication for surgery was congenital spinal stenosis. Clinical outcomes were assessed using various measures including neurologic function, pain scores, and radiographic evaluation. The combination of laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion resulted in significant improvements in symptomatology and function. Complications were minimal and mostly related to hardware failure. We discuss the technical aspects of this procedure, including the choice of instrumentation and fusion technique, and highlight the importance of careful patient selection and close follow-up to optimize outcomes in this challenging patient population.

Bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia, in an 8-yr-old boy. We present the case of an 8-year-old boy with a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon. The lesion appeared endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia. The patient presented with intermittent episodes of bright red blood per rectum and was found to have hemoglobin levels below the normal range. Colonoscopy revealed a tortuous, dilated vascular lesion with a distinctive cherry-red appearance in the sigmoid colon. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of angiodysplasia. To our knowledge, this is a rare case of angiodysplasia occurring in a pediatric patient, particularly involving the sigmoid colon. The patient was managed conservatively with iron supplementation and supportive care, as the bleeding episodes were self-limiting. Long-term monitoring will be necessary to assess the progression and resolution of the lesion. Given the rarity of this condition in children, further research is warranted to better understand its etiology and optimal management strategies.

Pelvic lipomatosis associated with cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. Pelvic lipomatosis is a rare abnormal condition characterized by the excessive deposition of fat in the pelvis, which can cause compression of nearby structures. It is often associated with genitourinary abnormalities such as cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. This case report aims to present a unique case of a 56-year-old male patient who presented with lower urinary tract symptoms and was subsequently diagnosed with pelvic lipomatosis, cystitis glandularis, and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. The patient underwent surgical intervention with a combination of transurethral resection of the bladder tumor and pelvic lipomatosis debulking. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. Early diagnosis and prompt management of these coexisting conditions are crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology and optimal treatment strategies for this rare combination of conditions.

Relationship of ischemic heart disease to sudden death. Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a leading cause of mortality worldwide. Sudden death due to IHD is a significant concern, and understanding the relationship between IHD and sudden death is crucial for prevention and management strategies. This study aimed to investigate this relationship in a large population-based cohort.
A total of 10,000 individuals with suspected or confirmed IHD were followed for an average of 10 years. During this follow-up period, 500 cases of sudden death were identified. Analysis of the data revealed a strong association between IHD and sudden death, with individuals diagnosed with IHD having a 5-fold higher risk of experiencing sudden death compared to those without IHD.
Further analysis stratified by age, sex, and comorbidities revealed that the association between IHD and sudden death remained consistent across different subgroups. Moreover, individuals with more severe forms of IHD, such as those with previous myocardial infarction or significant coronary artery stenosis, had a higher risk of sudden death compared to those with milder forms of IHD.
In conclusion, this study provides evidence of a clear relationship between IHD and sudden death. These findings highlight the importance of early detection and intervention for individuals with IHD to prevent fatal outcomes. Further research is needed to identify specific risk factors and develop targeted prevention strategies for reducing the burden of sudden death in individuals with IHD.

Possible mechanisms of abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels and the development of hypertension in spontaneously hypertensive rats. Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) are a widely used animal model to study hypertension and its underlying mechanisms. This study aimed to investigate the possible mechanisms of abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels in SHR and its relation to the development of hypertension. The results showed that SHR exhibited increased norepinephrine-induced vasoconstriction compared to normotensive controls, indicating enhanced sensitivity to norepinephrine. Additionally, SHR exhibited increased vascular reactivity to norepinephrine, suggesting hyperreactivity of resistance vessels. These findings suggest that abnormal norepinephrine signaling pathways may contribute to the development and maintenance of hypertension in SHR. Further investigations are needed to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for hypertension management.

Psychological stress and the fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome. The relationship between psychological stress and the fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome was investigated in this study. A total of 150 participants with fibrositis/fibromyalgia were included. Psychological stress was assessed using a validated scale, and severity of fibrositis/fibromyalgia symptoms was measured using standardized criteria. Results showed a significant positive correlation between psychological stress levels and severity of fibrositis/fibromyalgia symptoms. Participants with higher stress levels reported greater pain, fatigue, and sleep disturbances. Additionally, higher stress levels were associated with increased psychological distress and decreased quality of life. These findings suggest that psychological stress may play a role in the exacerbation and maintenance of symptoms in fibrositis/fibromyalgia patients. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential avenues for intervention.

Recurrent lateral rectus palsy in childhood. Recurrent lateral rectus palsy, a rare condition characterized by intermittent or recurrent paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, is seen in childhood. This study aims to evaluate the clinical features, etiology, and outcomes of individuals with this condition. A retrospective analysis of medical records identified 15 patients with recurrent lateral rectus palsy who presented to our clinic between 2000 and 2020. The average age at onset was 8 years, with a male predominance. The most common presenting symptom was sudden-onset esotropia. Etiological factors included trauma, infection, congenital anomalies, and underlying systemic diseases. Conservative management with observation and occlusion therapy was successful in 9 patients, while surgical intervention was required in 6 patients. This study highlights the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of recurrent lateral rectus palsy in childhood.

Deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass after failed femoropopliteal reconstructions.
