A total of 54 childhood deaths from toy balloons were identified during the study period. The majority of cases (67%) occurred in children under the age of 5. The main cause of death was airway obstruction, accounting for 83% of cases. Factors identified to contribute to these accidents included inadequate supervision, improper handling, and presence of small children in the vicinity of inflated balloons. To prevent childhood deaths from toy balloons, it is crucial to raise awareness among parents and caregivers about the potential hazards associated with their use and promote safe practices such as monitoring children during play and ensuring balloons are kept away from young children.

Pharynx: value of oblique projections for radiographic examination. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the usefulness of oblique projections in the radiographic examination of the pharynx. A total of 100 patients presenting with various pharyngeal symptoms were included in the study. All patients underwent both direct lateral and oblique radiographic views of the pharynx. Two experienced radiologists independently reviewed the images and assessed the visibility of different anatomical structures in the pharynx.

The results showed that oblique projections provided enhanced visualization of the pharyngeal region compared to direct lateral views. The pharyngeal recesses, including the piriform sinuses and the vallecular spaces, were better visualized in oblique projections, allowing for a more accurate assessment of any structural abnormalities or pathological findings in these areas.

Furthermore, the oblique projections allowed for better assessment of the relationship between the pharyngeal structures and adjacent anatomical structures such as the cervical vertebrae. This information can be particularly valuable in the diagnosis and management of conditions such as retropharyngeal abscess or cervical spine pathology.

In conclusion, oblique projections of the pharynx provide improved visibility of the pharyngeal region and allow for better assessment of anatomical structures and their relationships. The utilization of oblique projections should be considered in routine radiographic examination of the pharynx to enhance diagnostic accuracy and improve patient management.

Normal pituitary gland: coronal MR imaging of infundibular tilt. Coronal MR imaging is commonly used to evaluate the pituitary gland. In this study, the authors investigated the infundibular tilt on coronal MR images of normal pituitary glands. The tilt angle of the infundibulum was measured in 50 normal pituitary glands, and the relationship between the tilt angle and patient age, sex, and pituitary volume was analyzed. The mean infundibular tilt angle was found to be 28.5 degrees. There was no significant difference in tilt angle between males and females or among different age groups. However, a weak positive correlation was observed between the tilt angle and pituitary volume. The findings suggest that the infundibular tilt angle may vary in normal individuals, but it is not influenced by age or sex. Understanding the normal variations in infundibular tilt can assist in accurate interpretation of coronal MR images of the pituitary gland.

A follow-up study of intractable seizures in childhood.  One hundred forty-five children with seizures that were refractory to medical therapy for at least 2 years were followed 5 to 20 years after onset. The aim of this study was to assess the long-term outcomes of children with intractable seizures. One hundred forty-five children who had experienced seizures refractory to medical therapy for a minimum of 2 years were followed for a period ranging from 5 to 20 years after onset. The mean follow-up period was 10.5 years. The study found that 76% of the patients continued to experience seizures during the follow-up period, despite various treatment attempts. Of these patients, 45% exhibited a worsening of seizure frequency and severity. In addition, 32% of the patients experienced developmental delays and cognitive impairments. Only 24% of the patients achieved seizure freedom, but those who did often required multiple anti-epileptic drugs. The findings of this study highlight the challenging nature of intractable seizures in childhood and emphasize the need for more effective therapeutic strategies.

Long term follow-up of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral bypass.  A prospective study of 26 patients undergoing descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass was conducted over a 13-year period with an average follow up of 53 months. The long-term outcomes of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass are not well documented. This prospective study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and durability of DTAI/F bypass over a 13-year period with a mean follow-up of 53 months. A total of 26 patients who underwent DTAI/F bypass were included in the study. Primary patency was achieved in 92.3% of the patients, secondary patency in 100%, and limb salvage in 100% at the end of the follow-up period. A significantly high survival rate of 92.3% was observed at 13 years. Our study demonstrates the long-term effectiveness and durability of DTAI/F bypass in managing aorto-iliac/femoral occlusive disease, emphasizing its role as a favorable treatment option.

Risk factors for gestational diabetes in black population. Gestational diabetes (GDM) is a common pregnancy complication associated with adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes. Previous studies have identified various risk factors for GDM, but limited research has focused specifically on the black population. Therefore, this study aimed to identify risk factors for GDM in a black population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 256 pregnant women with GDM and 343 pregnant women without GDM. Logistic regression analysis was performed to determine independent risk factors for GDM. The results showed that advanced maternal age, pre-pregnancy overweight or obesity, family history of diabetes, and multiparity were significant risk factors for developing GDM in the black population. Furthermore, gestational hypertension and preeclampsia were also associated with an increased risk of GDM. These findings indicate that targeted interventions and increased surveillance should be implemented for black women with these identified risk factors to prevent and manage GDM effectively.

Tumor factors predicting for prognosis in metastatic breast cancer.  The presence of P24 predicts for response to treatment and duration of survival. In metastatic breast cancer, the identification of tumor factors that can predict prognosis is essential for guiding treatment decisions and predicting patient outcomes. This retrospective study aimed to determine the prognostic significance of the presence of P24 in metastatic breast cancer patients. Clinical data and tumor samples were collected from a cohort of female patients with metastatic breast cancer. The presence of P24 was assessed using immunohistochemistry. Survival analysis was performed to evaluate the association between P24 expression and treatment response as well as overall survival. Our results showed that the presence of P24 was a strong predictor for treatment response, with patients expressing P24 more likely to achieve a favorable response to treatment. Additionally, the presence of P24 was associated with longer overall survival, indicating its potential as a prognostic biomarker in metastatic breast cancer. Further validation studies are warranted to confirm these findings and explore the underlying mechanisms of P24 in breast cancer progression and treatment response.

Surgical resection of cor triatriatum in a 74-year-old man. Cor triatriatum is an extremely rare congenital cardiac anomaly characterized by the presence of a fibromuscular membrane that divides the left atrium into two chambers. We present a case of cor triatriatum in a 74-year-old man who presented with dyspnea and atrial fibrillation. Echocardiography revealed a membrane in the left atrium, obstructing blood flow and causing marked left atrial dilation. The patient underwent successful surgical resection of the membrane, resulting in resolution of symptoms and restoration of normal atrial function. This case highlights the importance of considering cor triatriatum in the differential diagnosis of atrial fibrillation and dyspnea, even in elderly patients, as surgical intervention can lead to favorable outcomes.

Relationship among level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. The relationship between the level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals was investigated. Twenty-four animals were subjected to distraction of the spinal cord and the level of distraction was measured. Evoked potentials were recorded before and after the distraction, and spinal cord ischemia was evaluated using histological analysis. The clinical status of the animals was also monitored. The results showed a correlation between the level of distraction and the severity of spinal cord ischemia. Additionally, a decrease in evoked potentials was observed with increasing levels of distraction. Furthermore, animals with more severe spinal cord ischemia had poorer clinical outcomes. These findings suggest that the level of distraction directly affects spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and can impact the clinical status of animals.

The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap in composite defects of the oral cavity involving bone, skin, and mucosa. The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap is a surgical technique used for the reconstruction of composite defects in the oral cavity that involve bone, skin, and mucosa. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications associated with this flap procedure. A total of 48 patients with composite defects in the oral cavity were included in the study. The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap was successfully used in all cases, and the majority of patients achieved satisfactory functional and aesthetic results. However, there were several complications reported, including donor site morbidity and flap failure. Overall, the internal oblique-iliac crest free flap is a viable option for the reconstruction of composite defects in the oral cavity, but careful patient selection and meticulous surgical technique are crucial for optimal outcomes.

Acute sensorineural deafness in Lassa fever A prospective audiometric evaluation of 69 hospitalized febrile patients in Sierra Leone, West Africa, revealed a sensorineural hearing deficit (SNHD) in 14 (29%) of 49 confirmed cases of Lassa fever and in 0 of 20 febrile controls. Of the 14 Lassa fever patients with SNHD, 6 (43%) had severe or profound bilateral hearing loss. SNHD was more common in patients with severe disease manifestations, including shock, bleeding, and impaired renal function. Audiometric evaluation performed three to four weeks later in five patients revealed persistent hearing loss in all cases. The etiology of SNHD in Lassa fever remains unclear, as no evidence of cochlear pathology was found on autopsy. This study highlights the importance of early detection and management of SNHD in Lassa fever patients, as it can have a significant impact on their long-term quality of life.

Experience with photocoagulation in Behcet's disease. This study presents the experience with photocoagulation in the management of Behcet's disease. Photocoagulation has been used as a therapeutic modality for ocular manifestations of Behcet's disease, including posterior uveitis, retinal vasculitis, and macular edema. The outcome of photocoagulation in terms of visual acuity improvement and disease control was evaluated in a cohort of 20 patients with Behcet's disease. The results showed that photocoagulation was effective in controlling disease activity and preserving visual acuity in the majority of cases. Complications associated with the procedure were minimal, with only minor transient adverse effects reported. These findings contribute to the growing body of evidence supporting the role of photocoagulation as a valuable tool in the management of ocular manifestations of Behcet's disease. Further studies are warranted to explore the long-term outcomes and optimize the treatment approach.

A double-masked evaluation of lignocaine-prilocaine cream (EMLA) used to alleviate the pain of retrobulbar injection A randomised, placebo controlled, double-masked study was undertaken in 115 patients undergoing cataract surgery to assess the efficacy of the anaesthetic cream EMLA (eutetic mixture of local anaesthetic, lignocaine-prilocaine) in alleviating the pain of retrobulbar injection. In this study, 115 patients undergoing cataract surgery were randomly assigned to receive either a topical cream containing lignocaine-prilocaine (EMLA) or a placebo. The objective was to evaluate the effectiveness of EMLA cream in reducing the pain associated with retrobulbar injection. The study was double-masked, meaning both the patients and the evaluators were unaware of the treatment received. The results indicated that EMLA cream significantly alleviated the pain experienced during retrobulbar injection compared to the placebo. This suggests that EMLA cream has the potential to improve patient comfort during cataract surgery by reducing injection-related pain.

Deterioration following delay in performing femoral angioplasty.  It is not uncommon for a delay to occur between assessment arteriography and angioplasty attempt. This study aimed to investigate the effects of delay in performing femoral angioplasty on patient outcomes. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 68 patients who underwent femoral angioplasty for peripheral arterial disease. The patients were divided into two groups based on the time interval between assessment arteriography and angioplasty attempt. Group A consisted of patients with a delay of less than 24 hours, while group B had a delay of more than 24 hours. The results showed that patients in group B had a significantly higher incidence of complications, including thrombosis and embolism, compared to group A (p<0.05). Furthermore, patients in group B had a longer hospital stay and higher rates of amputation. These findings suggest that delay in performing femoral angioplasty may lead to worsening of patient outcomes and should be minimized.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic evaluation of patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.  We compared brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic performance in 20 neurologically asymptomatic patients suffering from idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (mean age 41 [range 18-49] years) and 20 age-matched controls (mean age 38 [range 28-49] years).  Patients exhibited a significantly higher rate of cerebral infarcts (20% versus 0%, p less than 0. 05) and a higher prevalence of white matter hyperintensities (50% versus 10%, p less than 0.05) compared to controls. There were no significant differences in global cognitive function, attention, or executive function between the two groups. However, patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy had poorer performance on verbal memory and visuospatial memory tasks compared to controls. These findings suggest that neurologic abnormalities are common in patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy and may be associated with subtle cognitive deficits. Further research is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of these findings.

Parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation for peptic duodenal stricture.  Gastric outlet obstruction due to peptic duodenal stricture (pyloric stenosis) was treated with parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation of the stricture in 32 patients.  Follow-up is in the range of 5 years in 37. Parietal cell vagotomy combined with dilatation has been shown to be an effective treatment for gastric outlet obstruction caused by peptic duodenal stricture. In this study, 32 patients underwent the procedure and were followed up for a period of 5 years. The results demonstrated successful resolution of the stricture in all patients, with improvement in symptoms and restoration of normal gastric emptying. No major complications were reported during the follow-up period. This study supports the use of parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation as a safe and effective treatment option for peptic duodenal stricture leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

Trends in conserving treatment of invasive carcinoma of the breast in females. The management of invasive carcinoma of the breast in females has seen significant changes over the years, with a shift towards more conservative approaches. This study sought to identify trends in the conserving treatment of this condition. A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted on 500 consecutive female patients diagnosed with invasive breast carcinoma who underwent treatment between 2010 and 2018. The primary endpoint was the type of surgical treatment received, including breast-conserving surgery (BCS) and mastectomy. Secondary endpoints included the use of adjuvant therapies such as radiation and chemotherapy. The results showed a significant increase in the utilization of BCS over the study period, from 45% in 2010 to 65% in 2018. This trend was accompanied by a decrease in the rate of mastectomies. The use of adjuvant therapies remained stable throughout the study period. These findings indicate a growing preference for conservative approaches in the treatment of invasive breast carcinoma in females.

The effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation.  The properties of the omentum and its effect on spinal neurologic disease was investigated. In this study, we investigated the effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation. The omentum, a highly vascularized tissue with regenerative properties, has been shown to have therapeutic effects in various neurologic diseases. Using a rat model, we examined the microcirculatory changes in the spinal cord following omental pedicle graft transfer. Our results showed a significant improvement in spinal microcirculation, as evidenced by increased blood flow and oxygenation. Additionally, we observed a reduction in laminectomy membrane formation, indicating a potential role for omental pedicle graft transfer in preventing postoperative complications, such as epidural fibrosis. These findings suggest that omental pedicle graft transfer may be a promising therapeutic strategy for spinal neurologic disease.

Successful liver transplantation in a patient with a thrombosed portomesenteric system after multiple failed shunts. We present the case of a 32-year-old male with end-stage liver disease secondary to alcohol-related cirrhosis who developed portal hypertension and subsequent thrombosis of the portomesenteric system. Despite multiple attempts to establish shunts, including a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) and surgical portosystemic shunt, all efforts were unsuccessful in reducing his portal pressure. The patient continued to experience recurrent episodes of variceal bleeding and hepatic encephalopathy. Ultimately, he underwent a successful liver transplantation, resulting in resolution of his portal hypertension and improvement in his liver function. This case highlights the challenging management of portal hypertension in patients with thrombosed portomesenteric systems and emphasizes the potential efficacy of liver transplantation in this population.

Late relapse with nodular lymphoma after treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Late relapse with nodular lymphoma after treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is uncommon. We present a case of a patient who initially presented with diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and achieved complete remission following chemotherapy and radiation therapy. However, five years later, the patient developed relapsed disease with nodular lymphoma in a different anatomic site. This case highlights the importance of long-term surveillance for patients with a history of diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, as late relapse and transformation to a different subtype of lymphoma can occur. Accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment based on the specific subtype of lymphoma are crucial for optimal management and outcomes for these patients. Consideration should also be given to genetic, molecular, and immunophenotypic assessments to guide therapy decisions.

The freckle sign--an endoscopic feature of the cecum. The freckle sign is defined as dark brown speckling or freckle-like pigmentation seen on the surface of the cecum during endoscopic examination. It has been observed in patients with inflammatory bowel disease and is thought to represent chronic inflammation or mucosal healing. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the reliability and clinical significance of the freckle sign in diagnosing inflammatory bowel disease. A total of 100 patients underwent colonoscopy, and the presence or absence of the freckle sign was recorded. It was found that the freckle sign had a sensitivity of 82% and a specificity of 92% for diagnosing inflammatory bowel disease. These findings suggest that the freckle sign can serve as a useful endoscopic marker for the presence of inflammatory bowel disease.

Lipolytic factors associated with murine and human cancer cachexia. Cancer cachexia is a complex syndrome characterized by weight loss, muscle wasting, and systemic inflammation. Lipolysis, the breakdown of adipose tissue, plays a significant role in the development and progression of cachexia. This study aimed to investigate the lipolytic factors associated with murine and human cancer cachexia. 

Using a murine model of cachexia induced by colon adenocarcinoma, we observed increased lipolysis in cachectic mice compared to control. Gene expression analysis revealed upregulation of key lipolytic genes, including hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and adipose triglyceride lipase (ATGL), in cachectic mice. Furthermore, we found elevated circulating levels of free fatty acids (FFAs), indicating increased lipid mobilization in cachexia.

To validate these findings in humans, we analyzed adipose tissue samples from cachectic cancer patients. Consistent with the murine model, we observed upregulation of HSL and ATGL gene expression in cachectic patients compared to non-cachectic controls. Additionally, FFAs were significantly higher in cachectic individuals.

These findings highlight the importance of lipolysis in cancer cachexia and suggest that targeting lipolytic pathways may be a potential therapeutic strategy for managing cachexia-associated weight loss and muscle wasting.

Molteno implants and operating microscope-induced retinal phototoxicity. Molteno implants are commonly used in the surgical treatment of glaucoma. However, there have been reports of retinal phototoxicity occurring after Molteno implant surgery. This study aims to investigate the association between Molteno implants and operating microscope-induced retinal phototoxicity. 

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 20 patients who developed retinal phototoxicity after Molteno implant surgery. The patients' medical records and surgical videos were reviewed to identify potential risk factors and examine the surgical technique used. 

Our findings suggest that the occurrence of retinal phototoxicity after Molteno implant surgery is associated with the use of an operating microscope. Specifically, a prolonged exposure to the microscope light during the surgery was identified as a potential risk factor. 

In conclusion, caution should be exercised when using an operating microscope during Molteno implant surgery to minimize the risk of retinal phototoxicity. Further studies are required to determine optimal surgical techniques and lighting protocols to prevent this complication.

Otitis media in day-care children. Otitis media is a common infection among children attending day-care centers. This study aimed to assess the prevalence, risk factors, and clinical characteristics of otitis media in day-care children. A total of 200 children aged 6 months to 4 years, attending day-care centers, were included in the study. Otitis media was diagnosed in 78% of the children, with bilateral involvement in 42% of cases. Risk factors associated with otitis media included age <2 years, male gender, attendance at day-care for more than 6 months, and exposure to passive smoking. The most common clinical presentation was ear pain (62%), followed by fever (45%) and ear discharge (39%). Streptococcus pneumoniae was the most commonly isolated bacteria (52%), followed by Haemophilus influenzae (34%). Antibiotic treatment was administered to all children, with amoxicillin being the most frequently prescribed. In conclusion, otitis media is highly prevalent among day-care children, with specific risk factors identified. Early diagnosis, appropriate antibiotic treatment, and preventive measures such as vaccination and smoking cessation are crucial in reducing the burden of this condition in day-care settings.

Micromotion of cemented and uncemented femoral components. The stability and longevity of total hip replacements rely on the fixation of the femoral components. Cemented and uncemented techniques are commonly used, but their comparative micromotion has not been extensively studied. This study aimed to analyze and compare the micromotion of cemented and uncemented femoral components in total hip replacements. Thirty patients who underwent total hip replacement surgery were recruited for this study. Fifteen patients received cemented femoral components, and the other fifteen patients received uncemented femoral components. Micromotion of the femoral components was measured using radiostereometric analysis (RSA) at different time points postoperatively. The results showed that cemented femoral components had significantly less micromotion compared to uncemented femoral components at all time points. These findings suggest that cemented femoral components offer better stability in total hip replacements compared to uncemented femoral components, which may have implications for the long-term success of the prosthesis. Further studies with larger sample sizes are recommended to validate these findings.

Posterior transfer of the adductors in children who have cerebral palsy.  A long-term study. Cerebral palsy (CP) is a debilitating disorder in children characterized by motor impairment and muscle spasticity. The adductor muscles of the hip are commonly affected, leading to a scissoring gait and functional limitations. Posterior transfer of the adductors is a surgical procedure commonly performed to improve gait and function in these children. However, there is limited long-term data on the outcomes and complications associated with this procedure. 

In this study, we conducted a long-term follow-up of children with CP who underwent posterior transfer of the adductors. We assessed the functional outcomes, gait pattern, and complications associated with the procedure over a period of 5 years. Our findings demonstrate that posterior adductor transfer significantly improves gait and functional abilities in children with CP. Moreover, long-term follow-up revealed sustained benefits with minimal complications. 

This study provides valuable insights into the efficacy and safety of posterior transfer of the adductors in children with CP, supporting its use as a long-term management strategy for improving functional outcomes in this population. Further research is needed to explore additional factors that may influence outcomes and optimize patient selection for this procedure.

Amebic meningoencephalitis in a patient with AIDS caused by a newly recognized opportunistic pathogen.  Leptomyxid ameba. Amebic meningoencephalitis is a rare but life-threatening infection that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals. We report a case of amebic meningoencephalitis in a patient with AIDS caused by a newly recognized opportunistic pathogen, Leptomyxid ameba. The patient presented with severe headache, altered mental status, and neurological deficits. Initial diagnostic tests, including cerebrospinal fluid analysis and imaging, were inconclusive. However, further investigation using molecular techniques identified the presence of Leptomyxid ameba DNA in the cerebrospinal fluid. Treatment with a combination of antimicrobial agents targeting free-living amebae was initiated, but the patient's condition deteriorated rapidly, leading to a fatal outcome. This case highlights the importance of considering rare pathogens, such as Leptomyxid ameba, in the etiology of amebic meningoencephalitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Early diagnosis and prompt initiation of appropriate therapy are crucial for improving outcomes in these patients. Further research is needed to better understand the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and optimal management of this emerging opportunistic infection.

Multiple noncontiguous spine fractures.  The data from a prospective study of 508 spine injuries were reviewed to determine the incidence of multiple noncontiguous spine fractures. Multiple noncontiguous spine fractures are a rare but significant injury that can result in severe disability and complications. This study aimed to determine the incidence of multiple noncontiguous spine fractures in a population of patients with spine injuries. The data from a prospective study of 508 spine injuries were reviewed, and it was found that 17 patients (3.3%) had multiple noncontiguous spine fractures. The most common cause of these fractures was high-energy trauma, such as motor vehicle accidents or falls from heights. The presence of multiple noncontiguous spine fractures was associated with increased morbidity and mortality. It is important for healthcare professionals to recognize and accurately diagnose these injuries to provide appropriate treatment and optimize outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms and risk factors for multiple noncontiguous spine fractures.

Sequential esophageal motility studies after endoscopic injection sclerotherapy: a prospective investigation.  To assess prospectively the effects of endoscopic intravariceal sclerosis (EIS) on esophageal function, we performed esophageal manometry on 13 cirrhotic patients before EIS, 24 h after the second session and 4 wk after the fourth session. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of endoscopic intravariceal sclerosis (EIS) on esophageal motility in cirrhotic patients. Thirteen patients with cirrhosis underwent esophageal manometry before EIS, 24 hours after the second session of EIS, and 4 weeks after the fourth session. The results showed a significant decrease in lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure after the second session of EIS compared to baseline measurements. However, there was no significant change in LES pressure between the fourth session and the baseline measurements. Furthermore, there was no significant alteration in esophageal peristalsis or amplitude of contractions throughout the study period. These findings suggest that EIS has a transient effect on LES pressure in cirrhotic patients, but does not significantly impact esophageal motility.

Risk of cancer death in first-degree relatives of patients with hereditary non-polyposis cancer syndrome (Lynch type II): a study of 130 kindreds in the United Kingdom. This study aimed to assess the risk of cancer death in first-degree relatives of patients with hereditary non-polyposis cancer syndrome (HNPCC) or Lynch type II syndrome. A total of 130 kindreds from the United Kingdom were included in the study. The risk of cancer death in first-degree relatives was compared to that in the general population. The results showed a significantly increased risk of cancer death in first-degree relatives compared to the general population. The most commonly affected sites were the colon and endometrium. The risk was particularly elevated in relatives of individuals with early-onset cancer. These findings emphasize the importance of early detection and screening in individuals with a family history of HNPCC in order to reduce the risk of cancer-related mortality.

Managing geriatric arrhythmias, II: Drug selection and use [published erratum appears in Geriatrics 1991 Jun;46(6):100] Age-related impairments in antiarrhythmic drug distribution, metabolism, and excretion may result in accumulation of these potent drugs, increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions and drug interactions in the elderly. Geriatric patients with arrhythmias pose unique challenges in choosing and administering antiarrhythmic drugs. Age-related changes in drug distribution, metabolism, and excretion can lead to drug accumulation and potential adverse reactions and interactions. This article provides an overview of the considerations for selecting and using antiarrhythmic drugs in this population. Understanding the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of these drugs in the elderly is crucial for optimizing treatment outcomes while minimizing the risk of complications. Further research is needed to improve drug management strategies for geriatric patients with arrhythmias.

Hashimoto's encephalopathy: a steroid-responsive disorder associated with high anti-thyroid antibody titers--report of 5 cases. Hashimoto's encephalopathy (HE) is a rare autoimmune condition characterized by the presence of high anti-thyroid antibody titers and diverse neurological symptoms. Here, we present a case series of five patients diagnosed with HE and discuss their clinical features, treatment, and outcomes. All patients presented with neurological symptoms, including cognitive impairment, seizures, myoclonus, and psychiatric disturbances. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed nonspecific abnormalities in three cases. Elevated anti-thyroid antibody titers were observed in all patients, confirming the autoimmune nature of the disease. An initial trial of corticosteroids led to significant improvement in all cases, supporting the diagnosis of HE. Long-term management with corticosteroids maintained remission in four patients, while one patient experienced relapse upon steroid tapering. Our findings suggest that HE should be considered in patients with unexplained neurological symptoms, especially when accompanied by high anti-thyroid antibody titers. Early recognition and treatment with corticosteroids can lead to favorable outcomes in this steroid-responsive disorder.

Cholecystokinin enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction calculation as an indicator of disease of the gallbladder. Cholecystokinin (CCK) enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction calculation is a valuable tool for assessing gallbladder disease. In this study, we evaluated the accuracy of this technique in diagnosing gallbladder disease in 55 patients. Patients underwent hepatobiliary scanning before and after intravenous administration of CCK. Gallbladder ejection fraction was calculated using a standardized protocol. Results were compared to histopathological findings or clinical follow-up. Our findings showed a high sensitivity (86%) and specificity (92%) for detecting gallbladder disease using CCK enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction calculation. This suggests that this non-invasive imaging modality could be a useful diagnostic tool for gallbladder disease. Further studies are needed to confirm these results.

A cellist with arm pain: thermal asymmetry in scalenus anticus syndrome.  We report on a cellist with pain and coldness of the upper extremity. Scalenus anticus syndrome (SAS) is a rare condition characterized by compression of the brachial plexus and subclavian artery by the scalenus anticus muscle. We present a case of a 38-year-old female cellist who developed pain and coldness in her right upper extremity, with decreased range of motion. Electric thermography revealed thermal asymmetry, with significantly colder temperatures on the affected side compared to the contralateral side. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine showed compression of the brachial plexus by the scalenus anticus muscle. Diagnosis of SAS was confirmed by electromyography, which revealed denervation changes in the affected muscles. Treatment with physical therapy and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs resulted in partial improvement of symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering SAS in musicians presenting with upper extremity pain, and the potential role of thermal asymmetry as a diagnostic tool in such cases.

Massive allografts in salvage revisions of failed total knee arthroplasties.  Ten patients with failed total knee arthroplasties and severe bone loss were treated with massive whole distal femur and proximal tibial allografts in combination with prosthetic implants. The use of massive allografts in salvage revisions of failed total knee arthroplasties for patients with severe bone loss has shown promising outcomes. In this study, ten patients were treated with a combination of massive whole distal femur and proximal tibial allografts along with prosthetic implants. Radiographic evaluation demonstrated stable fixation, osseointegration, and bone graft incorporation in all cases. Additionally, functional outcomes, including range of motion and Knee Society Scores, improved significantly postoperatively. No major complications or graft failures were observed during the follow-up period. These findings suggest that the use of massive allografts in salvage revisions is a viable option for patients with failed total knee arthroplasties and severe bone loss.

Controlled trial of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease.  Clofazimine versus placebo. Crohn's disease, a chronic inflammatory bowel disorder, has been associated with Mycobacterium paratuberculosis (MAP) infection. This study aimed to investigate the efficacy of antimycobacterial therapy in treating Crohn's disease. A randomized controlled trial was conducted, comparing the use of clofazimine, an antimycobacterial agent, with placebo. A total of 100 patients with active Crohn's disease were enrolled in the study. The primary outcome measure was clinical remission at 12 weeks, defined by a decrease in Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) score of at least 70 points. Secondary outcomes included endoscopic improvement, quality of life measures, and adverse events. Results showed that the clofazimine group had a significantly higher rate of clinical remission compared to the placebo group (52% vs 28%, p<0.05). The clofazimine group also demonstrated greater endoscopic improvement and improved quality of life. Adverse events were minimal and comparable between the two groups. This study provides evidence of the efficacy of antimycobacterial therapy, specifically clofazimine, in treating Crohn's disease, highlighting the potential role of MAP in its pathogenesis.

Blue breath holding is benign. Blue breath holding is a common phenomenon in infants and young children characterized by transient cyanosis and loss of consciousness due to voluntary breath holding. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical characteristics and outcome of blue breath holding in a large cohort of patients. Medical records of patients diagnosed with blue breath holding between 2000 and 2018 were retrospectively reviewed. A total of 142 patients were included in the analysis. The mean age of onset was 18.6 months, and the male-to-female ratio was 1.4:1. The most common precipitating factor was emotional stress (61.3%). The majority of patients had a self-limited course, with only 4.2% experiencing recurrent episodes. Overall, blue breath holding was found to be a benign condition with a favorable outcome in the majority of cases.

Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction presenting as ascites: the importance of clinically assessing central venous pressure. Ascites is typically associated with liver cirrhosis or congestive heart failure, but its presentation as an isolated finding can be challenging to diagnose. We report a case of a 68-year-old male who presented with abdominal distension and ascites. Initial evaluation revealed normal liver function tests and echocardiography showed preserved left ventricular systolic function. However, the patient had elevated central venous pressure on physical examination, suggestive of increased left atrial pressure. Further evaluation, including cardiac catheterization, confirmed the diagnosis of left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. This case emphasizes the importance of considering diastolic dysfunction as a cause of isolated ascites and highlights the significance of clinically assessing central venous pressure in the evaluation of such patients.

Excitatory amino acids in the developing brain: ontogeny, plasticity, and excitotoxicity. Excitatory amino acids play a crucial role in the development of the brain, with glutamate being the most abundant and important one. This review article explores the ontogeny, plasticity, and excitotoxicity of excitatory amino acids in the developing brain. The review highlights the dynamic changes in glutamate receptors and transporters during different stages of brain development, emphasizing the critical period of neuronal plasticity. Excitotoxicity, a pathologic condition characterized by excessive stimulation of excitatory amino acid receptors, is discussed in relation to neurodevelopmental disorders such as cerebral palsy and epilepsy. The review also discusses therapeutic strategies targeting excitotoxicity, including NMDA receptor antagonists and glutamate transporter activators. Understanding the role of excitatory amino acids in brain development and their contribution to excitotoxicity may provide valuable insights into the pathogenesis and treatment of various neurodevelopmental disorders.

Fresnel prisms improve visual perception in stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect. Homonymous hemianopia and unilateral visual neglect are common visual deficits in stroke patients that significantly impact their daily life activities. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Fresnel prisms in improving visual perception in these patients. A total of 30 stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect were included in the study. Visual perception was assessed using standardized tests before and after the application of Fresnel prisms.

The results showed a significant improvement in visual perception in patients after wearing Fresnel prisms. The prisms effectively expanded the visual field and reduced the spatial neglect, leading to better awareness and attention to the neglected side. Furthermore, patients reported an enhanced ability to navigate their environment and perform activities of daily living. No adverse effects or discomfort were reported during prism usage.

In conclusion, Fresnel prisms are a beneficial tool for stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect, as they improve visual perception and promote independence in daily life activities. Further studies are warranted to explore the long-term effects and optimal prism configurations for individual patients.

Adjunctive use of beta-adrenergic blockers, calcium antagonists and other therapies in coronary thrombolysis. The use of adjunctive therapies, such as beta-adrenergic blockers and calcium antagonists, in coronary thrombolysis was investigated. A randomized controlled trial was conducted on patients undergoing thrombolysis for acute coronary syndrome. Patients were assigned to receive either standard thrombolysis alone or standard thrombolysis plus adjunctive therapy. The outcomes measured included mortality, incidence of reinfarction, and adverse drug reactions. The results showed a significant decrease in mortality and reinfarction rates in the group receiving adjunctive therapy compared to the standard thrombolysis group. Adverse drug reactions were similar between the two groups. These findings suggest that the use of adjunctive therapies in coronary thrombolysis can improve patient outcomes and should be considered in clinical practice.

Relationship among level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. Distraction is known to cause spinal cord ischemia and neurological deficits in animals; however, the relationship between the level of distraction and the resulting evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status remains unclear. In this study, animals were subjected to varying levels of distraction and were subsequently assessed for evoked potentials, spinal cord blood flow, and neurological function. The results showed that increasing levels of distraction were associated with decreased evoked potentials and spinal cord blood flow, as well as worsening neurological function. Additionally, animals with higher levels of distraction had greater spinal cord ischemia and reduced spinal cord integrity. These findings suggest a direct relationship between the level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. Further research is needed to validate these findings and translate them to human studies.

Perianal appearances associated with constipation.  The perianal appearances were studied prospectively of 136 constipated children (mean age 3. This study aimed to investigate the perianal appearances associated with constipation in a cohort of 136 children with a mean age of 3. Perianal examinations were performed prospectively to assess the presence of various perianal abnormalities. The majority of children (83%) exhibited at least one perianal abnormality, with the most common being anal fissures (56%), followed by perianal erythema (42%) and skin tags (28%). Other less common findings included perianal excoriation (12%), anal polyps (8%), and perianal abscesses (6%). The presence of perianal abnormalities was significantly associated with longer duration of constipation symptoms and increased stool consistency. These findings suggest that perianal appearances can serve as indicators of chronic constipation and may aid in diagnosing and managing this condition in pediatric patients. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology underlying these perianal changes and their clinical implications.

Fluorometric determination of pseudocholinesterase activity in postmortem blood samples.  A fluorometric assay using 3-(p-hydroxyphenyl) propionic acid (HPPA) was conducted to determine the activity of pseudocholinesterase (ChE) [Enzyme Commission (EC) No. Postmortem blood samples were collected to assess pseudocholinesterase (ChE) activity using a fluorometric assay with 3-(p-hydroxyphenyl) propionic acid (HPPA) as a substrate. The activity of ChE was measured in 50 blood samples, and the results were expressed as units per liter (U/L). The median ChE activity was found to be 900 U/L (range, 400-1400 U/L) in samples collected within 24 hours postmortem, and 700 U/L (range, 300-1000 U/L) in samples collected after 24 hours. These findings suggest that the fluorometric determination of pseudocholinesterase activity could be a useful tool in forensic investigations involving postmortem blood samples.

Intravenous but not intracolonic epidermal growth factor maintains colonocyte proliferation in defunctioned rat colorectum. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of intravenous (IV) and intracolonic (IC) administration of epidermal growth factor (EGF) on colonocyte proliferation in defunctioned rat colorectum. Twenty-four rats were divided into four groups: control, defunctioned, defunctioned+IV EGF, and defunctioned+IC EGF. The rats in the defunctioned groups underwent colonic ligation to induce defunctioning of the colorectum. EGF was administered either intravenously or intracolonically for 14 days. Colonocyte proliferation was assessed by immunohistochemical staining for proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). Results showed that defunctioning of the colorectum significantly decreased colonocyte proliferation compared to the control group. Intravenous administration of EGF significantly increased colonocyte proliferation in the defunctioned colorectum, while intracolonic administration had no significant effect. These findings suggest that intravenous, but not intracolonic, administration of EGF can maintain colonocyte proliferation in the defunctioned colorectum. This supports the potential therapeutic use of IV EGF in preventing detrimental effects of colorectal defunctioning.

Endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch".  The fiberoptic endoscope has never gained popularity among neurosurgeons although it is ideally suited for navigating within the cerebral ventricles. Endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch" is a novel technique that has shown promise in treating obstructive hydrocephalus. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this procedure in a cohort of 50 patients with ventricular obstruction. The saline torch, which consists of a saline-filled tube with a light source, allows for better visualization and accurate fenestration within the ventricles. All procedures were performed by experienced neurosurgeons using a minimally invasive approach. The results showed a significant improvement in ventricular size and reduction in symptoms postoperatively. Complications were minimal, with no cases of infection or hemorrhage observed. The use of the saline torch for endoscopic ventricular fenestration appears to be a promising alternative to traditional techniques and warrants further investigation in larger controlled trials.

Wound infection following early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding. Wound infections are a common complication following sternotomy surgeries. This study aimed to assess the incidence and risk factors associated with wound infection following early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 patients who underwent early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding at a tertiary care hospital. The incidence of wound infection was found to be 14%, with the majority of infections being superficial. Risk factors identified for the development of wound infection included diabetes, obesity, prolonged operating time, and prolonged ventilation. The presence of preoperative blood transfusion and a higher American Society of Anesthesiologists score were also associated with an increased risk. However, there was no statistically significant difference in mortality or length of hospital stay between patients with and without wound infection. These findings highlight the importance of identifying and managing modifiable risk factors to reduce the incidence of wound infection following early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding.

Relaxation training in school classes does not reduce headache complaints. This study aimed to investigate the effects of relaxation training in school classes on headache complaints. A total of 200 students aged 12-15 years were randomly assigned to either a relaxation training group or a control group. The intervention group underwent a 6-week relaxation training program consisting of weekly sessions focused on muscle relaxation and breathing exercises. Headache complaints were assessed using self-report questionnaires before and after the intervention. Results revealed no significant differences in headache complaints between the relaxation training group and the control group. These findings suggest that relaxation training in school classes may not be an effective intervention for reducing headache complaints in adolescents. Further research is needed to explore alternative strategies for headache management in this population.

Complications of general anesthesia for Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors.  We studied the incidence and mechanisms of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency associated with GA and Nd:YAG laser endobronchial tumor resection. A total of 63 patients who underwent Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors under general anesthesia (GA) were included in this study. The overall incidence of cardiovascular complications was found to be 23.8%, with hypotension being the most common complication (19.0%). The occurrence of postoperative respiratory insufficiency was observed in 15.9% of patients. The mechanisms underlying these complications were attributed to disturbance in systemic vascular resistance, myocardial depression, and impaired pulmonary function. Furthermore, patients with a history of cardiovascular disease and those who required longer surgery duration were more prone to developing cardiovascular complications. On the other hand, preoperative pulmonary function impairment and prolonged operation time were identified as risk factors for postoperative respiratory insufficiency. These findings highlight the importance of meticulous monitoring and management to prevent and address these complications in patients undergoing Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors under GA.

Natural history and cardiac manifestations of homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia.  Forty-nine patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia (diagnosed on the basis of family history, xanthomatosis, total serum cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein receptor status) were studied over a period of 13 years, and underwent cardiovascular assessment. The natural history and cardiac manifestations of homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia (HFH) were investigated in a study involving 49 patients over a 13-year period. HFH was diagnosed based on family history, presence of xanthomatosis, total serum cholesterol levels, and low-density lipoprotein receptor status. Cardiovascular assessments were conducted to evaluate the cardiac manifestations of HFH. Results showed that HFH patients had a significantly higher risk of premature coronary events compared to the general population. The majority of patients exhibited elevated serum cholesterol levels, atherosclerosis, and cardiovascular complications such as angina, myocardial infarction, and strokes. Revascularization procedures, such as coronary artery bypass grafting and angioplasty, were required in a substantial number of patients. These findings emphasize the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive management of HFH to prevent cardiovascular events and improve patient outcomes.

Radiation necrosis of the optic chiasm, optic tract, hypothalamus, and upper pons after radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma, detected by gadolinium-enhanced, T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging: case report. Radiation therapy is a common treatment modality for pituitary adenoma, but it can lead to complications such as radiation necrosis. We present a case report of a patient who developed radiation necrosis involving the optic chiasm, optic tract, hypothalamus, and upper pons following radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma. The diagnosis was made using gadolinium-enhanced, T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The patient presented with visual disturbances and endocrine dysfunction, which prompted further investigation. MRI revealed characteristic findings of radiation necrosis, including enhancement and T1 hyperintensity in the affected areas. Treatment options for radiation necrosis include observation, corticosteroids, hyperbaric oxygen therapy, and surgical intervention. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of radiation necrosis in patients receiving radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma.

Pancreatic ascites: treatment by continuous somatostatin infusion. Pancreatic ascites is a rare complication of acute or chronic pancreatitis, characterized by the accumulation of pancreatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity. Current treatment options include medical therapy, percutaneous drainage, or surgical intervention. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of continuous somatostatin infusion as a novel treatment approach for pancreatic ascites.

A total of 15 patients with pancreatic ascites were enrolled in the study. They received continuous somatostatin infusion at a rate of 250 mcg/hour for a duration of 7 days. The primary outcome measure was the resolution of ascites, defined as the absence of fluid collection on abdominal ultrasound or computed tomography scan.

At the end of the 7-day treatment period, 12 out of 15 patients (80%) demonstrated complete resolution of ascites. The mean duration of treatment required for ascites resolution was 4.5 days. No major adverse events were reported during the treatment period.

Continuous somatostatin infusion appears to be an effective and safe treatment modality for pancreatic ascites. Further studies are warranted to evaluate its long-term efficacy and compare it to other treatment options.

Management of posterior urethral strictures secondary to pelvic fractures in children.  Bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty was performed in 20 children with posterior urethral strictures secondary to bony pelvic fractures. Posterior urethral strictures secondary to pelvic fractures can lead to significant urinary dysfunction in children. In this study, the authors performed bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty in 20 children with this condition. The surgical technique involved anastomosing the bulbous urethra to the prostatic urethra. Outcomes were assessed in terms of urinary flow rate, post-void residual volume, and patient satisfaction. The results showed a significant improvement in all parameters following surgery. Complications were minimal, with only one case of recurrent stricture requiring reoperation. The authors conclude that bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty is an effective treatment option for posterior urethral strictures secondary to pelvic fractures in children.

Acupuncture and chronic pain: a criteria-based meta-analysis. Chronic pain is a prevalent condition that poses significant challenges for both patients and healthcare providers. Acupuncture has been increasingly recognized as a potential treatment option for chronic pain management. This meta-analysis aimed to evaluate the efficacy of acupuncture in reducing chronic pain based on established criteria. A systematic search was conducted, and 32 high-quality randomized controlled trials (RCTs) were included in the analysis. The results revealed that acupuncture demonstrated statistically significant improvements in reducing chronic pain compared to sham acupuncture and standard care. Furthermore, acupuncture was found to be superior to both sham acupuncture and standard care in terms of pain intensity reduction and functional improvement. These findings provide robust evidence supporting the use of acupuncture as an effective intervention for chronic pain management. Further research is warranted to determine optimal treatment protocols and long-term effects.

Carcinoma of the pancreas: a retrospective review.  Eighty-five patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas were reviewed in order to evaluate the efficacy of our methods of diagnosis and treatment. This retrospective review aimed to assess the effectiveness of the methods employed for the diagnosis and treatment of adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. A total of 85 patients with carcinoma of the pancreas were included in the study. The patients' medical records were thoroughly examined to gather data regarding their diagnosis and treatment. The study findings revealed that the current diagnostic methods utilized were able to accurately identify adenocarcinoma of the pancreas in all cases. As for treatment, various modalities such as surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy were employed based on the individual patient's condition. The overall survival rate was found to be 25%, with a mean survival time of 12 months. This review highlights the ongoing challenges in the diagnosis and management of pancreatic adenocarcinoma and emphasizes the need for further research to improve patient outcomes.

Acute respiratory tract infection in children in Idikan Community, Ibadan, Nigeria: severity, risk factors, and frequency of occurrence.  A longitudinal, community-based study of the epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) in children less than 5 years old was carried out in a community of low socioeconomic level in Ibadan, Nigeria. The study assessed the severity, risk factors, and frequency of occurrence of acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) in children under 5 years old in the Idikan community in Ibadan, Nigeria. A longitudinal, community-based approach was utilized to examine the epidemiology of ARI in this low socioeconomic community. The results revealed a high frequency of ARI episodes, with a mean of 5.4 episodes per child per year. Risk factors identified included overcrowding, low education levels of mothers, and poor housing conditions. Severe ARI episodes were found to be significantly associated with malnourishment and lack of exclusive breastfeeding. These findings highlight the need for interventions to reduce the burden of ARI in this vulnerable population.

Achieving pH control in the critically ill patient: the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. Acid-base imbalances are common in critically ill patients and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Achieving pH control is therefore an important goal in their management. While intermittent administration of H2-receptor antagonists has traditionally been used for acid suppression, continuous infusion may offer several advantages, including more consistent inhibition of gastric acid secretion and improved pH control. This review aims to summarize the current evidence on the use of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists in achieving pH control in critically ill patients. The pharmacokinetics, safety, and dosing strategies of various H2-receptor antagonists will be discussed, as well as their potential benefits and limitations in this population.

Obstructing carcinoma of the cecum. Cecal carcinoma is a common malignancy that can present with various symptoms, including bowel obstruction. In this study, we report on a case of obstructing carcinoma of the cecum in a 62-year-old male patient. The patient presented with abdominal pain, distension, and constipation. After clinical examination and imaging studies, the diagnosis of obstructing cecal carcinoma was made. The patient underwent an emergency laparotomy, during which a right hemicolectomy with primary anastomosis was performed. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of an adenocarcinoma involving the cecum. The patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery and was referred for adjuvant chemotherapy. This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and prompt surgical management in cases of obstructing cecal carcinoma.

Unusually late onset of cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea after head trauma. We present a case of an unusually late onset of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea following head trauma in a 35-year-old male. The patient initially presented to the emergency department with a history of head injury sustained four weeks prior, during which he experienced a loss of consciousness and a scalp laceration. He had no obvious signs of CSF leak at that time. However, four weeks later, he developed clear nasal discharge, which was confirmed to be CSF by beta-2 transferrin testing. Imaging studies revealed an anterior skull base fracture involving the cribriform plate. The patient underwent endoscopic repair of the CSF leak, which successfully resolved his symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering late onset CSF rhinorrhea in patients with a history of head trauma, even in the absence of immediate symptoms. Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial to prevent potentially serious complications such as meningitis.

Monomorphic adenomas of the major salivary glands: clinicopathological study of 44 cases. In this study, we present a clinicopathological analysis of 44 cases of monomorphic adenomas of the major salivary glands. These tumors are relatively common, accounting for approximately 80% of all salivary gland neoplasms. We found that the mean age of presentation was 44 years, with a predominance in females. The most common site of involvement was the parotid gland, followed by the submandibular gland. Microscopically, the tumors exhibited a variety of architectural patterns, including tubular, trabecular, and solid growth patterns. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive staining for cytokeratin and S100 protein in all cases. Our findings contribute to the understanding of the clinicopathological features of monomorphic adenomas and may aid in their accurate diagnosis and management.

Questionable role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension. The role of central nervous system (CNS) radioprophylaxis in the management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension is not well-established. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of CNS radioprophylaxis in this patient population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 25 pediatric patients with rhabdomyosarcoma and meningeal extension who received multimodal therapy, including chemotherapy, surgery, and radiation therapy. Eight patients received CNS radioprophylaxis, while the remaining 17 did not. The outcomes assessed included local control, overall survival, and treatment-related toxicities. The results showed no significant difference in local control or overall survival between the two groups. However, the incidence of acute and late radiation toxicities was higher in the CNS radioprophylaxis group. These findings suggest a questionable role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension, as it does not appear to improve outcomes while increasing the risk of radiation-related toxicities. Further research is warranted to clarify the optimal management approach for this patient population.

Role of ultrasound guided fine needle aspiration biopsy in the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a common and aggressive malignancy of the liver. The accurate and timely diagnosis of HCC is crucial for appropriate management and prognosis. This study aimed to evaluate the role of ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) in the diagnosis of HCC. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 78 patients with suspicious liver lesions who underwent FNAB. The FNAB results were compared with the final histopathological diagnosis obtained through surgical biopsy or follow-up imaging. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, negative predictive value, and diagnostic accuracy of FNAB for HCC diagnosis were calculated. Our findings demonstrate that ultrasound-guided FNAB is a valuable tool for the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, providing high sensitivity and diagnostic accuracy.

Hyperglycemia presenting with occipital seizures.  Seizures are common in hyperglycemia and are often the first manifestation, particularly in nonketotic hyperglycemia (NKH). Hyperglycemia can present with various neurological symptoms, including seizures. Occipital seizures, although rare, have been reported as a presenting feature of hyperglycemia. We present a case of a 52-year-old male who presented with recurrent occipital seizures and was subsequently diagnosed with hyperglycemia. Neuroimaging revealed no structural abnormalities, and the electroencephalogram showed epileptic activity localized to the occipital area. Laboratory investigations revealed marked hyperglycemia, with a blood glucose level of 414 mg/dL. The patient was managed with intravenous fluids and insulin therapy, resulting in the resolution of his seizures and normalization of glucose levels. Occipital seizures in the setting of hyperglycemia should prompt clinicians to consider nonketotic hyperglycemia as a possible etiology. early recognition and prompt treatment of hyperglycemia are essential to prevent further neurological complications associated with this condition.

Propranolol and the morning increase in sudden cardiac death: (the beta-blocker heart attack trial experience).  To provide insight into the protective effect of propranolol on mortality after myocardial infarction observed in the beta-Blocker Heart Attack Trial, the time of occurrence of sudden cardiac death was examined in this population. In the beta-Blocker Heart Attack Trial, patients who had experienced a myocardial infarction were randomized to receive either propranolol or placebo. The analysis focused on the timing of sudden cardiac death events in both groups. The results revealed a significant association between propranolol administration and reduction in sudden cardiac death occurrence during the morning hours (6:00 AM to 12:00 PM). This finding suggests that propranolol may have a protective effect against sudden cardiac death by modulating physiological factors that contribute to morning peaks in cardiovascular events.

Labetalol and MRI as initial medical and diagnostic modalities in a marfanoid patient with expanding ascending aortic aneurysm. Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder characterized by aortic dilation and aneurysm formation. We present a case of a 32-year-old male with a Marfanoid phenotype who presented with chest pain and was found to have an expanding ascending aortic aneurysm. Due to the patient's hemodynamic instability, labetalol was initiated as a first-line medical therapy to control his blood pressure and reduce the risk of aortic dissection. Subsequently, the patient underwent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to assess the extent of the aneurysm and plan for further intervention. MRI revealed a maximum aortic diameter of 5.6 cm and involvement of the aortic arch. The patient was referred for surgical intervention, and a combined Bentall and aortic arch replacement was performed. This case highlights the importance of prompt medical management with labetalol and the utilization of MRI in guiding treatment decisions in Marfanoid patients with expanding ascending aortic aneurysms.

Oral diseases in older adults [clinical conference] In the case presented, a 65-year-old man with multiple dental, medical, and social problems benefited from interdisciplinary assessment and treatment. This clinical conference discusses the case of a 65-year-old man with a combination of dental, medical, and social issues. The patient's oral health was negatively impacted by factors such as poor oral hygiene, dental anxiety, limited access to dental care, and systemic conditions including diabetes and hypertension. The case highlights the importance of an interdisciplinary approach in managing oral diseases in older adults. The patient's comprehensive assessment involved collaboration between dental professionals, medical specialists, and social workers, resulting in an individualized treatment plan. This included oral hygiene education, periodontal therapy, restorative dentistry, and referral to appropriate medical specialists for the management of systemic conditions. The successful outcome of this case demonstrates the benefits of a multidisciplinary approach in addressing the complex oral health needs of older adults.

Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage: imaging and management. Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage, also known as Wunderlich syndrome, is a rare condition characterized by non-traumatic bleeding into the perinephric space. Prompt and accurate diagnosis of the condition is crucial for providing appropriate management and optimizing patient outcomes. This article reviews the imaging modalities used for diagnosing spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage and highlights the key considerations in choosing the most suitable imaging technique. Radiographic findings, including the presence of a perinephric hematoma, active extravasation, and adjacent organ involvement, are discussed. Additionally, the article describes the various management options available for spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage, ranging from conservative management with blood transfusion and close monitoring to more invasive interventions such as arterial embolization and surgical exploration. The importance of a multidisciplinary approach involving radiologists, urologists, and interventional radiologists is emphasized for the successful management of this condition. Overall, a systematic approach to the imaging and management of spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage is essential for timely diagnosis and appropriate intervention, leading to improved patient outcomes.

Fast short-tau inversion-recovery MR imaging. Fast short-tau inversion-recovery (FAST-STIR) magnetic resonance (MR) imaging is a technique developed to improve the visualization of edema and inflammation in various clinical settings. This study aimed to assess the diagnostic performance of FAST-STIR MR imaging in the evaluation of pathologic conditions. A total of 100 patients with suspected inflammatory or infectious diseases underwent FAST-STIR MR imaging. The results were compared with conventional MR imaging and histopathologic findings. FAST-STIR MR imaging exhibited superior sensitivity and specificity in detecting edema and inflammation compared to conventional MR imaging. It provided higher contrast resolution and shorter acquisition times, enabling a more efficient and accurate diagnosis. FAST-STIR MR imaging has the potential to become a valuable tool in the assessment of various pathologies, allowing for more targeted and effective treatment strategies.

Treatment of duodenitis with cimetidine: a clinical, endoscopic, and histologic study.  We studied the effectiveness of cimetidine in the treatment of endoscopically diagnosed duodenitis. Duodenitis is a common gastrointestinal disorder characterized by inflammation of the duodenal mucosa. The use of cimetidine, a histamine H2-receptor antagonist, has been proposed as a potential treatment option due to its ability to reduce gastric acid secretion and promote healing of ulcerative lesions. 

In this clinical, endoscopic, and histologic study, we aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cimetidine in the treatment of duodenitis. A total of 50 patients with endoscopically diagnosed duodenitis were enrolled in the study. They were randomly assigned to receive either cimetidine or a placebo for a period of 4 weeks. 

Endoscopic examinations and histologic assessments were performed before and after the treatment period to evaluate the degree of inflammation and the presence of ulcers. Additionally, clinical symptoms were assessed using a standardized scoring system. 

Results showed that cimetidine significantly improved endoscopic findings compared to the placebo group. The healing rate of ulcers was significantly higher in the cimetidine group, and there was a significant reduction in the severity of inflammation. Clinical symptoms, including abdominal pain and dyspepsia, were also significantly improved in the cimetidine-treated patients. 

In conclusion, cimetidine appears to be an effective treatment option for duodenitis. It provides significant improvements in endoscopic findings, histologic changes, and clinical symptoms associated with the condition. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer treatment durations are warranted to confirm these findings.

Cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma.  We describe eight cases of cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma, a rare tumor previously reported only once under the term cutaneous angiomyolipoma. Cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma is a rare tumor that has only been reported once under the term cutaneous angiomyolipoma. We present eight cases of this unique tumor. The patients ranged in age from 32 to 56 years and presented with solitary, asymptomatic nodules located on the trunk and extremities. Histopathological examination revealed a distinct combination of mature adipose tissue, smooth muscle fibers, and abnormal blood vessels. Immunohistochemical staining showed positive staining for smooth muscle actin and desmin, confirming the smooth muscle component of the tumor. No evidence of malignant transformation or recurrence was seen in any of the cases during the follow-up period. Cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma should be included in the differential diagnosis of subcutaneous tumors, and surgical excision is recommended for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

Topical treatment of necrotic foot ulcers in diabetic patients: a comparative trial of DuoDerm and MeZinc. Foot ulcers in diabetic patients are a common and challenging complication that often lead to significant morbidity and increased healthcare costs. This study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of topical treatment with DuoDerm and MeZinc in the management of necrotic foot ulcers. A total of 50 diabetic patients with necrotic foot ulcers were enrolled in a randomized, double-blind trial. The patients were assigned to receive either DuoDerm or MeZinc for a period of 4 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the rate of wound healing, assessed by reduction in ulcer size and presence of necrotic tissue. Secondary outcomes included pain relief, occurrence of adverse events, and patient satisfaction. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the optimal topical treatment for necrotic foot ulcers in diabetic patients.

Sumatriptan in acute migraine: pharmacology and review of world experience. Sumatriptan is a widely used medication for the acute treatment of migraines. This medication acts as an agonist of serotonin receptors, specifically targeting the 5-HT1B/1D receptors in cranial blood vessels, leading to vasoconstriction and inhibition of pro-inflammatory neuropeptide release. Numerous clinical trials have demonstrated the efficacy of sumatriptan in relieving migraine symptoms, including pain, nausea, and photophobia. Its onset of action is rapid, with peak plasma concentrations achieved within 30 minutes of administration. The adverse effects of sumatriptan are generally mild and transient, with the most common being injection-site reactions and sensations of tingling, warmth, or heaviness. Sumatriptan has been extensively studied and used worldwide, proving to be an effective and well-tolerated medication for the acute management of migraines.

Newer antihypertensive agents. Hypertension is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease and its management is crucial in reducing associated morbidity and mortality. Over the years, several classes of antihypertensive agents have been developed and are widely used in clinical practice. However, there is a constant need for newer agents with improved efficacy, safety, and tolerability profiles.
