Using chromatin immunoprecipitation assays, we demonstrate the binding of transcriptional repressor proteins to two distinct positive regulatory domains within the beta-interferon gene promoter region. Mutation analysis of these regulatory domains revealed that their disruption resulted in increased beta-interferon gene expression upon viral induction. Furthermore, we show that these repressor proteins interact with components of the transcription complex, suggesting their involvement in the repression of beta-interferon gene transcription. Our findings provide new insights into the complex regulation of beta-interferon gene expression and may have implications for developing novel therapeutic interventions to enhance immune responses against viral infections.

Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs for filling and lining the post-exenteration pelvis. Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs have been recognized as a viable option for patients undergoing pelvic exenteration due to various pelvic malignancies. These reservoirs offer the advantage of utilizing a patient's own intestine for urinary storage and provide continence. In this report, we present the outcomes of using ileocolonic reservoirs in nine patients who underwent pelvic exenteration. The reservoirs were created by anastomosing the proximal ileum to the descending colon. The success rate of continent reservoir creation was 100%, with all patients achieving continence. Postoperative complications, such as urine leak and pouchitis, were minimal. Additionally, the reservoirs provided effective urinary function and significantly enhanced patient quality of life. Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs prove to be a feasible and successful option for filling and lining the post-exenteration pelvis, offering patients improved urinary control and functional outcomes.

Exercise capability in heart failure: is cardiac output important after all? The exercise capability of 39 patients with severe chronic heart failure was assessed in several ways and compared with measurements of cardiac output.  The relation between cardiac index and exercise tolerance measured on a treadmill was poor (r = 0. 11, p > 0.05), suggesting that cardiac output might not be the main determinant of exercise capacity in these patients. Instead, other factors such as peripheral muscle abnormalities or impaired oxygen utilization may play a more significant role. Furthermore, the patients' exercise tolerance was found to be inversely related to their resting pulmonary artery pressure (r = -0.56, p < 0.001), indicating that pulmonary vascular function may have a greater impact on exercise capability than cardiac output. These findings highlight the complex and multifactorial nature of exercise intolerance in heart failure patients and suggest that therapeutic interventions should target not only cardiac function but also peripheral muscle and pulmonary vascular abnormalities.

Routes and incidence of communication of lumbar discs with surrounding neural structures. The communication between lumbar discs and surrounding neural structures is a topic of interest in the field of spine surgery. This study aimed to investigate the routes and incidence of communication between lumbar discs and adjacent neural structures. Twelve fresh cadaveric lumbar spines were dissected to identify any communication between the discs and neural structures, including the dural sac, nerve roots, and lateral recesses. The results revealed that communication between the lumbar discs and neural structures was present in 9 out of the 12 specimens, with the majority of cases involving the L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels. The most common route of communication was found to be through the lateral recesses, followed by direct extension into the dural sac. These findings suggest that communication between lumbar discs and neural structures is not uncommon and should be considered during surgical planning to avoid iatrogenic injury and optimize outcomes. Further studies are necessary to explore the clinical implications and potential impact on treatment strategies.

Rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias with high-dose oral amiodarone.  To shorten the delay in the onset of antiarrhythmic effect when using amiodarone for the conversion of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm, 19 patients were given oral amiodarone according to a high-dose loading protocol. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of high-dose oral amiodarone for rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias. Nineteen patients with refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias were enrolled in the study and given oral amiodarone according to a high-dose loading protocol. The protocol consisted of an initial loading dose of 800 mg/day for the first week, followed by a maintenance dose of 400 mg/day thereafter. The patients were closely monitored for cardiac rhythm and adverse events. The results showed that high-dose oral amiodarone led to rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias in all patients, with conversion to sinus rhythm achieved within a mean time of 48 hours. The treatment was generally well-tolerated, with no serious adverse events reported. In conclusion, high-dose oral amiodarone can be an effective and safe strategy for the rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias.

Malignant glandular triton tumor. Malignant glandular triton tumor (MGTT) is an extremely rare, aggressive malignancy that arises from neurogenic elements and exhibits a dual histological pattern of both malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) and malignant rhabdomyoblastic differentiation. This study aims to present clinical, histological, and molecular characteristics of MGTT.

A systematic review was conducted using multiple databases to identify cases of MGTT reported in the literature. Data on patient demographics, clinical presentation, imaging findings, histological features, immunohistochemical analysis, treatment modalities, and outcomes were collected and analyzed.

A total of 22 cases of MGTT were identified. The mean age at diagnosis was 37 years, with a slight male predominance. The most common clinical presentation was a rapidly growing mass, often associated with pain and neurological symptoms. Histologically, MGTT demonstrated a mixture of malignant glandular and rhabdomyoblastic elements. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed positive staining for various markers specific to neurogenic and myogenic differentiation. Molecular analysis demonstrated frequent alterations in TP53 and NF1 genes.

MGTT is a highly aggressive tumor with a poor prognosis. Early recognition and accurate histological diagnosis are crucial for appropriate management. Further research is needed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying its development and identify potential therapeutic targets for this rare malignancy.

Reversed lateralization of cognitive functions in right handers. The lateralization of cognitive functions in right-handed individuals has traditionally been believed to be primarily left hemisphere dominant. However, emerging research has suggested that there may be instances of reversed lateralization in certain cognitive tasks. This article aims to review the current literature on the phenomenon of reversed lateralization in right-handers.

Several studies have demonstrated instances where right-handers exhibit right hemisphere dominance in specific cognitive domains such as language processing, spatial orientation, and attentional control. These findings challenge the long-held assumption of left hemisphere dominance in right-handed individuals.

The mechanisms underlying reversed lateralization in right-handers are not yet fully understood. Possible explanations include genetic factors, developmental influences, and compensatory mechanisms in response to brain damage.

Understanding the existence and implications of reversed lateralization in right-handers is crucial for accurately interpreting cognitive function in clinical settings. Furthermore, this knowledge may have implications for rehabilitation strategies after brain injuries or in the context of neurodevelopmental disorders. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and broader implications of this phenomenon.

Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. Ichthyosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the abnormal scaling and thickening of the skin. It is often associated with other developmental abnormalities, such as mental retardation and spasticity. This abstract presents a case study of a patient with ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. The patient, a 10-year-old male, presented with the classical features of ichthyosis, including dry, scaly skin and pruritus. However, he did not exhibit any signs of motor dysfunction or neurologic deficits. The patient underwent a comprehensive evaluation, including genetic testing, which revealed a mutation in the ABCA12 gene, confirming the diagnosis of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis. Although the patient's mental retardation and spasticity remained asymptomatic, ongoing monitoring and early intervention are recommended to address potential future challenges associated with developmental delay and motor abnormalities. This case highlights the need for multidisciplinary care and genetic counseling to optimize the management and outcome of patients with ichthyosis and associated comorbidities.

Early gastric cancer.  Twenty-eight-year experience.  A retrospective study of early gastric cancer (60 patients) was performed to evaluate its diagnosis and treatment. The mean age of patients with early gastric cancer was 59 years and the male to female ratio was 1.4:1. The majority of cases presented with symptoms such as epigastric pain, dyspepsia, and weight loss. Endoscopy was the primary diagnostic modality, with 56 cases (93.3%) accurately identifying the tumor. Histological examination revealed that 35 cases (58.3%) were well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Radical surgery was performed in 58 patients (96.7%), while endoscopic resection or palliative surgery was performed in the remaining two cases. The 5-year survival rate was 83.3%. Lymph node involvement was significantly associated with decreased survival. In conclusion, early gastric cancer can be effectively diagnosed and treated. Endoscopy plays a vital role in identifying tumors and guiding appropriate treatment. Radical surgery should be considered as the first-line treatment option to maximize long-term survival. Further studies are needed to explore strategies for improving prognosis in cases with lymph node involvement.

Surgical treatment of active native valve endocarditis.  A report is presented of 24 patients (23 male), mean age 38 years, who underwent surgery for active native valve endocarditis of the left heart in 1975-1988. The patients were classified into three groups based on disease severity. The majority of patients (71%) had severe disease, while 17% had moderate disease and 12% had mild disease. The most common causative organisms were Staphylococcus aureus (42%) and Streptococcus viridans (21%). The median time from admission to surgery was 6.5 days. Valve replacement surgery was performed in 83% of cases, with 63% receiving a mechanical valve and 37% receiving a bioprosthetic valve. The overall in-hospital mortality rate was 17%, with the highest rate seen in the severe disease group (23%). Postoperative complications included heart failure (25%), renal failure (8%), and neurological complications (4%). The results suggest that surgical treatment of active native valve endocarditis can be successful in achieving good outcomes, particularly in patients with less severe disease.

Response to suxamethonium in a myasthenic patient during remission. A case report describes a myasthenic patient who experienced a unique reaction to suxamethonium during a remission period. Suxamethonium is a neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia. The patient, diagnosed with myasthenia gravis, had previously experienced adverse reactions to suxamethonium during active disease but remained asymptomatic during remission. However, during a routine surgical procedure, the patient displayed immediate muscle weakness and respiratory distress after administration of suxamethonium. Laboratory tests confirmed the patient's stable disease state during this time, ruling out disease exacerbation as the cause. This case highlights the importance of considering individual patient responses and potential divergent reactions to medications, even during periods of disease remission. Further investigation is warranted to understand the underlying mechanisms involved.

Interpleural analgesia [published erratum appears in Heart Lung 1991 Jul;20(4):413] Postoperative pain relief is necessary not only for patient comfort, but also to facilitate ventilation and ambulation. Interpleural analgesia is a viable method for postoperative pain relief, as it not only improves patient comfort but also aids in ventilation and ambulation. A published erratum in Heart Lung 1991 highlights the significance of this technique. By administering analgesics directly into the interpleural space, this method provides effective pain relief, allowing patients to breathe deeply and cough without discomfort. In turn, this promotes better lung ventilation and reduces the risk of atelectasis and pneumonia. Additionally, interpleural analgesia facilitates early mobilization, enhancing recovery and decreasing the length of hospital stay. Overall, interpleural analgesia is a valuable approach that should be considered for postoperative pain management.

Mobile knee reconstructions after resection of malignant tumors of the distal femur. Resection of malignant tumors in the distal femur often results in significant bone loss and functional impairment. Mobile knee reconstructions using endoprosthesis have shown promise in restoring joint function and providing stability. In this study, we present our experience with 26 patients who underwent mobile knee reconstructions after resection of malignant tumors in the distal femur. The mean follow-up period was 36 months. Clinical and radiographic evaluation revealed satisfactory knee function and implant survival in the majority of patients. Complications, such as infection and implant loosening, were observed in a small number of cases. Mobile knee reconstructions appear to be a viable option for patients undergoing resection of malignant tumors in the distal femur.

Serial CA 125 levels during chemotherapy for metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer. This study aimed to assess the use of serial CA 125 levels during chemotherapy for metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients diagnosed between 2000 and 2010 at a single institution. CA 125 levels were measured at baseline and during chemotherapy. The study included 54 patients with a mean age of 62 years. The majority had stage III disease (n=43) and were treated with platinum-based chemotherapy. A significant correlation was found between CA 125 levels and tumor burden at baseline (p<0.001). During chemotherapy, CA 125 levels showed a significant decrease in 75% of patients. Patients with a complete response had a significant decline in CA 125 levels compared to those with stable or progressive disease (p=0.001). Serial CA 125 measurements can serve as a useful tool in monitoring response to chemotherapy and predicting tumor burden in metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer.

Role of systemic therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer. Systemic therapy plays a crucial role in the management of advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC). This medical abstract aims to summarize the current understanding of systemic therapy in NSCLC. The use of chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy has significantly improved outcomes for patients with advanced NSCLC. Combination chemotherapy regimens have shown superior efficacy compared to single agents, and platinum-based combinations remain the standard of care. The emergence of targeted therapies, such as tyrosine kinase inhibitors and immune checkpoint inhibitors, has revolutionized treatment options for specific subsets of NSCLC patients with driver mutations or high PD-L1 expression. Personalized medicine, guided by molecular profiling and biomarkers, is increasingly important in selecting the most appropriate systemic therapy. Ongoing research continues to refine treatment strategies and identify novel therapeutic targets for advanced NSCLC.

An inner city cancer prevention clinic. Inner city cancer prevention clinics play a crucial role in promoting early detection, prevention, and education in underserved communities. These clinics aim to reduce health disparities by providing accessible and culturally sensitive services, including cancer screenings, risk assessments, and counseling. The implementation of evidence-based strategies, such as community outreach programs, mobile screening units, and targeted educational campaigns, enhances the clinic's effectiveness in reaching the at-risk population. Additionally, partnerships with local community organizations, healthcare providers, and policymakers facilitate the provision of comprehensive and coordinated care. By addressing the unique challenges faced by individuals in inner city communities, such as limited access to healthcare, low health literacy, and socioeconomic barriers, these clinics contribute to reducing cancer incidence, improving outcomes, and promoting health equity.

Unusual blink reflex with four components in a patient with periodic ataxia. We present a case report of a patient with periodic ataxia who exhibited an unusual blink reflex with four components. The patient, a 48-year-old female, presented with a history of episodic ataxia and slurred speech. Neurological examination revealed dysmetria and abnormal eye movements. Electrophysiological testing demonstrated a blink reflex with four distinct components: an early response, a late response, a mid-response, and a prolonged response. This atypical blink reflex pattern has not been previously described in patients with periodic ataxia. The patient was treated with a combination of antiepileptic medications and experienced partial improvement in her symptoms. Further research is needed to elucidate the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying this unique blink reflex pattern in patients with periodic ataxia, as well as to determine the optimal treatment strategies for managing this condition.

Ischaemic heart disease among men in Norway during the period 1966-1985: two counties with different mortality time trends.  We have examined regional differences in mortality from ischaemic heart disease, including sudden, unexpected death (IHD/SUD), among Norwegian men aged 30-69 years, during the period 1966-1985. We found significant variations in mortality rates from ischaemic heart disease (IHD) between two counties in Norway during the years 1966-1985. One county demonstrated a steady decline in IHD mortality over the study period, while the other county experienced a stable or increasing trend. The observed differences in mortality time trends were primarily attributed to variations in rates of sudden, unexpected death (SUD) related to IHD. The county with declining IHD mortality also showed a significant decrease in SUD rates, whereas the county with stable or increasing IHD mortality had stable or increasing SUD rates. These findings suggest that regional differences in mortality from IHD/SUD can occur within a single country, highlighting the need for targeted interventions in specific regions to reduce IHD-related deaths.

pH-adjustment and discomfort caused by the intradermal injection of lignocaine [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):242] One hundred adult day-case patients who required intravenous access had cannulae inserted using local anaesthesia with 1% lignocaine, 1% lignocaine with adrenaline or the corresponding pH-adjusted solutions. This study aimed to investigate the discomfort caused by intradermal injection of lignocaine and the role of pH-adjusted solutions in reducing this discomfort. One hundred adult day-case patients requiring intravenous access were enrolled in the study. Cannulae were inserted using local anesthesia with 1% lignocaine, 1% lignocaine with adrenaline, or pH-adjusted solutions of lignocaine. Patients were evaluated for their perception of discomfort using a visual analogue scale. Results showed that the pH-adjusted lignocaine solutions significantly reduced discomfort compared to the non-pH-adjusted solutions. The findings highlight the importance of pH-adjustment in reducing discomfort associated with lignocaine injections, leading to improved patient experience during intravenous access procedures.

Histochemical demonstration of 5'-nucleotidase activity in inflammatory muscle disease. Inflammatory muscle diseases, such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis, are characterized by muscle inflammation and damage. The diagnosis of these diseases often relies on muscle biopsy and histopathological examination. We present a study on the histochemical demonstration of 5'-nucleotidase activity in inflammatory muscle disease. Muscle biopsies from patients with dermatomyositis, polymyositis, and healthy controls were stained using a histochemical technique to detect the presence of 5'-nucleotidase activity. Our results show a significantly higher level of 5'-nucleotidase activity in muscle fibers from patients with inflammatory muscle disease compared to controls, indicating its potential as a diagnostic marker for these conditions. This study contributes to the understanding of the pathological mechanisms underlying inflammatory muscle disease and provides a promising target for future diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

An epidemic outbreak of cryptosporidiosis: a prospective community study from Guinea Bissau.  In the first year of a prospective community study of childhood diarrhea conducted in a semiurban area in the capital of Guinea Bissau, Cryptosporidium sp. was identified as the causative agent in an epidemic outbreak of diarrhea. A total of 235 children aged 0-59 months were included in the study, with a median age of 15 months. The incidence of cryptosporidiosis was found to be 46.4%, with a peak occurring during the rainy season. Children infected with Cryptosporidium sp. experienced higher rates of persistent diarrhea and malnutrition compared to those without the infection. Additionally, coinfections with other enteropathogens were observed in a significant proportion of cases. These findings highlight the importance of recognizing and addressing the impact of cryptosporidiosis in resource-limited settings, particularly during outbreaks, to improve the management and control of childhood diarrhea.

Prediction of cognitive change as a function of preoperative ability status among temporal lobectomy patients seen at 6-month follow-up. This study aimed to examine the relationship between preoperative cognitive ability status and cognitive change among temporal lobectomy patients at a 6-month follow-up. The sample consisted of individuals who underwent temporal lobectomy for the treatment of epilepsy. Preoperative cognitive ability was assessed using standardized neuropsychological tests, and cognitive change was measured using the same tests at the 6-month follow-up. Regression analyses were conducted to determine whether preoperative ability status predicted cognitive change. Results showed that individuals with higher preoperative cognitive ability exhibited less decline in cognitive function at the 6-month follow-up compared to those with lower preoperative ability. This finding suggests that preoperative cognitive ability may serve as a predictive factor for postoperative cognitive outcomes in temporal lobectomy patients. Further research is needed to explore other potential predictors of cognitive change and to develop interventions that can mitigate cognitive decline following temporal lobectomy.

Antiepileptic drugs, cognitive function, and behavior in children: evidence from recent studies.  The effects of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) on cognitive function and behavior in children are reviewed on the basis of published studies. Several studies have examined the effects of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) on cognitive function and behavior in children. Overall, these studies indicate that AED use is associated with cognitive and behavioral changes. Specifically, some AEDs have been found to have negative effects on attention, memory, language skills, and executive functions. Additionally, AEDs have been associated with increased risk of behavioral problems, such as hyperactivity and aggression. However, some studies suggest that the cognitive and behavioral effects may be drug-specific, with certain AEDs having less detrimental effects. Further research is needed to better understand the specific effects of different AEDs on cognitive function and behavior in children.

Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage: imaging and management. Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage, also known as Wunderlich syndrome, is a rare condition characterized by non-traumatic bleeding into the perinephric space. This condition can be associated with various etiologies, including renal tumors, vascular abnormalities, and anticoagulant use. The presenting symptoms often include severe flank pain, hematuria, and hypovolemic shock. Prompt recognition and accurate imaging play a crucial role in the management of this condition. Computed tomography (CT) scan is the modality of choice for diagnosis, providing detailed information about the extent and cause of the hemorrhage. Conservative management is the primary approach in stable patients with small, well-controlled hematomas. However, in cases of uncontrolled bleeding, persistent hemodynamic instability, or large hematomas causing compression of adjacent structures, interventional radiology techniques may be necessary, including arterial embolization or nephrectomy. The clinical outcome of spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage depends on the severity of underlying pathology, timely intervention, and appropriate management. Prognosis is generally favorable for patients undergoing prompt and appropriate treatment. Further research is needed to elucidate optimal management strategies and improve patient outcomes.

New horizons in the treatment of coronary artery thrombosis. Coronary artery thrombosis is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt and effective treatment. Traditional management strategies have focused on the use of antithrombotic medications and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). However, emerging evidence suggests that novel approaches may offer additional benefits in the treatment of this condition. This review aims to explore these new horizons in the treatment of coronary artery thrombosis. One such approach is the use of thrombolytic agents, which can rapidly dissolve the thrombus and restore blood flow. Additionally, advancements in interventional techniques, such as the use of drug-eluting stents and bioresorbable scaffolds, have shown promise in preventing rethrombosis and improving long-term outcomes. Furthermore, there is ongoing research on the use of adjunctive therapies, such as antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants, to optimize the management of coronary artery thrombosis. With the integration of these new strategies, the future of coronary artery thrombosis treatment appears promising, with the potential to improve patient outcomes and reduce morbidity and mortality.

Threshold perimetry in tilted disc syndrome.  Twelve consecutive patients (17 eyes) with tilted disc syndrome underwent quantified visual field examination with the G1 Octopus program (Interzeag AG, Schlieren, Switzerland). Tilted disc syndrome is a condition characterized by an abnormal tilting of the optic disc, which can result in visual field defects. This study aimed to assess the utility of threshold perimetry in diagnosing and monitoring visual field changes in patients with tilted disc syndrome. Twelve patients with tilted disc syndrome, accounting for 17 eyes, were enrolled in the study. Quantified visual field examinations were conducted using the G1 Octopus program. The results showed that all patients exhibited visual field defects, with the inferotemporal region being the most commonly affected area. Additionally, there was a correlation between the degree of tilt of the optic disc and the severity of visual field defects. The study concludes that threshold perimetry is a valuable tool in the diagnosis and follow-up of visual field changes in patients with tilted disc syndrome.

Long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. This study aimed to investigate the long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. The records of 105 individuals who had experienced these forms of sexual abuse were analyzed. Participants' medical histories were reviewed to identify any physical or psychological health issues that could be attributed to their traumatic experiences. Results showed that individuals who had experienced incest, rape, or molestation had a higher prevalence of various medical conditions, including sexually transmitted infections, chronic pelvic pain, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder. These findings highlight the need for comprehensive medical care and support services for survivors of sexual abuse, with a focus on addressing both physical and psychological health issues.

The electrocardiogram in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a common and debilitating respiratory condition that is associated with various cardiac manifestations, including electrocardiographic abnormalities. These abnormalities can provide valuable information regarding the severity and prognosis of COPD. In this review, we aim to summarize the different electrocardiographic changes seen in patients with COPD, including right ventricular hypertrophy, right atrial enlargement, and arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation and ventricular premature beats. We also discuss the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms that contribute to these electrocardiographic changes, such as pulmonary hypertension, hypoxemia, and systemic inflammation. Understanding and recognizing these electrocardiographic findings is crucial for clinicians in the management and prognosis of COPD, as they can guide further investigation, risk stratification, and treatment decisions.

Isolated trigeminal sensory loss secondary to a distal anterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm: case report.  A previously healthy 25-year-old woman suddenly developed right-sided facial numbness and a headache. Further investigation revealed isolated trigeminal sensory loss on the right side of the face. A cranial magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) showed a distal anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) aneurysm. The patient underwent endovascular coiling of the aneurysm without any complications. Follow-up examination showed resolution of the facial numbness and headache. Isolated trigeminal sensory loss is a rare symptom of AICA aneurysms, with only a few cases reported in the literature. AICA aneurysms often present with symptoms such as hearing loss, vertigo, and facial weakness, but isolated trigeminal sensory loss is unusual. In this case, the small size and distal location of the aneurysm likely contributed to the isolated sensory loss. Awareness of this atypical presentation is important for clinicians to consider when evaluating patients with facial sensory disturbances. Further studies are needed to determine the underlying mechanisms of isolated trigeminal sensory loss in AICA aneurysms.

Umbilical cord hematoma following diagnostic funipuncture. Diagnostic funipuncture, also known as umbilical cord blood sampling, is a procedure commonly performed during pregnancy to obtain fetal blood for diagnostic testing. Despite being a relatively safe procedure, rare complications can occur, including umbilical cord hematoma. This abstract presents a case of umbilical cord hematoma following diagnostic funipuncture and a review of the literature on this rare complication. The patient, a 26-year-old pregnant woman, underwent a diagnostic funipuncture at 32 weeks gestation. Within hours of the procedure, she developed increasing abdominal pain and tenderness. Ultrasound examination revealed a hematoma within the umbilical cord. The patient was managed conservatively with close monitoring and supportive care. Umbilical cord hematomas are uncommon but potentially serious complications of diagnostic funipuncture. Prompt recognition and appropriate management are essential to prevent fetal distress and improve outcomes. This case highlights the importance of careful technique and close post-procedural monitoring in reducing the risk of complications associated with diagnostic funipuncture.

Endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch".  The fiberoptic endoscope has never gained popularity among neurosurgeons although it is ideally suited for navigating within the cerebral ventricles. Ventricular fenestration is a surgical procedure performed to alleviate hydrocephalus by creating a communication between the cerebral ventricles and the subarachnoid space. This abstract presents a novel approach for ventricular fenestration, utilizing a fiberoptic endoscope and a "saline torch" technique. This technique involves the use of a saline solution to create a controlled steam cloud, which is used to create a fenestration within the ventricular wall. This endoscopic procedure offers several advantages over traditional methods, including improved visualization, reduced risk of infection, and shorter recovery times. In a series of 15 patients with obstructive hydrocephalus, all patients underwent successful ventricular fenestration using the saline torch technique. Postoperative outcomes were favorable, with resolution of symptoms and improvement in ventricular size observed in all cases. The use of the fiberoptic endoscope and the saline torch technique presents a promising alternative for ventricular fenestration, offering potential benefits for patients with hydrocephalus. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.

Neurinoma in the cavernous sinus: report of two cases. This case report describes two cases of neurinoma located in the cavernous sinus. Both patients presented with symptoms such as headache, diplopia, and facial numbness. Imaging studies revealed a well-defined mass within the cavernous sinus in both cases. Surgical excision of the tumors was performed successfully in both patients without any complications. Histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of neurinoma in both cases. Follow-up imaging showed no evidence of recurrence or residual tumor. Neurinomas in the cavernous sinus are rare and challenging to treat due to the complex anatomy of the region. This report adds to the limited literature on this rare entity and highlights the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate surgical intervention.

Intraosseous lipoma within the femoral head. Intraosseous lipoma is a rare benign tumor that occurs within the medullary cavity of bone. We present a case of a 52-year-old male with longstanding hip pain, who was found to have an incidental intraosseous lipoma within the femoral head on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The patient underwent surgical excision of the lesion, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of intraosseous lipoma. This case highlights the importance of considering intraosseous lipoma as a differential diagnosis in patients with hip pain, especially when imaging studies demonstrate characteristic findings such as well-defined lobulated lesions with fat-suppressed sequences on MRI. The management of intraosseous lipomas involves surgical excision, which can provide symptomatic relief and prevent potential complications such as fracture or malignant transformation.

Infarct of the conus medullaris simulating a spinal cord tumor: case report. We present a case report of a 45-year-old male patient who presented with progressive lower back pain and bilateral lower extremity weakness. Initial imaging studies showed a mass lesion in the conus medullaris region, raising suspicion for a spinal cord tumor. However, upon further evaluation, including magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography myelography, the lesion was found to be an infarct of the conus medullaris. This rare entity, often misdiagnosed as a spinal cord tumor, can present with similar clinical and radiological features. Recognition of this condition is vital to avoid unnecessary surgical interventions and to initiate appropriate management promptly. We discuss the clinical presentation, imaging findings, and differential diagnosis of infarct of the conus medullaris.

Unusual aspects of aortovenous fistulas associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms. Aortovenous fistulas (AVFs) associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) are rare but potentially life-threatening vascular complications. In this case series, we describe the unusual characteristics and management of AVFs in patients with ruptured AAAs. Nine patients with AVFs secondary to ruptured AAAs were identified over a 5-year period. The mean age was 68 years, with a male predominance. All patients presented with hemodynamic instability and signs of hemorrhagic shock. Diagnostic imaging revealed the presence of AVFs in all cases, with characteristics including large fistula size, high-flow rates, and multiple communication points between the aorta and adjacent veins. Surgical intervention was performed in all patients, involving open AAA repair and ligation or endovascular embolization of the AVF. Despite the complex nature of these cases, favorable outcomes were achieved, with successful repair of the ruptured AAA and resolution of the AVF. This case series highlights the importance of prompt recognition and management of AVFs associated with ruptured AAAs, emphasizing the need for a multidisciplinary approach for optimal patient outcomes.

Genetic diagnosis of Lynch syndrome II in an extended colorectal cancer-prone family. Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by an increased risk of developing colorectal and various other cancers. The diagnosis of Lynch syndrome is crucial for the identification of at-risk individuals and the implementation of proper screening and surveillance protocols. In this study, we report the genetic diagnosis of Lynch syndrome II in an extended colorectal cancer-prone family.

Using a combination of DNA sequencing and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA), we identified a germline mutation in the mismatch repair (MMR) gene MSH2 in several affected individuals within the family. This mutation was absent in healthy relatives and in a control population.

Furthermore, immunohistochemical analysis revealed a loss of MSH2 protein expression in tumor samples from mutation carriers, confirming the pathogenicity of the identified mutation. Our findings provide evidence for the genetic basis of Lynch syndrome II in this family and underscore the importance of genetic testing in the management of individuals with a suspected genetic predisposition to colorectal cancer.

Epstein-Barr virus associated oesophageal ulcers in AIDS. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) association with oesophageal ulcers in individuals with AIDS has been reported in the literature. This study aimed to further investigate this association. Ten patients with AIDS and oesophageal ulcers were included in the study. Biopsy samples were obtained from the ulcerated areas and subjected to histological examination and viral identification techniques. EBV DNA was detected in all ten patients, confirming the presence of EBV infection. Additionally, immunohistochemical staining revealed a high viral load in the ulcerated areas. The findings suggest a strong correlation between EBV infection and the development of oesophageal ulcers in individuals with AIDS. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for this condition.

Recurrence rate after discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy in alveolar echinococcosis (preliminary results).  The recurrence rate was investigated in 19 patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuation of a long-term therapy with mebendazole (average treatment 4. The recurrence rate of alveolar echinococcosis following the discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy was examined in a study involving 19 patients with non-resectable disease. The average duration of mebendazole treatment was 4.9 years. Patients were followed up for a mean duration of 3.1 years after stopping the therapy. Recurrence of disease was observed in 5 out of the 19 patients, resulting in a recurrence rate of 26.3%. The median time to recurrence was 1.5 years. Analysis of the recurrence cases indicated that they were mainly restricted to the liver and adjacent organs. No extrahepatic spread or dissemination was observed. These preliminary results suggest that discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy may lead to a significant risk of recurrence in patients with alveolar echinococcosis. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these findings.

Transient myocardial ischemia and its relation to determinants of myocardial oxygen demand. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship between transient myocardial ischemia and determinants of myocardial oxygen demand. A total of 75 patients with stable angina were enrolled in this prospective cohort study. All patients underwent continuous electrocardiogram monitoring and ambulatory Holter monitoring for 24 hours. Transient myocardial ischemia episodes were identified using predefined criteria. Multiple linear regression analysis was used to assess the association between transient myocardial ischemia and determinants of myocardial oxygen demand. The results showed a significant positive association between transient myocardial ischemia and heart rate, systolic blood pressure, and rate-pressure product. These findings suggest that increased heart rate, systolic blood pressure, and rate-pressure product contribute to transient myocardial ischemia by increasing myocardial oxygen demand. Further research is needed to explore strategies for reducing myocardial oxygen demand and preventing transient myocardial ischemia.

Surgical results of intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating hiatal hernia.  From 1981 to 1988, 138 patients with hiatal hernia were treated surgically at our centre. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the surgical results of intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating hiatal hernia. A total of 138 patients with hiatal hernia who underwent surgical treatment at our center between 1981 and 1988 were included in the study. Among these patients, 16 (11.6%) had intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating their hernia. The mean age of the patients was 61 years, and there was a slight female predominance (female to male ratio of 1.2:1). 
Surgical intervention involved repair of the hiatal hernia with fundoplication. In cases of gastric ischemia or necrosis, partial gastrectomy with gastrojejunostomy was performed. The overall surgical mortality rate was 6.3%, with two deaths attributed to gastric ischemia and necrosis. 
In conclusion, intrathoracic gastric volvulus can be a serious complication of hiatal hernia. Early surgical intervention with hernia repair and potential gastric resection is necessary, especially in cases of gastric ischemia or necrosis, to prevent adverse outcomes. Further studies are required to assess long-term outcomes and potential risk factors for this complication.

Mesial temporal sclerosis: pathogenesis, diagnosis, and management. Mesial temporal sclerosis (MTS) is a highly prevalent form of epilepsy characterized by selective neuronal loss and gliosis in the mesial temporal lobe, particularly in the hippocampus. MTS is associated with temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) and is a common cause of medically refractory seizures. The pathogenesis of MTS is multifactorial and includes genetic factors, prenatal insults, febrile seizures, and prolonged seizures. The diagnosis of MTS relies on thorough clinical evaluation, video electroencephalography (EEG) monitoring, neuroimaging techniques such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and neuropathological examination. Management of MTS consists primarily of antiepileptic drug therapy, with surgical resection reserved for patients with intractable seizures. Despite the advances in neuroimaging and surgical techniques, challenges still remain in the accurate diagnosis and effective management of MTS. This review aims to provide an overview of the pathogenesis, diagnosis, and management of MTS, with a focus on the current strategies and future directions in the field.

Doppler echocardiographic evaluation of streptokinase lysis of thrombosed right-sided St.  Jude Medical valves in patients with congenital heart defects. Thrombosis of mechanical heart valves is a serious complication in patients with congenital heart defects. Streptokinase lysis has been shown to be effective in resolving thrombosis in prosthetic valves. However, there is limited data on the efficacy of streptokinase lysis specifically in thrombosed right-sided St. Jude Medical valves. We conducted a Doppler echocardiographic evaluation of streptokinase lysis in 25 patients with congenital heart defects who had thrombosed right-sided St. Jude Medical valves. The results showed successful resolution of thrombosis in 22 out of 25 patients (88%) following streptokinase lysis, as evidenced by restored valve function and absence of thrombus on echocardiography. There were no major complications during the lysis procedure. Our study suggests that streptokinase lysis is an effective and safe treatment option for thrombosed right-sided St. Jude Medical valves in patients with congenital heart defects. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore long-term outcomes in larger cohorts.

Indwelling epidural catheters for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. The use of indwelling epidural catheters for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients was evaluated in this study. A total of 57 patients who underwent surgery for gynecologic cancer were included in the analysis. The mean age of the patients was 61 years. The majority of patients had advanced stage disease (stage III or IV) and underwent radical surgery. The indwelling epidural catheters were placed preoperatively and remained in place postoperatively for pain control. The results showed that the use of indwelling epidural catheters provided effective pain relief in the majority of patients, with a mean pain score of less than 3 on a 0-10 scale. The incidence of epidural catheter-related complications was low, with only two cases of catheter dislodgement requiring repositioning. In conclusion, indwelling epidural catheters are a safe and effective option for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients undergoing surgery.

Cumulative load as a risk factor for back pain.  The association between cumulative load (biomechanic load and exposure time integral over the entire work experience) and back pain was investigated in a group of institutional aides with physically stressful jobs. This prospective cohort study aimed to determine the association between cumulative load and the risk of back pain in institutional aides with physically stressful jobs. A total of 256 participants were followed up for one year. Cumulative load was assessed using a validated questionnaire, which included questions about job demands, duration of employment, and exposure to biomechanical stressors. Back pain was assessed using a standardized pain scale. The results showed a significant association between cumulative load and the risk of back pain, with higher cumulative load scores associated with an increased risk of experiencing back pain. These findings highlight the importance of considering cumulative load as a potential risk factor for the development of back pain in physically demanding occupations. Further research is needed to explore potential preventive strategies in this population.

Perivascular innervation of the cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats--an immunohistochemical study. The perivascular innervation of cerebral arteries plays a crucial role in regulating cerebral blood flow and maintaining vascular homeostasis. In this study, we aimed to investigate the perivascular innervation of cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) using immunohistochemical techniques. We observed a significant increase in sympathetic innervation, as indicated by the enhanced staining for tyrosine hydroxylase, in the cerebral arteries of SHR compared to control rats. Furthermore, immunostaining for calcitonin gene-related peptide, a marker of sensory innervation, revealed a reduction in sensory nerve fibers in the SHR group. These findings suggest that the perivascular innervation in cerebral arteries is altered in SHR, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of hypertension and the development of cerebrovascular complications in this animal model. Further investigations are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets in hypertensive cerebrovascular disease.

Chronic Lyme disease with an expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle.  Expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa are rare and have not been reported in conjunction with Lyme disease. This case report describes a patient with chronic Lyme disease who presented with an expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle. Expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa are uncommon, and to the authors' knowledge, have not been previously reported in association with Lyme disease. The patient initially presented with symptoms consistent with cranial nerve deficits and imaging studies revealed a lesion in the cerebellopontine angle. Surgical resection of the lesion was performed and histopathological examination confirmed the presence of granulomatous inflammation. Further evaluation revealed positive serology for Lyme disease. This case highlights the importance of considering Lyme disease as a potential underlying cause in patients presenting with expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa, even in non-endemic areas.

The effect of chemotherapy on growth in the skeletally immature individual.  One hundred twenty-two children with nonmetastatic osteogenic or Ewing's sarcoma were studied to assess the effect of multiagent adjuvant chemotherapy on skeletal growth and final stature. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of multiagent adjuvant chemotherapy on growth and final stature in skeletally immature individuals with nonmetastatic osteogenic or Ewing's sarcoma. A total of 122 children were included in the study and followed-up for a median duration of 7 years. Skeletal growth was measured using serial height measurements and compared to age and gender-matched control populations. The results indicated that children receiving chemotherapy had a significantly decreased growth velocity during treatment compared to the control groups. However, catch-up growth was observed after completion of chemotherapy, leading to a final height within the normal range. No significant differences in final stature were observed between the chemotherapy group and the control groups. These findings suggest that multiagent adjuvant chemotherapy has a transient inhibitory effect on skeletal growth in skeletally immature individuals, but does not have a long-term impact on final stature.

An objective comparison of intrathecal lidocaine versus fentanyl for the treatment of lower extremity spasticity.  The reduction of spasticity after administration of intrathecal fentanyl, 35 micrograms, and intrathecal lidocaine, 50 mg, was compared with preinjection spasticity levels in ten subjects with central nervous system disease or injury. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of intrathecal lidocaine versus fentanyl for the treatment of lower extremity spasticity in individuals with central nervous system disease or injury. Ten subjects were included in the study and their spasticity levels were measured before and after the administration of intrathecal fentanyl (35 micrograms) and intrathecal lidocaine (50 mg). The results showed a significant reduction in spasticity after both treatments compared to preinjection levels. However, there was no statistically significant difference between the efficacy of intrathecal lidocaine and fentanyl in reducing spasticity. These findings suggest that both medications can be equally effective in managing lower extremity spasticity in individuals with central nervous system pathology.

Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome. Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome (PMPS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the impairment of both bone marrow and pancreatic function. The syndrome is typically diagnosed in infancy or early childhood and is caused by mutations in the mitochondrial DNA. Patients with PMPS present with a wide range of symptoms, including anemia, neutropenia, lactic acidosis, pancreatic insufficiency, growth retardation, and developmental delays. Histological examination of bone marrow samples reveals hypocellular marrow with maturation arrest of all hematopoietic cell lineages, while pancreatic histology shows atrophy of acinar and islet cells.

Treatment options for PMPS are limited and primarily supportive, focusing on managing anemia, providing hematopoietic growth factors, and replacing pancreatic enzymes. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may be considered in severe cases. Prognosis varies depending on the severity of the disease and the presence of associated complications such as liver dysfunction. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and develop targeted therapies for PMPS.

Intraoperative massive suprachoroidal hemorrhage during pars plana vitrectomy.  Seven eyes (7 patients) developed massive suprachoroidal hemorrhage (MSCH) during pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) for complicated retinal detachments. Intraoperative massive suprachoroidal hemorrhage (MSCH) is an uncommon but devastating complication during pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) for complicated retinal detachments. This study aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics, visual outcomes, and associated risk factors of patients who developed MSCH during PPV. A retrospective analysis of seven eyes (seven patients) with MSCH was conducted. The mean age of the patients was 56 years, and all patients had pre-existing conditions including hypertension and diabetes. During surgery, the mean duration of hypotony was 15 minutes. Visual acuity outcomes were poor, with all eyes experiencing severe visual loss. Risk factors identified included hypertension, presence of choroidal detachment, and prolonged intraocular hypotony. These findings highlight the importance of carefully monitoring intraocular pressure during PPV and implementing preventive measures to reduce the occurrence of MSCH. Further research is needed to identify additional risk factors and develop strategies to minimize the occurrence and impact of this devastating complication.

Human cerebral malaria: association with erythrocyte rosetting and lack of anti-rosetting antibodies. Human cerebral malaria (HCM) is a severe manifestation of Plasmodium falciparum infection that is associated with high mortality rates. Previous studies have suggested a potential role for erythrocyte rosetting in the pathogenesis of HCM. Rosetting refers to the adhesion of infected erythrocytes to uninfected erythrocytes, forming clumps that can occlude small blood vessels and contribute to the development of cerebral complications. In this study, we examined the association between erythrocyte rosetting and HCM in a cohort of 50 malaria-infected individuals. We found a significantly higher frequency of rosetting in patients with HCM compared to those without cerebral complications. Furthermore, we investigated the presence of anti-rosetting antibodies in the plasma of these individuals and found that none of the samples exhibited detectable levels of these antibodies. Our findings suggest that rosetting plays a crucial role in the development of cerebral complications in P. falciparum infection, and that the lack of anti-rosetting antibodies may contribute to the severity of HCM. This knowledge could inform the development of novel therapeutic strategies for HCM treatment.

Cor triatriatum dexter: antemortem diagnosis in an adult by cross sectional echocardiography. Cor triatriatum dexter (CTD) is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of a membrane dividing the right atrium into two compartments. It is often diagnosed in childhood or infancy, with very few cases reported in adults. We present a case of CTD diagnosed in a 45-year-old female using cross-sectional echocardiography. The patient presented with symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and palpitations. Echocardiographic examination revealed an abnormal membrane within the right atrium, dividing it into two distinct chambers. The right atrium was dilated, and mild tricuspid regurgitation was observed. Cardiac catheterization confirmed the diagnosis, showing a pressure gradient across the divide. The patient underwent surgical correction, and the membrane was successfully resected. This case highlights the importance of echocardiography in the antemortem diagnosis of CTD in adults, allowing for timely intervention and improved outcomes.

Questionable role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension. The use of central nervous system (CNS) radioprophylaxis in the treatment of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) with meningeal extension remains controversial. While previous studies have shown conflicting results regarding its efficacy, the optimal therapeutic management for this condition remains unclear. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 50 pediatric patients with RMS and meningeal extension who were treated at our institution between 2000 and 2010. Patients were divided into two groups based on whether they received CNS radioprophylaxis or not. Our results showed no significant difference in overall survival or disease-free survival between the two groups. Furthermore, we observed a higher incidence of long-term side effects in patients who received CNS radioprophylaxis. Based on our findings, we question the role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood RMS with meningeal extension and suggest further studies to assess its benefits and risks in this patient population.

Natural killer cell activity in patients with liver cirrhosis relative to severity of liver damage. The present study aimed to investigate the natural killer (NK) cell activity in patients with liver cirrhosis and its relationship with the severity of liver damage. A total of 50 patients with liver cirrhosis and 30 healthy controls were included in the study. The NK cell activity was assessed using a standard chromium release assay. The severity of liver damage was assessed using the Child-Pugh score and Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score. The results revealed a significant decrease in NK cell activity in patients with liver cirrhosis compared to healthy controls (p<0.001). Moreover, a negative correlation was observed between NK cell activity and both the Child-Pugh score (r=-0.642, p<0.001) and MELD score (r=-0.586, p<0.001). These findings suggest that the decreased NK cell activity observed in patients with liver cirrhosis may contribute to the progression of liver damage and may serve as a potential prognostic marker for disease severity.

The neuroradiology of visual disturbances.  The neuroradiology of visual deficits has advanced dramatically in recent years. Advancements in neuroradiology have greatly improved our understanding of the underlying causes and mechanisms of visual disturbances. This review aims to summarize the current knowledge on the neuroradiological evaluation of visual deficits, highlighting the key imaging modalities and findings associated with different etiologies.

Neuroradiological evaluation of visual deficits includes both structural and functional imaging techniques. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computed tomography (CT), and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) are commonly employed to assess the anatomy and function of visual pathways. Structural imaging can identify lesions affecting the visual pathway, such as tumors, vascular abnormalities, and demyelinating diseases. Furthermore, functional imaging techniques can evaluate the functional integrity of visual processing regions and help localize specific abnormalities.

Various disorders can present with visual deficits, including optic nerve pathology, lesions affecting the optic chiasm, and visual cortex abnormalities. Neuroradiological imaging aids in differentiating between these etiologies, guiding appropriate management and treatment options. Additionally, advanced imaging techniques, such as diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) and magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS), have provided valuable insights into the microstructural changes and metabolic abnormalities associated with visual impairments.

In conclusion, neuroradiology has made remarkable advancements in the evaluation of visual deficits. The use of various imaging modalities and techniques has improved our understanding of the underlying pathologies and their impact on visual pathways, leading to better diagnosis and management of patients with visual disturbances.

Sleep apnoea syndrome associated with maxillofacial abnormalities. Maxillofacial abnormalities have been observed in patients with sleep apnoea syndrome (SAS). This study aimed to investigate the relationship between maxillofacial abnormalities and SAS severity. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with SAS were included in the study. Maxillofacial abnormalities, including malocclusion and craniofacial asymmetry, were assessed using dental casts and lateral cephalometric radiographs. SAS severity was measured using the apnoea-hypopnea index (AHI). Statistical analysis revealed a positive correlation between maxillofacial abnormalities and SAS severity. Patients with more severe SAS displayed a higher prevalence of maxillofacial abnormalities. These findings suggest that maxillofacial abnormalities may contribute to the development or progression of SAS, highlighting the importance of evaluating and managing these abnormalities in patients with SAS.

Postural hypotension: pressor effect of octreotide not mediated by norepinephrine. Postural hypotension is a common condition characterized by a drop in blood pressure upon standing. Octreotide, a somatostatin analogue, is commonly used to treat hormone-secreting tumors, but it has been associated with the development of postural hypotension. However, the mechanism by which octreotide causes this effect is not fully understood. This study aimed to investigate whether the pressor effect of octreotide is mediated by norepinephrine, a key neurotransmitter involved in blood pressure regulation. Using a rat model, we found that octreotide increased blood pressure even in the absence of norepinephrine release, suggesting that its pressor effect is mediated by mechanisms independent of norepinephrine. Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms of octreotide-induced postural hypotension.

Glucose intolerance and hyperinsulinemia of cirrhosis are not results of spontaneous or surgical portosystemic shunting.  To assess if spontaneous portosystemic shunting from collaterals contributes to the hyperinsulinemia of cirrhosis, 12 patients with alcoholic cirrhosis underwent a 5-hour oral glucose tolerance test 1 day before and 10 days after an elective side-to-side portacaval shunt. A study was conducted to determine if spontaneous portosystemic shunting from collaterals contributes to the hyperinsulinemia observed in patients with alcoholic cirrhosis. Twelve patients with alcoholic cirrhosis underwent a 5-hour oral glucose tolerance test before and after an elective side-to-side portacaval shunt. Results showed that glucose intolerance and hyperinsulinemia of cirrhosis were not the direct outcomes of spontaneous or surgical portosystemic shunting. The findings suggest that other factors may contribute to the development of these conditions in patients with cirrhosis. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and identify potential therapeutic interventions for managing glucose intolerance and hyperinsulinemia in cirrhosis patients.

Power drills to fenestrate exposed bone to stimulate wound healing. Power drills have been widely used in various surgical procedures to fenestrate exposed bone and promote wound healing. This technique involves creating small openings in the bone surface to enhance blood flow, cellular migration, and tissue regeneration. We conducted a retrospective study to evaluate the efficacy of power drill fenestration in promoting wound healing in a cohort of patients with non-healing wounds. A total of 50 patients with chronic wounds were included in the study, and power drill fenestration was performed as a supplementary treatment alongside standard wound care. The results demonstrated a significant improvement in wound healing, with 42 patients (84%) showing complete wound closure within the study period. Additionally, there were no reports of postoperative complications or adverse events associated with the power drill fenestration procedure. Based on our findings, power drill fenestration can be considered a safe and effective adjunctive therapy for promoting wound healing in patients with non-healing wounds. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine optimal techniques and patient selection criteria for power drill fenestration.

Surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions: an overview. Intrinsic brain stem lesions pose a significant challenge in surgical management due to their deep location and proximity to critical structures. This overview aims to summarize the current approaches and outcomes of surgical resection for these lesions. Various surgical techniques, such as transcortical, transsylvian, or transcallosal approaches, have been employed depending on the location and nature of the lesion. Intraoperative monitoring techniques, including neurophysiological mapping and nerve monitoring, have been utilized to preserve neurological function during surgery. Despite the technical difficulties, surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions has shown promising results in terms of symptom relief and survival outcomes in selected cases. However, the decision to pursue surgical intervention should be tailored to each patient based on factors such as tumor characteristics, neurological symptoms, and overall health condition. Further studies are needed to optimize surgical techniques and refine patient selection criteria to improve outcomes in this challenging population.

Experimental oral foreign body reactions: vegetable materials. A literature review and experimental study. Foreign body reactions to vegetable materials are uncommon but can occur in the oral cavity. This study aims to investigate the histopathological features of such reactions using experimental models. Five different types of vegetable materials were inserted into the oral cavities of rats for a period of four weeks. Histopathological analysis revealed varying degrees of inflammatory response, granuloma formation, and foreign body reaction in all experimental groups. The severity of these reactions differed depending on the type of vegetable material used. These findings contribute to our understanding of oral foreign body reactions and highlight the importance of considering vegetable materials as potential causative agents in cases of oral inflammation or granulomatous lesions.

Massive splenomegaly.  Superior results with a combined endovascular and operative approach. Massive splenomegaly is a challenging condition to manage, often requiring a multidisciplinary approach. In this study, we present our experience with a combined endovascular and operative approach for the treatment of massive splenomegaly. 

A total of 15 patients with massive splenomegaly were included in the study. All patients underwent preoperative imaging and were evaluated by a team of interventional radiologists and surgeons. Selective splenic artery embolization was performed as a first step to decrease the size of the spleen and relieve symptoms. Subsequently, patients underwent splenectomy using a minimally invasive approach.

The combined approach yielded superior results, with significant reduction in spleen size and improvement in symptoms. The mean operative time was shorter compared to conventional open splenectomy, and there were no major complications observed. Additionally, the combined approach allowed for preservation of splenic function in select cases.

In conclusion, a combined endovascular and operative approach is a safe and effective strategy for the management of massive splenomegaly, offering improved outcomes and potential preservation of splenic function. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare this approach to other treatment modalities.

Vitrectomy retinotomy aspiration biopsy of choroidal tumors We used an investigational technique for the biopsy of intraocular tumors to aid in the diagnosis of three choroidal tumors. Vitrectomy retinotomy aspiration biopsy is a novel technique employed for the diagnosis of choroidal tumors. Three patients presenting with choroidal tumors underwent this investigational procedure. The technique involves vitrectomy, retinotomy, and aspiration biopsy of the tumor tissue. The collected samples were then analyzed to aid in the diagnosis of the tumors. This procedure provides an alternative to more invasive techniques and offers a less traumatic approach for obtaining tissue samples for analysis. The application of this technique in the diagnosis of choroidal tumors shows promise and warrants further investigation as a potential diagnostic tool in ophthalmology.

Multiple representations of pain in human cerebral cortex. Neuroimaging techniques have revealed multiple representations of pain in the human cerebral cortex. Previous studies have focused on the somatosensory cortex as the primary site for pain perception. However, recent advances in functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) have identified additional cortical areas involved in the processing of pain. This review summarizes the findings from various fMRI studies, highlighting the involvement of the anterior cingulate cortex, insula, prefrontal cortex, and other regions in pain perception. These cortical areas are involved in the affective and cognitive dimensions of pain, suggesting a multidimensional representation of pain in the brain. Understanding these different pain processing pathways may contribute to the development of targeted interventions for chronic pain management.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy are known risk factors for the development of cancer in patients with pelvic pouches. We present a case of a 45-year-old male who underwent subtotal colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis for ulcerative colitis 20 years ago. Routine surveillance endoscopy revealed dysplasia in the pouch mucosa and subsequent histopathological examination confirmed high-grade dysplasia. DNA ploidy analysis showed aneuploidy, indicating a higher risk for malignant transformation. The patient underwent total proctocolectomy with permanent ileostomy as a preventive measure. The subsequent histopathological examination of the resected specimen revealed carcinoma in situ within the dysplastic pouch mucosa. This case highlights the importance of regular surveillance and early detection of dysplasia in patients with pelvic pouches. Furthermore, DNA ploidy analysis may provide additional information about the risk of malignant transformation and guide treatment decisions. Further research is needed to establish optimal surveillance strategies and preventive measures for this high-risk population.

Tympano-cartilago-stapediopexy: a method to improve hearing in open technique tympanoplasty. Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure used to repair a perforated or damaged eardrum. One common technique is the open technique, which involves creating an incision behind the ear to access the middle ear. However, this approach can sometimes lead to hearing impairment due to disruption of the normal sound transmission pathway. In this study, we propose a modification to the open technique called tympano-cartilago-stapediopexy. This method involves using a cartilage graft to bridge the gap between the eardrum and the stapes bone, improving sound conduction. Our preliminary results suggest that tympano-cartilago-stapediopexy can be a valuable addition to the open technique tympanoplasty, offering improved hearing outcomes for patients. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Molecular phenotype of a pediatric small round cell tumor. Small round cell tumors (SRCTs) are a heterogeneous group of pediatric malignancies characterized by undifferentiated or poorly differentiated cells with a similar appearance under the microscope. The molecular phenotype of SRCTs remains poorly understood, hampering accurate diagnosis and targeted treatment strategies. In this study, we aimed to characterize the molecular phenotype of a pediatric SRCT using comprehensive molecular profiling techniques. We performed gene expression profiling, DNA methylation analysis, and targeted sequencing on tumor samples from six pediatric patients with SRCTs. Our findings revealed distinct molecular subtypes within the SRCT cohort, suggesting underlying biological heterogeneity. Furthermore, we identified potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets that may aid in the development of personalized treatment approaches for children with SRCTs. Further studies are warranted to validate and expand upon these findings.

Intraocular lens complications. Intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is a commonly performed procedure for the correction of vision in cataract patients. While the majority of these surgeries are successful, complications can occur, leading to poor visual outcomes and patient dissatisfaction. This review aims to summarize the various complications associated with IOL implantation and their diagnostic significance.

Complications discussed include posterior capsule opacification, which occurs in up to 30% of cases and can affect visual acuity; intraocular lens dislocation, which can lead to significant visual disturbances and may require surgical intervention; and cystoid macular edema, a postoperative complication that can impair visual function. Other complications reviewed include endophthalmitis, retinal detachment, glaucoma, and secondary lens implantation.

Understanding the diagnostic significance of these complications is crucial for early identification and appropriate management. Diagnostic techniques such as slit-lamp examination, optical coherence tomography, and fundus photography are essential tools in the evaluation and monitoring of patients with suspected or confirmed IOL complications. Early recognition and prompt intervention can lead to improved visual outcomes and patient satisfaction in cases of IOL complications.

Cutaneous melanoma and bilateral retinoblastoma. Cutaneous melanoma and bilateral retinoblastoma are two different malignancies that rarely occur simultaneously in an individual. We present a case report of a 34-year-old male who was diagnosed with cutaneous melanoma on his upper back and bilateral retinoblastoma in both eyes. The patient underwent surgical excision of the melanoma lesion and adjuvant radiotherapy. After genetic testing, he was found to carry a mutation in the RB1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of hereditary retinoblastoma. The patient subsequently received chemotherapy and enucleation of the affected eyes. This unique case highlights the importance of thorough evaluation and genetic testing in patients diagnosed with multiple cancers, as it can aid in identifying underlying genetic predispositions and optimizing treatment strategies. Further research is necessary to unravel the complex relationship between cutaneous melanoma and retinoblastoma and identify potential shared genetic or environmental risk factors.

Abdominal wall reconstruction (the "mutton chop" flap). The "mutton chop" flap is a surgical technique used for abdominal wall reconstruction. This approach involves utilizing a pedicled flap of tissue, typically harvested from the lateral thigh or buttock region, to restore the integrity of the abdominal wall in cases of complex abdominal wall defects. In this procedure, the flap is dissected with its blood supply intact and then rotated into position to cover the defect. The "mutton chop" flap offers several advantages, including the ability to provide a large amount of well-vascularized tissue for reconstruction and the potential for primary closure of the donor site. While this technique requires careful preoperative planning and meticulous surgical technique, it has demonstrated favorable outcomes in terms of wound healing, patient satisfaction, and functional restoration of the abdominal wall.

Therapeutic embolization: enhanced radiolabeled monitoring. Therapeutic embolization is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat various medical conditions, including tumors and arteriovenous malformations. However, monitoring the effectiveness of embolization therapy poses challenges as conventional imaging techniques may not accurately assess treatment outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility of enhanced radiolabeled monitoring in therapeutic embolization. Thirteen patients with different embolization indications underwent embolization procedures using radiolabeled microspheres. Post-procedural evaluation was performed using single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) to assess the distribution of radiolabeled particles. Enhanced radiolabeled monitoring provided valuable information regarding the perfusion patterns following embolization. Moreover, SPECT revealed the embolization extent and confirmed the reduced blood flow to the targeted tissue.
