The findings of this study suggest that enhanced radiolabeled monitoring using SPECT improves the assessment of therapeutic embolization outcomes, thus aiding in treatment optimization and patient management.

Surrogate receptor-mediated cellular cytotoxicity against malignant human glioma cells. Surrogate receptor-mediated cellular cytotoxicity (SRCC) is an emerging immunotherapeutic strategy for the treatment of glioma, a highly aggressive form of brain cancer. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of SRCC in inducing cytotoxicity against malignant human glioma cells. We used a panel of surrogate receptors, including natural killer (NK) cell receptors and chimeric antigen receptors (CARs), to engineer effector cells capable of specifically targeting and killing glioma cells. Our results demonstrate that SRCC using NK cell receptors, such as NKG2D and DNAM-1, as well as CARs targeting glioma-associated antigens, significantly enhanced the cytotoxicity against glioma cells in vitro. Furthermore, in vivo experiments using a glioma xenograft mouse model showed that SRCC-treated effector cells effectively suppressed tumor growth and prolonged the overall survival of the mice. These findings suggest that SRCC holds promise as a novel immunotherapeutic approach for the treatment of malignant glioma, and warrant further investigation in preclinical and clinical settings.

Inflammatory pseudotumor of intra-abdominal lymph nodes manifesting as recurrent fever of unknown origin: a case report. We present a case report of a 36-year-old female who presented with recurrent fever of unknown origin. Initial investigations were inconclusive, including blood cultures and imaging studies. Eventually, a diagnostic laparoscopy was performed, revealing multiple enlarged intra-abdominal lymph nodes. Excisional biopsy of the lymph nodes was taken, and histopathological examination revealed an inflammatory pseudotumor. The patient was treated with a course of corticosteroids, resulting in resolution of her symptoms and normalization of laboratory findings. Inflammatory pseudotumor of intra-abdominal lymph nodes, although rare, should be considered in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with recurrent fever of unknown origin. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with corticosteroids can provide a favorable outcome for these patients. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology and optimal management of this rare condition.

Rehabilitation in brain disorders.  1. Rehabilitation plays a crucial role in the management of brain disorders, aiming to maximize functional independence and quality of life for affected individuals. In this review, we focus on the current understanding of rehabilitation strategies for brain disorders, including stroke, traumatic brain injury, and neurodegenerative diseases.

For stroke patients, early rehabilitation interventions have been shown to improve motor function, activities of daily living, and overall functional outcomes. Various approaches, such as constraint-induced movement therapy, virtual reality training, and robotic-assisted therapy, have demonstrated promising results in enhancing motor recovery.

In traumatic brain injury, rehabilitation interventions address impairments in cognition, mobility, and psychosocial functioning. Multidisciplinary rehabilitation programs, incorporating speech therapy, physical therapy, and occupational therapy, have been effective in promoting functional improvements and community integration for these patients.

In neurodegenerative diseases, rehabilitation focuses on maintaining independence and slowing disease progression. Exercise and physical therapy interventions have shown benefits in improving physical function and delaying functional decline in diseases such as Parkinson's disease and multiple sclerosis.

Overall, rehabilitation is an integral component of comprehensive care for individuals with brain disorders, providing opportunities for functional recovery and improving overall quality of life. Further research is needed to optimize rehabilitation strategies and tailor interventions to individual patient needs.

Gastrointestinal pathology in adult iron overdose.  The gastrointestinal effects of iron overdose have been described in children. However, there is limited information on the gastrointestinal pathology associated with iron overdose in adults. In this study, we present the findings from a series of adult patients who presented with iron overdose and underwent gastrointestinal examination. We found that iron overdose can result in severe gastrointestinal injury and pathology, including mucosal necrosis, submucosal hemorrhage, and gastric ulceration. Additionally, iron deposition was observed in the gastrointestinal tract, particularly in the stomach and small intestine. These findings suggest that iron overdose can cause significant damage to the gastrointestinal system in adults, similar to what has been reported in children. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms underlying these gastrointestinal effects and to develop appropriate management strategies for patients with iron overdose.

Antisocial alcoholics: are there clinically significant diagnostic subtypes? Of 360 alcoholic male inpatients assessed with a diagnostic interview, 106 (29%) were found to have a co-occurring diagnosis of antisocial personality. The aim of this study was to explore whether there are clinically significant diagnostic subtypes within the population of antisocial alcoholic male inpatients. Using a diagnostic interview, 360 alcoholic male inpatients were assessed, and 106 (29%) were found to have a co-occurring diagnosis of antisocial personality. Subsequently, these individuals were further examined to identify potential subtypes. Results indicated the presence of two distinct subtypes: primary and secondary antisocial alcoholics. Primary antisocial alcoholics demonstrated a higher prevalence of aggressive behaviors, impulsivity, and a history of conduct disorder, while secondary antisocial alcoholics had a higher prevalence of depression and anxiety disorders. The identification of these subtypes may have important implications for treatment planning and intervention strategies, as tailored approaches could be implemented based on the specific subtype profile of the individual.

Locked intramedullary nailing of femoral shaft fractures. Locked intramedullary nailing (IMN) is a widely used surgical technique for the treatment of femoral shaft fractures. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the clinical outcomes and complications associated with locked IMN in a cohort of patients. A total of 100 patients who underwent locked IMN for femoral shaft fractures were included in the study. The mean age of the patients was 38 years (range, 18-65 years). The majority of fractures were caused by high-energy trauma (73%), while the remaining fractures were caused by low-energy trauma (27%). The overall union rate was 97%, with a mean time to union of 16 weeks. Complications included infection (4%), nonunion (2%), and implant failure (1%). Our results demonstrate that locked IMN is an effective treatment strategy for femoral shaft fractures, with high union rates and low complication rates.

Acute oculogyric crisis after administration of prochlorperazine. Prochlorperazine is a commonly used antiemetic medication. However, it has been associated with various adverse effects, including extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute oculogyric crisis (AOC). We present a case of a 42-year-old female who experienced AOC shortly after receiving a single intravenous dose of prochlorperazine for postoperative nausea. The patient presented with involuntary upward deviation of the eyes, often accompanied by sustained upward movement of the head. The symptoms resolved spontaneously within 30 minutes without any intervention. AOC is a rare but potentially distressing adverse effect of prochlorperazine and other antipsychotic medications. Clinicians should be aware of this complication and consider alternative antiemetic options in susceptible individuals.

Use of monoclonal antibody KP1 for identifying normal and neoplastic human mast cells. The use of monoclonal antibody KP1 for identifying normal and neoplastic human mast cells was evaluated in this study. Tissue samples from 50 patients were examined using immunohistochemical staining with KP1. The results showed that KP1 was able to reliably detect mast cells in both normal and neoplastic tissues. Normal mast cells were found to express KP1 in a characteristic pattern, while neoplastic mast cells demonstrated varying degrees of KP1 expression. The intensity of KP1 staining was found to correlate with the degree of mast cell activation and degranulation. Importantly, KP1 was found to be highly specific for mast cells, with minimal cross-reactivity observed with other cell types. Overall, these findings suggest that KP1 can be a valuable tool for accurately identifying and characterizing mast cells in both normal and neoplastic tissues.

Narrow excision (1-cm margin).  A safe procedure for thin cutaneous melanoma. The management of thin cutaneous melanoma remains controversial, particularly regarding the optimal surgical margin. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of narrow excision with a 1-cm margin for thin melanoma. A total of 500 patients with thin cutaneous melanoma (Breslow thickness  1 mm) underwent surgical excision with a 1-cm margin. The median follow-up time was 5 years. The overall local recurrence rate was 4.6%, with no significant difference between patients with different tumor thickness or location. The disease-specific survival rate was 96.5%, with a 5-year survival rate of 92.3%. The overall recurrence-free survival rate was 92.4%. Furthermore, no significant associations were found between the surgical margin size and local recurrence, disease-specific survival, or recurrence-free survival. These results demonstrate that narrow excision with a 1-cm margin is a safe procedure for thin cutaneous melanoma, achieving low rates of local recurrence and high survival rates. Further studies with long-term follow-up are warranted to confirm these findings.

Routine and quantitative EEG analysis in Gilles de la Tourette's syndrome. Gilles de la Tourette's syndrome (GTS) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by motor and vocal tics. This study aimed to investigate the electroencephalogram (EEG) characteristics of GTS patients using routine and quantitative EEG analysis. Twenty-five GTS patients and twenty-five age-matched healthy controls underwent EEG recording during resting state. The EEG data were analyzed using both visual inspection and quantitative measures, such as spectral power and coherence. Compared to healthy controls, GTS patients showed increased theta and alpha power in the frontal and central regions, as well as decreased alpha power in the occipital region. Coherence analysis revealed decreased connectivity in both intra- and interhemispheric regions in GTS patients. These findings suggest altered brain functional connectivity in GTS, providing insights into the underlying neural mechanisms of the disorder. Further research is needed to explore the clinical implications of these EEG abnormalities in GTS diagnosis and treatment.

Interphase cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. Interphase cytogenetic analysis plays a crucial role in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. This technique involves the examination of interphase nuclei for the presence of aberrant chromosomal rearrangements that are characteristic of specific neoplasms. By utilizing fluorescently labeled DNA probes that target specific chromosomal regions or genes, interphase cytogenetic analysis allows for the detection of clonal chromosomal abnormalities, such as translocations, amplifications, and deletions. 

Interphase cytogenetic analysis has proven especially valuable in the diagnosis and classification of hematologic malignancies, such as leukemia and lymphoma, where specific chromosomal abnormalities are diagnostic and prognostic markers. Additionally, it has aided in the identification of subtypes within these neoplasms, guiding treatment decisions and predicting patient outcomes.

Moreover, interphase cytogenetic analysis has expanded beyond hematologic malignancies to solid tumors, including those of the breast, lung, and colon. By analyzing tumor cells obtained from fine-needle aspiration biopsies or surgically resected specimens, interphase cytogenetic analysis can provide valuable information for risk stratification, treatment selection, and monitoring of treatment response.

In summary, interphase cytogenetic analysis is a powerful tool in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders, providing invaluable information for accurate classification, prognosis, and personalized treatment strategies.

Potential role of beta-carotene in prevention of oral cancer. Oral cancer is a significant global health issue, with a high incidence and mortality rate. It has been suggested that dietary factors, including antioxidants like beta-carotene, may play a role in its prevention. This study aims to evaluate the potential role of beta-carotene in preventing oral cancer. A comprehensive literature review was conducted, considering both in vitro and in vivo studies, epidemiological evidence, and clinical trials. The findings suggest that beta-carotene exhibits chemopreventive properties due to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities, as well as its ability to modulate cellular proliferation and apoptosis. Epidemiological studies have shown an inverse association between beta-carotene intake and oral cancer risk. However, conflicting results from intervention studies have raised questions about the optimal dosage and form of beta-carotene supplementation. Further research, including well-designed clinical trials, is warranted to elucidate the precise mechanisms and establish the potential use of beta-carotene in oral cancer prevention strategies.

Unusual aspects of aortovenous fistulas associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms. Aortovenous fistulas (AVFs) associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are a rare but serious condition. This study aimed to describe the unusual aspects of AVFs associated with ruptured AAAs. The authors reviewed a series of cases of AVFs in patients with ruptured AAAs that were treated at their institution. Six patients were identified and their clinical and radiological characteristics were analyzed. Unusual aspects of these AVFs included the presence of multiple fistulas (in four patients), involvement of uncommon venous structures (inferior vena cava or renal veins), and an atypical presentation (with symptoms suggestive of aortocaval compression rather than rupture). In addition, one patient had a juxtarenal AAA and another had a mycotic aneurysm. These unusual aspects highlight the importance of considering AVFs in the differential diagnosis of patients with ruptured AAAs, as they may present with atypical features. Early diagnosis and prompt intervention are crucial for optimal management of this potentially life-threatening condition.

General assay for phosphoproteins in cerebrospinal fluid: a candidate marker for paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis plays a crucial role in the diagnosis and monitoring of various neurological disorders. The identification of specific biomarkers in CSF can provide valuable insights into the underlying pathophysiology of these conditions. Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD) is a rare autoimmune neurological disorder associated with an underlying malignancy. Currently, there are no specific diagnostic markers for PCD, making its diagnosis challenging. In this study, we developed a general assay for the detection of phosphoproteins in CSF, with the rationale that aberrant phosphorylation events may occur in PCD. Using mass spectrometry and bioinformatics analysis, we identified a panel of phosphoproteins that showed differential expression in PCD patients compared to controls. These phosphoproteins could serve as potential diagnostic markers for PCD, aiding in its early detection and management. Further validation studies are warranted to establish the clinical utility of this assay in routine CSF analysis for PCD.

Ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy for neuropathy at the elbow.  Ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy was performed in 66 elbows between 1966 and 1986 for compressive ulnar neuropathy at the elbow. We report the results of ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy in 66 elbows with neuropathy at the elbow. Preoperative evaluation included clinical examination, electrodiagnostic studies, and radiographic imaging. The surgical procedure involved releasing the ulnar nerve from the fibrous bands of the cubital tunnel and excising the medial epicondyle to create additional space for the nerve. Postoperative evaluation included clinical follow-up, neurologic examination, and assessment of pain relief and functional improvement. Overall, 58 (88%) of the 66 elbows had improvement in symptoms, with complete resolution of neuropathy in 46 (70%). Complications included wound infection in one patient and temporary elbow stiffness in two patients. Ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy is an effective treatment option for neuropathy at the elbow, providing significant pain relief and functional improvement.

Management of renovascular disease. Renovascular disease is a common cause of secondary hypertension and renal dysfunction. It is often characterized by narrowing or occlusion of the renal arteries, leading to impaired blood flow to the kidneys. Management of renovascular disease typically involves a combination of medical therapy, percutaneous intervention, and surgical revascularization. This abstract aims to provide an overview of the current management strategies for renovascular disease. Medical therapy includes the use of antihypertensive medications, such as ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers, to control blood pressure and preserve renal function. Percutaneous interventions, such as angioplasty and stenting, are performed to restore blood flow to the affected kidneys. Surgical revascularization, such as bypass grafting, may be considered in cases where percutaneous interventions are not feasible or unsuccessful. The choice of management strategy depends on various factors, including the severity of the disease, presence of comorbidities, and patient preference. A multidisciplinary approach involving nephrologists, interventional radiologists, and vascular surgeons is crucial for optimal management of renovascular disease.

Skin exudate levels of interleukin 6, interleukin 1 and other cytokines in mycosis fungoides. This study aimed to investigate the levels of interleukin 6 (IL-6), interleukin 1 (IL-1), and other cytokines in skin exudates of patients with mycosis fungoides (MF), a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Skin exudate samples were collected from 30 patients with MF and 20 healthy controls. The levels of IL-6, IL-1, and other cytokines were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. 

Results showed that patients with MF had significantly higher levels of IL-6 (p<0.001) and IL-1 (p<0.05) compared to the healthy controls. Additionally, the levels of other cytokines, including tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-) and interferon gamma (IFN-), were also elevated in patients with MF. 

Furthermore, a positive correlation was found between the levels of IL-6 and IL-1 (r=0.648, p<0.001), suggesting a potential synergistic effect between these cytokines in the pathogenesis of MF. 

In conclusion, this study demonstrates elevated levels of IL-6, IL-1, and other cytokines in skin exudates of patients with MF. These findings suggest a role for these cytokines in the inflammatory response and disease progression in MF, highlighting their potential as therapeutic targets for this condition.

Is liver transplantation justified for the treatment of hepatic malignancies? Twenty-eight patients received orthotopic liver transplants for malignant disease between February 1, 1984, and December 31, 1989.  Preoperative diagnoses included hepatocellular carcinoma (n = 16), cholangiocarcinoma (n = 3), other primary hepatic tumors (n = 6), and metastatic diseases to the liver (n = 3). The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of liver transplantation as a treatment option for hepatic malignancies. Twenty-eight patients with various types of malignant liver diseases underwent orthotopic liver transplants between 1984 and 1989. The preoperative diagnoses included hepatocellular carcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma, other primary hepatic tumors, and metastatic diseases to the liver. The results showed that liver transplantation provided a potential curative treatment option for selected patients with hepatocellular carcinoma, with a 5-year survival rate of 50%. However, the outcomes for patients with cholangiocarcinoma or other primary hepatic tumors were less favorable, indicating that liver transplantation may not be justified as a primary treatment for these diseases. Further studies are required to determine the optimal selection criteria for liver transplantation in patients with hepatic malignancies.

Microstaging of squamous cell carcinomas. Microstaging is a crucial process in the assessment and management of squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs). This study aimed to develop a comprehensive microstaging system for SCCs based on histopathological analysis. A total of 100 SCC cases were included in the study, with detailed clinical and pathological data collected. The microstaging system was designed to capture the depth of invasion, involvement of lymphovascular spaces, perineural invasion, and presence of tumor budding. The results demonstrated that the microstaging system provided valuable information on tumor aggressiveness and prognosis. Patients with higher microstaging scores were found to have a significantly higher risk of lymph node involvement and distant metastasis. Furthermore, the microstaging system allowed for the identification of high-risk subgroups within SCCs, which could aid in the selection of appropriate treatment strategies. Overall, this study presents a comprehensive microstaging system for SCCs that has the potential to improve patient risk stratification and inform personalized treatment decisions. Further validation and prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings and establish the clinical utility of this microstaging system.

An autosomal recessive gene that delays expression of lupus in BXSB mice. BXSB mice are a common model for studying systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In this study, we identified a novel autosomal recessive gene in BXSB mice that delays the expression of lupus-like disease. Through breeding experiments, we found that the presence of this gene significantly prolonged the onset of SLE symptoms, such as proteinuria and autoantibody production. Histological analysis also revealed reduced glomerular and interstitial inflammation in mice carrying the gene. Furthermore, we demonstrated that this gene influenced the development of T and B cell subsets, leading to altered immune responses. Our findings suggest that this gene plays a crucial role in modulating lupus-like disease in BXSB mice and may provide insights into potential therapeutic targets for delaying the onset and progression of lupus in humans.

Intracatheter streptokinase for recurrent peritonitis in CAPD. Recurrent peritonitis is a significant complication in patients undergoing continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD). Traditional treatment options include antibiotics and catheter removal. However, these approaches are sometimes ineffective or not feasible. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of intracatheter streptokinase in the management of recurrent peritonitis in CAPD. 

A total of 30 patients with recurrent peritonitis underwent intracatheter streptokinase therapy. Streptokinase infusion was delivered directly into the peritoneal cavity through the CAPD catheter for a duration of 48 hours. Clinical and laboratory parameters were monitored before and after the treatment, including white blood cell count, peritoneal fluid culture, and inflammatory markers.

The results showed a significant improvement in clinical symptoms and resolution of peritonitis in 26 out of 30 patients. The mean white blood cell count decreased dramatically after treatment, indicating reduced inflammation. Peritoneal fluid culture also demonstrated decreased bacterial load in the majority of cases. Furthermore, there were no major adverse events related to streptokinase infusion.

In conclusion, intracatheter streptokinase appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for recurrent peritonitis in CAPD patients. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings and determine optimal dosing regimens.

Isolated ventral pancreatitis in a patient with pancreas divisum. Pancreas divisum is a congenital anomaly of the pancreatic ducts, characterized by incomplete fusion of the ventral and dorsal ducts during embryogenesis. This condition can lead to various pancreatic disorders, including pancreatitis. However, isolated ventral pancreatitis in the setting of pancreas divisum is a rare entity. We present a case of a patient with recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis attributed to isolated ventral ductal obstruction in the setting of pancreas divisum. The diagnostic evaluation, management, and outcome of this patient are discussed. Recognition of this uncommon entity is crucial for appropriate management and the prevention of further complications in patients with pancreas divisum.

Kenneth McKenzie, Harvey Cushing, and the early neurosurgical treatment of spasmodic torticollis.  In 1923, Dr. Kenneth McKenzie and Harvey Cushing collaborated to investigate the early neurosurgical treatment of spasmodic torticollis in 1923. They conducted a retrospective analysis of 38 patients who underwent surgical intervention for this condition. The study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and efficacy of neurosurgical procedures, specifically sympathectomy and myomectomy, in relieving symptoms and improving quality of life. The results showed that 65.8% of patients experienced significant improvement in symptoms, with a mean reduction in torticollis severity of 78.4%. Additionally, patients reported improved functional ability and decreased pain following surgery. McKenzie and Cushing's study revealed promising results regarding early neurosurgical interventions for spasmodic torticollis, providing a foundation for future research and treatment approaches.

Defective dystrophin in Duchenne and Becker dystrophy myotubes in cell culture. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) are both caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, resulting in the absence or reduced levels of the dystrophin protein. Here, we aimed to study the effect of defective dystrophin on muscle fibers derived from DMD and BMD patients in cell culture. We cultured myotubes from muscle biopsy samples of DMD and BMD patients and examined the dystrophin expression and localization using immunofluorescence staining. Our results showed a complete absence of dystrophin in DMD myotubes, while BMD myotubes exhibited reduced levels of dystrophin with abnormal distribution at the sarcolemma. Furthermore, we observed impaired myotube formation and increased susceptibility to apoptosis in both DMD and BMD myotubes. These findings provide further insight into the molecular mechanisms underlying DMD and BMD and highlight the potential of cell culture models for studying disease progression and developing therapeutic strategies for these debilitating muscular dystrophies.

Transesophageal echocardiography in the diagnosis of ostial left coronary artery stenosis. Ostial left coronary artery stenosis is a potentially life-threatening condition that requires prompt diagnosis and intervention. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) in detecting ostial left coronary artery stenosis compared to coronary angiography, the gold standard test. A retrospective analysis of 50 patients with suspected ostial left coronary artery stenosis who underwent both TEE and coronary angiography was conducted. TEE images were reviewed by two experienced cardiologists who were blinded to the angiographic findings. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, negative predictive value, and accuracy of TEE in detecting ostial left coronary artery stenosis were calculated. The results showed that TEE had a high sensitivity (90%) and specificity (92%) in detecting ostial left coronary artery stenosis, with an accuracy of 92%. TEE can be considered a valuable and non-invasive diagnostic tool for the evaluation of ostial left coronary artery stenosis, allowing for timely diagnosis and appropriate management to prevent adverse cardiac events.

Long-term effects of delapril on renal function and urinary excretion of kallikrein, prostaglandin E2, and thromboxane B2 in hypertensive patients.  The effects of delapril, an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, on renal function and the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-prostaglandin systems were investigated in 10 hypertensive patients who were treated for between 4 months and 1 year. The study aimed to evaluate the effects of delapril, an ACE inhibitor, on renal function and the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-prostaglandin systems in hypertensive patients. Ten patients with hypertension were treated with delapril for a duration of 4 months to 1 year. Renal function parameters, urinary excretion of kallikrein, prostaglandin E2, and thromboxane B2 were measured before and during treatment. Results showed that delapril significantly improved renal function, as evidenced by the increase in glomerular filtration rate and creatinine clearance. Furthermore, delapril treatment led to an increase in urinary excretion of kallikrein and prostaglandin E2, suggesting a modulation of the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-prostaglandin systems. These findings support the beneficial effects of delapril in hypertensive patients by improving renal function and modulating important regulatory systems.

Management of hypertension by reduction in sympathetic activity. Hypertension is a global health problem with significant morbidity and mortality. One approach to managing hypertension is to target sympathetic activity, as increased sympathetic outflow is a key contributor to the development and maintenance of elevated blood pressure. Various strategies have been employed to reduce sympathetic activity, including lifestyle modifications, pharmacotherapy, and invasive procedures.

Lifestyle modifications, such as weight loss, exercise, and dietary interventions, have shown modest reductions in sympathetic activity and blood pressure. Pharmacotherapy options include centrally acting sympatholytics, such as alpha-2 adrenergic agonists and imidazoline receptor agonists, as well as beta blockers. These medications act by reducing sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system or blocking the effects of sympathetic stimulation on target organs.

Invasive procedures, such as renal denervation and carotid baroreceptor stimulation, directly target sympathetic nerves and have shown promise in reducing blood pressure in patients with resistant hypertension.

Overall, reduction in sympathetic activity is a valuable therapeutic approach in managing hypertension, and further research is needed to optimize its effectiveness and long-term outcomes.

Surgery for acute and chronic cholecystitis.  Cholecystostomy and cholecystectomy remain appropriate and effective therapy for acute and chronic cholecystitis. Advancements in surgical techniques and technology have resulted in improved outcomes for patients with acute and chronic cholecystitis. Cholecystostomy, a minimally invasive procedure, is a viable option for patients who are not suitable candidates for cholecystectomy due to comorbidities or high surgical risk. It involves the placement of a catheter into the gallbladder to drain the infected bile and alleviate symptoms. Cholecystectomy, the gold standard treatment, involves the complete removal of the gallbladder, typically performed laparoscopically. This procedure provides definitive treatment, eliminating the risk of recurrence. However, careful consideration should be given to the patient's overall health status and individual circumstances to determine the most appropriate surgical approach. Close postoperative monitoring and appropriate pain management are essential for optimal patient outcomes.

Bleeding gastroesophageal varices: gastric vein embolization after partial portal decompression. Gastroesophageal varices are a common complication of portal hypertension. In this study, we present a case of a 42-year-old male with bleeding gastroesophageal varices who underwent gastric vein embolization following partial portal decompression. The patient had previously undergone a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedure, which partially reduced portal pressure. However, recurrent bleeding necessitated further intervention. Gastric vein embolization was performed using a combination of coils and sclerosants, leading to successful obliteration of the varices. Post-procedural imaging showed complete resolution of the varices, with no evidence of rebleeding during the follow-up period. This case highlights the feasibility and efficacy of gastric vein embolization as an adjunctive treatment option for patients with bleeding gastroesophageal varices following partial portal decompression. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine long-term outcomes.

Delayed onset of cardiac arrhythmias from sustained-release verapamil. We present a case report of a patient who experienced delayed onset cardiac arrhythmias following ingestion of sustained-release verapamil. The patient, a 62-year-old male with a history of hypertension, was prescribed sustained-release verapamil for the management of his blood pressure. Four days after starting the medication, the patient developed episodes of palpitations and dizziness. Electrocardiograms revealed irregular ventricular arrhythmias suggestive of sustained release verapamil toxicity. The patient was immediately taken off the medication and given appropriate cardiac monitoring and supportive care. His symptoms gradually resolved over the next few days, and his cardiac rhythm returned to normal. This case highlights the importance of recognizing the potential for delayed onset cardiac arrhythmias in patients taking sustained-release verapamil.

Polyglucosan body disease.  Adult polyglucosan disease has been described in 15 cases. Polyglucosan body disease is a rare neurological disorder that primarily affects adults. In this case study, we present 15 individuals diagnosed with adult polyglucosan disease. The patients exhibited a range of clinical manifestations, including progressive gait disturbance, muscle weakness, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment. Neurological examination revealed widespread involvement of the central and peripheral nervous systems, including the presence of polyglucosan bodies in the neurons and glial cells. Genetic analysis identified mutations in the glycogen branching enzyme gene as the underlying cause of the disease. Other systemic manifestations, such as cardiomyopathy and liver dysfunction, were also observed in some patients. To date, no effective treatment options are available for adult polyglucosan disease, highlighting the need for further research and therapeutic interventions for this debilitating condition.

Plasma cell granuloma of the nasal cavity treated by radiation therapy. Plasma cell granuloma is a rare benign lesion that can occur in various anatomical sites, including the nasal cavity. We report a case of plasma cell granuloma in a 43-year-old male patient who presented with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and facial pain. A biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of plasma cell granuloma. In light of the tumor size and location, radiation therapy was chosen as the primary treatment modality. The patient received a total dose of 45 Gy in 25 fractions over a five-week period. Follow-up at six months showed complete resolution of the symptoms and no evidence of recurrence on imaging. Radiation therapy is a viable treatment option for plasma cell granuloma of the nasal cavity, providing excellent local control and symptom relief. Further studies are warranted to establish optimal treatment protocols and long-term outcomes.

The recalcitrant perineal wound after rectal extirpation.  Applications of muscle flap closure. The management of perineal wounds following rectal extirpation can be challenging and may require innovative approaches for closure. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of muscle flap closure in the treatment of recalcitrant perineal wounds. A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent muscle flap closure for perineal wounds after rectal extirpation was conducted. The study included 30 patients with persistent perineal wounds despite previous management attempts. The majority of patients had underlying comorbidities such as diabetes and obesity. Muscle flap closure was successfully performed in all cases, with no immediate postoperative complications reported. Follow-up evaluations revealed complete wound healing in 27 patients, while three patients experienced minor wound complications that were managed conservatively. Muscle flap closure proved to be an effective and reliable technique for the management of recalcitrant perineal wounds following rectal extirpation. This approach should be considered as a viable option in cases where conventional wound closure methods have failed.

Surgical correction of hydrothorax from diaphragmatic eventration in children on peritoneal dialysis.  Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) is frequently used in the pediatric age group for reversible and end-stage renal failure. Hydrothorax is a rare but serious complication in children receiving continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD). Diaphragmatic eventration, a condition characterized by abnormal elevation of the diaphragm, has been identified as a potential cause of hydrothorax in these patients. This study presents a series of five cases of hydrothorax in children on CAPD due to diaphragmatic eventration. All patients underwent surgical correction of the eventration, and the outcomes were evaluated in terms of resolution of hydrothorax and improvement in respiratory function. The results showed that surgical correction successfully resolved the hydrothorax in all cases and led to significant improvement in respiratory function. This study highlights the importance of considering diaphragmatic eventration as a possible cause of hydrothorax in children on CAPD and emphasizes the efficacy of surgical intervention for its management. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and develop preventive strategies for this complication.

Progressive coma after the transsphenoidal decompression of a pituitary adenoma with marked suprasellar extension: report of two cases. We present two cases of progressive coma after transsphenoidal decompression of pituitary adenomas with marked suprasellar extension. Both cases had initial successful decompression with improvement in visual symptoms. However, within 24 to 48 hours postoperatively, they developed progressive neurological deterioration, leading to coma. Radiographic imaging demonstrated significant hemorrhagic infarctions and mass effect, mainly in the posterior fossa. Despite aggressive medical management, both patients succumbed to their condition. Histopathological examination showed necrosis and infarction of the pituitary adenoma, with evidence of vascular compromise. This report highlights a rare but potentially devastating complication following transsphenoidal decompression, emphasizing the need for close monitoring and prompt intervention in cases with marked suprasellar extension. Further research is necessary to identify risk factors and develop strategies for early detection and management of this complication.

Cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid, as revealed by fine-needle aspiration biopsy. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) is a widely used method for the diagnosis of thyroid nodules. However, the cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid are not well defined. In this study, we aimed to investigate the cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid. We retrospectively reviewed 12 cases of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid that were confirmed by surgical pathology. FNAB samples from these cases were analyzed for cytologic features. The cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid were characterized by high cellularity, pleomorphism, nuclear crowding, and nuclear atypia. The cells exhibited a high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio and had irregular nuclear contours. There was also evidence of necrosis and mitotic activity. The cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid were distinct from those of well-differentiated papillary carcinoma. These findings suggest that FNAB can be a useful tool for the preoperative diagnosis of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid.

Differences between florid osseous dysplasia and chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis.  Florid osseous dysplasia (FOD) is confused in the literature with chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis. FOD and chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis are two distinct pathological entities that share some clinical and radiographic similarities, leading to diagnostic challenges. FOD is characterized by extensive and symmetric osseous lesions predominantly affecting the mandible, maxilla, and surrounding tissues, while chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis involves the long bones, particularly the tibia. Radiographically, both conditions exhibit areas of sclerosis and cortical thickening, with FOD presenting as multiple well-defined radiolucencies and chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis as single, poorly defined radiolucencies. However, histopathological examination reveals crucial differences, with FOD demonstrating organized fibro-osseous tissue and chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis showing chronic inflammation and presence of microorganisms. Awareness of these differences is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of these conditions.

Supported employment: an alternative model for vocational rehabilitation of persons with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disability. Supported employment is an emerging model for vocational rehabilitation of individuals with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disabilities. This review provides an overview of the principles and effectiveness of supported employment programs. The concept of individual placement and support, which emphasizes individualized job placement with ongoing support, is highlighted. Various studies have demonstrated the efficacy of supported employment in improving employment outcomes, including job acquisition, retention, and wages earned. The benefits extend beyond vocational success, with individuals experiencing improved self-esteem, quality of life, and social integration. Challenges and barriers to implementing supported employment programs are discussed, including limited resources, stigma, and lack of coordination between vocational and mental health services. Strategies for successful implementation, such as collaboration and integration of services, are also explored. Overall, supported employment offers a promising approach to help individuals with severe disabilities integrate into the workforce and lead productive lives.

A diagnostic expert system for colonic lesions. Colorectal cancer is a leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide. Early detection of colonic lesions is crucial, as it greatly improves patient outcomes. In this study, we propose a diagnostic expert system for colonic lesions to aid in accurate and timely diagnosis. The system incorporates artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms to analyze patient data, including medical history, imaging findings, and laboratory test results. By examining a large dataset of patients with confirmed colonic lesions, the expert system has been trained to detect and classify various types of lesions, including polyps, adenomas, and malignant tumors. Preliminary results demonstrate high accuracy and sensitivity of the diagnostic expert system, outperforming traditional diagnostic methods. Implementation of this system in clinical practice has the potential to significantly improve the efficiency and accuracy of colonic lesion diagnosis, facilitating early intervention and increasing patient survival rates.

Pharmacologic stress imaging. Pharmacologic stress imaging is a valuable tool in the evaluation of patients with suspected or known coronary artery disease (CAD). It provides crucial information regarding myocardial perfusion and function under stress conditions, helping to guide appropriate management strategies. This abstract reviewed the current evidence on the use of pharmacologic stress imaging with emphasis on the two commonly used stress agents: adenosine and dobutamine.

Multiple studies have demonstrated the diagnostic accuracy and prognostic value of pharmacologic stress imaging in patients unable to exercise or with equivocal exercise stress tests. Adenosine is a potent coronary vasodilator that produces reversible perfusion defects indicative of CAD. It is particularly useful in patients with bronchospastic airway disease or inability to achieve an adequate heart rate response. Dobutamine, a synthetic catecholamine, stimulates myocardial contractility and can unmask ischemic wall motion abnormalities.

Although both agents have proven efficacy and safety profiles, they also have unique limitations and potential complications. Adenosine may cause transient side effects such as chest pain and dyspnea, while dobutamine can provoke arrhythmias and myocardial infarction in patients with significant CAD. Therefore, careful patient selection, risk-stratification, and close monitoring during pharmacologic stress imaging are essential for optimal outcomes.

In conclusion, pharmacologic stress imaging is a valuable non-invasive tool for the evaluation of CAD. Adenosine and dobutamine are the commonly used stress agents, each with its unique advantages and limitations. Proper patient selection and close monitoring are crucial to ensure the safe and accurate assessment of myocardial perfusion and function.

A histopathologic study of spinal cord ischemia using an isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model. Spinal cord ischemia is a devastating condition that can result in significant neurological deficits. This study aimed to investigate the histopathological changes that occur in spinal cord ischemia using an isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model. Twenty-five rats were included in the study and divided into two groups: the ischemia group (n=15) and the control group (n=10). In the ischemia group, the thoracic aorta was temporarily occluded using a vascular clamp for 10 minutes, while the control group underwent a sham procedure. The rats were sacrificed at various time points (1, 3, 7, 14, and 28 days) after the procedure, and spinal cord tissue samples were obtained for histopathological analysis. The histopathological examination revealed significant neuronal cell loss, gliosis, and spinal cord tissue necrosis in the ischemia group compared to the control group. These findings suggest that spinal cord ischemia leads to severe histopathological changes, highlighting the importance of early intervention and prevention strategies in this condition.

The incidence of deep vein thrombosis after cementless and cemented knee replacement. The incidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following knee replacement surgery has been a subject of ongoing investigation. This study aimed to compare the occurrence of DVT in patients who underwent cementless versus cemented knee replacement procedures. A total of 200 patients were included in the study, with 100 patients receiving a cementless knee replacement and 100 patients receiving a cemented knee replacement. The incidence of DVT was monitored during postoperative follow-up visits using duplex ultrasonography. Results showed that the incidence of DVT was significantly lower in the cementless group compared to the cemented group (p<0.05). These findings suggest that cementless knee replacement may be associated with a reduced risk of DVT compared to the cemented approach. Further research is needed to explore the benefits and potential drawbacks of both techniques.

Reduction in bleeding after heart-lung transplantation.  The importance of posterior mediastinal hemostasis. Bleeding complications following heart-lung transplantation can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. One area of concern is the posterior mediastinum, where hemostasis plays a crucial role in reducing bleeding. This abstract aims to highlight the importance of posterior mediastinal hemostasis in the reduction of bleeding after heart-lung transplantation.

Extensive dissection and manipulation of the heart and lung grafts during transplantation can disrupt the delicate blood vessels and increase the risk of bleeding. A thorough understanding of the anatomy and proper surgical techniques are essential in achieving effective hemostasis in the posterior mediastinum.

Techniques such as ligature of major vessels, use of hemostatic agents, and careful suturing of blood vessels can contribute to preventing bleeding. Additionally, the application of adjunctive measures like protective packing or temporary compression devices can help maintain hemostasis in this critical area.

Close monitoring and continuous assessment of coagulation status are paramount in ensuring timely and appropriate intervention if bleeding occurs. Collaboration among the multidisciplinary team, including cardiac surgeons, anesthesiologists, and perfusionists, is crucial for successful management of bleeding complications.

In conclusion, thorough attention to posterior mediastinal hemostasis is crucial in reducing bleeding complications following heart-lung transplantation. Implementation of appropriate surgical techniques and close interdisciplinary collaboration are vital for optimizing patient outcomes in this complex procedure.

Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of vater. Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater is a rare and aggressive tumor originating from neuroendocrine cells in the ampulla. This malignancy accounts for less than 1% of all periampullary cancers. Patients commonly present with obstructive jaundice, abdominal pain, weight loss, and anemia. The diagnosis is challenging due to non-specific symptoms and lack of specific tumor markers. Advanced imaging techniques, such as endoscopic ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging, aid in the preoperative evaluation. Treatment options include surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Prognosis is generally poor, with a high recurrence rate and limited survival. Further research is needed to improve early detection and develop effective therapeutic strategies for this rare malignancy.

Co-trimoxazole for childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions. In malaria-endemic regions, co-trimoxazole has been widely used as prophylaxis against opportunistic infections in HIV-infected individuals. However, its effectiveness in treating childhood febrile illness in these regions remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of co-trimoxazole for childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic areas. A randomized controlled trial was conducted, enrolling children aged 6 months to 12 years presenting with febrile illness. The intervention group received co-trimoxazole, while the control group received standard care. The primary outcome was the proportion of children with treatment failure at day 7. Secondary outcomes included parasite clearance rate, duration of hospitalization, and adverse events. Preliminary results suggest that co-trimoxazole is not superior to standard care in treating childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions. Further studies are needed to explore alternative treatment options in this population.

Immunohistochemical investigations of estrogen receptors in normal and neoplastic squamous epithelium of the vulva. Estrogen receptor (ER) status plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis and prognosis of various neoplastic conditions. This study aimed to investigate the presence and distribution of estrogen receptors in normal and neoplastic squamous epithelium of the vulva. Immunohistochemical staining was performed on paraffin-embedded tissue sections from 28 cases of vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and 14 cases of normal vulvar tissue. The results demonstrated that ER expression was significantly higher in SCC compared to normal tissue (p<0.001). Interestingly, ER expression was also found to be significantly higher in high-grade SCC compared to low-grade SCC (p=0.002). Our findings suggest that ER status may serve as a potential diagnostic and prognostic marker in vulvar SCC, providing valuable insight into the underlying molecular mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for this malignancy.

Spinal accessory nerve palsy: an unusual complication of coronary artery bypass The neurologic complications of coronary artery bypass surgery have been well documented, with a reported incidence of 61% in one large study.  Most injuries to the peripheral nervous system involve the brachial plexus. Spinal accessory nerve palsy is a rare complication of coronary artery bypass surgery. In a study examining the neurologic complications of this surgical procedure, it was found that the reported incidence of spinal accessory nerve palsy was 61%. This is considered an uncommon injury to the peripheral nervous system, as most injuries involve the brachial plexus. The exact mechanism of injury for spinal accessory nerve palsy during coronary artery bypass surgery is not well understood. Further research is needed to identify risk factors and develop strategies for prevention and management of this complication.

Preferential mitogenic activity for myoblast-like cells can be extracted from uterine leiomyoma tissues. Uterine leiomyomas, also known as uterine fibroids, are benign tumors that develop in the smooth muscle tissue of the uterus. Previous studies have shown that leiomyoma tissues possess mitogenic activity that can enhance the growth of myoblast-like cells. This study aimed to extract and analyze the preferential mitogenic activity present in uterine leiomyoma tissues. The methods involved extracting soluble factors from leiomyoma tissues and applying them to myoblast-like cells. The results demonstrated a significant increase in cell proliferation and migration in response to the extracted factors, indicating the presence of potent mitogens. This finding suggests that uterine leiomyoma tissues may contain unidentified growth factors that have the potential to promote the growth of myoblast-like cells. Further research is needed to identify and characterize these growth factors, which may have implications for understanding leiomyoma pathogenesis and developing targeted therapies.

Levels of mRNA for a putative kainate receptor are affected by seizures. Seizures have been implicated in the alteration of gene expression in the brain, including changes in mRNA levels. The putative kainate receptor, a subtype of glutamate receptor, has been suggested to play a role in epileptic seizures. This study aimed to investigate the effect of seizures on the levels of mRNA for the putative kainate receptor. Using a rat model of seizures induced by pentylenetetrazole (PTZ), mRNA levels were measured in different brain regions using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR). The results demonstrated a significant upregulation of mRNA for the putative kainate receptor in the hippocampus and cortex following PTZ-induced seizures. These findings suggest that the putative kainate receptor may be involved in the pathophysiology of seizures and could be a potential target for future therapeutic interventions.

Evaluating oxygen delivery and oxygen utilization with mixed venous oxygen saturation monitoring: a case study approach. Monitoring oxygen delivery and utilization is crucial in assessing tissue perfusion and overall patient status. Mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) is a reliable indicator of global tissue oxygenation and has been used to guide therapeutic interventions in critically ill patients. This case study investigates the utility of SvO2 monitoring in two patients with different clinical presentations. Patient A presented with septic shock and demonstrated a low SvO2, indicating impaired oxygen delivery. Prompt intervention led to an improvement in SvO2 and ultimately, patient outcomes. Patient B, on the other hand, had congestive heart failure and exhibited a high SvO2, suggesting inadequate oxygen utilization. Adjustments in therapeutic management resulted in a decrease in SvO2 and an improvement in clinical parameters. Overall, this case study highlights the importance of SvO2 monitoring in guiding interventions for optimizing tissue oxygenation in critically ill patients.

Association of Escherichia coli HEp-2 adherence patterns with type and duration of diarrhoea. This study aimed to investigate the association between Escherichia coli (E. coli) HEp-2 adherence patterns and the type and duration of diarrhoea in patients. Stool samples were collected from 150 patients presenting with acute diarrhoea, 80 patients with persistent diarrhoea, and 80 healthy controls. E. coli strains were isolated from the samples and tested for adherence to HEp-2 cells using an adherence assay. Adherence patterns were classified into localized, diffuse, agglomerative, and aggregative adherence. The results showed that the prevalence of E. coli adherence was significantly higher in both acute and persistent diarrhoea groups compared to the healthy controls. Additionally, the diffuse adherence pattern was significantly associated with acute watery and persistent diarrhoea, while the localized adherence pattern was more prevalent in acute bloody diarrhoea. These findings suggest that E. coli HEp-2 adherence patterns may vary depending on the type and duration of diarrhoea, providing insights into the pathogenesis and clinical manifestations of E. coli-associated diarrhoeal diseases.

The Van Nes tibial rotationplasty. Tibial rotationplasty is a surgical procedure used in the management of bone and soft tissue tumors located around the knee joint. This technique involves removal of the distal part of the femur, knee joint, and proximal part of the tibia, followed by rotation and reattachment of the foot to the residual tibia. This procedure allows for the preservation of functional length, joint stability, and muscle attachments, consequently maintaining the ability to walk and perform activities of daily living. The purpose of this article is to provide an overview of the Van Nes tibial rotationplasty, including indications, surgical technique, postoperative rehabilitation, complications, and long-term outcomes. Various studies have demonstrated the efficacy and functional outcomes of this procedure, making it a viable option for selected patients with bone and soft tissue tumors around the knee joint.

Acute oculogyric crisis after administration of prochlorperazine. Prochlorperazine is a widely used medication for various conditions, including nausea and vomiting. We present a case of a 53-year-old male who developed an acute oculogyric crisis shortly after receiving a single intramuscular injection of prochlorperazine for nausea. The patient experienced sudden and involuntary upward eye deviation, accompanied by fixed gaze for several minutes. Symptoms resolved spontaneously without intervention. This adverse event is a well-documented extrapyramidal symptom associated with antipsychotic medications, but rarely reported with prochlorperazine use. Clinicians should be aware of this potential side effect when prescribing prochlorperazine, especially in patients with a history of extrapyramidal symptoms or susceptibility to dystonic reactions. Prompt recognition and appropriate management can prevent unnecessary distress to patients.

Choroid plexus tumors in the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. Choroid plexus tumors (CPTs) are rare neoplasms originating from the specialized epithelial lining of the choroid plexus, predominantly found in the brain. However, there have been a few reported cases of CPTs occurring in patients with the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome (BCSS), a genetic disorder characterized by an increased risk of breast cancer and sarcomas. This abstract presents two cases of BCSS patients diagnosed with CPTs. Both patients had a history of breast cancer and presented with symptoms consistent with CPTs. Imaging studies revealed intraventricular masses, and histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of CPT. The management involved surgical resection followed by adjuvant therapy. These cases highlight the need for increased awareness and surveillance in BCSS patients for the development of rare tumors such as CPTs.

Simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck in congenital Brown's syndrome. Congenital Brown's syndrome is a rare strabismus disorder characterized by limited upward and downward movement of the affected eye due to a mechanical restriction in the superior oblique tendon. The current standard surgical approach for treating this condition is superior oblique tendon sheath incision or sheathectomy. However, this procedure alone may result in worsening of the ocular motility due to the unopposed action of the inferior oblique muscle. 

To address this issue, simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck have been proposed as a combined surgical technique for the management of congenital Brown's syndrome. This approach involves the resection of a portion of the superior oblique tendon to remove the restriction, followed by an inferior oblique tuck to provide a counterbalance to the superior oblique dysfunction. 

Several case studies have reported successful outcomes with this combined procedure, with significant improvement in ocular motility and minimal complications. However, further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck as a treatment option for congenital Brown's syndrome.

Oral contraceptives, lipoproteins, and atherosclerosis. The association between oral contraceptive use, lipoproteins, and atherosclerosis has been widely investigated. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of oral contraceptive use on lipoprotein levels and their potential contribution to the development of atherosclerosis. A total of 150 female participants were recruited, with 75 being oral contraceptive users and the remaining 75 being non-users. Lipoprotein profiles, including total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), and triglycerides, were measured for all participants. Additionally, carotid intima-media thickness (cIMT), a marker of atherosclerosis, was assessed using ultrasound. The results revealed that oral contraceptive users had significantly higher levels of total cholesterol, LDL-C, and triglycerides, along with a lower level of HDL-C compared to non-users. Moreover, cIMT was significantly greater in the oral contraceptive group, indicating a higher risk of atherosclerosis. These findings suggest that oral contraceptive use may negatively impact lipoprotein profiles and contribute to the development of atherosclerosis, emphasizing the importance of regular cardiovascular risk assessment and monitoring for women using oral contraceptives.

Clinical observation on the association of gallstones and colorectal cancer.  A possible association between gallstones, colorectal cancer, and gastric cancer was investigated. A clinical observation was conducted to investigate a possible association between gallstones and colorectal cancer, as well as gastric cancer. A total of 458 patients with gallstones were enrolled in the study. Among them, 192 patients had colorectal cancer, while 59 patients had gastric cancer. The control group consisted of 500 individuals without gallstones. The results showed a significantly higher prevalence of colorectal cancer in patients with gallstones compared to the control group (p < 0.001). However, there was no significant association between gallstones and gastric cancer (p = 0.243). Subgroup analysis based on age and gender did not reveal any significant differences. Furthermore, logistic regression analysis suggested an independent association between gallstones and colorectal cancer (adjusted odds ratio, 2.57; 95% confidence interval, 1.78-3.71). These findings imply a potential link between gallstones and colorectal cancer, supporting the need for further research to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore possible preventive strategies.

Warner-Lambert/Parke-Davis Award lecture. This lecture presents the findings of a study conducted on 74 larynges removed from infants who died from sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). The larynges were examined using serial sectioning in the transverse plane. The study revealed an increase in subepithelial glandular tissue in many specimens, which was further quantified by measuring the reduction in the available subglottic area using the Measuremouse Image Intensifying system. The results of this preliminary report suggest that in some infants with SIDS, particularly around the age of 3 months, there is a potentially life-threatening narrowing of the subglottic airway due to an increase in mucus-secreting glands, possibly triggered by a mild upper respiratory tract infection. These findings offer a potential explanation for the tragic occurrences associated with SIDS. The lecture was the recipient of the Warner-Lambert/Parke-Davis Award.

Celiac disease, brain atrophy, and dementia. Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by gluten intolerance and can manifest with various extraintestinal symptoms, including neurological manifestations. Brain atrophy and dementia have been described in association with celiac disease; however, the exact mechanisms are not fully understood. This case report describes a patient with longstanding celiac disease who presented with progressive cognitive decline and was found to have brain atrophy on imaging studies. Further evaluation revealed evidence of gluten cross-reactivity and elevated circulating antibodies against neural tissue. A gluten-free diet was initiated, resulting in stabilization of cognitive function and improvement in the patient's overall neurological status. This report highlights the importance of considering celiac disease in the differential diagnosis of dementia and the potential for neurologic improvement with appropriate management.

Toward a rational therapeutic strategy for arachnoiditis. Arachnoiditis is a debilitating condition characterized by inflammation of the arachnoid membrane surrounding the spinal cord. Its etiology remains elusive, and current treatment strategies primarily aim at symptomatic relief rather than disease modification. We conducted a comprehensive review of the literature to evaluate the efficacy of various therapeutic interventions for arachnoiditis and identify gaps in knowledge that need to be addressed. Non-pharmacological interventions such as physical therapy and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation have demonstrated some benefit in managing arachnoiditis-related pain. Pharmacological approaches, including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, opioids, and anticonvulsants, have also been used with mixed results. Novel treatment options including corticosteroid injections, neuroprotective agents, and targeted immune modulators have shown promise in preclinical studies, but their efficacy and safety in human subjects remain to be established. There is a pressing need for well-designed clinical trials to evaluate the long-term outcomes of different therapeutic approaches and develop a more rational management strategy for arachnoiditis.

Increasing the cancer screening of the medically underserved in south Florida. Cancer screening is a vital component in the early detection and management of various malignancies. However, the medically underserved population in South Florida often faces barriers in accessing proper healthcare services, resulting in inadequate cancer screening rates and delayed diagnoses. This study aims to address this issue by implementing interventions to increase cancer screening among the medically underserved in South Florida.

Through community partnerships and targeted outreach programs, increased access to cancer screening services will be provided to the underserved population. This will involve mobile screening clinics, community health fairs, and educational campaigns to raise awareness about the importance of cancer screening.

Furthermore, cultural sensitivity and language accessibility will be prioritized to ensure effective communication and understanding among the diverse population in South Florida. Collaboration with local healthcare institutions and organizations will facilitate the provision of comprehensive screening services, including mammograms, pap smears, and colorectal cancer screenings.

By improving access to cancer screening services, the aim is to reduce health disparities and improve early cancer diagnosis rates among the medically underserved population in South Florida, ultimately leading to better treatment outcomes and survival rates.

Use of intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate in patients with prostatic carcinoma refractory to conventional hormonal manipulation. Intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate (ISP) was evaluated in patients with prostatic carcinoma resistant to conventional hormonal therapy. A total of 29 patients were included in this study. The objective was to assess the efficacy and safety of ISP in this population. Results showed a partial response in 10 patients and stable disease in 9 patients, while the remaining 10 patients experienced disease progression. The median duration of response was 6.4 months. Adverse events were generally mild and manageable. These findings suggest that ISP may be a useful treatment option for patients with prostatic carcinoma who have failed standard hormonal manipulation. Further research is warranted to explore its potential benefits and optimal dosing strategies.

Outcome of cataract surgery in central India: a longitudinal follow-up study. Cataract surgery is a common procedure to restore vision in individuals with cataracts. However, the outcomes of cataract surgery can vary depending on various factors. This longitudinal follow-up study aimed to assess the outcome of cataract surgery in central India. A total of 300 patients who underwent cataract surgery were followed up for one year. Visual acuity and complications were assessed at different time points post-surgery. The results showed a significant improvement in visual acuity post-surgery, with the majority of patients achieving good visual outcomes. However, a small percentage experienced complications, such as posterior capsule opacification and corneal edema. Older age, presence of pre-existing ocular comorbidities, and longer duration of cataract symptoms were associated with poorer visual outcomes. These findings highlight the importance of early detection and timely cataract surgery, as well as appropriate management of post-operative complications to optimize visual outcomes in cataract patients in central India.

Computed tomography staging of the paranasal sinuses in chronic hyperplastic rhinosinusitis. Chronic hyperplastic rhinosinusitis (CHRS) is a common inflammatory condition affecting the paranasal sinuses. The aim of this study was to evaluate the utility of computed tomography (CT) staging in assessing the severity and extent of disease in patients with CHRS. CT scans of the paranasal sinuses from 120 patients with clinically diagnosed CHRS were reviewed and scored according to the Lund-Mackay staging system. The severity of disease was found to correlate positively with the CT stage, indicating a progressive increase in disease extent and severity with higher stage scores. The presence of nasal polyps, ethmoid sinus involvement, and maxillary and sphenoid sinus opacification were significant predictors of advanced disease on CT staging. This study highlights the value of CT staging in providing a comprehensive assessment of disease severity in CHRS, assisting in treatment planning and monitoring response to therapy.

Depression after acute myocardial infarction.  The role of primary care physicians in rehabilitation. Depression is a common comorbidity following acute myocardial infarction (AMI), and patients often rely on primary care physicians (PCPs) for their post-AMI rehabilitation. This study aimed to explore the role of PCPs in detecting and managing depression in AMI patients. A systematic review was conducted, analyzing relevant literature from various databases. Findings indicated that PCPs play a crucial role in identification, treatment, and monitoring of depression in this patient population. Collaborative care models, involving both PCPs and mental health professionals, were found to be effective in reducing depression symptoms and improving overall cardiac outcomes. Therefore, integrating mental health services into primary care settings may be beneficial for post-AMI patients with depression.

Dietary predictors of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women.  In 1980, 88,837 women aged 34-59 y completed a semiquantitative food frequency questionnaire and were followed for 4 y. Gallstones are a common gastrointestinal disorder, and certain dietary factors have been implicated in their development. This study aimed to investigate the dietary predictors of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women. A total of 88,837 women aged 34 to 59 years completed a semiquantitative food frequency questionnaire in 1980 and were followed up for 4 years. Information on the presence of gallstones and associated symptoms was collected through biennial questionnaires. Multivariable logistic regression models were used to calculate the relative risks of gallstones in relation to specific dietary factors. The analysis revealed that a higher intake of red meat, refined grains, and sugar-sweetened beverages was associated with an increased risk of gallstones. Conversely, a higher intake of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy products was associated with a decreased risk. These findings highlight the importance of adopting a healthy dietary pattern to prevent the development of symptomatic gallstones in middle-aged women.

Ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas after aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery. Ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas are rare but potentially serious complications of aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery. This study aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics, diagnostic methods, and treatment outcomes of these complications. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who developed ureteral obstruction or ureteral fistulas after undergoing aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery between January 2010 and December 2019. A total of 12 cases were identified, with a mean age of 66.3 years. The most common presenting symptom was flank pain, followed by hydronephrosis and recurrent urinary tract infections. Diagnosis was confirmed using imaging studies, including computed tomography and retrograde pyelography. Treatment involved surgical intervention, with ureteral stenting being the most common procedure performed. Successful management was achieved in 9 out of 12 cases, with resolution of symptoms and improvement in renal function. In conclusion, ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas after aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery require prompt diagnosis and appropriate surgical intervention to prevent further complications and improve patient outcomes.

Patient-controlled analgesia in children.  We report our experience in introducing patient-controlled analgesia at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Glasgow.  Twenty-five children used the technique after orthopaedic or general surgery using the Graseby system. Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) has become increasingly popular for managing acute postoperative pain in adults, but its use in children is less well established.  In this study, we report our experience in introducing PCA in children at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Glasgow. Twenty-five children aged between 5 and 16 years underwent orthopedic or general surgery and used the Graseby system for PCA. The majority of children (92%) were able to effectively use the PCA device with minimal assistance from nursing staff or parents. The mean pain scores were significantly decreased after initiation of PCA, indicating effective pain relief. Furthermore, there were no documented adverse events related to the use of PCA. Our findings suggest that PCA is a safe and effective method of pain management in children, which can empower them to have a greater sense of control over their pain relief. Further research is needed to assess its long-term efficacy and safety in pediatric populations.

Occurrence of beta-hexachlorocyclohexane in breast cancer patients.  The residues of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) and neutral organochlorine compounds in breast fat of 44 breast cancer patients and 33 women free of cancer were determined. In this study, we investigated the presence of beta-hexachlorocyclohexane (beta-HCH) in breast cancer patients and control subjects. The breast fat samples from 44 breast cancer patients and 33 cancer-free women were analyzed for residues of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) and neutral organochlorine compounds. Our results showed that beta-HCH was detected in significantly higher levels in breast cancer patients compared to control subjects. These findings suggest a potential association between the presence of beta-HCH and breast cancer development. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms and implications of beta-HCH exposure in breast cancer pathogenesis.
